column2: William Wallace of 338 East Fifty-fourthstreet was knocked down and run over by a horse and wagon driven by Christian Lauros of 142 Avenue A at Sixtieth-street and Third-avenue last night. Wallace had three of his ribs fractured and was taken to the Mount Sinai Hospital. The driver was arrested.

MOUNT PLEASANT, Iowa, Aug. 6.--Saturday E. B. Manning rode out to his farm near Greenfield, Adair County. Sunday morning his horse returned without his saddle. After diligent search Manning's body was found half way to the farm concealed by high weeds. He leaves a widow and babe. The cause of death is supposed to have been sun stroke. He was a son of Edward Manning, the capitalist.
Messrs. Blackford, Bowman, Joline, and Burden were present at the meeting of the Fish Commissioners yesterday and approved the bonds of several of the newly-appointed Fish and Game Protectors.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 6.--The eleventh annual convention of St. Patrick's Alliance of America was held here to-day. W.E. McDermitt of Newark presided, and speeches were made by Judge McCarthy of New-York and the Hon. J.J. Matthews of Newark.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 7.--During the past 10 days burglars have been at work in this city with almost unequaled activity, and scarely a night has passed that two or three cases of house-breaking have not been reported to the police.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7--A dispatch from Lawrence, Kan., says: "An east-bound passenger train on the Santa Fe Railroad left the track near here yesterday while running 40 miles an hour. All the cars except the sleepers went off the track, several of them being demolished. Martin Meyers, engineer, was killed instantly, and John Harff, the fireman, was badly scalded. A broken rail caused the accident."

ROCKLAND, Me., Aug. 7.--The steamer Lucy P. Miller of the New-York and Bangor Line reports having been run into on Nantucket shoals on Sunday during a thick fog by the schooner William Wiler o Philadelphia. The schooner lost her headgear, and the steamer's bow was injured, but both proceeded.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug, 7.--Mayor Strong's latest exploit is the town's talk. On Sunday night he appeared at the Recorder's office in company with Rosa Frey, a young German girl, and wanted to be married.

NONQUITT, Mass., Aug. 7.--The only signs of mourning at Nonquitt to-day have been the flags at half mast upon the hotel and the cottage of W. C. Taber. The place is always quiet, and the death of Gen. Sheridan has not made it more so.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 7.--Near Dalton, Ga., last night the Rev. J. Giddins was stabbed five times and had his throat out. His death is only a question of hours. The crime was committed by a renter on Giddins's farm, who called the preacher to the door and attacked him.

PIERRO, Dakota, Aug. 7.--The Rev. J. W. Hanford, Indian teacher and missionary at St. Stephen's Mission, who married Chaska and Miss Fellows, was thrown from a mowing, machine yesterday. He was badly mangled aml bled to death before assistance could be procured.
DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 7.--The Republican State Convention meets in this city to-morrow, and members are nearly all in the city to-night. There is less interest than usual in the proceedings...

LONDON, Aug. 7.--The High Court of Foresters, sitting at Reading, has carried, by a vote of 403 to 93, a motion revoking the powers of the Subsidiary High Court of America and suspending American Courts until they comply with the rules regarding the admission of colored persons.

A fog, which was at times extremely dense, rested on the waters of the harbor last evening. The excursion boats and ferryboats were obliged to proceed with great caution, and in some instances their pilots were obliged to depend for guidance upon the fog bells on shore. The returning excursion steamers were somewhat delayed, but no accidents were reported.

The yachts of the New-York Yacht Club will to-day rendezvous at New-London, off the Pequot House, for their annual cruise. Commodore Gerry, who, with the other flag officers of the club, will start at 10 o'clock this morning in the flagship Electra, thinks the cruising squadron will be the largest over had by the club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7.--German grand opera will be given in this city early next year. This point was settled to-day, and what is more the operas will be staged and sung as magnificently as in New-York.

The Tammany Hall voters of the Twentythird Assembly District will celebrate their banner raising tomorrow evening by ratification meetings in and around the Harlem Temple, on One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, between Lexington and Fourth avenues. Gen. Samuel F. Carey, Senators Ives, Cantor, and Reilly. Assemblyman William F. Sheehan, and others will speak.

RONDOUT, N. Y., Aug. 7.--The outlook for the Concord grape crops along the Hudson Valley this Fall causes the producers to feel jubilant. The gross tonnage will exceed that of any previous year, and the fruit promises to be exceptionally fine in quality.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7.--The authorities of the village of Hyde Park, Chicago's largest suburb, have gained a sweeping victory over the saloon keepers in their efforts to maintain the law relating to the Sunday closing of saloons.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 7.--Franklin H. Giddings of this city has been appointed resident lecturer on political science in the college for young women at Bryn Mawr, Penn., and will begin his duties there next month. Mr. Giddings is a graduate of Union College, and has been editorially connected with the Union during his residence here.

RONDOUT, Aug, 7.--"Gingle" Shulti is a snake charmer and general reptile destroyer in the Catskills, in the vicinity of the little hamlet of Chichester. A short time ago "Gingle's" boy was up on the mountain back of the place, and he heard a "rattler" close by him.

BOSTON, Aug 7.--It is stated to-night that the Boston Herald Building on Washingtonstreet has been sold by Royal M. Pulsifer, the transfer being effected Aug. 2. The terms of the transaction are withheld, and no one appears to understand its significance. The building is valued by the Assessors at $370,000, and covers an area of 8,495 square feet.

HALIFAX, Aug. 7.--James Miller, baker, confectioner, and fruit dealer, has left this city, and is supposed to be is the United States. He lately became involved financially and it is stated, has left a large number of creditors. His liabilities are believed to be about $25,000.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 7.--J. N. Livingston, a dry goods merchant at East Saginaw, has made an assignment. SHARON, Conn., Aug. 9.--Dr. Charles H. Shears said to-night: "There is no material change in Mr. Lawrence Jerome's condition since yesterday. CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--Provisions were again bearish to-day. For September delivery the trading in Pork opened at a decline of 17 c. and is Lard and Short Ribs of 5c. There are now being constructed in the Canadian Pacific Railway shops at Hochelaga 40 locomotives which will have an average weight each, with tender, of 157 tons. They are for use in the Rocky Mountain section of the Canadian Pacific Railway.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug, 13.--The smallpox epidemic at the New-Jersey State Prison has not yet extended beyond the one case reported yesterday. PANAMA, Aug. 4.--Layers of stone containing some of the supposed human footprints lately discovered in the vicinity of Lake Managua, in Nicaragua, have been forwarded to the Natural History Museum of Vienna. If it is proved that these impressions are genuine the conclusion must follow that man existed in Central America at a very remote period of prehistoric times.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 15.--A strike of weavers is in progress at the linen mill in this city, and 2,000 looms are idle.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 15.--Acting under instructions from the International Union of Bricklayers and Masons the strike which has been in progress here for several months has been declared off, and it has been decided to work ten hours per day instead of nine. This is a backdown on the part of the masons, who struck for nine hours a day at ten hours' wages.

Miss Garrett, who is searching for some quiet place down East for her brother in which to regain his health, has about decided upon one, but as the owners are in Europe some time must elapse before arrangements can be made for Mr. Garrett's removal.

NEWFORT, R.I., Aug. 15.--Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt of New-York, who was injured yesterday by being thrown from her carriage, is quite comfortable, aad she expects to be out by Saturday or Sunday. She has a slight cut on her lip and a bruise on the forehead and cheek.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 15.--The convention of the league of Republican clubs of the State of New-Jersey was held at this place today to deliberate on the ways and means to restore the party to power at the Fall election. The league comprises 200 clubs throughout the state, representing an aggregate of over 20,000 voters.
Capt. Gunn, Allen Williams, and Oscar Simonson, all living on Staten Island, went sailing in a Yacht belonging to the Columbia Fishing Club at Hugunet, Staten Island, Monday evening.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 15.--Henry K. Bush Brown to-night tendered to the city of Newburg all of the models of works made by his uncle, the famous sculptor, Henry K. Brown, deceased, also all pictures, drawings, sketches, photographs of his works, , that are now in or may come into his possession.
SARATOGA, Aug. 15.--The eleventh annual convention of the American Bar Association was called to order by the Hon. Thomas B. Semmes of Louisiana in Putnam Music Hall this morning.

The New-York Board of Underwriters yesterday elected William A. Anderson, President of the Mercantile Fire Insurance Company of this city, Superintendent of Surveys from Sept. 12, at an annual salary of $6,500. The election was recommended by the Committee on Surveys, and the action of the board was unanimous.
Mrs. Cahterine Jones of West Brighton Coney Island, has a little place on a side street between Surf and Ocean avenues, a very intricate bank yard, and a son who runs a shooting gallery.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 15.--The squadron of the New-York Yacht Club bade farewell to Martha's Vineyard at four bells this morning in a smoky son wester with the beginning of the flood tide. The course was from off the Schoolship Bouy to and around the Vineyard Sound Lightship, and thence to a finish off Clark's Point. BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 15.--W.H. May, editor of the Bridgeport Weekly Sun, was to-day severely assaulted by ex-Alderman Thomas Ronan, at the shop where the latter is employed as a wood worker.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 15.--The situaation this morning makes the doctors smile and the people here much better pleased. Up to 11 o'clock last night there were only three new cases, two coming from the original soures of all the trouble. They are Frank Donovan and Miss Annie Robinson, at the Grand Union, and St. Simmons, a fireman at the Central Station.

Col. W.V. Gannon of Omaha arrived here yesterday on his way to Maine, where he will speak in behalf of the Democratic ticket. In 1884 Col. Gannon was the Democratic candidate for Attorney-General of Iowa.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15.--The second day's session of the National Convention of the American Party was called to order at 11:10 o'clock this morning by Chairman Wigginton.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 15.--The eleventh conference of the Young Men's Christian Associations of the world convened in this city to-day. During the morning the World's Committee met and approved of the report prepared by its Central Committee at Geneva, giving the details of the past four years' work and recommendations for the coming three years.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15.--Mrs. Charles Crocker reached this city in a special car at a late hour last night. Her son, George Crocker, was here to meet her, having come on from Utah. He was in ignorance as to whether his mother had received the news of her husband's death.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 15.--The first public meeting under the auspices of the Tariff Reform Club of New-Haven will be held in the Hyperion Theatre, the largest opera house in New-Eagland, on Sept. 1.

The committee of New-York members of the Typothetae who are arranging for the meeting of the Natonal Typothetae, to be held in the Masonic Temple Sept. 18, 19, and 20, have nearly completed their preparations.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15.--The American Meat Campany, which now embraces the syndicate owning the mammoth dressed beef establishment in Armourdale, has perfected its organization and will soon begin shipping its cattle to this city for slaughter.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 15.--Between 5,000 and 6,000 visitors from the three counties of Rush, Decatur, and Delaware paid their respects to Gen. Harrison to-day. The delegation from Rush County numbered about 2,000. In their procession were 12 township clubs. About 40 colored men accompanied this delegation.

The bark Veronica of St. John, NewBrunswick, which arrived yesterday from Northfleet, port of London, had on board two French sailors, whom she had picked up in an open dory drifting off the banks of Newfoundland, latitude 46 22', longitude 48 10'.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 15.--The effects of Sunday's severe storm were still visible at the race track to-day, but five well-contested races in slow time were witnessed by a much larger crowd than usual on an extra day. MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 15.--A number of telegrams have been received in the last three days from business men in Chicago and Eastern cities stating that yellow fever was reported in Memphis, and asking if the report was true.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 15.--The Democratic State Convention to-day renominated L.S. Ross for Governor and T.B. Wheeler for LieutenantGovernor. J.W. Stayton, R.R. Gaines, and J. L. Henry were nominated for supreme Judges, the last being a new man. Stayton was made Chief-Justice.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 15.--The Board of Directors of the National League of Professional Baseball Clubs held a special meeting at the Coleman House to-day.
OLEAN, N.Y., Aug. 15.--The Republicans of Chautauqua Cattarangna, and Allegany Counties assembled in this city to-day to nominate a Congressman to represent the Thirtyfourth Congressional District.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, Aug. 15.--The Regimental Board of the First Regiment, Uniform Rank, Knights of Pythias, met here to-day and decided to hold their next parade at Elizabath the latter part of September. The committee was empowered to draw up a form which will be sent to all the divisions who will vote on the question of having a burial fund. Seven of the 11 divisions in the State were represented.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 15.--The rate of taxation for this place will be $15, or $1 less than last year. The total valuatlon of the city last year, real and personal was $59,652,810: this year it has increased to $62,400,140. The valuation of real estate is $48,180,700, or $1,838,140 more than in 1887.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 15.--The Republican State Convention, which was held here today, carried out the work expected of it in the nomination of ex-Mayor Morgan G. Bulkley of this city for the Governorship by acclamation. The leading politicians of the State were present in force.

Upward of 100 distinguished scientists, mainly specialists, are in attendance, many of them prepared with papers to show the progress of science in its several branches. During the year 137 papers have been filed for acceptance.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 15.--The twentyfirst annual reunion of the Connecticut Valley Association was held in this city to-day. The attendance was large, many of the veterans being accompanied by their wives and children.

OTTAWA, Aug. 15.--Mr. J.G.E. Painchaud, Collector of Customs at the Magdalem Islands, has arrived here. He asked the Minister of Customs for a cutter to better enable him to carry out his official duties.

The drowning of Miss PYLE in the shallow inlet on the New-Jersey coast known as the Shark River is a typical Summer resort disaster. That is to say, it is a disaster that the sagest and most cautious mind would not have apprehended.

A young man named Constant W. Travis of the firm of Travis Chase, grocers, at Peekskill, while examining a revolver belonging to John Levy, a baker, a Verplanck's Point, yesteraday, accidentally discharged it. The ball struck the heart, and he died in two minutes. He leaves a wife and one child. Coroner Sutton held the inquest.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 15.--Levi Davis, a prominent Hebrew of this town, has instituted a suit for $10,000 damages against Charles Schweede of the firm of Schweede Brothers, a large clothing firm of Somerville and Plainsfield, N.J., for ruining his daughter, Jonnie. Schweede denies the charge and will fight the case.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 15.--Yesterday while fishing in the Saugatuck River, Joseph Ennis, a young man of Portuguese parentage, was thrown into the water by a sudden movement of his boat and was drowned. The story of Sheridan's commission as Colonel, told at considerable length in the Tribune, does not at all agree with Gov. Blair's account of it, as I heard it from him two or three years ago.

Capt. Muller came ashore from the Wieland on board the revenue cutter. He is a short, thick-set man, sturdy and weatherbeaten, but apparently much broken by the fearful experiences through which he had passed within the past few days.

BERLIN, Aug. 16.--Emperor William attended the unveiling of the monument erected in memory of the late Prince Frederick Charles at Frankfort-on-the-Oder to-day. The Emperor was present at a breakfast given in his honor after the unveiling, and gave a toast to German unity.

LONDON, Aug. 16.--At a meeting of the Liverpool Reform Club to-day it was resolved to start a fund to assist Mr. Parnell in meeting the expenses of his action against the Times. It is intended to make the movement a national one. Many prominent Gladstonians attended the meeting.
Police Captain Charles McDonnell, commander of the Eighth Precinct, was buried from his home, 42 King-street, yesterday morning.

The action of the Brooklyn Jockey Club in taking three days claimed by the Rockaway Steeplechaso Association last May for their Fall meeting is very generally condemned in racing circles by owners, trainers, and the public generally, and it looks as if the management had made a mistake.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16.--Elliot Zborowski of the Polo Club was seriously injured on the polo grounds this afternoon. W.K. Thorn accidentally ran into him and knocked him and his pony down. Pony and rider were thought to be dead, as the pony did not move for some time.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 16.--The World's Conference of the Young Men's Christian Associations met at 9 o'clook this morning. The devotional exercises were conducted by the Rev. E. Osterman of Goteborg.

SEVENTEEN HOURS FOR FIFTY CENTS. The Congressional Immigration Commit tee found the weather so warm yesterday that no recess was taken, but the morning session was prolonged and an early adjournment taken. Still, a good deal of interesting testimony was given.
The election last Monday passed off with less excitement than could have been reasonably expected. Under the local option law the saloons were all closed.

BOSTON, Aug. 16.--The death of an unknown woman at a police station Sunday morning is attracting much attention and keeping a lot of police officers busy hunting for a solution of the mystery in which her death and identity are involved.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 16.--Teemer's articles for his race with O'Connor have been received. They stipulate that the race shall be for $1,000 and the championship of America. ROCHESTER, Aug. 16.--After a sharp shower last night the track dried up well under the hot sun to-day, and some fast time was made at the Grand Circuit races this afternoon. Spofford, the over-night favorite in the unfinished race, was still heavily backed.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 16.--A molder named Patrick Cahill was drunk in the streets Tuesday evening and carried a spade with which he threatened to kill any one who came in his way.

A well-known Irish-American took into the National Democratic headquarters yesterday a letter which "Pat" Ford sent out in 1881 in company with his pamphlet denouncing Mr. Blains for his conduct while Secretary of State.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Ang. 16.--Col. D.S. Alexander of this city, who has been acting as Gen. Harrison's private secretary since his nomination, has returned home.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16.--A call for a National Convention of the National Greenback Party, to be held at Cincinnati, on Wednesday, Sept. 12, 1888, was to-day issued by Mr. George O. Jones, Chairman of the National Committee.
COLUMBUS, Ohio., Aug. 16.--The Rev. Dr. George Thomas Dowling will resign the Pastorate of the Euclid Avenue Baptist Church at the prayer meeting, to-morrow evening.

ALBANY, Aug. 16.--At the West Albany car shops of the Central-Hudson Railroad there are being constructed two funeral cars. These are of unusual excellence, being finished in the interior with mahogany, richly carved. There is one compartment for the coffin and a larger one for the mourners. These cars are to be used about New-York City. They are the first of their kind ever constructed at the shops here.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 16.--A most singular accident occurred near here the other day. Dr. Edmunds, while in bathing at Cascade, was taken with cramps, and becoming unconscious, floated face downward upon the lake.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 16.--Charles Van Houghton of Jersey City contracted with the Raritan River Railroad some weeks ago to grade the road and lay the stone oulverts at South Amboy.

A young lad named Alexander Welters entered the Newark Police Headquarters last night and said that he and two companions had gone to Elizabeth the day before to sell some produce, and upon their return they were attacked by six men in a piece of woods, who stopped the horse and rifled them of $15 in money.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Aug. 16.--John H. Murdoch, Master, this afternoon made his report in the case of Hallam, Edgerly Stockdale against the Union Oil Company.

Mayor Chapin of Brooklyn watched the Giants administer a "Chicago" defeat to the Detroit team yesterday. He and about 5,000 other admirers of the New-Yorks gazed upon the work of their favorites with evident pleasure.
The wholesale grocers of New-York City have taken preliminary steps toward the establishment of a local protective organization whose objects are manifold.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 16.--A number of boys were swimming in a creek near the old Moravian town of Lititz, in this county, a few days ago. One of them, in diving, found an old demijohn, which he brought ashore.

MEXICO, Aug. 16.--The continual depreciation of silver exchange on New-York, being now a fraction above 37, gives much anxiety to bankers, who now universally admit that the bottom has dropped out of silver and predict a still higher rate of exchange.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Ang. 16.--Bush fires have been raging fiercely in the townships of Clarendon, Laval, Canonti, and Oso, and have already done damage to the extent of nearly $500,000.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 16.--James Scully was examined to-day at South Amboy in the James Griffin murder case. He was the last man seen with Griffin.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 16.--A special to the Evening Wisconsin from Coleman, Wis., says the new Catholic church collapsed to-day, killing one man and crushing seven others so that several may die.

PALMYRA, Mo., Aug. 16.--Last night the county jail here contained 28 prisoners. This morning there were only 14 in it. During the night a breach was made in the wall and 14 prisoners gained their liberty. Sheriff Ray organized a posse and recaptured four. The rest are still out.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 16.--The Fall races at Charter oak Park will begin Tuesday, Sept. 4, and continue four days. The list of enitries assures a week of superb sport, surpassing an interest the great events which have taken place on this popular track in past seasons.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 16.--Mayor Smith to-day received a letter from Manchester, England, calling attention to a letter sent by express to John S. Barnos of St. Paul, and asking that the consignee be found.
WILMINGTON, Del. Aug. 16.--The Government dock test of the machinery of the iron-clad monitor Amphitrite, begun at 8 o'clock last evening, was still going on satisfactorily up to noon.
MAPLEWOOD, N.H., Aug. 16.--The White Mountain coaching parade, which takes place here next Monday, will probably be the largest affair of the kind ever witnessed in New-England.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 16.--To-day opened bright and clear and somewhat hot, but with a pleasant breeze blowing from off the river, making it far more pleasant than for some days past. A light shower set in at 9 o'olock, but it was of short duration. The doctors and people this morning all feel better.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16.--One "Dave" Waldo, an associate of Edward Corrigan in the management of the West Side Racing Park here, and equally disreputable as a man, has been sued for $8,000 damages by Walter Campbell, a racing reporter on the Inter Ocean.
FINDLAY, Ohio, Aug. 16.--A singular result from a vision seen in a trance by Miss Mary Searfoss of Marion Township, this county, is reported.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 16.--There is a pretty fight in progress at present between the Northern Pacific and Manitoba Roads, each of which is making a strenuous effort to secure the lion's share of harvest traffic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16.--The President has sent the following nominations to the Senate: To be Judges of Probate, Territory of Utah--John Houston of Garfield County, in said county; Thomas J. Brandon of Davis County, in said county; Pardon Dodds of Uintah County, in said county; John A. Marshall of Salt Lake County, in said county. Ernest W. Smith of Massachusetts to be Consul at Mozambique.

Ferdinand N. Chivvis of the former firm of Conkling Chivvis was yesterday committed by Judge Ehrlich of the City Court to the Middletown Asylum for the Insane on the affidavits of Dr. E.C. Spitzka and another physician.

William Ginnett has just died at Southampton, England, after having almost rounded a half century. He had long been a consumptive. Reared to sawdust and spangles he became a manager while in his teens, or at least as early as 1858.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16.--Further investigations have convinced the officers more strongly than ever that Oberkampf and Mack, the men arrested for robbing mail boxes, are guilty, and that strong cases will be presented against them when they are brought to trial next Tuesday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 17.--The Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company has sold the Honore Building, at Chicago, to William A. Slater of Norwich for $730,000, the transaction being completed in this city this afternoon.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 17.--A fire broke out on the new tugboat Nat Sutton just before 2 o'clock this morning while she was lying at the India-street wharf. The boat's fires were supposed to be banked, but the flames broke out in the fire room.

There was an average attendance at the Sing Sing Methodist camp meeting yesterday. In the morning the Rev. George E. Jayne, formerly of Sing Sing, now a Presiding Elder in Utah, preached. The afternoon sermon was preached by the Rev. Delos Luil, and the Rev. Dr. W.B. Osborne preached in the evening. This evening there is to be a grand jubilee and illumination of the grounds.

Winfield S. Meehan, a well-dressed young man of 23, was arraigned yesterday before Justice Patterson for having obtained money on false pretenses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--Secretary Whitney has ordered Admiral Luce, commanding the South Atlantic squadron, to proceed in the Galena to Port au Prince, as the presence of an American man-of-war is needed there on account of the state of martial law which exists.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 17.--To-day will be remembered as a great day in the history of Arkansas Democracy. Never has the party shown up to better advantage nor was there ever more enthusiasm manifested.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Aug. 17.--The boarding house of Summers Lynch and the storeroom of Walker Kelly were burned this morning at 3 o'clock at West Charleston. Simon Wallace, aged 31, and his mother, aged 55, were burned to death. Robbery, murder, and arson are suspected.

According to the annual statistical report of the German Jewish community, the number of Jews in the kingdom of Prussia in 1880 was 363,790, or 1.33 per cent. of the total population; in 1885 the number was 366,543, or 1.29 per cent.

LONDON, Aug. 17.--A dispatch from Suakim says: "The report that Lupton Bey died at Khartoum of consumption recently is confirmed by an eye witness of his funeral, which was conducted in public with Mohammedan ceremonies."
Austin Corbin and the Manhattan Beach Improvement Company began a legal fight yesterday against the stenches of Barren Island.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 17.--Sprout Post, G.A.R., of this city has passed resolutions denouncing the use of Grand Army of the Republic badges for political campaign purposes as delusive, deceptive, beguiling, and mischiefmaking, and characterize such attempts to use their badge as an atrocious fraud. The post has the support of other posts in Rochester and Buffalo in this matter.
PARIS, Aug. 17.--Gen. Boulanger has returned to Amiens. He was greeted on his arrival by mingled cheers and groans.
The ferryboats Fulton and Mineola of the Fulton Ferry had a slight collision yesterday morning about 10 o'clock. There were few passengers on either boat.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17.--Peter Klaus, a German drawing teacher, has been taken into custody for imprisoning his wife for the past eight years in their home on Keokuk-avenue.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 17.--In his weekly crop summary prepared for the information of the elevator companies Arbitrator C.E. Wenzel of Minneapolis says that the wheat prospects along the Manitoba Railroad lines vary greatly in different localities.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 17.--Coroner Fred Vanderveer went late last evening to the Highlands of Navesink, the scene of the murder of Mrs. Adolph Harmon by her husband, and the suicide of the latter.

LONDON, Aug. 17.--Mr. Parnell denies the report that he intends to vacate his seat in Parliament until either the Parliamentary commismission or the Scotch court has completed its inquiries into the Times's charges against him.

SARATOGA, Aug. 17.--Rain and mud, with an accident in the last race, made to-day's sport anything but enjoyable. The Chicago Stable tied Lucky Baldwin's record of yesterday, capturing three races, the horses being easy winners...

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 17.--To-day is hot and very uncomfortable. This torrid sun, after the late heavy rains, will be apt to bring out a number of new cases. This is what the physicians expect, and they are making their calculations to take care of them as soon as reported.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 17.--At the closing session of the National Insurance Commissioners' Association several resolutions looking to the securing of additional insurance legislation in the several States were adopted.

The meeting of the Reform Club last evening at its rooms, 12 East Thirty-thirdstreet, was largely attended and a lively interest in the proceedings was shown. George Foster Peabody presided and Louis F. Post, a disciple and follower of Henry George, was the orator of the evening.

John McCormack, the coachman who ran over and killed Mrs. Elizabeth Barclay on Feb. 25, was yesterday arraigned before Judge Martine in General Sessions, and pleaded not guilty.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 17.--William A. Homan, the ex-Suspension Bridge Water Works Commissioner, who has been lying in jail here for the past eight months with four indictments for embezzlement against him, was released on $5,000 bail to-day. Homan was tried for grand larceny on one of the indictments and acquitted.

Mr. John Swinton, who lost his sight early this year through the growth of cataract in both eyes, a fortnight ago submitted to an operation upon the right eye. Ellison, who for a number of years has been employed as bookkeeper in the Pennsylvania Hospital for the Insane, met with an awful death at 7:30 o'clock this morning at Shawmont station while crossing the track to take, the 7:31 train on the Pennsylvania Railroad for this city. Solomon Anderson, a dealer in men's furnishing goods on Third-avenue, near Fiftyfourth-street, occupies a flat at 100 East Fiftysecond-street. During the absence of his young family, who were in the country, he has spent only his sleeping hours at home.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 17.--The rainy weather which prevailed here to-day dampened the spirits of the lawn tennis players, and the contests of the tournament were given up until the sun shines again.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 17.--Shortly before 2 o'clock this morning a carpenter named Owen Ward called at Police Headquarters. He had with him a small parcel, which was wrapped in a common newspaper.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. Aug. 17.--At Round Mountain, Ala., James Elliott, the managed of a large iron furnace, dissatisfied with his force of white employes, discharged them and engaged colored laborers. The white men swore that the blacks should not work, and severs riots followed in which firearms and knives were used. The telephone wires are cut, but news is received that most of the trouble is over.

John Holste, a Hoboken grocer, was arrested yesterday on complaint of John Fenner, a liquor dealer of the same town, who charges that Holste is running a bar in violation of the law. This is the first arrest under the new law in Hoboken. The liquor dealers have declared their intention of prosecuting all grocers who sell liquors to be drank ...

John Carter, who recently in herited $20,000 was arrested yesterday in Newark charged with running away with the wife of John Lake of 225 Sullivan-street, in this city. To-day Lake tried to shoot Carter. Mrs. Lake, who was in Carter's house at the time, made her escape. Carter gave bail for trial.
James N. Matthews of Buffalo is at the Hotel Bartholdi.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 17.--A sensation was created here to-day by the assertion that a 12year-old boy named Gussie Robinson had been cruelly beaten and half starved by Mr. and Mrs. John Sinsbury.

Assistant District Attorney Goff and Bail Clerk William N. Penney, accomplished a clever piece of work yesterday by landing in jail Emil Lindburg, who is under indictment for perjury in falsely swearing to the ownership of property.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 17.--The picnic given by the British-American Association at Milford to-day was attended by nearly all the members of the association in the State.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13.--One of the heaviest sufferers by the incendiary fire at Fresno early on Sunday morning was ex-Judge David Terry, who lost his library, valued at $15,000, on which there was no insurance.
The Larchmont Yacht Club will enjoy three more days of official yacht races before Sept. 1.

Practice evolutions and sham battles like those in which the British naval forces have just been indulging often admit of diverse deductions, depending very much upon the observer's temperament or inclination.

An examination into the antiquity of the various members of the Senate shows that we have 4 Senators who are over 80 years of age, 14 who are over 70 and under 80, and 18 who are over 60 and under 70.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 17.--A train of 20 empty freight cars on the Pennsylvania Railroad bridge over the Delaware River in this city were run into by a train of 25 empty passenger cars this morning. The caboose of the freight train was completely demolished, together with one other freight and one passenger coach. Nobody was injured, but travel was impeded several hours.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 17.--To-night the Press, a Democratic organ, announces officially that William R. Brown, Postmaster of the city, is a candidate for the nomination of Clerk of Orange County.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 17.--At the beginning of this week Inspector McAleese was sent a box by the Cleveland Chief of Police from the residence of Daniel Negley, in the east end.
Statistics showing the number of foreigners settled in Russia in agricultural communities have just been published.
LOUISVILLE, Quebec, Aug. 17.--Richelieu's Hotel, at this place, which has been closed since May, was burned last night, with all its contents, by an incendiary.

AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 17.--Mr. Blaine attended the camp of the State militia to-day. He and Col. Coppenger drove into headquarters at at 11 o'clock in company with members of the State Government, being received by General of the Brigade Mitchell and staff, in full uniform. He lunched at brigade headquarters, and for an hour chatted with Gov. Marble, who was escorted into camp this morning by the First Regiment.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 17.--One of our county prison officials had, a narrow escape from death to-day. C.L. Eaby, the baker, was suffering from pain in the stomach and took from the medicine chest what he supposed was a dose of some simple remedy, but he got hold of the wrong bottle and swallowed poison. He sank into a stupor and the prison physician had hard work to save him.
Some days ago Judge Goldsborough of Cambridge wrote to Judge Irving, asking his opinion on some points of law.

PARIS, Aug. 17.--Mme. Bernhardt, who is at present staying at Cauterets, drove to Railliero in a tilbury yesterday, her sister and friends following in a break. When crossing the Benquez bridge ever a dangerous and rapid torrent, the horses attached to the break became frightened and started to run.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 17.--A day or two ago Charles Harris, a young married man of this place, went out with his wife for an evening drive. When they returned Mrs. Harris entered the house and retired at once, while her husband went to the stable to put up his horse.

Private Arthur Douglas of Company A, Battalion of Engineers, stationed at Willet's Point, mysteriously disappeared Aug. 7. On that day he obtained a leave of absence for 24 hours. His comrades did not see him alive again after he left the post.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 17.--While a force of laborers were engaged this morning in digging a trench and laying pipes on Centre-street for the plant of the Pottsville Steam Heat Company a cave-in occurred, burying a number of the men under several tons of earth. One man has been taken out dead. The others escaped serious injury.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 17.--John Van Voorhis has withdrawn from the canvass for Representative in Congress. This action assures the return of Charles S. Baker.

A fire broke out early last evening in Henry E. Rogers's drug store, at 33 Fultonstreet, Brooklyn, and spread to the offices of the Standard-Union, in another part of the building. The floors of the pressroom were partiallydestroyed, but the flames were extinguished before the presses fell. The damage sustained by the newspaper did not exceed $1,000. The losses were fully covered by insurance.

The body of Private Henry Douglass of Company C, Engineer Corps, stationed at Willett's Point, was found at 9 o'clock yesterday morning in the woods near Point View, Long Island, by a man named Brachket, who lives at College Point. Coroner Cartier of Flushing had it removed to the Morgue.

Coroner Levy yesterday called the attention of the jurors in the Chrystie-street fire inquest to an anonymous letter he had received stating that the building at 10 Manhattanstreet has no fire escapes, and that it is occupied by 200 working tailors.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 17.--At 6:30 o'clock this morning the Citadel reported a firstclass steamer in sight, which proved to be the disabled Thingvalla. She steamed very slowly up the harbor, and was docked at 9 o'clock.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17.--The New-York Yacht Club squadron came rushing into this port this afternoon with the propelling power of a lively southwesterly squall behind it. The run from New-Bedford was a lively one, and resulted in the Mayflower's showing that her...

BOSTON, Aug. 17.--Nelson Tibbetts, with a long record as a professional gambler and more recently as a stock broker, shot himself through the heart this morning, at his home on Dartmouth-street. He died instantly, his wife finding his body lying across the bed when she ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--Republicans as well as Democrats in Congress are disposed to be very outspoken in their opinions about Mr. Blaine's flippant references to "trusts" in his Portland speech. The Republicans do not go so far as the Democrats, but they ...
Although a heavy rain, which set in after the third race, rather marred the sport at Brighton yesterday, it was decidedly enjoyable and several close finishes tended to make it exciting.

Capt. Woodward of the brig Acadia, which arrived yesterday with a cargo of sugar and molasses from Barbadoes and Antigua, reported that on Aug. 13, while in latitude 36 north, longitude 70 west, the vessel was struck by a cyclone or whirlwind.

The convention of the Twenty-fourth Assembly District Republicans, representing the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards and King's Bridge, was held last night at Hohmann's Hall, Courtlandt-avenue near. One Hundred and Fiftieth-street.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 17.--A disgraceful scene was enacted at the Hotel Athegaeum this forenoon by Joseph Cook. He had just arrived and been shown to a room, when he began ringing the bell violently.

LITCHFIELD, Ill., Aug. 17.--A gay and extremely festive tailor, who was known here by the name of J.H. Mullen, was arrested to-day for marrying three women in a short space of time without going through the form of obtaining a divorce.

The east side branch of the Anti-Poverty Society held its second annual picnic and festival yesterday at the Empire City Colosseum, Sixty-ninthstreet and Avenue A. About 9 o'clock in the evening Dr. McGlynn made an address to the picnicers, who nearly filled the large pavilion, rehearsing his position and the theology he was teaching. He closed by telling his audience to enjoy themselves and forget their poverty and their sorrows in innocent amusement.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 17.--Observer Lyons reports the occurrence of "killing frost" for the first time this season at St. Vincent, Minn., where the temperature fell to 30 before sunrise this morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17.--Count Zbrowski, who was injured while playing polo yesterday, was quite comfortable to-day. No bones were broken, and he will soon be out.

SARATOGA, Aug. 17.--Notwithstanding the fact that Forepaugh's circus and Tony Pastor's show were in full working order here last night, the midsummer festival in Congress Spring Park was a great success. This was the second day, or rather night, of the carnival, and ...

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 17.--The third day's meeting of the Young Men's Christian Association's convention opened at 9 o'clock this morning in the Blasieholm Church, with devotional exercises conducted by the Rev. Mr. Johanson ...
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 17.--Passengers arriving from Leland this morning report that the heaviest rain fell there between noon on Wednesday and 8 A.M. on Thursday that was ever known in the delta.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 17.--The attendance of visitors at the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science to-day was greater than ever. Several interesting papers were read in section D, which is devoted to mechanical science and ...

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 17.--THE TIMES'S correspondent has it upon the best of authority that the proposed railway contract between the Manitoba Government and the Northern Pacific is off, the latter declining to enter the province except at the unanimous wish of the people. In the meantime the work of construction on the Red River Valley and Portage extension will be pushed rapidly forward by the Government.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 17.--Barney Ward of Downingtown, track watchman on the Pennsylvania Railroad, was killed on the road at Valley Creek, east of Downingtown, at 8:30 o'clock on Thursday evening. He was struck by extra freight No. 343, west, and thrown under an east-bound freight. Both legs were cut off, and his head was crushed.
A big brindle bulldog created a deal of excitement at Park-row and Mulberry-street yesterday by running around among a crowd of children snapping and frothing at the mouth.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 17.--Eastern railroad circles have been surprised by the announcement that the Canadian Pacific Road has signed contracts with St. John and European receivers of Western grain and other merchandise to transport the freight to St. John this Fall, and such shipments are to begin the latter part of September.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 17.--The body of E. Payson Smith, slain in the battle yesterday at Freetown, was buried to-day, a large number of people being in attendance. He was 42 years of age, a bachelor, a native of Ohio, and had been here only a few years.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17.--Passenger rates east and west from Chicago are not in a very stable condition. The stock market gained a little in activity yesterday, but it was an activity at the cost of good prices. Quotations went over on all sides. Many stocks declined materially, led by substantial old Northwest, which dropped over two full points.

REEDSBURG, Wis., Aug. 17.--News reached here to-day of a fatal shooting affray in the town of Woodland, southwest of here. Jennie Woolever, a domestic employed on the farm of William Sletser, was shot and killed by George Moon, 20 years of age.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 17.--William H. Barnum, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, had a long conference at the Hartford Club, in this city, Wednesday night with the Hon. George G. Sumner, who is understood to have informed his friends here that he cannot accept the Democratic nomination for Governor this Fall on account of poor helath.

The members of District No. 1 of the Order of B'nai B'rith will hold a reunion festival Thursday at Jones's Wood, under the auspices of the Grand Lodge. It will be the first time in many years that there has been a general gathering of the order, and great efforts are being made to make the occasion a memorable one.

R.F. Tucker, a partner in the firm of J.B. Brewster Co., carriage manufacturers at 143 East Twenty-fifth-street, who voted for every Republican candidate for the Presidency from Lincoln to Blaine, now renounces his allegiance ...

Eight railroads reported earnings yesterday in Wall-street for the second week of August, and all but one showed an increase. The exception was the St. Louis and San Francisco, whose week's earnings of $119,200 were $6,700 less than for the same week of last year.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 17.--The great 2:30 Consolation Stake was the feature of the closing day's sport at the Driving Park. Frequent showers interrupted the sport early in the afternoon, but, notwithstanding, a fair crowd was present.

If the golden rod be a few days late its setting is none the less superb. The roadsides, even the railroad sides, where the uncultivated banks have been left to the clouds' own watering, are rich and dense with wild-growing things, in this neighborhood at least.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 17.--Gov. Hill returned from Plattsburg to-day, having been heartily received by the local Democracy there last night. The Governor was introduced to an immense throng by the Hon. Smith M. Weed. Mr. Weed said that four years ago ...
ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 17.--The wagon works at Cortland have suspended operations. Unless work can be recommenced nearly 1,000 men will be thrown out of employment.

To-day, (Saturday,) Aug. 18, will be the event of the season at Monmouth Park. The Criterion Stakes, three-quarters-of-a-mile dash, purse $7,000, will be an interesting race, the participating colts being the best on the turf.

ALBANY, Aug. 17.--Louis Bender and John Sommerman left home early this morning and went to Rensselaer County for a day's sport woodchuck shooting.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Aug. 17.--The Republican candidate for Assembly will be Rufus I. Peck and the delegates to the State Convention are Arthur F. Stilson, George N. Valentine, Enos E. Mellon, Otis D. Patrick, and Henry Howe. The unanimous choice of the delegates for Governor is Warner Miller.
Trusts, according to Mr. BLAINE'S definition, "are largely private affairs with which neither President CLEVELAND nor any private citizen has any particular right to interfere."
CHICAGO, Aug. 17.--The problem which most puzzles the Post Office authorities is to find out who is Thomas J. Mack, the prisoner arrested with the mail-box thief, Frederick Oberkampf.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 17.--A sensation of gigantic proportions was created at the Newport Iron and Steel Works this morning. It was caused by the discovery of a lot of dynamite bombs. Enough were found to blow up all that section of Kentucky lying ...

Assistant Corporation Counsel Wickes argued yesterday before Judge Patterson in Supreme Court, Chambers, to have the writ of prohibition restraining Coroner Messemer from taking action against Secretary McLean of the Twenty-thirdStreet Railroad dismissed.

Justice Patterson yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court settled a dispute about a dog in a way that made on-lookers laugh. Mary Munaton, a colored girl who lived at 123 West Fortieth-street, had had Philip McArden of 468 Seventh-avenue arrested on a charge of stealing a black-and-tan terrier.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17.--A morning paper says: "It has been reported about town in a quiet way for some time past that the Northern Pacific Railroad Company was making arrangements to secure an entrance of its own into Chicago, and that large purchases of land were in prospect.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 17.--A fishers' commission, consisting of Edward G. Harrison of Asbury Park, William T. Baily of Camden, and Thomas E. French of Atlantic City, was appointed by the last session of the New-Jersey Legislature to inquire into the causes of the decline...

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 17.--Notwithstanding the rain the exercises of Initial Sunday School Day were well attended. They were conducted by Dr. B.M. Adams.

The application of James Horgan, a onelegged man, to the Brooklyn Charities Commissioners yesterday for assistance disclosed the fact that the authorities in Philadelphia are in the habit of sending their paupers to Brooklyn in order to get rid of them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--The President has detailed Col. John M. Wilson, Corps of Engineers, as a member of the Lighthouse Board, vice Brig. Gen. James C. Duane, retired. This is in addition to his present duties as engineer in charge of the Washington Monument and Commissioner of Public Buildings and Grounds.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 17.--Jonas Hallstead, brother of General Manager W.F. Hallstead, of the Delaware, Lackawana and Western Railroad, was killed at 1:20 o'clock this afternoon by a train near the Hallstead homestead, about a mile above Nicholson.
RICHMOND, Ky., Aug. 17.--The closing races of the New-Madison County Association Fair were held to-day with threatening weather. There was large attendance. The track was very dusty.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 16.--The Porter estate, valued at $100,000, at Niagara Falls is about to be divided.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 17.--Judge Thurman received a call to-day from Messrs. S.P. Cady, William Fitzgerald, John A. King, and Thomas Graham, all of Chicago. These gentle men comprise a committee who were appointed by the Cook County Democretic Club to come ...

About 700 men are now constantly employed in the famous quarries of red sandstone near Saverne, where concrete is manufactured for the extensive new fortifications of Strasburg and Metz. The German experts regard this concrete as the best possible material for such work, and the French have adopted it since the success of the elaborate experiments at Chalons.

At yesterday morning's early mass in the Italian Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, North Eighth-street, Williamsburg, a woman in the congregation suddenly rushed up to the altar and, with cries of "You scoundrel!" and "You thief!" attempted to stab the Rev. Father Pietro Saponaro.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 17.--A tinge of romance lights up one incident of the railroad disaster that occurred on the Erie Railway at Shehola early on Monday morning last.

Deputy United States Marshal Bernhard Thursday evening arrested Arne Weisse, an alleged German forger, in the steerage of the Hamburg steamer Wieland, which brought the survivors of the Geiser-Thingvalla collision. Weisse comes from Goenitz, Saxony, where he was a merchant.

CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 17.--The annual reunion of the Knights of Pythias of Pennsylvania convened to-day at Williams's Grove. Upward of 3,000 Knights and their friends were on the grounds. This evening the Oriental degree was conferred on quite a large number of the members. To-morrow addresses will be made by the Grand Lodge officers. The crowd will be much larger to-morrow than to-day.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., Aug. 17.--The Democratic Convention got down to work again this morning at 10:30 o'clock, and nominated for Judges of the Supreme Court Judge Henry Brannon of Lewis County and Judge David E. Johnson of Moyer. The attendance was very much smaller than yesterday. The ticket is generally conceded to be a strong one, and Democrats claim that the issue in the State is placed beyond a doubt.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 18.--The Norwegian steamer Liberta ran on White Island, off Ecum Secum, last night, and is a total wreck. The crew were saved, and have reached the mainland. The Liberta was from NewYork, bound to Stettin. No particulars of the disaster have been received, further than that the ship's bottom was crushed in, and her cargo is being washed out.

HOLBROOK, Arizona, Aug. 18.--William Nagler and Louis Nagler, ranchers and stockmen, have been lynched by outlaws in Pleasant Valley, and W. McRaigy, employed on the ranch of the Aztec Land and Cattle Company, has arrived here, having been driven from the ranch by outlaws. This is the continuation of a fight between sheep and cattle men in the Tonto Basin.

The Russian Steam Navigation Company have just contracted with an agent of the Persian Government to carry during the next three months large quantites of war material, such as cannon of various calibre, balls, and cartridges, from Odessa to Batoum, whence they will be sent by rail to the Caspian.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 18.--At the present time there is but very little wheat in country elevators in Minnesota and Dakota, much less even than has commonly been supposed, and this is an important fact to be taken into consideration in estimating the marketing prospect.

Samuel Henderson, aged 73 years, a resident of this city 50 years, a well-known lower bay pilot, and formerly a pilot on the Morgan line of steamers plying between Mobile and NewOrleans, died yesterday morning.

Neither Judge Henry A. Moore of the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, nor his son, John H. Moore, were in town yesterday to answer the charges made before the Ford investigating committee that they had been parties to a scheme by which foreign Captains had been illegally naturalized in order that they might take command of American vessels.

The announcement that the British Yacht Racing Association had thrown overboard the rule which has heretofore prevented centreboard yachts from entering for British cups has not created as much interest in this city as its importance would warrant, for the reason that nearly all the prominent yachtsmen are away.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 18.--Secretary Dillon of the American Flint-Glass Workers' Union returned home this afternoon from the conference he was attending in Wheeling.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18.--The Democrats of the Thirteenth Missouri District, in convention at Springfield, nominated C.C. Matlock of Marionville for Congress.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 18.--"When the Labor Convention meets in St. Paul we will nominate Ignatius Donnelly for Governor." Thus spoke "Ed" Sparks, a prominent local Knight of Labor, to-day. The laboring men are taking much interest in the approaching State Convention, and the various Knights of Labor...

LONDON, Aug. 18.--Mr. John Morley addressed a meeting at Lincoln to-day. He said he regarded the action of the Government in rushing the Parnell Commission bill through Parliament without debate as the most revolutionary thing that had been done in England in the present day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--To-day's bond offerings amounted to $655,600 in lots, as follows: Four per cents, registered--$25,000 at 128, $5,000 at 128, Four and a half per cents, registered--$276,000 at 108, $149,600 at 107 $200,000 at 108 1/8.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18.--A special dispatch to the Daily News from Scranton, Ohio, says: "The Sheriff and a posse had a fight with a band of desperadoes at Marion, in the interior of this county, yesterday afternoon, and one of the Sheriff's party was wounded.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 18.--The cottagers are returning from the seashore in large numbers, and the Autumn festivities will soon be inaugurated. Many prominent people from the large cities who have been spending the season...

A young man called at the store of the Winchester Fire Arms Company, 312 Broadway, a few days ago and presented an order for some goods signed by the Nason Manufacturing Company, 71 Beekman-street. The firm, believing the order to be a forgery, refused the goods.
RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 18.--An exciting regatta was sailed over the long or 12-mile course on the North Shrewsbury River at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18.--The Erie and the Chicago and Atlantic Roads will give notice on Monday of an advance of the rate on provisions, to take effect Sept. 1.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 18.--The crowds of people that came here by rail and water from all points of the compass during the past week seeking relief from the overheated cities taxed the hotels for accommodation.
Maestro Verdi has lately arrived at Montecatini, where he intends taking the waters, and with them a well-earned holiday.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 18.--Travel to the Catskill Mountains has been phenomenally heavy today, the heat of the present week having driven great crowds to the mountain tops.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 18.--The largest crowd of the meeting was at the races to-day. The weather was delightful, but the track was a trifle heavy. The events were well contested, the favorites winning a majority of them. Diablo would probably have beaten Gypsy...

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18.--Drafts--Sight, 10 cents, telegraphic, 15 cents.

Senator Gorman returned to Washington yesterday afternoon, where he will be obliged to remain most of the time until after the adjournment of Congress, which he does not believe will occur for three months.

A large number of horsemen gathered around Col. S.D. Bruee in the saddling paddock of Monmouth Park, yesterday, when he mounted a starter's stand to sell the horses in training of Mrs. G.L. Lorillard and five of her yearlings.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Aug. 18.--The dispatch which appeared in THE TIMES and World to-day, dated Ithaca, stating that the Cortland Wagon Company had suspended operations, throwing 1,000-men out of employment, is false and does great wrong to one of the soundest manufacturing concerns in the State.
There was a merry crowd yesterday afternoon at the Queens County Driving Park, where three races were trotted.

The Seventy-first Regiment goes to Creedmoor for its final general rifle practice next Thursday. H.C. Stahl has been elected Corporal in Company H. The company has instructed the following committee to prepare a series of entertainments next drill season: Lieut. Smith, Sergt. Paul, Corp. Bogert, and Privates Holbrook and Walker.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 18.--The Harlan Hollingsworth Company this morning successfully launched the iron steamboat Maine, building for the Brooklyn and New-York Ferry Company, to ply between those cities. Passed Assistant United States Engineer Annan, of the Amphitrite inspection board, christened the new boat. The Maine is a side wheeler, 188 feet long over all, 62 feet beam, and 14 feet deep.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18.--Alexander Young, an attorney of this city, returned here to-day from Toronto, where he was sent to make a settlement with Mrs. Norton, the woman who recently eloped with Editor Moore.
The police made 1,543 arrests during last week. "M.H.F."--No. 21 University-place, New-York.

BOSTON, Aug. 18.--The Democratic State Committee at its meeting this afternoon decided to hold the State Convention at Springfield, Sept. 5. The Executive Committee has selected John J. Donovan of Lowell to preside over the convention and Col. Charles H. Taylor as Chairman of the Committee on Resolutions.

Missouri is the only State in the Union in which the Supreme Court Judges actively participate in politics. Judge Sherwood, with four years on the Supreme Bench yet ahead of him, was an active member of the Springfield Convention yesterday, and was made its Chairman. The Springfield Convention, though judicial in its object, is political in its character just as mush as the Jefferson City Convention of next week will be.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Aug. 18.--Greenfield has a new jail that has been occupied only a few weeks and cost $70,000. Its utility as a prison was shown last night when William M. Williams, awaiting sentence for burglary, made his way through the wall with an iron nail.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18.--It is stated that the General Managers of the various roads between Chicago and the Missouri River have definitely concluded to take off their limited express trains one week from next Sunday regardless of the protests of the Kansas City and Omaha people. One concession has been made to the public, however.
Miss Ida Montfort, aged 23, a public school teacher, was drowned at Bayville, Long Island, yesterday morning, while bathing.
CONCORD, N.H. Aug. 18.--Papers were served upon the Concord Railroad to-day in two suits brought by the Manchester and Lawrence Railroad.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Aug. 18.--Senator Blackburn of Kentucky, the Hon. R.Q. Mills of Texas, and Phil Thompson, Secretary of the National Democratic Executive Committee, arrived in this city this morning, and are the guests of Senator Kenna. Large numbers of people came to the city to hear Mr. Mills's arguments on the tariff.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 18.--The schedule of assets and liabilities of E.H. Steele, who made an assignment a few days ago, was filed at the Court House to-day.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 18.--The annual regatta for the championship pennant of the Lake Champlain Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon. The harbor was dotted with craft and many people witnessed the race.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 18.--An addition to the rumors respecting the management of the St. Paul and Duluth Railway has been recently made in the reported probable resignation of Vice-President and General Manager Fisher.
The electric railway in this city has been subjected to the tests of short curves and heavy grades, and has stood those tests.
LONDON, Aug. 18.--The Cunard Line steamship Servia, Capt. McKay, from New-York Aug. 11 for Liverpool, arr. at Queenstown at 7:30 P.M. to-day.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 18.--Reports have just reached headquarters to the effect that an attempt was made at 2:30 o'clock this morning to hold up and rob the Union Pacific eastbound passenger train at Dana water tank, near Rawlins, Wyoming.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 17.--Yesterday morning a party of New-York brokers, who are stopping at the Hotel Kaaterskill, went on a fishing expedition. S.R. Quinlin was the champion story teller of the company, but he was completely routed in his special line by an old farmer whom they met on the way. The old man told a capital "bar" story, in which Bruin was demolished after a terrific fight with the farmer.

Chairman William H. Murtha of the Democratic State Committee, speaking of the Republican claims of Democratic defections, said that the great mistake which the Republicans made was in going into details.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 18.--The lifeless body of Miss Kate Mallon of New-York was found floating in Wesley Lake near the lower bridge at noon to-day by two boys. Miss Mallon was about 20 years of age and had been boarding in Ocean Grove for the past three weeks.
WINNIPEG, Aug. 18.--The hearing of J.L. Tegare's claim for indemnity from the American Government for securing the surrender of Sitting Bull has been commenced at Regina.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 18.--The black 2year-old colt, Lansing B., by Hambletonian Mambrino, dam by Lumps, has been sold by George Land to Brook Curry, both of this city; price, $1,000. Five thoroughbred yearlings, the property of W.B. Jennings of Washington, ...

EDINBURGH, Aug. 7.--To do the Forth Bridge properly you leave the City of Cliffs from Waverley Station, and by dint of tuppence, patience, and an extremely slow train are at some short but indefinite time in the future deposited at Leith Docks.
The ninth marksman's badge match was shot yesterday at Creedmoor. The weather was fine, light and wind being good.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18.--The passenger-rate war which has been brewing west of Chicago in consequence of the cutting of emigrant rates by the trunk lines has broken out in earnest.
Another historical chateau has just gone the way of a good many famous mansions in France.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18.--A Times special from Pine Ridge Agency, Dakota, says that a large band of armed Sioux have gone to the Cheyenne country on the Tongue River in defiance of Agent Gallagher's orders.

Twenty-four oyster boats, with sides newly pot-leaded and well-trimmed sails, crossed the starting line in the fourth annual oyster boat race given by the Larchmont Yacht Club off the Larchmont Clubhouse yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 16.--The commercial travelers of Indiana and Illinois paid their respects to Gen. Harrison to-day. It was anticipated that large delegations would arrive from Cleveland and Dayton, Ohio, but telegrams were received from both cities last night and this morning postponing their visit until some later...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--Speaker Carlisle has not yet decided to challenge Mr. Blaine to a joint debate, in fact he has heard nothing about the joint debate except what he has read in the newspapers. No proposition to discuss the tariff with Mr. Blaine has come to Mr. Carlisle from the National Committee, but he says that if the committee...

There were reported at Sanitary Headquarters during the past week 802 deaths, 684 births, and 248 marriages. The deaths were 44 less than those of the preceding week. The death rate was 27.22, with an estimated population of 1,532,060.

M. Ernest Renan is again busily engaged in taking venerable and respected tradition to pieces. In the current number of the leading review he has continued his task of demolishing David King of Israel, and he does it with the same mixture of good humor and cynicism of which we have had experience of old.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18.--In a telegram received to-day by the Alton Road Chairman Pierson of the Trunk Line Association states that he had been granted permission to make the St. Louis and Kansas City rate $5.

Michael Bailey, a compositor employed on a New-York paper, was found dead in the bathtub of his flat at 322 Bergen-street, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning. It is uncertain yet whether he committed suicide by drowning or died of heart disease.
DETROIT, Aug. 18.--What is known as the Toledo, Saginaw and Mackinac Railroad is just completed and will be ballasted and ready for business by the middle of next month.

ALBANY, Aug. 18.--That the rank and file of the Republican Party here is thoroughly disgusted with the manner in which party affairs are run is apparent from the exceedingly light vote cast at the primaries held to-day to select delegates to the Assembly and County Conventions. In five wards two polling places each were opened, and in four others there were lively...

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Aug. 18.--Some startling, revelations are just being made concerning the operations of the White Caps organization. While the infamous operations of the lawless gang have been known, the fountain head of the organization has remained a mystery, which is now being revealed through a clever ruse.

One more report has now come from the Soudan, which, by its explicit confirmation of previous tidings, puts beyond all doubt that a white man heading a strong body of armed followers is in the northern part of the Bahr-el-Ghazel region, and is there, too, for the purpose of disputing its possession with the Mahdi.

MEDINA, N.Y., Aug. 18.--The Republican County Convention at Albion to-day was a very harmonious affair. Full delegation were present and several enthusiastic speeches were made by confident Republican leadars. Chauncey H. Lum was elected Chairman, and delegates were elected to the State Convention, who are all...

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 17.--It is doubtful whether there is another section of country in the State of Pennsylvania, or in any other State, where the woodchuck, or groundhog, as it is better known, is found in so great numbers...
A richly-dressed young woman called twice at Police Headquarters last evening to see a prisoner about whom the detectives made a great mystery.

Mrs. Annie Winig of 1,716 Broadway, Williumsburg, obtained a warrant from Justice Naeher yesterday for the arrest of her husband, August, and her sister, Minnie Rudolph, who eloped, taking with them much of Mrs. Winig's jewelry and clothing.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 18.--This was another of the big days of the season. Early in the morning the crowds began coming in, and not till late in the afternoon did the influx cease.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 18.--Additional interest was added to the railway situation by the announcement telegraphed last night that the deal with the Northern Pacific Railway Company is off. Hammil Booth, silk jobbers of 96 and 98 Grand-street, have been missing small quantities of their goods for some time. Patrolmen Kerry and Logan of the Twentieth Precinct last night saw a man staggering up Eighth-avenue with a bolt of silk under one of his arms.

BERLIN, Aug. 18.--Emperor William lunched to-day at the headquarters of the First Infantry Guards and made another energetic speech in response to a toast to his health proposed by Col. Plessen. PARIS, Aug. 18.--The Bonapartist, Orleanist, Legitimist, and Clerical concentration is evident in the spasmodic revival of the popularity of Boulanger. His journey thus far in the north has been most triumphant. The Boulangists assert that no Government ever so tried before to counteract the popular enthusiasm to such an extent, and that no King or Emperor over attempted the like coercion.

There was an alleged race against time for an alleged $1,000 at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday. The distance was to be 50 miles and the man who was to beat the record was Guerrero. The record for 50 miles was made by George Littlewood at London on Nov. 24, 1884, when he covered 50 miles in 6 hours and 8 minutes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18.--The committee of General Passenger Agents appointed by the Western lines to prepare a revised form of passenger agreement and rules concluded its labors to-day, and its report will be printed and forwarded to the Managers of the Western roads interested Monday.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 18.--A notice has been posted in the Penn Rolling Mill stating that the finishing department will continue operations, the puddling department alone suspending. This will coutinue 200 men in employment.

The following persons died from the effects of the heat yesterday: John Matchett of 438 West Thirty-sixth-st.; Joseph Taske, aged 37, of 59 Cherry-street; Daniel Shea, aged 48, of 89 Baxter-street; Edward Naughton of 45 Broad-street, and Matthew Jones, aged 31, of 1,485 Fourth-avenue.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 18.--Engineers of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company have been at work between Butler and New-Castle for the last few weeks surveying a line to connect these two points by a shorter route.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, Aug. 18.--The festivities of the past week drew to Narragansett one of the largest assemblages of fashionable people known in its history. The lawn tennis tournament and kirmess proved undoubted successes. The kirmess, given Tuesday and Thursday evenings, was witnessed by an audience that overflowed the building. Tickers had been limited to 800.

At an early hour of July 15 a terrible disaster took place at Wakamatsu, Fukushama Prefecture, Japan, when the mountain known as Bandaizan burst forth into flame. This was followed by a long series of earthquake shocks and fierce showers of debris that continued for several hours.

Workmen in a gravel bed on the Western Railway of Alabama recently came upon the skeleton of what they think was an Indian Princess. On it were found a silver coronet, silver bracelets, a necklace made of silver buckles tied together with a silk ribbon, and a peculiar knife with a sabre blade.

VERONA, Mo., Aug. 18.--A wife murder and suicide took place here to-day. About 7 o'clock pistol shots were heard in the residence of Frank Linneberg and when the neighbors entered they found Linneberg and his wife both lying on the floor shot through the head.

At 11 o'clock yesterday Robert Mayer Co., 50 Barclay-street, received a dispatch dated at the Ship News Office, signed "Officer," and setting forth that a young man named Snyder had been seriously injured on Broadway and taken to a hospital at One Hundred and Thirty-eighth-street and Tenth-avenue.

FORT WILLIAM HENRY, LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 18.--From blue to green, from green to black, from black to glistening white, the waters of this beautiful lake, nestled in the foothills of the Adirondack, change beneath one's very eyes as one looks upon the scarcely ruffled surface.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 18.--The air is full of well-defined rumors relative to the probable resignation of General Manager Manvel of the Manitoba Railroad.

The ceremony of unveiling Mirabeau's statue at Montargis took place this afternoon in the presence of the President of the republic. Notwithstanding a downpour of rain the streets were thronged, and the firemen, brass bands, and the regiment of the place lined the way to the market place.

The Swatara sailed for South America at 10 o'clock yesterday morning.
MONTREAL, Aug. 18.--A Cazer, who shot and killed Joseph Pilow, the hotel keeper of Coteau Landing, on Tuesday last, has been arrested at kosses Creek and brought to this city.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 18.--The situation at the Elliot furnace at Round Mountains, Ala., is serious. The discharged white employes threaten to blow up the furnace if it is started with colored labor, as ordered. Arms and ammunition have been sent to defend it, and the Sheriff, with 100 men, has gone to the scene. The life of Capt. Elliot, owner of the plant, is threatened by the whites.

In the absence of Capt. Ewing yesterday O'Rourke filled the position, and he covered himself with glory. He made three hits--two singles and a home run--just when they were needed, and enabled the Giants to win another game from the Detroits.

The wheat boom in the stock market is over. Now we have to wait and see what the corn crop will do for it. In the waiting period, necessarily one of uncertainty, the market will probably go down. It cannot be known how the crop will turn out until about the 10th of September. If that time passes without a hard frost, corn is safe.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 18.--The officials of the Burlington Road announced this morning that the rate on west-bound passenger business coming from the sea coast which has been made by the Wisconsin Central will be met by their line.
NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 18.--A dispatch just received from New-Iberia says that things have assumed their normal condition again, and no further trouble is anticipated.

APALACHICOLA, Fla., Aug. 18.--A lynching took place at Ocheenee, Calhoun County, Wednesday. Noah Griffin, a negro, wrote an insulting note to a young white woman, Miss Simmie Griffin. She showed the note to white men, who caught Griffin, gave him 100 lashes, and ordered him to leave the county. He did not go, when a gang of 40 masked men caught and shot him to death. No arrests have been made.

In announcing to Chairman Abbott of the Western States Passenger Association the reduction of rates on the Wisconsin Central, General Passenger Agent Barker of that road says that the action was not taken until he has positive knowledge that the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy was cutting rates.
Some time ago I described a mysterious crime which had been creating an extraordinary sensation in Madrid, and all the efforts of the police to trace its authors were futile.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Aug. 18.--Several hundred men are now at work on the Jacksonville and St. Augustine Road strengthening and widening the roadbed, and laying nine-foot ties. By December the road is to be a standard gauge with improved rolling stock, one coach to cost over $10,000.

CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 18.--Considering the threatening weather, the attendance at the State reunion of the Knights of Pythias to-day at Williams's Grove was very large. The lodges from nearly every county in the State were present. The oration was delivered by the Rev. William Maller Fishburn of Harrisburg on "The Quality of Men." Ten bands of music are on the grounds. Addresses were made this evening by the Grand Lodge officers, after which they adjourned.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 18.--The fourth day's session of the Young Men's Christian Association Convention in this city opened at 9 o'clock this morning with the usual devotional exercises, conducted by the Rev. A. Kolmodin of Stockholm.

Yachts ranging from catboats to fullrigged cabin sloops, together with several naphtha launches, all flying the pennant of the New-Jersey Yacht Club, made the harbor present quite a sprightly appearance yesterday afternoon.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 18.--The Women's Foreign Missionary Society of the Methodist Church began its annual two days' session in the tabernacle this morning.
