Violations of the contract labor law was the subject principally inquired into yesterday by the Ford Congressional committee. The testimony evolved showed that for a considerable length of time Messrs. Barbour Co. of the Paterson (N.J.) Flax Mills have been importing skilled labor from England and Ireland, and that one of their Superintendents, a man named Seton, had been abroad giving these people steamship tickets on absolutely no security.

Fannie vaughn, daughter of Sheriff Vaughn of Richmond County, is learning telegraphy, and has an instrument in her father's house, at Richmond, Staten Island, which is connected with the telegraph wires that run through the town.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Aug. 18.--Elmer Bush, a noted horse thief and jail breaker, was yesterday captured near North Wales, Penn., by officers from this town. On Sept. 4 last year Bush stole a valuable animal at Stewartsville and was arrested the following day at Hackettstown, where he was placed in the town jail.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 18.--The annual reunion of the General Association of the County Democracy was held at Exposition Park, Allegheny City, this afternoon and evening and was attended by fully 10,000 persons. The demonstration was in many respects the most extensive that the Democracy has held for years, and the enthusiasm was unbounded.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 18.--Only one death to-day and one new case. New cases are expected daily, as they would come from those last sick, but certainly the outlook is very encouraging for all. Another meeting of the Executive Committee of the Jacksonville Auxillary Sanitary Association was held this morning at the Board of Trade room.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H., Aug. 18.-- Although the week's weather has been provocative of much profanity on the part of itinerant pleasure seekers, the accessions to the tourist population of the White Mountains have been steady and large.

PARIS, Aug. 18.--There can be no doubt that the proper place to be in this week is Trouville, or, if you cannot do just the right thing, put your foot on the fashionable ladder one rung below, and go to Deanville. CHICAGO, Aug. 18.--A great deal of work has been done by the postal inspectors who are looking up the cases against Oberkampf and Mack, the men charged with robbing street mail boxes, and much proof has been received that Mack is the Edwards or McEdwards of whom Oberkampf has told such wonderful tales as the chief of a national gang of robbers.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 18.--Information has been received by letter to the effect that the arctic whaling fleet had not done well up to date. Plenty of whales had been seen, but the vessels were in the ice and could not get them. Up to July 13 total catch was 21 whales by 14 vessels.

LEWISTON, N.Y., Aug. 18.--Old Fort Niagara is alive with men, and the green bluffs of the Niagara River are dotted with white tents at its mouth.

Charles M. Grant, a peddler living at 4 East Broadway, was locked up in the Madison street police station last night on the charge of kidnapping l0-year-old William Bronahan of 23 Monroe-street. Grant kidnapped the boy Friday, and took him on board the steamer Albertina. He was arrested on leaving the boat yesterday.
SARATOGA, Aug. 18.--Much excitement was caused at the race course to-day by the appearance of ex-Senator James Daly, who wore a Tammany button in the left lappel of his coat.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 18.--There were no new developments in the war between the Northern Pacific and Manitoba Road brought about by the harvest excursion.

"Prince Methusalem's" Court at Wallack's Theatre was broken up last evening, but the courtiers, unlike some in real life, are not out of a situation. The Hon. R.C. Pendleton of Indiana addressed an enthusiastic Democratic meeting at Newtown last evening. On Monday evening Mr. Pendleton, ex-Gov. Half the races of the Long Island Amateur Rowing Association's third annual regatta were rowed at Bowery Bay Beach yesterday afternoon before the stiff breeze that was blowing went down and the course was anything approaching favorable shape for sculling.

Salisbury and the 2-year-old Minion, by King Ernest, out of Minority, were galloping in company, when the first named crowded Minion into the fence, throwing her down.

READING, Penn., Aug. 18.--The burning of Van Reed's paper mill, five miles from this city, last night has blotted out one of the few Revolutionary landmarks in this section of the State. The property has been in the possession of the Van Reed family for 130 years, and flour was made there for Washington's army.

Entries for the Fall games of the New-Jersey Athletic Club, booked for Bergen Point on Labor Day, will close Aug. 27 with B. Salinger, Secretary of the committee, Post Office Box 3,029 New-York City. A handsome silk banner will be given to the club securing the greatest number of points. An open four-oarad shell race and several canoe races are on the programme.

The Pekin Gazette recently contained an imperial rescript severely censuring a number of officials concerned in the execution of a criminal who was sentenced to death by strangulation, but who "by a stupid piece of reckless and unpardonable bungling" was decapitated instead.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 18.--The police are after a colored man who has been pretending to be deaf and dumb, and who by his seeming worthiness has secured large amounts from several sources. He called yesterday at the residence of a prominent citizen and presented a slate on which was written a plea for succor for an unfortunate deaf mute.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 18.--The scaffold on which the murderer Palladoni is to be hanged on Oct. 5th reached the jail in this city yesterday, having been brought over from NewHaven, where it was last used, on a truck.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18.--The polo games to-day were uninteresting. The match was a final one for the $250 cup offered by the club and was between two teams representing the Meadow Brooks club, they being winners in the previous matches of the week.

LONDON, Aug. 18.--Those who expected great things of the Peterhof interview already confess to their disappointment. Russia and Germany are no whit nearer an all-round amicable understanding than they were before the Czar rubbed his huge Cossack-like beard against the smooth and pachydermatous cheek of the young Kaiser.

A census of the population of St. Petersburg was taken during the night between the 26th and 27th of June. It is stated that the population amounts to 843,883 persons, of whom 110,002 were in the suburbs.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 18.--There is now no doubt of the truth of the statement of O.M. Shaw of the West End, Bar Harbor, who was with Mr. Blaine in Forence, Italy, that the latter gentleman is seriously afflicted with kidney disease.

There were five races on the card at Yonkers yesterday. The first four events resulted in some good sport, but the fifth event, a hurdle race, at a mile, was a farce. Three horses were announced as starters, but in the race it was shown conclusively that but one of them was out to win, that one being Zampa. Taking the first hurdle, however, Zampa knocked it down, jumped the fence, and threw his rider.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 18.--The twenty-first session of the Western New-York Turnfest closed at Dolgeville, eight miles from here, to-night, after four days of literary and athletic exercises and general festivities, and turners were present from New-York, Baltimore, Albany, Utica, Rochester, Syracuse, Buffalo, Auburn, and elsewhere.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 18.--Mr. Morton S. Patton of New-York won the all-comer's singles in the Mossley Hall lawn tennis tournament here to-day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--Major-Gen. Schofield and Lieuts. Sawyer and Pitcher of his staff left Washington this evening for New-York, where they will remain several days on business connected with the Division of the Atlantic. Lieut. Bliss of Gen. Schofield's staff will remain at Army Headquarters. Until some other arrangement is made Gen. Schofield...

A meeting of the New-York Commission for Gettysburg Monuments will be held at 23 Fifth-avenue on the 10th of October next at 10 o'clock A.M. for the consideration of the designs or monuments which are to be erected on the battlefield of Gettysburg next Summer. Regimental and battery organizations proposing...

CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 18.--The Democratic campaign was formally opened in this city to-day, when the County Convention met and unanimously nominated Capt. W.E. Miller, a veteran soldier, as Chairman of the committee to conduct the campaign. Speeches were made by ex-Congressman Beltzhoover, the Hon. William Penn Lloyd, ...

The Fassett investigating committee will resume its investigation of the history of the new Croton Aqueduct in the Court House tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock. It is probable that the committee will hold its daily sessions during the week, and important developments are expected. The testimony promises to be interesting, at any rate, as several gentlemen prominent in municipal and politcal circles will be called to the witness stand.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18.--Hitherto cases of lepresy have been found mainly in the rural districts, but at last one has been discovered at the county hospital in this city.

A cloudy semi-official denial to the statements which appeared in these columns a fortnight ago about the diary of the late Emperor Frederick has been published in a German paper; but I maintain the absolute accuracy of the information on this subject.

CHESTER STATION, Vt., Aug. 18.--Burglars entered the residence of George C. Allen early this morning. One, with revolvers, kept Mr.Allen and his wife in bed. Another ransacked the house, seduring $1,500 in money and valuable property. Rewards are offered of $1,000 for the arrest of the burglars and $500 for the recovery of the property.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 18.--The rain of the latter part of the week was a sad disappointment to the many tennis lovers among the guests and villagers of Cooperstown. The annual tennis tournament has been the great event of the season at Cooperstown for several years, and it was expected that the present would surpass all former events of a like kind.

Considerable exagger ation has been perpetrated in reference to the adulteration of bread with alum. The quantity actually used is very small, and the question whether the term adulteration is fairly applicable to such addition is a debatable one.

Frank Harvey's melodrama called "The World Against Her" was presented at the Grand Opera House last night to begin the season there. It is a play that will insure to Miss Kate Claxton and Mr. Charles A. Stevenson, its ...
A Raleigh gentleman has collected and preserved an interesting souvenir of war times down South in the shape of a scrapbook filled with samples of home-made cloth of every description.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19.--Twenty-four wholesale liquor dealers of St. Louis have formed a corporation to build a gigantic distillery in this city. The purpose of the organization is to directly oppose the Whisky Trust, which has put the price of high wines at a figure which the organization claims is altogether too high in comparison with distilled goods, notably the Kentucky brands.

Nearly all the horses in training at Fleetwood have been shipped to Poughkeepsie to take part in the races there, which commence to-morrow, and as a result but few horses were worked out yesterday morning. Johnny Murphy gave the gray mare Lady B., by Deucalion, three miles in 2:29 , 2:29 , and 2:27 , the last mile in economy with Skylight Pilot.

So far it doesn't appear that the Republican State ticket has carried a singly county, except the county of Lawrence, where they have about 200 majority. All the other counties which defeated Democratic nominees gave Gov. Seay and the whole Democratic State ticket handsome majorities.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 19.--The official order of President Julius Dexter of the Cincinnati, Hamilton, and Dayton Railway, completing the transfer of the Cincinnati, Richmond and Chicago branch of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton to the Pennsylvania Railway Company, has been issued, as was also the official order of Vice-President McCullough of the Pennsylvania Company, accepting the transfer.

LONDON, Aug. 19.--The Dublin Freeman's Journal gives prominence to an authorized paragraph declar ing that Mr. Parnell is able to make the clearest case of disproof of the charge that he was the author of the Times letters by a chain of evidence of the most perfect character.

BOSTON, Aug. 19.--It becomes more and more apparent that the interests of the Gloucester fishermen and those of the vessel owners are two different things, and that Senator Hoar, while talking for American fishermen, really represents the vessel owners. This difference of sentiment is mainly due to the fish trust or monopoly.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--While the postal inspectors feel sure that Oberkampf and Mack, the mail thieves, operated on their own responsibility and without allies in other cities, they have been convinced that the men had some assistance in disposing of the captured stamps.

A revolt occurred last week at the prison of Illava, where the worst criminals in Hungary are confined. The ringleader was an assassin named Porgetoth. It appears that the present Director was disliked for his severity, and a conspiracy was organized to murder him.

The recent action of the House has left legislation for the supply of heavy ordnance in a somewhat dubious state. The Army Appropriation bill as it passed that body contained little except the usual routine items, and was disposed of with only a few hours' consideration.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 19.--David B. Hill's boom for the Governorship progressed and some of Mr. Hill's warmest friends from far and near had what they considered a jolly time here to-day, even if it was Sunday.

AT THE MOUTH OF THE NILE, July 7.-- Tradition tells of a certain young English officer in India who, having been fortunate enough to meet with a number of the most noted Hindu Princes in the course of his travels, published an account of his earliest interview of this kind under the title of "My First Rajah."

Edward Conklin of the Progressive Painters' Union presided yessterday at the meeting of the Central Labor Union. The Web Press Union sent a letter stating that it had changed its name to Newspaper Printers' Union No. 1, and that the members would turn out in full force in Labor Day's Parade.

All New-York had a picnic. That is what it seemed to be yeaterday. It was a very good sort of a day--sometimes cloudless, but never hot--and the people came out of doors. The mercury rose to 88 at 3 P.M.

Between Buffalo and Attica a pale-faced young man with a cube-root look about him came into the car with a package of blank slips and a pencil and announced: "Prepare your ballots to vote on the Presidency!" There were 10 men in the car. The 10 rose up as one.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 19.--Mrs. Adolph Harman, who was murdered Thursday by her husband before he shot himself, was buried to-day in Branchburg Cemetery, West Long Branch. The funeral services were held at the home of her brother, in Long Branch. There was a large attendance.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 19.--Passenger trains on the West Shore Railroad were delayed from two to three hours this afternoon near West Camp, 10 miles north of this city, by two stock cars, laden with sheep, jumping the track. A wrecking train was sent to the scene of the mishap and by 8 o'clock to-night all the tracks were clear. All up trains are on time.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--There was a secret meeting last night at the Grand Pacific Hotel of members of the recently formed Lumbermen's Association, which now controls one-half the standing pine in Northern Wisconsin and Weyerhauser of Rock Island, who heads the trust; Senator Sabin, F.U. Prince, J.C. O'Gorman of Stillwater, Minn., and Gen A.G. Norton of Winona, Minn. None of them would give any details of the meeting's doings.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--The following is the crop summary which will be printed in the Farmer's Review this week:

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 19.--Congressman Matson of Indiana has declined to accept the silver service which was presented to him yesterday by the employes of the Government Printing Office, on the ground that it is not proper for him to accept any reward for the performance of a duty imposed upon him as a member of Congress, and that it would set a very bad precedent.

PARIS, Aug. 19.--Gen. Boulanger was elected to the Chamber of Deputies in the Department of Somme to-day by a majority of 34,723. He also heads the polls in the Charente and Nord Departments. The announcement of the figures caused great excitement in this city.

The spot on the shores of New-York Bay at Greenville, N.J., that the members of the Faith Cure Mount Zion Church have selected for their camp meeting grounds never looked more enticing to a city dweller than it did yesterday.

There are not so many cotton spinners in New-York as there are in New-England. Still, there were about 10,000 in 1880, and since then the number has increased. It may be easily shown that protective tariffs have had nothing whatever to do with building up the business of spinning cotton, but with that question we have nothing to do at present.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 19.--William B. Catlin, Jr., died at his home, 29 Admiralstreet, at 3:30 P.M., to-day, and the cause of his death is so uncertain that Medical Examiner White has ordered a post-mortem examination.
The Albion Cricketers will meet an eleven of the Staten Island Cricket Club at Livingston, Staten Island, in a cricket match next Saturday.

Charles Mitchell, aged 20, of 305 East Twentyeighth-street, called on his father, Martin, at 337 East Thirty-eighth street, last night and told the old man to prepare for a "licking." the father prepared, and when the "licking" process was over it was found that the son's scalp was so badly cut and bruised as to require the aid of a surgeon. He was placed under arrest in Bellevue Hospital.

C.A. Sweet of Sloansville has in his possession a petrified mud turtle found by him in the Schocharie Creek. It is 15 inches in length, 25 inches in circumference, and weighs 38 pounds. It is a curious and wonderful formation, and its possessor thinks it is worth going many miles to see. Mr. Sweet has refused many tempting offers, and will not part with the curiosity.

All the States will elect Presidential Electors on Tuesday, Nov. 6. The Electors then chosen will meet at their respective State Capitols on Wednesday, Dec. 5, and cast their ballots for President and Vice-President of the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--Chicago people are still going to the playhouses in flocks, and the Summer season, now nearly ended, has shown pretty conclusively that, with something spectacular, something funny, and something musical joined, the heated term yields financial harvests nearly, if not quite, as freely as do the Winter months.

The British Consul at Palermo in his last report observes that business during last year suffered greatly from an epidemic of cholera in Sicily, the mortality being very great in most of the towns. The population of Palermo lived for some months in a state of "savage panic."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19.--The Democrats of the Fifth Congressional District of Missouri have nominated John C. Tarsney of Kansas City for Congress.

The Rev. Edward H. Camp, a Presbyterian minister of Newark, N.J., who had just returned from Palestine, committed suicide in Newark last night by cutting his throat and then jumping into a cistern. Ill health was the cause.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--The sealing season in the Behring Sea, which lasts from the middle of June to the end of August, is now nearly over, but no seizures of vessels violating the laws of Congress by capturing seals in the neighboring of the Pribyleff Islands have thus far been reported to the Revenue Marine Department of the Treasury.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 19.--The will of the Very Rev. Anthony Smith, the deceased Vicar-General of the Diocese of Trenton, will be offered forprobate this week. He leaves $30,000 in charitable bequests, and about $60,000 to relaives.

Amos Lawrence, son of Amos Lawrence, was born in 1814, and both of them took the family surname after a grandsire, who was the minister of Roxbury Church during the Revolution. The Lawrence stock was of sound English origin, coming from Suffolk. Amos's first schooling may be said to ...

A breach of promise suit for $10,000 is the pleasant prospect before Charles Dallon, the son of a wealthy farmer of Stony Brook, Long Island. Miss Annie Dalton, a cook, who was formerly employed by Farmer Dullon, says that young Dullon proposed marriage to her and was accepted.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 19.--The most eloquent and the strongest lecture of the season was given last night by Judge Albion W. Tourgee. His subject was "Our Greater National Debt," which he asserted to be the debt we owe the negro race.

Suddenly relieved from a double burden of heat and humidity, the spirit of the metropolis leaped forth yesterday gratefully and joyously. Long days of labor filled with sweltering torture and longer nights of tossing about on slumberless beds were succeeded, as if by magic, by a day of ideal loveliness.

BOSTON, Aug. 19.--The arrest of a smuggler yesterday afternoon came about under circumstances that constitute it one of the biggest jokes in the annals of the Customs Service. These circumstances and the fact that it was not a police matter kept it out of the papers today, but Col. L.A. Montgomery, a Special Agent of the Treasury, told the story to THE TIMES'S correspondent this evening.

When the Academy of Music reopens for the season on Aug. 30 with the long-promised grand production of Denman Thompson's "Old Homestead," the old patrons of this large playhouse will find little but the four walls to remind them of the old Academy.

With liberal scratching so as to reduce the fields of starters to reasonable numbers the programme announced for to-day is one that will produce good sport. With the original entries it is, however, entirely too heavy. The card announced is as follows:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 19.--Early last evening Hermann Stube, a German, entered the boarding house of Charles Kroses at Sayreville, and after ransacking the upper story and securing watches, jewelry, and other valuables, started off with his booty. Down stairs he met Mary McLaughlin, a servant, and, seizing her, demanded her money or her life. She screamed, and, with an oath, he drew and fired a revolver.

Daniel Lyons, who will be hanged tomorrow morning, broke down yesterday when his aged mother entered the prison corridor to pay him her final visit. At sight of the feeble, broken woman his stoicism of the last few days deserted him, and for the first time since his incarceration he gave way to tears.

The first hard coal ever handled in this market for general use was in 1850 by H. Norton Co. This firm received by steamer for their own use in 1849 30 hogsheads of hard coal. Their office was on River-steet in the vicinity of Fort Dearborn.

For the first Sunday since the beginning of the Presidential campaign the Oriental Hotel, at Coney Island, yesterday, did not have on its piazzas a crowd of distinguished personages. Even Thomas C. Platt was away, and senator Fassett failed to seek for strength with which to endure the asperities of the aqueduct investigation by bathing in the salt sea waves.

We are sure that every one will mark with great satisfaction the progress made by the Hon. JOHN SHERMAN in the study of trade combinations. We have already spoken of his discoveries in this field, but we find in his remarks of the 14th inst. evidence that his acquisitions of knowledge have been notable since our last report.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--General Manager Chappell of the Chicago and Alton Road, who has just finished a trip over that system, is not sanguine about railroad business for the rest of the year. "The prospect is decidedly poor," he says.

SARATOGA, Aug. 19.--This was the greatest day of the season in Saratoga, great in the number of people here, great in weather, and great in everything. It was a perfect day, and everybody made the most of it. All of the hotels were crowded to their fullest capacity, and it ...
FIRE ISLAND, Aug. 19.--The Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler to-day preached to 300 persosns at the Surf Hotel here. A large collection was taken up for the benefit of the School for Trained Nurses.

Amsterdam claims to have become the principal market in Europe for tobacco in consequence of the excellent quality of the Sumatra tobacco, which is sought for there by buyers from all parts of the world, and especially by American cigar manufacturers, and of the large amounts of Dutch capital invested in the ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 19.--Michael Murray, short stop for the Ontario Baseball Club, an amateur club of this city, was hit by a pitched ball this afternoon in a game with the Actives, another amateur club, and killed. His neck was broken from the force of the ball. Murray employed as a brakeman on the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railway. He was 24 years old.

Ignatius Donnelly returned from England yesterday by the Cunard steamer Aurania. He said last night that he had been received with great consideration abroad. Mr. Donnelly is an ex-member of Congress from Minnesota, and it has been reported recently that there would be ...

The annual festival of the United German Festival Association, an organization formed for the purpose of holding such gatherings once a year, began yesterday at Washington Park, at the foot of East Sixty-eighth-street, and will last three days. The grand pavilion and the grounds were elaborately decorated with bunting and flowers.

Benjamin Diamont, 40 years old, and Marie Rodmann, about 10 years younger, with a child, were passengers in the steerage of the steamship Republic. They were detained at Castle Garden yesterday, it appearing that neither have any means whatever. They were both Hungarian peddlers from Karaz, Hungary. The woman claims to be Diamont's wife, but he disowns her, saying that he merely met her in Liverpool, whence she followed him to this country.

NEWPORT, R.I., Ang. 19.--This has not been, strictly speaking, a day of rest for the yachtsmen of the New-York squadron, for most of them have spent it visiting each other and their friends on shore, so that the boats' crews had very little real rest. At "colors" this morning, in obedience to a previous signal from the ...

SYDNEY, New South Wales, July 10.--The Oceanic Steamship Company's steamer Alameda, which sails hence to-morrow for San Francisco, will bear numerous accounts of an incident in which she has been a prominent actor.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 19.--The two days' session of the Woman's Foreign Missionary Society came to a close to-day. A holiness meeting was held in the Tabernacle at 9 A.M., which was presided over by Mrs. Palmer and the Rev. J.H. Thornley.

LONDON, Aug. 19--Only a sentence of Blaine's Portland speech has been cabled here, but that one is comprehensive enough to make every monopolist regret the day that submarine telegraphy was made possible.

The Hon. Robert T. Lincoln, ex-Secretary of War, and his daughter, Miss Mary Lincoln, were among the passengers who arrived in this city yesterday on the Cunard steamship Aurania. Mr. Lincoln appeared in the best of health and spirits.

ALBANY, Aug. 19.--The charge of the Brooklyn Eagle that the Executive Chamber and the Executive Mansion have been the resort of a lot of "unscrupulous rascals" since Mr. Hill has been Governor contains little that is news to this vicinity.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 19.--Last night Ernest Schram attempted suicide by shooting himself in the head with a 22-calibre revolver. He walked out to the centre of the Robert-street bridge, and after firing a shot in the river, presumably to test his little revolver, he sent a ball into his head over the right eye. He fell to the sidewalk, and Officer ...

The entries to the Fall Stakes of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, which closed on Wednesday last, are of a nature that is very flattering to the young organization. The stakes for future years are the more noticeable in the increase of nominations numerically, but even for the stakes to be run during the coming Fall meeting the entries are very good.

It was said at the Brevoort House last night that there was practically no change in Mr. Garrett's condition, except that he appeared to be a little easier. No arrangements have as yet been made for his departure, as Miss Garrett has so far failed to find a suitable place to which he can be removed.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 19.--Inquiry at the different railroad offices failed to confirm the reports of widespread damage to crops from frost, as reported yesterday. There was frost all along the main line of the Northern Pacific, but the agents at Fargo, Bismarck, Jamestown, and other cities reported that there had been no damage to the crops.

A fresh breeze blowing from the Hudson kept the Sing Sing Methodist camp grounds cool and comfortable yesterday, and crowds kept pouring in all day long to the various services. Every road leading from the back country and connecting with the villages on the Harlem Railroad was full of teams. By 5 o'clock in the afternoon there were fully 10,000 persons on the grounds.

The fifteenth Summer festival of the Italian Young Men's Christian Association Sunday school was held in the hall of the association yesterday afternoon. The room was prettily decorated and the music, under the supervision of Mrs. Stauder, was excellent.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 19.--Beginning tomorrow morning and continuing for three days the Rondout Social Maennerchor will hold a Saengerfest, and every indication points that it will be one of the largest German musical festivals held in this State in several years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 19.--Dr. A.K. Fischer, a well-known German writer and politician, committed suicide in this city last night by taking opium, dying at 9 o'clock, one hour after swallowing the fatal draught. He was 46 years old and a native of Munich. During the late war he was surgeon of a New-York regiment.
It was a question of identity in the matter of beer that agitated the minds of the delegates at the Brooklyn Central Labor Union meeting yesterday afternoon.

HALLIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 19.--People wishing to see the damaged steamer Thingvalla, which was in collision with the Geiser, are charged 5 cents admission to the wharf where she lies. Crowds visited the wharf to-day. The money is to go to the Hallifax Sailors' Home.
Seventy-six arrests for violations of the excise law were made yesterday. James Birch of 2,456 Fourth-avenue, was drowned yesterday while bathing in the Harlem River at Fourth-avenue.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 19.--The Hon. Allen G. Thurman, accompanied by quite a large party of friends, will leave here to-morrow afternoon for Port Huron, Mich., at which point he will open the campaign on Wednesday.

The historians say that the wolves swept down from the North 200 years ago and ate up all the deer then in Maine. Some of the deer, however, swam to the various islands along the coast and a remnant was saved. The wolves, robbed of their food by their own bloodthirsty ...

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 19.--Yesterday morning a caravan of railroad hands consisting of 80 men and 26 wagons passed through Charlotte, going to Winston to work on the Roanoke and Southern Railroad. A few hours afterward messengers came flying into Charlotte stating that the men had committed numerous outrages ...

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Aug. 19.--The uncalled-for quarantine on the Mexican side of the Rio Grande has culminated in a tragedy. Yesterday two respectable Mexican citizens of this county named Fernando Mentz and Juan Dolores tried to run the quarantiue into Matamoras by swimming the river below Nogales.

Charles Bell of Washington, D.C., a welldressed man, who was unaccompanied by friends, was taken from the last iron steamboat from Coney Island last night suffering from alcoholism. It was believed at Chambers-Street Hospital that he would not recover.

Two prisoners from Cooperstown arrived at the Delaware and Hudson station yesterday afternoon sentenced to the penitentiary for 60 days each. The sheriff who had them in charge was left behind at Cobleskill. The conductor on the train looked after them, and Officer Kyle took charge of them upon their arrival at this city.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 19.--An interested crowd of 500 or more persons gathered on Bay-street at 7 o'clock last night. They were the street-cleaning gang, and they were awaiting the appearance of the paymaster.
Edward McCabe, a peddler, living at 345 East Thirty-sixth-street, visited Sam Long's laundry at 659 First-avenue on Saturday night in search of a shirt he had left there to be laundered.

A meeting of the Provincial Council of the Catholic Total Abstinence Unions of NewYork, New-Jersey, and Brooklyn was held yesterday afternoon at the rooms of Our Lady of Mercy, T.A.B. INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 19.--Gen. Harrison passed a quiet Sabbath preparatory to his trip to Middle Bass Island. He spent the afternoon in the country, returning home this evening. To-morrow is his fifty-fifth anniversary.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 19.--Frank Gingras, son of a wealthy citizen of this place, was killed in a barroom fight early this morning. He was struck on the head with a bottle by the bartender. The blow caused concussion of the brain. He died almost instantly. The bartender was arrested to-night for murder.

A blunder dies slowly. The "Renaissance Studies" of Mr. Walter Pater have just deservedly reached their fourth thousand; but the droll idea that husbandmen winnow corn with a flail, or all implements in the world, is still to be found there. It will be seen in the account of Dr. Bellay's well-known winnow song. Oxford dons are not required to be farmers, but Mr. Pater must have seen a flail.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 19.--Last night at Wadesborough the keeper of the county jail was overpowered and beaten by three prisoners while removing them from one cell to another. The outcries of the keeper brought several persons to his assistance. Henry Dunlop, one of the prisoners, got possession of the keeper's pistol and started out, when he was met by James Craig and Mr. Hardison, two prominent citizens of Wadesborough.

One of many instances which go to show the futility of the cries that there is dissatisfaction among the Democrats in President Cleveland's home occurred on a train coming from Rochester the other night.
The game at Louisville yesterday was postponed on account of rain. The Gorhams and Pittsburgs will play the first colored championship match at the Polo Grounds to-day.

Since the consolidation of the German Empire the greatest zeal has been displayed in schemes of internal improvements. Germany has nothing exactly corresponding to our River and Harbor bill, but she spends her millions as regularly as we do in bettering her ports and waterways.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 19.--Francis L. Vineent of this city attempted to commit suicide by cutting his throat, to-day, at his residence on Chestnutstreet. He will be remembered as the bookkeeper employed by the Auburn Woolen Mill Company who had some difficulty with his accounts. The matter troubled him so much that he left the city.
Twenty-five thousand persons visited Schutzen Park, on Union Hill, New-Jersey, yesterday, and the fourteenth annual Plattdeutsche Volksfest, which is to continue four days, was auspiciously opened.

The criticisms applied to Brother James Blaine for his manner of tackling the trust question indicates that this is not going to be quite so unadulterated a 'campaign of reason" as was announced. There are always some subjects of more than ordinary contemporary interest upon which a man must not talk sense.

The Excelsior Boat Club of Bay Ridge yesterday held its anunal regatta off the club-house at the foot of Bay Ridge-avenue, South Brooklyn. The course was 10 miles, around the buoy off Owl's Head and Robbin's Reef Light and return. Seventeen boats were entered in the three different clauses.

The brew of all the celebrated etablishments in this city and vicinity flowed freely yesterday in Hoboken notwithstanding the Sunday excise law. The personality of the individual brewer vanished, however, for the day behind a conspicuous label which contained only the significant words "weiss beer."

LONDON, Aug. 19.--There was a good demand for discount during the past week at 2 to 1 . The Stock exchange was quiet during the week. Business was restricted, owing partly to the absence of speculation. Prices drooped in every department, but there were no signs of decided weakness anywhere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--A good story is told of Gen. Sheridan's first interview with Mrs. Darrar, the artist who painted the excellent portrait of the General, which, by George W. Childs's generosity, is to ornament the Military Academy at West Point. Mrs. Darrar was asked by Mr. Childs to paint the portrait.

Nearly two years ago the architects and the local authorities of Seville called the attention of the Government to the dangerous condition of different parts of the cathedral. It will seem hardly credible that a country which devotes every year more than 4,000,000 sterling to its public works could not spare enough to avert the catastrophe that every one now laments.

SARATOGA, Aug. 20.--Many of the guests of the hotels who are making flying trips to the various watering places departed this morning, leaving room for others who have engaged apartments here for the remainder of the season.

GUIDE ROCK, Neb., Aug. 20.--Billy Cole, who shot William Montgomery and Charles Grant at a dance on the 17th inst., was taken from the jail here by 12 masked men at 2 o'clock this morning and hanged on the railroad bridge. Both of Cole's victims are still alive.

Some days ago the Tariff Reform Club of Nyack decided to hold a meeting in the Opera House in that place at which the tariff question should be discussed by a protectionist as well as by a tariff reformer. It was thought that the Republican National Committee would not refuse ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 20.--Shortly after midnight of Saturday last Patrick McManus had some words with Robert Conn on the highway at Milton Village. Words led to blows, and Conn was so severely beaten that his life is despaired of. To day McManus was arrested, and is held to await the result of Conn's injuries.

The remains of Mr. Frank Holl, R.A., were laid to rest at Highgate Cemetery on Tuesday. No recent death has created a more painful feeling than that, in the early prime of his life, of our most successful portrait painter. Among his personal friends was the Prince of Wales, who often visited his studio in Fitzjohn's-avenue. On one occasion, when the Prince was to ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--The following is published here: "Recent movements tend to confirm the belief that the Illinois Central will not only invade Nebraska, but aslo Wyoming and possibly Colorado. The objective point will be either Ogden or Denver, with the chances in favor of the former.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 20.--Entries for the annual exhibition of the State Agricultural Society, to be held at Elmira from Sept. 17 to 20, closed on Saturday night last in all except the implement and horticultural departments. They are 20 per cent. in excess of the entries made last year, which were the largest in the history of the society--4,007. Several days will be required to classify the entries.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 20.--The Deutsche Kriegerbund began its fourth annual session this morning. It is an association analogous to the Grand Army of the Republic and has a membership in America of about 2,500 men who served in the German Army and Navy during the Franco-Prussian war.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 20.--Meetings were held on the camp ground nearly all day today, preliminary to the formal opening of the annual camp meeting to-morrow. The morning and afternoon were devoted to protracted meetings of prayer for the success of the camp meeting. In the evening a communion service was held in the Auditorium.

Mayor Hewitt resumed his official duties yesterday, but he was not in an amiable mood. NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20.--Count Elliot Zborowski, who was injured at polo last week, is able to drive out, but is very weak yet.
BERLIN, Aug. 20.--A semi-official report of the speech of the Emperor at the headquarters of the First Infantry Guards on Saturday says: "The Emperor expressed pleasure at seeing the regiment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--The retirement of Brig.-Gen. Baird, which took place to-day, and the appointment of Col. Roger Jones to be InspectorGeneral of the Army, with the rank of BrigadierGeneral, will cause the promotion of Lieut. Col. R. P. Hughes to be Colonel and mayor G.H. Burton to be Lieutenant-Colonel Gen. Jones, who is now ...

We are informed by parties at the City Hall that a much larger number than usual of Democratic women has recenty registered to vote for the Boston School Committee, and that the movement is being quietly but effectively pushed.

Nelson Richardson, a colored laborer, 19 years of age, while working in the tunnel of the new Croton Aqueduct, between Shafts 27 and 28, at about One Hundred and Seventiethstreet and Tenth-avenue, was instantly killed at noon yesterday by coming in contact with an electric light lamp. He was one of a gang of 20 colored laborers brought from Columbia County, Va., to work on the aqueduct.

The fourth annual meeting and exhibition of the society of American Florists will open to-day in this city. The society has for its objects the teaching of the best methods of growing and caring for flowers and plants, and the advancement of the social and business interests of its members.

The Lackawanna Road has finally succeeded in making Passenger Commissioner Pierson understand that it will no longer recognize his authority as far as Castle Garden business is concerned. When the passenger agent of that line notified Mr. Pierson about ...

Not Mayor HEWITT but Gov. HILL produced before the Fassett Committee yesterday the letter which the former wrote to the latter on July 13 advising him to recommend to the Legislature at its special session the reorganization of the Aqueduct Commission. But it was not original letter ...

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 20.--A heavy southeast gale, following some 24 hours after the time predicted by the Weather Service Bureau, struck this coast Saturday and increased in violence until this morning at 2 o'clock, when it blew 57 miles an hour.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 20.--The model of the equestrian statue of Gen. Robert E. Lee, which is to be erected here, made by Mercie of Paris, was examined to-day by the Monument Board and accepted. The model gives perfect satisfaction, not only to the members of the ...

Lona Kohlbusch, the 10-year-old daughter of Horman Kohibusch, who does business at 61 Warren-street, in this city, was frightfully lacerated on a barbed wire fence while bathing at south Beach, Staten Island.

At a meeting of the Directors of the Mercantile Fire Insurance Company, held yesterday afternoon, it was decided to discontinue the business, and the policy holders were all reinsured in the German-American Insurance Company of this city. This step has been in contemplation for some time. The Directors thought that this was a good time to retire the capital of $200,000, and hence yesterday's action.

David Cohen of 91 Bride-street became disorderly in the Thalia Theatre, in the Bowery, just before the closing of the performance last night, and while being put out by force some one shouted "Fire!" The theatre was crowded and for a moment it looked as if there would be a panic, but the orchestra began to play furiously, the curtain went up, the play went on, and the people quieted down. Cohen was arrested.

WHEELING, West Va., Aug. 20.--By a premature blast at Troll Brothers' cement works, three miles south of this city, this afternoon, Jacob Mahew, aged 23, had his head blown off. William Mahew, his brother, was dangerously wounded.

The corner in August cotton, which has been attracting so much attention from members of the Cotton Exchange and merchants interested in the commodity, practically ended yesterday. There was a marked drop in the price on Saturday, and yesterday morning the market opened at 11.18 and closed at 10.74, a drop of 44 points.

Edward Aronson, business manager of the Casino, died yesterday morning at his home, 213 West Forty-fourth-street, from consumption of the stomach. Mr. Aronson had been sick for some time. The hard work which fell to his share at the Casino had three years ago undermined his health and his physicians recommended ...

A remarkable illustration of the sagacity of the horse reaches us from Gillott-road, Edgbaston. A man named Nathan Gilbey, a coal dealer and hauler, rents a field there, in which a horse and goat have been in the habit of grazing.

Several survivors of the lost steamship Geiser, who did not resume their journey on the Slavonia are about to bring suit against the Thingvalla Line to recover the value of their effects which went down with the ill-fated vessel. They have engaged as counsel August ...
The Duke of Marlborough has been married again. The second ceremony has now been celebrated for nearly a fortnight without any but the immediate relatives and friends being the wiser.
ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Aug. 20.--The worst disaster in the shape of fire that this city has experienced since the memorable fire of 1877 occurred this afternoon.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Aug. 20.--A messenger from Standing Rock Agency brings information that the Sioux Commissioners are still there. During the last fortnight nothing worthy of note has transpired, the commission taking things quite easy, probably in the hope that the Indians will be subdued by their persistency.
We have seen now that taxes on imports increase their price and diminish their volume, lessening the amount of articles for consumption which we get in return for our exports.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--Post Office Inspection Kidder has nearly completed the task of assorting the thousands of letters which were found in the possession of Oberkampf, the mail robber. The mail matter, except such as is necessary for evidence at the trial, will be returned to the senders on Wednesday.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 20.--This afternoon a skiff in which Dennis and Michael Reardon, Richard Welsh, and Martin Brennan were sailing above the State dam in this city overturned, and Dennis Reardon and Richard Welsh, who could not swim, were drowned. Dennis Reardon resided in New-York.

ELMIRE, N.Y., Aug. 20.--Robert R. Scott and wife, married only a few months, resided at Penn Yan, Yates County. This morning the couple went to a Summer resort-called the Ark, a short distance from their home.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--In reply to a Senate resolution the attorney-General has forwarded to the Senate a large number of letters comprising the correspondence of the department since Jan. 1 in relation to the appointment of supervisors and Deputy Marshals and their compensation and duties.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 20.--Half a dozen years ago Conrad Shenfield staggered on the stage at the Opera House at a Murphy temperance meeting and signed the pledge. He kept it, but his fortune was gone. He had been cast out by his friends and he was penniless.

An auction sale of a library comprising works on numismatics, genealogy, archaeology, and local history, catalogued by Mr. W. Elliot Woodward, was begun yesterday morning at Bangs Co.'s rooms, 739 and 741 Broadway.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 20.--The citizens of Fort Dodge have petitioned the State Railroad Commissioners to compel the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Company to reopen and operate its road from Tora to Fort Dodge and erect and maintain a station in Fort Dodge. Their petition states that the Keokuk, Des ...

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The Ontario County Republican Convention, held here to-day, elected delegates to the State Convention as follows: Edwin Hicks, Henry D. Weyburn, Fred Baker, Edwin Ottley, A.J. Phillips, W.A.

NEW-CASTLE, Penn., Aug. 20.--The Rev. C.M. Morse, Pastor of the Methodist Episcopal church in this place and a lifelong Rebublican, has deserted that party and will vote for Cleveland. His reason for changing his views is the tariff issue. He is in favor of protecting American workmen and opposed to the Pinkerton style of shooting down Americans to protect foreigners. He cannot go the free whisky plank in the Republican platform either.

A number of professional people assembled in the "Little Church ground the Corner" yesterday afternoon at the funeral of William A. Morgan, the tenor, who died suddenly at Pamrape, N.J., Friday morning, of congestion of the liver.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 20.--The Plainfield Quakers to-day held commemoration exercises in their old meeting house on Peace-street. On the front of the building is an ancient dateboard bearing the figures 1788.
LONDON, Aug. 20.--Gen. Boulanger's triple success yesterday is felt to have grievously unsettled again the French situation, domestic and foreign.

LONDON, Aug. 20.--Mr. Gladstone, addressing a deputation of Liberals of Burslem who had presented him with a vase, said the Government had treated Mr. Parnell with gross inequality when they refused to allow ...
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The track to-day was better than for several days. There was a good crowd present, and the races were well contested, favorites and fielders dividing the events equally.

The Star Theatre, which with the alterations which have been made is practically a new house, and one of the prettiest in the city, will begin its first season as a popular price combination theatre on Monday evening next.

The appearance of Telie Doe and Boaz in the five-hundred-and-fifty-dollar purse races at Brighton Beach yesterday gave those events additional interest, but in neither case did the new arrivals achieve victory.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 20.--Last evening as the Rock Island flyer was pulling out of Valley Junction a criminal named James O'Connor jumped from the window and escaped. He was from Lundance, Wyoming, on route to Joliet, Ill., to serve in the penitentiary.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 20.--The scientists are going home, and the sessions of the American Society today showed a falling off in attendance. The work of the meeting will be finished to-morrow.

When the curtain rose at Wallack's Theatre last evening it disclosed a pretty picture of bright Autumn landscape, with a noisy brook tumbling down a rocky declivity in the background. It was the opening scene in Dellinger's ...

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 20.--Judging by the busy throngs on Bay and Main streets to-day and the air of bustle that prevailed, it was fair to presume that the announcement of new cases of yellow fever created no excitement.
BUFFALO, Aug. 20.--For 22 years W. Dayton Quick, a well-known general insurance agent, has voted the Republican ticket. He now says:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 20.--Over 100 horses have arrived for the Summer-meeting at the driving park, which begins to-morrow. Three events are to be decided on the first day--the 2:30 class, in which there are 21 entries; the 2:25 pacing class, in which there are 6 entries, and the 2:22 class, in which there are 12 enteries. The track is in fine condition and every race of the meeting promises to be hotly contested.

Not since the commencement of the present passenger rate war has there been so much excitement among the Broadway ticket agents as was shown yesterday.
The play at the Windsor Theatre this week is "Fate," by the late Bartley Campbell. The principal actors are Miss Rose Osborne and Mr. Russell Bassett.

A famous French lady, the Countess Pellegrini Boy--who had she lived until October next would be a centenarian--has just died in Italy. The Countess was the daughter of Gen. Boy, who fought in all the campaigns of the Revolution and the empire, and she married Count Pellegrini of Parma, one of her father's aides-de-camp, in 1811.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20.--The Hon. C.H. Tupper, Minister of Fisheries, has returned from the maritime provinces. During his absence from Ottawa he paid considerable attention to the fishery protection service, going over a portion of the fishing grounds in Northumberland Straits and the Gulf of St. Lawrence.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 20.--Dr. Lucern Clarke, Pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Erie. has accepted the assistant editorship of the American Christian Advocate of New-York at a salary of $3,500 a year. Dr. Clarke goes to his new field in October.

Nicholas G. Kortright, who died in 1863, named two Trustees in his will, whom he specifically empowered to sell his estate. These Trustees did not qualify, and the sons of the testator, Gouverneur and Lawrence M. Kortright, were appointed Trustees by the Supreme Court, without any clause as to the selling of the estate.

Over a hundred young business men met at 177 East Broadway last night and organized the Down-Town Tariff Revision Club. Jonas Leon was elected President, J.D. Eisenstein First, and M. Fround Second Vice-President; Harry Kramer, Secretary, and Henry Ettelson Treasurer.
Some testimony was adduced yesterday before the Ford Congressional committee which will give the Republican managers and Mr. Levi P. Morton, their candidate for Vice-President, some food for thought.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--David R. Shievely, a commission merchant at 160 South Water-street, to-day filed in the County Court a voluntary assignment of his property to James R. Dean for the benefit of his creditors. He scheduled liabilities of $2,700, with assets of a like amount.

Warden Brush said yesterday that he expected very unpleasant results from the idleness of the large number of convicts in Sing Sing Prison. The men were showing bad symptoms in various ways. They are discontented and very much dejectad in spirits and are continually writing letters to the Warden and principal keeper, begging to be put to work at something, they do not care what.
To-day's racing at Monmouth does not promise to be anything sensational on paper, but at the track the contests may assume a decidedly different aspect, as they have on several occasions this season.

A cablegram was sent to Chauncey M. Depew, at London, yesterday asking permission to tender him a reception on his return to America. The cablegram was signed A.R. Whitney, Levi P. Morton, Frank Hiscock, Charles E. Fitch, James Arkell, John M. Francis, Albert Van Dervere, John F. Plummer, W.J. Arkell, and others.

AMERICAN CANOE ASSOCIATION CAMP, LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 20.--A beautiful morning, with a brisk northwest wind, gladdened the hearts of the three hundred canoeists now in camp, who have experienced rather rainy and disagreeable weather thus far.
"It may be that reductions should be made," said Mr. HARRISON in Indianapolis on the l3th inst. to a party of Republicans from Illinois. He was speaking of "our present tariff schedule."

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Aug. 20.--At Oakland City, Gibson County, last night, Sherman Reeves, a deputized officer, arrested his nephew, Sherman Grim, for disorderly conduct. A fight ensued and both drew revolvers. Grim was shot three times and will die. Reeves was slightly wounded. He gave himself up and was placed under bond.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--Congressman Edmund Rice, the Democratic Representative from the St. Paul and Minneapolis district of Minnesota., was at the Grand Pacific to-day on his way home. "Minnesota I consider a debatable State," said he.

GARDEN CITY, Kan., Aug. 20.--Another move to renew the county seat war in Wachita County was made Friday night by two of the County Commissioners stealing away the Commissioner's records and removing them to Farmer City, where, it is presumed, they will attempt to set up a bogus County Government.

BUFFALO, Aug. 20.--A pretty young woman, whose hair was of the tint which causes gamins to look for "de white hoss;" was walking down Main-street this morning with an escort. When just below Seneca-street another lady was noticed running after them. In her hand she clutched an umbrella, with which she ...

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 20.--Joseph Richardson, estimated to be worth $12,000,000, came near being killed in the long tunnel of the Harlem Railroad in New-York yesterday. He was superintending repairs to the tunnel when two trains approached from opposite directions. The engine of one struck him, throwing him ...

John B. Fisk, 20 years old, a worthless fellow who lives at 13 Nelson-street, Brooklyn, was a prisoner in Justice Massey's court yesterday charged with arson and having attempted to burn his mother to death. This lady is now Mrs. William Morris, and she told the court a pitiful tale about her son's disgraceful conduct.
Daniel Lyons, who shot and killed Joseph J. Quinn July 5, 1887, will be hanged at about 8 o'clock this morning in the courtyard of the Tombs prison. Yesterday he passed in waiting ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 20.--At a late hour Saturday night a party of laborers, employed at J.J. Jones's brick yard at Dunskammer Point, met at McWilliams's Hotel, Marlborough, and Dan Shields, formerly of this city, and another person, whose identity has not yet been established, had a friendly sparring match in a rear balcony of the hotel.

BRECKENRIDGE, Col., Aug. 20.--O.O. Lee left this place on Aug. 10 for Silver Plume, over Argentine Pass. He reached the top of the range at about dark and missed the road at a very dangerous place, and by fellowing on an abandoned trail undertook to cross the broken bridge. HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 20.--The Directors of the Hartford and Connecticut Western Road will hold an important meeting here tomorrow. The new Directors, including William B. Scott and John W. Brock of Philadelphia, will be present. Mr. Brock is the principal

J.H. Le Veen, editor of the Kansas City Star, discussed the political situation in Kansas at the National Democratic Headquarters yesterday. CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 20.--The Republican campaign was formally opened in this county to-day, when the convention met and nominated a full county ticket as follows: For Congress, Hon. B.F. Seitz of Newville; for the Legislature, Charles Barnes of Mechaniesburg, James G. Rhea of West Pennsberg; Sheriff, George H. Miller of Carlisle. Several other minor officers were nominated.

The Rev. Edward H. Camp, who committed suicide at his residence, 1,040 Broad-street, Newark, on Sunday afternoon by cutting his throat with a razor and then throwing himself into a cistern, was the last of the direct line of the old Camp family of New-Jersey.

The abundant harvest, brilliant weather, and extraordinary demand for field labor have this season the curious effect of denuding the chief populous centres of the Taurida and Don of domestic servants. In Rostoff, for instance, there is not a cook, kitchenmaid, housemaid, or nurserymaid just now available. All are out on the Steppe harvesting.

If army gossip is correct, we have several field officers who cannot respectably drill a battalion, a few Captains who cannot properly drill a company, and a number of Lieutenants who cannot correctly drill a squad, and some of each grade who never worked out a soldier's clothing account.
Last Spring the cry was "Blaine or Bust"; now it's "Trust in the Trust."

Lucy Stone's friends celebrated her seventieth birthdays by letters and flowers last Monday. A good many of her old associates in anti-slavery and early woman's rights days were able to send her greetings, though the survivors of the noble band of come-outers are growing fewer very fast now.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 20.--The Frost Woodenware Works has made an assignment to James T. Campbell. The liabilities of the concern are $69,486 89, while the appraised value of the assets is $80,388 90. The concern was started 30 years ago by Milton Frost, who died within the past year, since which the business ...

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 20.--A special from Gadsden gives a meagre acoount of what threatens to be a bloody race conflict at Round Mountain Furnace, in Cherokee County. About a week ago the white and negro laborers about the furnace fell out about some social pretensions of the blacks, and, seeing that a collision was inevitable, the management banked the furnace.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 20.--The coke trade is now in a pretty healthy state as far as the demand is concerned. Nearly all the works will run next week, and a majority will be in operation full time.

NEWPORT, Aug. 20.--The race for the eight cups given by Newport, to be sailed for by the yachts of the New-York and Eastern Yaent clubs, was undertaken to-day, and proved to be a failure, owing to that plentiful lack of wind which seems to be one of the salient features of the Newport course.

BIDDEFORD, Me., Aug. 20.--The Hon. James G. Blaine will address the Republican meeting at Old Orchard next week. The exact date is not yet desided. He will also speak at South Berwick the latter part of the week.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20.--There was almost a riot on the Philadelphia baseball grounds to-day during the game between the Philadelphia and Boston Clubs, which was won by the latter, owing, the partisans of the Philadelpliia Club said, to the unjust decisions of Umpire Valentine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted the following bond offers: $50,000, $80, $100,000, and $2,200 registered four per cents at 128; $1,009 four and a half per cents, registered, at 197 5/8, and $1,000 coupon four and a half per cents at 197 5/8.

BOSTON, Aug. 20.--News of a singular tragedy resulting in the death of a lady well known in Hyde Park, near Boston, comes from Fort Fairfield, Me. Major Hewes and family, formerly of Boston, but now residing in Philadelphia, have been salmon fishing in the rivers of Eastern Maine and New Brunswick for the last six weeks.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 20.--The tenth annual Congress of the New-Jersey Federation of Trades and Labor Unions was held at the State House in this city to-day. President Dennis Mullins of Jersey City presided until the election of his successor, Samuel Mellor of Trenton. During the session, which was ...

BAIL HARBOR, Me., Aug. 20.--There was a very large and fashionable attendance at the Messley Hall lawn tennis tournament to-day, and the easy victory of Mr. R. Livingstone Beekman of New-York, who defended the cup won by him last Summer, against M.S. Paton of New-York, the winner of the tournament, was a throughly popular one.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 20.--A good many delegates to Wednesday's Republican state Convention are on hand. At the Savery are Gen. Beeson and Capt. Twomby, candidate for State Treasurer; Judges Given, Granger, and Seevers, candidates for Supreme Judge, and Messrs. Milton Reniley, H.J. Baker, J.Y. Stone, and H.T. Winslow, candidates for AttorneyGeneral.

The Cleveland and Thurman Campaign Club of the Twenty-fourth Ward (Tremont) began its work last night with a great demonstration at Ittner's Villa, on One Hundred and Seventy-seventh-street, better known as Tremont-avenue.

"Nobody approves of trusts but those who are in the ring" remarked a Wall-street lumber dealer to a TIMES reporter yesterday, in reply to a question regarding the probable effect of the reported formation of a trust for the control of Western lumber. FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 20.--The Hon. T.T.D. Andrews, President of the International Range Association, said to-day, in reference to Mr. Blaine's recent defense of trusts:

In the last race at Brighton Beach on Friday last, the horse Monmouth, one of the intended starters, went lame after the jockey had weighed to ride, and had to be withdrawn. Betting on the track went on uninterruptedly, the holders of Monmouth tickets having their money refunded in accordance with the rule.

Edward Harrigan returned Sunday from a vacation of two months spent on his estate at Schreon Lake. Manager Hanley had assembled the "Waddy Googan" company and the new play was given its first reading, the rumorous actors and actresses seated in a half circle of chairs upon the stage, their forms half hidden ...

CHARLESTON, West Va., Aug. 20.--Regarding the probable nominee of the Republican State Convention, which meets here Wednesday morning, everything is at sea, and the outlook is well calculated to discourage any but the most sanguine members of the organization. Col. J.L. McLean of Putnam County seems to be the foremost candidate for Governor.

A dispatch was received from Newburg yesterday that a man who gave his name as Charles Reno had walked into the police station at Hudson the night before and asked to have the handcuffs he wore on his wrists filed off. He declared he had snapped them on as a joke. The fellow was locked up on suspicion of being an escaped prisoner.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 20.--Capt. Adrian C. Anson of the Chicago Club, with 14 of his colts and veterans, arrived in this city late last evening. When seen by a TIMES reporter this evening he talked very freely about the situation in the League. Though not so hopeful of winning the championship as when he was last in the ...

Stocks were cheaper when the Stock Exchange first opened yesterday morning than at any other time during the day. Almost from the start quotations began to advance, and at the close of business the figures were at their highest, the bulls in high feather, and the hurrahing ...

At the Brevoort House last night Mr. Garrett's, private secretary, Mr. Guy, said that there was no perceptible change in the condition of the sick man, that he rested fairly well, and had a remarkably food appetite for an invalid. It is expected that Mr. Garrott will be removed in a very few days, but to what place has not yet been decided upon.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 20.--Gen. Harrison passed his fifty-fifth anniversary in a very quiet way. The morning was given up to his correspondence and the reception of an occasional caller. This afternoon the weather cleared up, and the General spent a couple of hours at his law office and paying a few friendly visits. Among his callers to-day was Congressman Owen of the Logansport district.

The yearling entries to the stakes of the different jockey clubs to be run in future years, which closed on the 15th inst., are not yet all in, but enough have been received to show an immense increase over any previous year.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 20.--A singularly fatal accident occurred near Aurora, Madison County, Saturday. Samuel Williams, with his wife and 6-year-old child, was returning home from a field near the house when a large oak tree suddenly fell upon them. Williams's neck was broken and his skull crushed. The child was mashed into jelly, the mother escaping with serious injuries. Williams was an exConfederate soldier, having served three years in an Arkansas regiment.

There was a collision on the New-York and Rockaway Railway at Hammel's, Long Island, at 4:43 yesterday afternoon between train No. 45, drawn by Engine No. 8, John Hunt, engineer, and a train on the rapid transit branch, which runs between Rockaway and Fa Rockaway.

BOSTON, Aug. 20.--When P.J. Rogers, the story of whose arrest for smuggling was told in THE TIMES this morning, was taken before Commissioner Hallett to-day some peculiar features about the case were developed, although its trial was postponed until Wednesday. TOLEDO, Aug. 20.--At a few minutes after 4 o'clock this afternoon Engine 57 on the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railroad, with baggage and parlor cars attached, pulled out of the Columbus Union Station carrying Judge Thurman and party on their way to Toledo and Port Huron, where the campaign will be opened on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--The Finance Committee of the Senate that started out at Mr. Evarts's hospitable house to get up a tariff bill, based upon the assumption that there is excessive revenue to be checked, has changed its course and is now preparing to utter a bill of a different sort.

A series of instrumental concerts by the band of the Thalia Theatre, increased in numbers, under the direction of Mr. Paul Steindorff, was begun at Terrace Garden last night. The hall and garden were crowded by an audience which manifested its appreciation of the performance by generous applause after each number.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The steam launch Dandy, which met with an accident in Thursday's race, to-day steamed over a measured mile in 3 minutes 20 seconds. She was not stripped for racing, and had 18 adults on board.
"R.B.W."--The articles are not written by him. The Yorkville Yacht Club's annual regatta will occur at Oak Point Sept. 2. Entries will close Sept. 2 at 9 A.M.

Inspector J.J. Kehoe found a gold watch and a diamond ring in the trunk of Armand Cailleau, a passenger on La Champagne. Inspectors Donohue and Brown found three bracelets, six pearl earrings, and six pearl breastpins on his person. None of these goods had been declared, and they were seized.

Congressman William McAdoo of NewJersey says that the Republicans are losing ground in his State every day; that their "hurrah is petering out, and the more thoroughly the people understand the issues of the canvass the more they become of our way of thinking.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 20.--James Bogart, Government Engineer of the Fishery Commission, was seriously injured in NewHaven this evening. He, with assistants, had been placing a buoy in Long Island Sound.
Miss Blanche Marsden, daughter of the recently-deceased dramatist, Fred Marsden, made her first appearance on any stage last night at Koster Bial's Concert Hall, appearing as a sirio-comic singer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--Mrs. H.J. Lindley is a book agent who is very likely to make things warm for the Chicago Police Department. She had started out on a canvassing trip, and was bound for Michigan, when she was taken into custody last night at the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad station.

The wheelmen of the American and English teams who arrived here late Sunday afternoon on the Cunard steamship Aurania leave to-morrow night for Buffalo, to train for the great "World's Tournament" to be held at Buffalo Sept. 4, 5, 6, and 8, in connection with the International Fair, Sept. 4 to 14.

Augusta claims to have the youngest grandfather in the United States in the person of Mr. James Lindsay, who will be 35 years old this month. Mr. Lindsay is a machinist, and when he was 17 years old married Miss Melvina Lewis. When Mr. Lindsay was 18 years old he became the father of a boy, who was named William.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 20.--The news received from Bishop Harris in London continues steadily unfavorable. His wife reached his bedside yesterday, but a dispatch sent this forenoon by his physiciau states that he is lying in an unconscious condition, and adds no word of encouragement. His friends here have ahout abandoned all hope of his recovery.

Every playgoer will be glad to learn of the success Mr. Edward H. Sothern met with at the Lyceum Theatre last evening. The career of this young comedian has thus far been distinguished by becoming modesty, as well as earnest endeavor.

William Sexton, in anticipation of a busy trade when the Presidential campaign waxes hot, and a busier one after it is over, is putting his Broadway room in first-class condition. The tables will all have new cloths and the floor new carpet.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 20.--At Delaware City yesterday morning, while several canalboats were waiting to get through the locks, James Gillson of Manayunk, Captain of one of the boats, was killed by Mart Richards of Port Elizabeth, N.J., Captain of another ...

Yesterday the weather was noticeably cooler, with a light wind, which freshened a little in the early afternoon. The thermometer ranged from 69 at 8 in the morning to 83 in the afternoon and 74 in the evening. The maximum for the day was 87 . To-day the indications are that it will be slightly cooler, with increasing cloudiness and probable rain by tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--The Chicago Evangelization Society has arranged for a convention of Christian workers, to be held in Farwell Hall, Aug. 29, 30, and 31. At the request of Mr. D.L. Moody, the Rev. Dr. Hudson Taylor, director of the China Inland Mission, and Mr. Reginald Radcliff of London, England, will be present at the convention.
OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 20.--James W. Wright, a wealthy retired tea merchant of New-York, took a dose of croton oil last night by mistake. It is thought he will die.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 20.--The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has in contenmplation the building of a line through the southern central portion of the State which will be gradually extended until it connects with the Southwest Pennsylvania, and will parallel the contemplated South Pennsylvania Railroad.

A daring murder was committed yesterday afternoon shortly before 4 o'olock in the open hallway of 73 Park-row, in full view of the crowds which all day pass that point. Still the identity of the dead man is a mystery and that of the assassin is not clearly established.

The Central Committee of the Henry D. Purroy Association held a meeting at the Morton House last evening, over which Mr. Purroy presided, at which the arrangements for the meeting at the Academy of Music on Saturday evening were perfected. Among the Vice-Presidents will be Ed Kearney, his son-in-law.

Robert C. Bell of Fort Wayne, Ind., for eight years a State Senator, is visiting this city. He says that the Democracy of that State was never so harmonious and enthusiastic, and that there is no danger of its being defeated. The Republicans, he says, cannot "work" the tariff scare in Indiana, for the reason that the workingmen ...

Stephen R. Post, one of the most prominent members of the New-York Produce Exchange, failed yesterday. The announcement of this fact was made on the bulletin board at 2:45 o'clock and created a decided sensation.
John Waters of 186 Park-row attempted to stop a runaway team at the Brooklyn entrance of the bridge Monday night by shutting one of the big wooden gates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21.--Col. John S. Mason, Ninth Infantry, was to-day retired from active service. First Lieut. F.S. Dudly, Second Artillery, has been relieved from duty at the University of Nebraska, Lincoln, Neb., and ordered to visit the State Encampment at Wahoo, Neb., on Sept. 1. First Lieut. Frank O. Hobbs. Ordnance Department, now stationed at Philadelphia, has been ordered to duty at Washington in connection with the construction of guns.

The Carlisle Indian School boasts of the oldest pupil now attending a school in the United States. This person is past the advanced age of threescore. He is man of vigorous physique, with a strong, open face for one of his age and his race. Louis Demont, or Danthault, as he sometimes called himself, a Frenchman about 50 years old, died suddenly last Friday at the New York Hospital from the effects of blood poisoning, and a mystery is the result of the occurrence.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., Aug. 21.--The White Mountain coaching parade that took place at Maplewood to-day surpassed, both in magnificence and extent, any coaching affair ever witnessed in New-England. The Executive Committee having the parade in charge consisted of William C. Harding, Stamford; John H. Flagg, ...

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21.--The first tennis match the morning was the unfinished match of the first round between H.W. Slocum, Jr., and W.H. Barnes. Only a small number of spectators were present. The first set easily went to Slocum by the score of 6--2. From the start it was evident that Barnes was no match for Slocum.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--Among the distinguished arrivals at the Hotel Todd yesterday was Col. Robert C. Brown of New-York. The Colonel was on a flying business visit, but found time to entertain a large party of friends at the Grand Union Hotel.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 21.--George L. Deved, iron founder of Baltimore, Md., was arrested while passing through here last week under an indictment found against him by the Grand Jury of this county for grand larceny.

WHEELING, West Va., Aug. 21.--By a premature blast at Troll Brothers' cement works, three miles south of this city, yesterday afternoon, Jacob Mahew, aged 23, had his head blown off. William Mahew, his brother, was dangerously wounded.

The greatest care has been taken in the education of the royal children in Greece. The Crown Prince, a tall, handsome young man of 19, unites great strength of character and will to a very amiable disposition, which gives a charm to his person and causes him to be adored ...

BOSTON, Aug. 21.--The young woman found wandering about Franklin Park on the night of Aug. 11, and who susbsequently died at the City Hospital from narcotic poisoning, was identified to-day as Christiana Baird of Brooklyn, N.Y. This is the woman who gave the name of Annie Clark.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 21.--Heavy rains to-day prevented the opening of the Summer meeting at the Driving Park, so the first day's events were put over until to-morrow.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 21.--James P. Bogart, the engineer of the Connecticut Shell Fish Commission, while in prosecution of his duties today, near the breakwater in the New-Haven harbor, fell and broke some of his ribs. His injuries though painful are not, according to his physicians, dangerous. He was conveyed as soon as possible to his home at 376 George-street, in this city. He is a very well known and prominent engineer.

BOSTON, Aug. 21.--A case of flagrant violation of the law which requires masters of American vessels to be American citizens has come to the knowledge of the United States officials here. For sevaral years Robert H. Hurlburt has been in command of American ...

Senator INGALLS meant well when he advised the Republicans to nominate for VicePresident "some fellow like PHELPS of New-Jersey, who could reach the conservative forces of the East and get contributions from the manufacturers and Wallstreet."
