The entries to the Brighton races are again altogether too numerous for good sport, but it may safely be considered that the state of the track to-day will make owners anxious to scratch, and large fields need not be feared.

The Tribune has not yet defended Mr. BLAINE'S opinion that Trusts are merely "private affairs" with which "neither President CLEVELAND nor any private person has any right to interfere," but its readers should not on this account permit themselves to believe that it has no opinions of its own upon this subject.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 21.--The storm which prevailed here all day cast a damper upon the opening of the camp meeting, which began its ten days' session this morning.

While Mrs. Louisa Hill of 75 Cook-street, Williamsburg, was doing laundry work at a neighboring house yesterday her son George rushed in and told her that this sister had been stolen. Mrs. Hill had left both the children at home when she went to work. While she was away a large woman entered her home and dragged away her adopted daughter, Annie, 11 years old.

BUFFALO, Aug. 21.--Curious to know more than the Republican newspapers are willing to print concerning some of the persons who have "ratted" from the Democracy at this end of the State, and the political effect of their action, I made inquiries ...

NORTH ATTLEBOROUGH, Mass., Aug. 21.-- The residence of Stanley Freeman, at Falls Village, one of the wealthiest jewelers in Attleborough, was robbed last night of diamonds valued at $2,000 and a fifty-dollar gold watch.
Judge Patterson yesterday referred the case of S. Skiddy Cochran against the American Opera Company to Samuel Jones.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 21.--Joseph Nef, a carpenter, who boarded at the house of Lorenz Schmidt, 222 East Walnut-street, has mysteriously disappeared. He left Mr. Schmidt's house on the morning of Saturday, Aug. 11, at 10 o'clock, since which time nothing has been hard of him.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 21.--Mr. Kendricks of the Northern Pacific Railway is expected here to-night, when developments in connection with the railway situation are expected. The Government says positively that the deal is not off, and it intimates if certain ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Ang. 21.--The American Association for the Advancement of Science finished its thirty-seventh meeting to-night and adjourned to meet next August in Toronto. Officers were elected as follows: President--T. E. Mendenhall of Terre Haute, Ind.;

BERLIN, Aug. 21.--Signor Crispi, the Italian Prime Minister, left Frankfort to-day for Friedrichsruhe. He will remain in Friedrichcruhe two days and will afterward go to Carlsbad. He will be visited to-morrow by Count de Launay, the Italian Ambassador to Germany.
The Journal recently advertised Jackson S. Schultz, the great tanner and leather mer chant of New-York, who supported Cleveland four years ago, as a "convert to Harrison."

LONDON, Aug. 21.--The force of police retailed during the administration of Mr. Gladstone in 1882 to protect the various members of the Ministry has been withdrawn for the first time since its assignment to duty.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 21.--When Gen. Harrison left for Middle Bass Island early this morning it was raining heavily. Accompanied by Mrs. Harrison, Judge and Mrs. W.A. Woods, and Sam Miller, son of Gen. Harrison's law partner, the General was taken to the Massachusetts-avenue station in a carriage at 7 o'clock.

Bolossy Kiralfy is grieved at some of his brother's utterances as reported in the papers. He was very anxious, however, lest the newspaper men who heard what he said yesterday should represent him as making an attack on his brother.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21.--"E.W. Brown of New-York" was written on the Palmer House register last Wednesday by a handsomelydressed middle-aged man. He staid one day at the hotel, and then paying his bill he hired an expressman to take his trunk to 386 Wabashavenue.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--Saratoga was thrown into excitement to-night over a rumor that the Grand Union Hotel was in a blaze. "Professor" Baldwin it great, but one who is greater than he has, a few days ago, descended from the clouds in a little North German village. He came with the light or noon as a background to his awful figure, slowly sailing through the eastern skies, making his way straight for the village in question.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21.--Michael Merigan, wall paper dealer at 1,223 Market-street, has failed for about $15,000, making a general assignment to John H. Scott, conveyancer. The causes of his misfortune are numerous--bad accounts and general depression of the wall paper trade. The assignment is for the benefit of all his creditors.

Beekman has transmitted to the Department of Public Parks an opinion in which he holds that the city has full control over Stuyvesant-square, to keep it open or closed after sundown. CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 21.--The recognition exercises of the Chautauqua Town and County occurred at 10 o'clock this forenoon. The leading address was given by Charles Barnard.
An Orange (Mass.) man has set out to make a record for himself in a rather unusual way. His purpose is to see how quickly he can wheel a plow from that town to Caribon, Me., a distance of 500 miles.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 21.--The Republican State Executive Committee met to-day with a large attendance of members from all parts of the state. The Hon. John R.T. Lynch presided, and in his speech gave a brief history of his observations in the North, which led him ...

Fully 900 of the 1,100 members of the Society of American Florists assembled from all parts of the United States and Canada at Cooper Union yesterday morning and opened the fourth annual meeting of their organization.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 21.--Lawyer M. C. McGuinness of this city has began legal proceedings against Mr. Donovan of South Norwalk for being thrashed. Mr. McGuinness, who was clerk of the Board of Selectmen last year, has lately been making a tour of the State for the purpose of organizing Irish-American Republican clubs.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Aug. 21.--Capt. Nat Kenny, the Bald Knobber chief, was killed in a duel last night. Bill Miles, a desperate enemy of the Bald Knobbers, did the killing. The feud originally arose in the troublesome times when Kenny was chief of the outlaw band and reigned ...

While Col. Brice, ex-Congressman Ben Le Fevre, and the other officials at the Democratic headquarters were in high spirits yesterday, at the Republican headquarters there was a depression which was not altogether caused by the rain.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Aug. 21.--Joseph B. Cheadle was renominatad for Congress for the Ninth District to-day.

Lucy Holmes, dealer in dry goods at the corner of Third-avenue and Twentieth-street, made an assignment yesterday to George Harjes, giving two preferences for $1,429. She has been in business several years in this city and at Yonkers and carried a stock of about $5,000. Her husband, William B. Holmes, who was for many years in business on Eighth-avenue, died in 1886.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 21.--The interState Farmers' Association convened here today and was called to order by Col. L.L. Polk of Raleigh, President, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Florida, Tennessee, Georgia, and Texas were represented. The convention was welcomed by the Hon. A.A. Thompson, Mayor, on behalf of the city of Raleigh.

A story came from Philadelphia yesterday to the effect that the Reading Railroad Company was about to obtain control of the New-Jersey Central again. It was stated that President Corbin of the Reading held a majority of the New-Jersey Central stock, which he would turn over to his company.

NORTHERN PACIFIC JUNCTION, Minn., Aug. 21.--There is a hitherto unpublished chapter in the history of the murderer Maxwell, which throws much light on his gentility, of which so much has been said. The scene is in this county of rocks and pines, and the time in the Summer of 1883.

About 300 of the male supernumeraries employed in "Nero" were discharged Monday night for bad conduct. Gustav Kahn, Imre Kiralfy's business manager, said last night that he would not tolerate any conduct on the part of the employes that was not strictly proper.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 21.--The customs authorities have seized three Chinamen who same from Vancouver by authority from Victoria. It was telegraphed here that they were contraband, having entered the country withous paying duty. Fellow-countrymen guaranteed their appearance when called for, and they were paroled.

"Did you get caught in the rain?" was the question that every dripping, rainsoaked citizen put to every other drenched and disconsolate individual whom he chanced to meet under some temporary or more comfortable shelter last night. It was almost as exasperating as that other inquiry: "Is it hot enough for you?" for everybody who was out had got caught in the hardest rain of the season.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 21.--"When the first dispatches from Pine Ridge Agency were received at headquarters," said Gen. Thomas H. Ruger, commanding the Department of Dakota, "they merely stated that a band of 25 Indians had left the reservation to go to Tongue River.

An announcement made by the crier on Wednesday evening that a man named William Samuels, a local innkeeper and the champion boxer of Wales, would enter alone a den of lions at Messrs. Wombwell's menagerie, now at Swansea, caused considerable excitement in the town and drew a great crowd to the show.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--The weather was cloudy and cool to-day. There was nothing in the Misses' Stakes except Gypsy Queen and the Lioness, and the pair had an easy time in disposing of the others. Gov. Bowie's winning streak was continued by Vosburg's victory over an exceptionally good field.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 21.--George Davis, Cashier of the West Side Bank of New-York, was thrown from his carriage by his runaway horse last evening and sustained fatal injuries. His sister, who was with him, was slightly injured. Mr. Davis's skull was fractured at the base behind the left ear.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 21.--The "combine" known as the United Jellico Coal and Iron Company, which was organized to-day at the meeting of some of the leading mine owners of Eastern Kentucky, Virginia, and Tennessee, will be one of the largest organizations of its kind in the country.
OTTAWA, Aug. 21.--The rejection of the fisheries treaty by the United States Senate has created regret and little surprise here.
ROME, Aug. 21.--The Tribuna says the Government has decided to send a new expedition against Abyssinia.

OYSTER BAY, Long Island, Aug. 21.--The body of Miss Ida Montfort of Glen Cove, who was drowned while bathing near Bayville, Saturday, was found floating in the harbor this morning. Coroner Hall held an inquest, and a verdict of accidental drowning was rendered.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 21.--The bark Cassandra Adams was wrecked last Thursday evening on a reef near Destruction Island. The trunk lines are in a deal of trouble and the immigrant rate war has developed into an unfortunate state of affairs. Passenger Commissioner Fierson comes in for his full share of the unplesant situation.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 21.--Doris La Breque, a barber, declares that he heard a woman scream "Murder!" several times at about 4 o'clock Friday morning near Wesley Lake.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21.--For several weeks two veiled statues have occupied places amond the marble and bronze figures of distinguished Americans which stand in the old hall of the House of Representatives and which were presented for that purpose by various States.

AMERICAN CANOE ASSOCIATION CAMP, LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 21.--The morning opened bright and pleasant, with a stiff breeze from the south, but by 9 o'clock, the hour given for the sailing races to commence, it had about died out, and the paddling races were substituted.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 21.--The steamer Camelia, bringing mails and passengers of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad from Pearl River Bridge, arrived at her wharf at Milneberg after midnight, the passengers reaching his city at 1 A.M. RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 21.--The most destructive fire that over occurred in South Rondout was that of this morning. At one time it looked as if the entire village would be swept away by the flames, but the efforts of the firemen and citizens saved it.

HAVANA, Aug. 21.--A man who had forged a check for $19,000 on the Spanish Bank was arrested to-day.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 21.--The annual session of the National Grand Lodge of Sons of St. George was opened in this city this morning. Worthy Grand President Thomas Brown of Germantown, Penn., presided.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 21.--The visiting German singing societies, who have been here attending the three days' Saengerfest of the Rondout Social Maennerchor, paraded the principal streets to-day. A downpour of rain all day prevented a picnic being held. To-morrow all the societies will make a trip to the Catskill Mountains.

"Recent Developments in Great Circle Sailing" is the name of a work which was been prepared in the United States Hydrographic Office, and has for its object the collection into one volume of all the analytical processes and the description of all charts and devices which have been constructed for the navigation of the great circle track.
Josephs Fuchs, a French cook of 11 Broadway, remonstrated with John Glaney, a gateman at the Hanover-square "L" station, on Monday night for his rough usage of a helpless drunken man.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 21.--Five thousand persons saw the second game of the BrooklynSt. Louis series to-day. As on yesterday, the St. Louis retired their visitors without a single run. Foutz, the old St. Louis pitcher, twirled for Brooklyn and was hit very hard.

Conductor Palmer put a man off a train at Rockaway last evening because he would not pay his fare, and, as the train passed out of the station, the stranger drew a revolver and fired two shots at Palmer. The bullets hit the woodwork near the conductor's head. The police later arrested a man named Wilson as the person who had discharged the weapon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21.--Rain poured in torrents to-night, but it failed to prevent the complete success of the grand ball given at the Edgar cottage by R.L. Hargous in honor of his sister, who was thus "introduced." It was by all odds the most elaborate and most costly affair given here for many years.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 21.--Mack Brown of Fulton, Ky., was shot and killed in the rotunda of the Peabody Hotel to-night by Lewis Lane, a young man employed as stenographer in a law office in this city.

The other day a leading Sydney solicitor recived instructions from London to hunt up a young man who had quitted England 10 years previously, and a draft for 300 was inclosed to pay his passage home. After a course of advertising a member of a charitable society called in and directed the solicitor to a certain hovel in Lower Alexandria, Sydney.
The bulls took their turn yesterday at the rumoring business. And they did well. All manner of good things were proclaimed in the promises that were sent flying through Wallstreet.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 21.--Frank Spencer of East Woodstock, Conn., a farmer, was found dead in a field in Dudley yesterday, with a bullet hole is his head and his pockets turned inside out. Spencer and Michael White drove to Dudley, Oxford, and Webster together on Sunday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 21.--Yesterday afternoon a constable filed papers in the Town Clerk's office attaching the property of Dr. W. G. Alling. The papers set forth that Dr. Alling is worth $60,000, and prays for $20,000 alimony for his wife, who makes charges of infidelity against him.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 21.--A serious wreck is reported at Oakdale, on the Cincinnati Southern Railway, 90 miles from Chattanooga. A large oak tree had fallen or been blown from the mountain side by last night's storm, which was struck by the engine while running 40 miles an hour.

The farmers living around High Shoals factory have seen the officers of the factory, and they have agreed to take their cotton packed with three pine boards on a side at the same price as is it was packed in bagging.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21.--The opening day of the Northwestern Breeders' Association trotting meeting was a cold one for the management and a very chilly one for those who attended. The racing, barring the many false starts, was all that could be asked for by any lover of the trotting horse. The track was very fast and very dusty.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 21.--The Grand Lodge of Independent Order of Odd Fellows of this State met to-day in annual session in the Leland Opera House. Grand Master Fred W. Cole of Albany presided.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 21.--For several days past there have been rumors of a Lumber Trust, the whole matter growing out of a meeting of several prominent lumbermen in Chicago last week. These rumors have been positively denied.

Catboats had a plucky fight yesterday afternoon for the Mill Rock Cottage Champion Cup. The start was made off Varlan O'Brien's cottage, at the foot of Ninety-second-street, with a strong east wind blowing and the rain falling in heavy scuds.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 21.--Peter McArdle, a white employe of the Georgia Chemical Works in this city, met a peculiar and distressing death today.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 21.--A shipment of 150 pounds of metallic, chemically pure aluminum, the first export of this metal from the United States, was made this week from Newport, Ky., to London, England. The precious metal, which sold at 50 cents per pound, was smelted from Kentucky ore and clay by a process which is as yet tedious and is kept a secret.

LONDON, Aug. 21.--The race for the Wynard Plate, for 2-year-olds, at the Stockton meeting to-day was won by Workington, with Queen Berengarie second and Help third. There were seven starters. The betting was 9 to 4 against Workington.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 21.--While Charles Taylor was digging near his homestead in Bansalem Township, Bucks County, yesterday, his spade struck what seemed to be a heavy plank. After much difficulty he hauled out an old and heavy oak chest partly decayed.

President James C. Bayles of the Health Department has answered the letter of Mayor Hewitt calling the department's attention to the necessity of taking precautions against yellow fever. Mr. Bayles says that Medical Commissioner Dr. J.D. Bryant believes that yellow fever is not contagious in this climate, and that there is nothing at present to warrant the fear that New-York will suffer this year from an epidemic of yellow fever.

LACONIA, N.H., Aug. 21.--About 70 persons left here to-night for the Shrine of Sainte Anne de Beaupre, Canada, to be cured of different diseases, upon recommandation of a young lady here who was formerly a cripple, and who returned home a few months ago entirely cured.
PARIS, Aug. 21.--Gen. Boulanger says that he will not contest any more by-elections unless a vacancy occurs in Paris, where he is confident he could obtain a quarter of a million votes.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 22.--The announcement is made here to-day that financial arrangements have been completed to build the Hudson's Bay Railway and equip and operate it. Mr. Onderdonk of New-York, who, with other American capitalists, composes a syndicate which has undertaken the work, will be here in a few days, being now on the way.

SHOKAN, N.Y., Aug. 22.--The Republican electors of the Third Assembly District met here this afternoon and elected delegates to represent the district at the State Convention to be held at Saratoga, as follows: Dr. Abram Deyo, George Deyo, Grant Hornbeck, and A.J. Simpson.
MONTREAL, Aug. 22.--Billy Moloney and his son and daughter sailed in the Vancouver for Europe yesterday afternoon. They go for a three months' tour.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22.--Major Ezra B. Kirk, Quartermaster, has been ordered to temporary duty at Atlanta, Ga., in connection with the National Cemetery. BOSTON, Aug. 22.--An interesting discovery of aboriginal remains was made at Winthrop to-day. Some little time ago a few bones were unearthed there, and Prof. Putnam of the Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, Cambridge, who examined them, said they must have been buried over 200 years ago as there are no records of Indian burials at Winthrop since.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 22.--A landslide occurred on the West Shore a short distance south of this station last night covering the north and south bound tracks for a distance of 100 feet with sand, gravel, and rocks to the depth of from 6 to 7 feet. Miss Alice F. Smiley, aged 30, was arrested yesterday at the Grand Hotel on Mrs. Elizabeth M. Barbour's camplaint that she stole from $17,000 to $20,000 worth of jewelry and other articles from her. BOSTON, Aug. 22.--The Democratic ratification meeting will be held on Sept. 3. The Republican press has had a great deal to say about the apathy of Massachusetts Democrats, but without cause.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 23.--This morning occurred the formal closing of the Normal Deparment and a public meeting of the Chautauqua School of Photography.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 23.--The area of Corn in Sangamon and the adjoining counties is nearly as large as in 1887. The prospects have not been as favorable for a large average yield per acre at the corresponding time for several years past.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 23.--All over the State of Nebraska the corn crop promises a large yield. In the whole southern and southeastern sections the same condition is observed, the South Platte country probably leading all other sections.

When Herr Anton Seidl began his series of concerts at Brighton Beach it was gently hinted in these columns that the financial success of serious musical performances at the beaches in the Summer season was extremely problematical.

At the National Democratic Headquarters yesterday a jubilation was held all day over Judge Thurman's great speech, and the Campaign Committee decided that it should be printed as soon as possible and a million copies be distributed.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 23.--President Vau Horn of the Canadian Pacific Road, General Manager Underwood of the Soo Road, and representatives of the Duluth and South Shore Company are holding a conference at Sault Ste. Marie.
NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 23.--J.B. Sargent of this city was questioned to-day with regard to a charge made in a New-York paper this morning to the effect that he has imported contract Italian labor.

The annual reunion and festival of District No. 1 of the Independent Order B'nai B'rith took place yesterday at the Empire City Colosseum.

Leo Schmidt of the Brunswick, Balke Collender Company, while out riding last Monday behind a fractions horse, was tossed from the buggy, breaking his collar bone and three ribs. At last advices his condition was encouraging.

PIERRE, Dakota, Aug. 23.--The Indian Commissioners arrived at Pierre this morning on the steamer Rosebud on their way to Crow Creek Agency.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23.--This was a field day for trotting in the West. The third day of the Northwestern Breeders' Association meeting was attended by 7,000 people.

The weather was delightful at Yonkers yesterday, and a large attendance witnessed the racing. The favorites were in good form, as they made a clean sweep, capturing the five events handily. The track was in good condition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23.--President Cleveland has invited the attention of Congress and the country to the Canadian question with a courage and vigor characteristic of the man and in such plain language that no American citizen who reads his message to Congress can fail to understand his meaning.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 23.--For the past few weeks railroads in the Northwest have been carrying freight at rates that heretofore were not dreamed of, and a constant struggle has been going on to adjust the tariffs on a paying basis.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Aug. 23.--The counties of Leavenworth, Wyandotte, Atchison, Jefferson, Jackson, Brown, and Pottawatomie, which compose the first and second tier of counties from the Missouri River north of the Kansas River, are assured of a better crop of corn this season than they have had in the past six years.

The President's message to Congress on the subject of retaliation against Canada is a striking illustration of his happy faculty of doing the right thing at the right time and in the right way.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 23.--Mr. Kendrick, chief engineer of the Northern Pacific Road, and Mr. McNaught, solicitor, are in the city on railway business. In interviews they appeared to be disgusted with the turn affairs seem to have taken here.

Wall-street had one story that it chuckled over in high glee yesterday. It represented that Deacon S.V. White had been caught short of Lackawanna, the stock of which he has ever been the recognized chosen apostle.
The wheat market has been furnishing the members of the New-York Produce Exchange with sufficient excitement this week.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 23.--The schooner Nannie Waterman, Capt. Barrio, which arrives here to-day, reports that about daylight yesterday morning she picked up a boat containing Capt. Frisbee and nine men of the schooner Active, and a short time after sighted the Active.

PROVIDENCE, R.I, Aug. 23.--The "Reform Club of Rhode Island," in the interests of tariff reform, was organized this afternoon at a meeting of some 20 prominent gentlemen representing both the leading political parties and prominent commercial and manufacturing concerns.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 23.--Six hundred men and boys employed at the Woodward Shaft of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company at Kingston, who went out on strike for higher wages three months ago, returned to work to-day, the company having acceded to their terms. There is in consequence great rejoicing among the miners or the Wyoming Valley.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 23.--In the Western Catskills a cold wave prevailed last night. At daylight this morning a slight frost could be seen on the roofs of buildings. Overcoats and grate fires were in demand. The oldest inhabitant never remembers having seen frost before in August. The advent of the cold wave was a novel experience for Summer boarders.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23.--August J. Moeller, a merchant tailor doing business at 716 Milwaukee-avenue, failed this morning, and a confession of judgment was filed in the Superior Court for $1,644.50 in favor of Ignatz Deimel. The assets and liabilities are both small.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 23.--There is considerable complaint of a lack of warm growing weather all over Minnesota. Corn in this territory got a late start, but the warm weather, so damaging to wheat, helped it out considerably.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 23.--Fears are entertained that the corn crop in the corn belt of Wisconsin will be what is known as a "soft crop." The increase in acreage is about 5 per cent. compared with last year, and the crop is about two or three weeks behind.

The United States Secret Service detectives between Wednesday evening and yesterday afternoon captured the principal members of the gang of counterfeiters who have been recently flooding the city with spurious five-dollar and one-dollar notes.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 23.--On Sept. 5 a boat race will take place at Hammondsport, on Lake Keuka. Teemer, Hamm, and Ten Eyck have already entered and will surely row. Other prominent oarsmen will also take part. It is the intention of the Watkins Regatta Association to make this the successful initiatory race of their annual regatta to be held at that place.

LONDON, Aug. 23.--The name of Gilbert and Sullivan's new opera, about which so much speculation has been indulged, is no longer a secret to such as have the inside track in matters theatrical and operatic, though it is still jealously guarded from the general public.

The big iron four-masted ship Falls of Hallidale, which has been expected for about a month to arrive from Calcutta, came up to Quarantine late Wednesday night and reports a very severe passage. She had been 168 days on her voyage.

The stakes for the Fall meeting of the Amarican Jockey Club, which closed on the 15th inst, show an excellent entry list, because the club has sensibly abandoned its idea of enforcing an almost obsolete and decidedly unpopular method of speculation upon the public and horse owners. The adjourned hearing in the case of the Long Island Railroad against Mayor Gleason of Long Island City for willfully destroying the property of the complainant on July 19 went on before Justice Delehanty in the City Court yesterday morning.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 23.--While George J. Kaisted, a painter, was adjusting a block and tackle on the roof of a house preparatory to swinging a ladder, clinging to a chimney for suppore, the chimney gave was, precipitating the man to the ground, a distance of over 40 feet. He escaped with a concussion of the spine and a few scratches.

The funeral of John M. Levey, a wellknown member of the Masonic fraternity, occurred at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning from the Masonic Temple in Twenty-third-street. The ceremony was under the direction of Star of Cuba Lodge, No. 742, of which the deceased was Treasurer at the time of his death. The burial was in Woodlawn Cemetery.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 23.--Interest in the great camp meeting is growing. This morning's sermon was preached by the Rev. W.K. Wardell of Brooklyn, Presiding Elder of the New-York East..

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 23.--The Boyer Brothers of Brooklyn, who own the steam yacht Dandy, having placed her in thorough repair since her race with the Pampero last week, to-day invited the Rogatta Committee to go over the course on a trial of speed. When about half of the distance had been completed she again blew up, but, so far as learned, no one was injured.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23.--The New-York members of the Board of Directors of the Keely Motor Company are placed in a curious predicament by the method adopted by Keely to fight their suit to compel him to turn over to them any inventions of his which may have a commercial value.

A registered mail pouch purporting to contain 50 pieces of registered mail matter was received at the registry department of the Post Office in this city at midnight last Friday from Portland, Oregon.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 23.--A collision occurred this morning on the New-York and Long Branch Railroad just south of this place.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 23.--This was the fourth day of the National Croquet Association's meet. Ten more games are to be played in the first division. Maurer of Keyport, N.J., leads with 5 won and 1 lost and 2 to play.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 23.--Indiana never had so fine a corn crop prospect as at the present time. The acreage is larger than ever, the growth is well advanced, the stand firm, the stock heavier and more prolific than usual, and the weather is very promising.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 23.--An accident occurred near Corning in a tunnel on the Toledo and Ohio Central Railroad last night that is likely to cost that corporation a round sum of money, as it was the result of carelessness on the part of an engineer, who should have taken the siding until after the passenger train bound north had passed.

PORT HURON, Mich., Aug. 23.--It was the intention of those with Judge Thurman to give him a quiet day to-day, and this he has had, although there have been some interesting and affecting incidents during the day.

WASHINGTON, AUG. 23.--The House Committee on Printing, which was charged with an investigation of the past and present adminis tration of the Government Printing Office, today made its report to the House through Chairman Richardson.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 23.--A St. Martinsville special to the Picayune says: Tuesday afternoon an encounter between the negroes and whites occurred at a negro house on Bayou Martin, nine miles above St. Martinsville.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23.--Although the bulge in wheat to-day was due mainly to bullish cable dispatches, it was helped out a little by private reports from the Northwest received by members of the Board of Trade, going to show that there has been considerable damage by frost to wheat in that section.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 23.--It is ascertained from the Secretary of State's office, where a monthly collection of crop statistics is gathered, compared, and tabulated, that the condition of the corn crop in this State is fair.

Thomas McCormick of East New-York was arrested Tuesday for assaulting his wife, but when arraigned yesterday it was found that McCormick had obtained a warrant for his wife's arrest on the charge of bigamy. McCormick said that when he married the woman on Aug. 7 she was the legal wife of Louis Buchmann, whom she married in 1885. Mrs. Buchmann fainted when she was arrested in court, and upon recovering was held for trial.

ALBANY, Aug. 23.--This breach in the ranks of the Republicans in this county continues to widen and disaffection with the course of the would-be leaders of both factions increases daily.
BOSTON, Aug. 23.--The first step was taken to-day in the case of Robert W. Hulburt, the alien master of an American vessel, details of which were given in THE TIMES on Wednesday.

BERLIN, Aug. 23.--Signor Crispi left Friedrichsruh at 8:30 o'clock this morning. Prince Bismarck accompanied him to the station and bade him a cordial farewell at the door of his railroad carriage.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 23.--About 1,200 people witnessed the game to-day, which the Pittsburgs won by heavy hitting in two innings. Colemao in particular distinguished himself by making three two-baggers.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 23.--The Wisconsin Central and the Burlington Roads have agreed to restore passenger rates on their Northwestern lines to tariff figures. The restored rates will go into effect Sept. 2.
Capt. Augustus P. Cooke, United States Navy, is at the Gilsey House.

After years of low prices for wheat, Chicago is greatly exciting itself with the expectation of again quoting it at a dollar a bushel. Dollar wheat at Chicago used to be proverbial. It meant something that was sure sooner or later to show a profit on the purchase. But times changed.

With the exception of Eurus and Wheeler T. all the favorites won at Monmouth Park yesterday, and a great crowd saw them do it, though the card was not a particularly good one, or one to draw crowds to a race track.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23.--The Cedar Hill cotton and woolen mill at Darby, Delaware County, was destroyed by fire this afternoon.

NEENAH, Wis., Aug. 23.--At 12 o'clock last night the large paper mill owned by George Whiting, situated on the island between this city and Menasha, was destroyed by fire. While the burning structure was surrounded by a crowd of spectators the battery of boilers exploded.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 23.--The American Canoe Association Camp at Lake George last night was very cold, the mercury dropping to 46 , and blankets, evercoats, and wraps of every description were in great demand.
SARATOGA, Aug. 23.--Tamer sport than was witnessed here to-day it would be hard to imagine. The track was heavy, the field ridiculously small, and the majority of the races virtually walk-overs.
BERLIN, Aug. 23.--Emperor William today went to Sonnenburg and held a chapter of the Order of St. John. The insignia as protecter of the order was handed to the Emperor with great ceremony.

To the Congress: The rejection by the Senate of the treaty lately negotiated for the settlement and adjustment of the differences existing between the United States and Great Britain concerning the rights and privileges of American fishermen in the ports and waters of British North America seems to justify a survey of the condition to which the pending question is thus remitted.

Mr. P.S. Gilmore gave three concerts at Manhattan Beach yesterday, the first at 3:30 P.M., the second at 7:15, and the third at 9 P. M. Special attractions were introduced at these entertainments, which were of the nature indicated by Mr. Gilmore's application of the word "jubilee."

PARIS, Aug. 23.--Three hundred Royalists, includiug the Marquis de Beauvoir, were present at a banquet given to-night in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of the birth of the Comte de Paris. Speeches appropriate to the occasion were made, and a congratulatory address was enthusiastically voted.
The Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee met at their headquarters on West Twenty-fifth-street last evening and discussed the situation.

CHEROKEE, Iowa, Aug. 23.--In this vicinity there is yet some doubt as to the corn crop. The only danger now is frost. If the frost holds off the crop will be immense. Some few late pieces will hardly escape unless the frost comes unusually late. The weather has been unusually cold, and much rain has fallen for several...

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 23.--Last night, by a vote of 41 to 40, the battalion Washington Artillery decided to leave the State's service. They will at once forward their application through the proper channels to be mustered out.

The situation in regard to immigrant rates becomes daily more complicated. A Guion, Line steamship with 400 passengers for the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Road is expected to arrive to-day, and this will be, it is probable, the total of the day's business.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 23.--By previous arrangements the annual fair of the Dutchess County Agricultural Society, an institution half a contury old, is to be held this Fall at the Hudson River Driving Park.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 23.--The Republicans of the Sixth Congressional District today nominated the Hon. Louis E. McComas for a fourth term. His opponent is Col. Kyd Douglass, who was Stonewall Jackson's Chief of Staff. Mr. McComas's re-election is practically admitted.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 23.--The Republicans have probably lost a Congressman by the nomination by their party of John A. Caldwell, in the Second Cincinnati District to-day.

Governeur Morris, the second of that name, was buried yesterday morning at 11 o'clook in the old family vault in the churchyard of St. Ann's, on St. Ann's-avenue, near One Hundred and Thirty-eighth-street.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 23.--The situation here is but little changed except that there were more cases of fever reported this morning than on any previous day, while there are several more suspicious cases that have not yet been reported.

JAMAICA, Long Island, Aug. 24.--The west-bound Port Jefferson freight train on the Long Island Railroad was partially wrecked last night between Hollis and Queens. The coupling between two cars broke, and a collision occurred between the two parts of the train. Several cars were derailed, two being thrown over into a ditch and badly damaged. No one was hurt.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 24.--The fact that the Board of Directors of the First Ward public school in this city had leased four unoccupied rooms to Rev. Father Sheedy to be used as a Catholic parochial school has caused considerable comment in religious and educational circles.

Wheat furnished another exciting day on the Produce Exchange yesterday. The dealings in options approached nearly 35,000,000 bushels, figures which are very rarely reached.
NASSAU, New-Providence, Aug. 20.--A quarantine has been established here against all vessels from Florida ports.
Mr. Wright Sanford left Saratoga last Tuesday for Fabyans in the White Mountains. He had greatly improved in health while at the springs and considered himself almost well.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--There is trouble over live stock rates between Southwestern Missouri River points and Chicago that bids fair to culminate in a rate war of extensive proportions unless speedly checked.

The programme for to-day at Monmouth Park is not a strong one in the number of entries to the different events, and one of the stakes, the Homebred Produce, shows a very weak list of probable starters, with not much of a contest in promise.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Aug. 23.--The Territorial Democratic Convention at Boise City, Idaho, yesterday nominated James G. Hawley for Delegate to Congress, and adopted the entire platform of the National Democratic Convention. They said nothing on the silver and lead tariff or Mermonism.

Max Rosenberg, who has been under arrest on a charge of attempting to blackmail Miss Nettie Guion, the actress, was discharged yesterday by Justice Patterson, in Special Sessions, Miss Guion, through sympathy for Rosenberg's wife, refusing to press her complaint.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--Capt. George S. Anderson, Sixth Cavalry, has been designated by the Secretary of War, under an invitation extended by the Government of France, to witness the manoeuvres of the Third Corps of the French Army, to take place this year. He will proceed to Paris and report to the United States Minister for instructions.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 24.--Jacob Moxter, a prominent piano dealer of this city, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself through the head. Mr. Moxter had been in business here for 20 years, and last Fall decided to increase his stock.

MENASHA, Wis., Aug. 24.--Business is suspended in Menasha to-day, and the city is in a deep gloom. All of the factories and mills on the water power are shut down, and will remain so until after the funeral of the victims of yesterday's accident at Neenah.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 24.--Edward Everett Hale discussed modern Sunday school methods to a large audience this forenoon. He sketched the work of the "Look-Up Legion" and gave an admirable summary of his famous book, "Ten Times One."
August coffee created some excitement yesterday by dropping 45 points. It opened at 11.65 and closed at 11.20.

OYSTER BAY, Long Island, Aug. 24.-- The packet Holdane, Capt. Studwell, which trades between this port and New-York, was sunk in the harbor this morning by collision with a canalboat. Nearly all the frieght was saved. The vessel will be raised.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24.--Not until the last inning did the Giants play good ball here today. At that stage, with the score 5 to 1 against them, they made one of their characteristic spurts, sent five men around the bases and, to the disappointment and astonishment of the onlookers, won the game. It was a victory at the home stretch, and, while the spectators did not enjoy it altogether, yet they were forced to applaud.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--As the regular train pulled through the suburbs of Battle Creek it was evident that a big crowd was on hand, and the arrival at the station made it certain that the people were trying to outdo all that had gone before.

The recent discovery in the harbor of St. John's, Newfoundland, during dredging oparations, which were being carried on for the purpose of building a Government dock, of the hull of an old American privateer sunk in 1781 is an interesting incident.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 24.--John Fierst and his young son, were drowned in Lake Chautauqua yesterday. Whether they came to their death by accident, or Fierst deliberately overturned the boat for the purpose of ending his life will probably never be positively known.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 24.--Tug Joseph Stickney, at Somerset with barges, reports that the barge American Eagle of New-London, one of two or three barges bound from South Amboy for Somerset, foundered and sank off Sandy Hook on Wednesday night in 24 feet of water. Captain and crew were saved, but lost personal effects.

SARATOGA, Aug. 24.--The local Republican committee is making preparations for the State Convention to be held in the Casino on Tuesday next. It is expected that the attendance will be very large, but it is quite likely that there will be plenty of room in the hotels for all ...

WHEELING, West Va., Aug. 24.--An Ohio River Railroad gravel train jumped the track and plunged down a 30 foot embankment, about seven miles south of this city, at 3 P.M. today. The train was crowded with men, but most of them escaped serious injury, except Charles Stilwell, Charles McCormick, and Quincy Moore who were seriousy wounded, the latter being in a dying condition to-night.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 24.--On Tuesday night, during the fierce wind and rain storm, the boat E. Emerick, in tow of the steamboats Austin and Oswego of the Cornell Line of Rondout, sunk in 48 feet of water in the Hudson River, near Manhattanville.
The order of arrest against Field W. Sweezey, who is being sued by Annie L. Murphy for $25,000 for breach of promise of marriage, was yesterday vacated by Judge Patterson, in Supreme Court, Chambers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--Frederick Oberkampf, the mail robber, was given a chance today to offer testimony on his own behalf before United States Commissioner Hoyne, but he introduced no evidence, and was bound over for trial in $5,000 bonds.
The sales agents of the various coal companies held a meeting yesterday at the Washington Building, and unanimously decided to put the price up.

BOSTON, Aug. 24.--The President's message was the one topic of conversation in business and political circles to-day, and one would be puzzled to say whether the predominant sentiment was one of exultation or chagrin.
The denizens of Harlem Flats are soon to enjoy the luxury of a refuge from rain, sleet, or snow at the Harlem Railroad's landing place, One Hundred and Tenth-street.

BREMOND, Texas, Aug. 24.--The boiler at James W. White's cotton mill and gin exploded this morning, killing W.L. Wootan, fatally wounding his two sons, John and Silas, and seriously injuring Ignatius Strumksi, Deny chambliss ,Mat Busby and Buck Walton, the last two colored. The mill was totally demolished.

FRANKLIN FALLS, N.H., Aug. 24.--One of New-Hampshire's most prominent and wealthiest citizens and a successful business man is the Hon. Walter Aiken, a resident of this "unchartered city at the head of the Merrimac."

Miss Maggie Mitchell's rather sudden determination to build a theatre on the site of her old homestead at One Hundred and Twentyfourth-street and Seventh-avenue is an unpleasant surprise to certain gentlemen who contemplated doing the very same thing.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 24.--The express train on the West Shore Railroad that leaves the stations in New-York and Jersey City at 8:40 and 8:50 respectively, due at Kingston at 11:40 in the forenoon, fortunately escaped being seriously wrecked in the town of Esopus, 10 miles south of here, to-day.

SARATOGA, Aug. 24.--The racing to-day was far superior to that of yesterday, although the programme was an extra one, and contained no special feature. The weather was enjoyable, and the track though still slow, much improved. It was another day for outsiders, and favorites failed badly. Details follow:

Any one could tell a Democrat from a Republican yesterday by the facial expression, the Democrats were so joyful, the Republicans so mournful. Wherever Democrats are wont to congregate there were crowds of jubilant people. The Republican resorts were "like banquet halls deserted."

Among the passengers whom the steamship Trave brought from Bremen to New-York yesterday were the eminent German Professor F.E. August von Esmarch and his wife, the Princess Henrietta of Schleswig-Holstein, a cousin of the present Empress of Germany.

The argument to have Brayton Ives's injunction against Elijah Smith and other Directors of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company made permanent was continued yesterday before Judge Patterson in Supreme Court, Chambers.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 24.--Black measles of a most virulent type has broken out among the negroes on the rice plantations on Santee River. Fifty deaths have already occurred and the disease has become epidemic. It has created a panic and will doubtless cause great loss in the harvest, which will begin by Sept. 1.

Hi Chee, the only Chinese tramp in this city, died suddenly yesterday, it is believed, of heart disease. He came to this country about 13 years ago and established a laundry and made plenty of money. In a short time he had over $2,000, and then sent letter to his friends in China advising them to come here. His friends came and found that Hi Chee had not told even half the truth.

GOUVERNEUR, N.Y., Aug. 24.--The Congressional Convention for the St. Lawrence-Jefferson district met here this afternoon. A.X. Parker, A.B. Hepburne, and F. Lansing were presented as candidates for the Congressional nomination.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--Notwithstanding the beauty of the weather to-day only 1,500 attended the trotting meeting of the Northwestern Breeders' Association. The track was, if any, faster than on any previous day and the time made was good in most cases.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 24.--The new freight tariff to all Pacific coast points was issued today, and will go into effect Sept. 1. The rates have been advanced slightly. In some cases the advance is on the commodity and others on the rate.

CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 24.--The Rev. J. R. Dangerfield, Pastor of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church of Harrisburg, and a very prominent colored minister of this part of the State, to-day announced that he would stump the State and vote for Cleveland and Thurman.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 24.--The Ohio Grain and Seed Company of Cincinnati has an agent operating what is believed to be a swindling game in the southern tier counties of this State.

The Autumn meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association began at Cedarhurst yesterday, under most favorable auspices. The attendance, though not large, was good, and was made up of the elite of the racing fraternity and of steeplechase enthusiasts.

The rooms of the Reform Club, at 12 East Thirty-third-street, were crowdod last evening on the occasion of the eighth meeting for the discussion of tariff reform. Edgar A. Tyrrel presided, and ex-Gov. Daniel H. Chamberlain delivered the address of the evening on the "Political Aspects of the Tariff, with some Special Reference to Wages." His arguments were carefully weighed by his hearers and enthusiastically applauded.

An exceedingly handsome Cleveland and Thurman banner was raised last night outside Odd Fellows' Hall, at Fifth and Washington streets, Hoboken. This was accomplished by the aid of a brass band, an unlimited amount of fireworks, and the attendance of thousands of people, who for a time effectually blockaded all traffic on Hoboken's principal thoroughfare.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 24.--Everybody is talking about President Cleveland's retaliation message. Democrats universally commend his position; Republicans echo Senator Edmunds's sneer. Business men, however, believe that the effect of retaliation measures will be felt with much greater effect in Canada than in the United States.

CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 24.--Mr. John Wilhelm, a prominent and influential farmer of Franklin County, who came out in a card for Cleveland and Thurman a few days ago, and who was unanimously nominated by the Democratic Convention for the Legislature, has declined.

LONDON, Aug. 24.--The Standard was the only morning paper in London to-day which had a syllable about President Cleveland's message. Even Reuter's Agency did not have a line, and the Standard's special came so late that, the paper had no comment upon it till this evening.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 24.--The Republicans of the First Otsego District, at their convention held here this afternoon, selected the following as delegates to the approaching State Convention: John J. Rider of Exeter, Robert S. Wescott of Richfield Springs, John K. Tyler of Worcester, and R.W. McKinley of Roseboom. They are uninstructed, but favor Warner Miller for Governor.
CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 24, via Galveston.--A rumor is current here that Mr. Thomas B. Connery, Secretary of the United States Legation, is about to resign his office.

LONDON, Aug. 24.--The Dublin Freeman's Journal says that the treatment to which Mr. Dillon is subjected in Dundalk Jail is seriously impairing his health, and that he has already lost seven pounds in weight.

Col. Dudley, Treasurer of the National Republican Committee, returned from Philadelphia yesterday. He ordered that all the reporters of Republican papers be sent to him, and he solemnly assured them that the story about his going for "fat" was a malicious invention of the enemy. One thing seems to be certain--he didn't come back with any "fat."

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 24.--In this centre of the fishing industry the President's message dropped like a bombshell this morning. Vessel owners and outfitters gathered early at the Board of Trade rooms to discuss tha situation, and this unexpected document had a very sobering effect.

NASSAU, New-Providence, Aug. 20.--On Wednesday, the 15th, a moderate hurricane passed over the Islands of Abaco, Harbor Island, and New-Providence, doing some damage to fruit orchards, crops, fences, The wind backed from northeast to southwest, and lasted for about eight hours. The damage to shipping was very light and no lives were lost.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 24.--The Republicans of the Seventh Congressional District held their convention yesterday and nominated Gen. William Hartsuff of Port Huron after several ballotings and two recesses for conferences.

DELANO, Minn., Aug. 24.--Yesterday afternoon a body of 12 masked men entered the house of John Pearson, three miles west of Armstrong, and demanded food and money, threatening Mrs. Pearson, who was alone in the house with her 10-year-old son, with a revolver.

Henry E. Dixey came home from Europe yesterday on the steamer Trave. He says he had a very pleasant voyage and a very pleasant time while in Europe. He has brought home two new plays from England, besides some French plays that he is to have translated and revamped.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 24.--In convention at Little Valley to-day the Republicans of the Second Cattaraugus District renominated the Hon. J.S. Whipple for the Assembly by acclamation. The sale of W. Elliott Woodward's books was concluded yesterday by Messrs. Bangs Co., but low prices ruled the day's sale. The most interesting feature was the last number on the catalogue--a manuscript relic of the witchcraft days of 1692, in Salem, Mass.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 25.--In the City Circuit Court this morning Judge Phelps filed an opinion in the case of tha Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company against the Canton Company of Baltimore and dismissed the bill.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 25.--There is much diphtheria in this city at the present time. In fact it has been hard all the Summer and many deaths of children have resulted therefrom. Last night two children named Dugan died in one family. The father and the remaining two children are very low from the same disease.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 25.--The lake is being dragged for the bodies of Frank Fierst and his son John of Pittsburg, who were drowned Wednesday night.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 25.--An accident occurred at the roller coaster here this morning. Several persons were on the steepest descent when the car jumped the track. A lady was painfully injured and other coasters were bruised.

The fifty-mile go-as-you-please race for the championship of the world, advertised to take place yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds,turned out to be a dreary affair. At 10 o'clock, the hour set for the race to begin, there were only 75 spectators present, and the prospect for the contestants, who were to receive 50 per cent. of the gate money, was discouraging.

Efforts are being made in Vera Cruz to secure capital there to build a direct railroad to the interior. It is said that the Central Mexican and Inter-Oceanic are likely to agree to build the road jointly to avoid competition.

--The second stage effect that comes up for our consideration is that very popular setting in modern melodrama--the double scene. Several recent writers on stage art, in condemning this device as unscenical, seem to imply that it is purely the outgrowth of recent seeking after sensationalism. The double scene may or may not be good art, but it has at least the flavor of antiquity.

CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 25.--Emanuel Baker was yesterday placed in the Franklin County Jail upon his own information that he had shot and killed Frederick Blake. Blake was sent to the Richmond Penitentiary a few years ado, and during his absence Baker married Blake's wife.

The culvert so recently uncovered by excavations for pipe laying is closely related to the old water systems of this city.

The production of "Lorraine" at Wallack's last Monday evening proved a most gratifying surprise to the audience. COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 25.--Philip McDonald, a street fakir, was arrested here Wednesday on a suspicion of having on his person a quantity of jewelry and over $300 in money. He is supposed to have belonged in Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26.--H.E. Read of Evansville, Ind., a guest at the Palmer House, fell over the stair railing the sixth floor of the Hotel last night and struck on the ground floor. He was about 35 years old.

Prof. Bogoluhoff is the artist, and he is to go to Berlin in the Autumn to paint the portraits of the Emperor, Prince Henry, and the members of the suite.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 26.--S.M. Ballingsley, a wealthy business man and farmer of Bronanga, a small station near Nevada, Mo., and his wife, have been stopping at the New Albany Hotel for several days. They left yesterday morning for home.

One of the literary papers announces that 22 unpublished letters by Dickens, which were recently discovered in a curiosity shop in a London suburb, are about to be published in one of the monthly magazines.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26.--Capt. William Nelson, one of the best known navigators in this country, who commanded the Clyde Line steamship Fanita, which plied between NewYork and Wilmington, N.C., died on board his vessel from apoplexy on Thursday last. His body was brought home yesterday and he will be buried from his late residence, 1,339 Ells-worth-street, to-morrow.

Sunday evening a party of gentlemen were seated at a table in Pedro Berazo's restaurant, 29 Duane-street, when they were joined by a stranger, who entertained them with tales of adventure he said he had gone through in the arctic regions. When the party broke up all but the stranger left the restaurant.

Stricken down by the pauper labor of the West the shoe industry of the once happy city of Lynn, Mass., yells for protection. "We are standing still," says one of the Lynn shoe manufacturers, "while the whole country is booming."

LONDON, Aug. 27.--Minnie Hauk is suffering from nervous prostration. She will not be able to go to America for the next operatic season.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 27.--The Clerical Party press manifests marked hostility to the proposed congress of the American nations of this hemisphere at Washington next year as provided for in the recent act approved by President Cleveland.

PUT-IN-BAY, Ohio, Aug. 27.--Gen. Harrison late this afternoon indulged in a long row on Lake Erie. His stroke was even, and he succeeded in shoving the boat over the waters at a rapid rate half way to Put-in-Bay. This evening he is writing in the cottage and quietly enjoying the lake breezes.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 27.--A man named Andrew Miller of Bridgeport was instantly killed by the cars this morning while walking on the track near the Darien station.

SARATOGA, Aug. 27.--It is settled that the issue in the Gubernatorial election, so far as Warner Miller can shape it, will be defined as the "church against the saloon in politics."

LONGVIEW, Texas, Aug. 27.--Ever since the light between the Democrats and Republicans and the Labor Union has been instituted in this county it has been very bitter, especially with the Republicans who joined the Union Labor Party and the straight Labor Party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--First Lieut. James Parker, Fourth Cavalry, has been granted leave of absence for 20 days. Lieut. Col. George B. Dandy, Deputy Quartermaster-General, has been ordered to visit the National Cemetery at Gettysburg.

ORILLIA, Ontario, Aug. 27.--The cricket match between the Irish Gentlemen and 15 residents of Orillia and district was begun to-day at 1 o'clock. The Irish gentlemen went to the bat first. Eight wickets went down for 60 runs, but a total of 144 had been run up before the next two men were disposed of.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--Since the President let go the other end of the rope at which the Republican Senators have been tugging so violently for three months the Senators have been making more or less vigorous attempts to get upon their feet and to conceal from the public gaze the marks of their ignominious tumble.

MOUNT TABOR, N.J., Aug. 27.--The nineteenth annual camp meetings of the Newark Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church terminated today. The services occupied 10 days, and among the prominent preachers and missionaries who spoke were Bishop J.N. Fitzgerald, ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 27.--Thomas Leach, a switchman in the Jeffersonville, Madison, and Indianapolis Railroad yards was killed last evening uuder peculiar circumstances. His foot caught in a frog, and he waved to an approaching, locomotive to stop. The engineer reversed his engine, but too late, and the man was cut in two.

The open jib and mainsail boats Nahli, owned by W.E. Connor, and Twilight, owned by H.B. Duryea, sailed a match race in the Lower Bay Thursday last in a strong nor'wester. The Nahli came in 6 minutes and 27 seconds ahead. The course was seven miles to windward from Spermaceti Cove and return. The winner's time was within a few minutes of three hours. W.S. Alley sailed the Nahli and Mr. Duryea the Twilight.

OSWEGO, Aug. 27.--For some time past storekeepers in towns in the eastern part of this county have suffered greatly from the depredations of a burglar who seemed to possess all the modern facilities for removing valuables regardless of the supposed security by which they were surrounded.

The investigating committee of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company, consisting of G. Clinton Gardner, Thomas B. Atkins, and William P. Robinson, which has been at work since June 7 last in an examination into the condition of the affairs of that road; submitted their report yesterday.

CHAUTAUQUA, Aug. 27.--The last day of the Chautauqua Assembly dawned gray and cold--three steamers instead of one went laden with home-bound Chautauquans to the morning train.

CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 27.--The opening day's attendance of the Inter-State Exhibition of Grangers at Williams's Grove was not so large as on former occasions, about 5,000 persons being on the grounds.

Mrs. L. Corwin, a widow living on Grovestreet, in Jersey City, received a letter two weeks ago informing her that the remains of her son George had been stolen, and asking what price she would pay for their recovery. Her son, a favorite child, was buried in September, 1880.

BOSTON, Aug. 27.--A cable message has been received from Lord Crawford at Dunecht, Scotland, saying that on the 13th and 22d inst. the variable star "R" Cygni was observed by Espin at walsingham, and that the spectrum was found to contain bright lines. The observation was confirmed yesterday at the Dunecht Observatory.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27.--The Indiana Republicans recognize the fact, apparently, that they have a hard fight before them, and that they must get their best timber to the front in order to stand a chance to win.

The Foxhall Keene Racing Association closed its Autumn meeting at Cedarhust yesterday on the grounds of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association. That the meeting should be brought to a sufficiently brilliant conclusion four flat races were provided, in each one of which young Keene rode the winner.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 27.--The work of demolishing the old yale laboratory, on the Yale campus, was begun to-day, and was helped considerably by the breaking out of a fire about 9:30 o'clock to-night. Some laborers had thrown some old bottles which contained chemicals into the cellar, ...

NEWARK, Aug. 27.--Dr. Dennis D. Mulcahy of this city sailed for Paris on Saturday. There he will sue the Duke of Aosta to recover an estate in Spain valued at $600,000.

SARATOGA, Aug. 27.--George Law, who is one of the best-known men about town in NewYork, and who is said to have an income of $200,000 a year, has had a very extraordinary experience with his sporting friends in Saratoga.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27.--Drafts--Sight, at par; telegraphic, 7 cents.

Manager J.M. Hill's work for the season is well under way. In addition to the production of Mrs. Fiske's new play, "Philip Herne," at the Fifth-Avenue last evening Mr. Hill began the season of his young star, Mr. Roach, in Brooklyn, and next Monday night he will produce Sydney Rosenfeld's "A Possible Case" at the Hollis-Street Theatre.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 27.--A report comes from Naushon of the death of William Forbes, the 16-year-old son of J. Malcolm Forbes, the well-known yachtsman and owner of the sloop Puritan.

Henry Melville, a wax-flower maker of 35 Clinton-place, was held for trial by Justice Patterson, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, on a charge of having brutally beaten a dog with a club on Sunday evening at the corner of Clinton place and Greene-street.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27.--Political circles in this city were startled this morning by the announcement that John McCullough, exmember of the Legislature from the Tenth District, had committed suicide. McCullough, who was one of the best known Republican politicians in the city, shot himself through the temple at his home, 1,460 Cherry-street, this morning at 8:30.

ST. LOUIS Aug. 27.--Lombert Levy was a St. Louis man of varied accomplishments. He was a Treasurer in several secret societies, kept a cigar store, was a Deacon in a church, and occasionally held political office.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27.--A campaign novelty in Chicago will be a marching club of young women. The requirements for membership are a height of at least 4 feet and Republican proclivities.
AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 27.--The Twenty-seventh Congressional District Convention was held at Weedsport, in this county, to-day. Congressman N.W. Nutting was unanimously renominated.

LONDON, Aug. 27.--The police of Wexford to-day arrested Mr. John Redmond, member of Parliament for Wexford; his brother, Mr. William Redmond, member of Parliament for Fermanagh, and Mr. Edward Walsh, editor of the Wexford People. They are charged with offenses under the Crimes act. The Redmonds and Mr. Walsh were subsequently admitted to bail.

He was standing in a cornfield when he felt something like a rope being drawn around his legs, and on looking down was horrified to see a large snake coiling itself around his body. There is virile force and energy in Mrs. Mary Fiske's four-act play called "Philip Herne," that was produced, amid boundless enthusiasm, at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre last night. There is wit of a very good quality, and a great deal of it, in the text.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 27.--Rumors of important changes among the general officers of the St. Paul, Minneapolis and Manitoba Company have been current for the past week, and although it is impossible at this time to gain any confirmation of the reports from the officials themselves, enough has been learned to warrant the statement that there will be a general change of some kind within a fortnight.

Michael J. Murray, President of the Laborers' Council, spent Saturday and Sunday in Trenton, N.J., talking to the pottery workers and other workingmen in that city. He found that Congressman Mills's speech there on Wednesday had made a great impression among the men and was the subject of earnest discussion.

NEWARK, Aug. 27.--Sebastiano Palazzo, who was arrested here on Wednesday night last for passing counterfeit five-dollar silver certificates, had an examination to-day before United States Commissioner Jones. The evidence showed that Palazzo was connected with a gang of counterfeiters. He was held in default of $3,000 bail.

ALBANY, Aug. 27.--The classification of the entries in the cattle department at the fair of the State Agricultural Society, to be held at Elmira Sept, 17-22, has been completed. The entries are 300 in excess of those of last year, when they were the largest in the history of the society.

The National Electric Light Association is coming to town. Mayor Hewitt was formally notified about it yesterday by representatives of the Exectutive Committee. He told the gentlemen that he was very much pleased with the news, and said that New-York was the proper place to hold the convention.

The methods of the false check operator, William L. Clark, or Colt, of the Prescott House, who was arrested on Saturday and has been several times remanded at the Essex Market Police Court, were told yesterday by Chief Inspector Byrnes. He belongs to a good family, has a captivating address, and his bearing is that of a staid young business man.

OTTAWA, Aug. 27.--There is a report in circulation that the Hon. J.S.D. Thompson, Minister of Justice, has been knighted for services rendered in connection with the negotiation of the fishery treaty. Judge Thompson declines to make any statement just now.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 27.--It has just come to light that there exists here an organization of a peculiar character which claims to have a membership of many thousands, and which has kept its organization and existence a profound secret from the general public.

BOSTON, Aug. 27.--A mysterious crime that will undoubtedly end in the death of the victim occurred at the South End early this morning, and there is little probability that the murderer will ever be captured.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 27.--A certificate of organization has to-day issued to the Clinton Bank of New-York. The capital is $200,000. D.L. Satterles is President.

MONTREAL, Aug. 27.--An American, who gave his name as Von Leer, and has been running a bogus employment agency here, skipped out to-day after having swindled a lot of poor people.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 27, via Galveston. --Advices from Chiapa state that the members of the commission appointed by Mexico to delimit the boundary between Mexico and Guatemala are 18 days' journey from San Cristobal, the capital of Chiapa, out of funds and in want. The State Government has forwarded food and money to them.

Herr Moritz Rosenthal, the Roumanian piano virtuoso, will make his New-York debut in the first of a series of Rosenthal concerts, to take place at Stein way Hall, on Nov. 14. Master Fritz Kreissler, tha young Austrian violinist, will have his first hearing on the same occasion.

HARTFORD, Aug. 27.--Gen. Edward E. Bradley of New-Haven, who is now considered in the field for the Democratic nomination for Governor, was on the State ticket two years ago as the candidate for Lieutenant-Governor.

Mrs. Frank Booth of Williamsburg is in trouble. Her husband left her about three months ago, and she believes that he is at Cape Cod, Mass. Her neighbors, however, say that he is not far from his old home, at 153 Richardsonstreet.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 27.--Daniel Swigert of this city has bought for use at Elmendorf Stud Farm the blk. s. Portland, 5 years old, by Virgil, out of Finework, by Lexington. The purchase was made from John Croker of Brighton Beach, who has handled the horse for some time past.
The five-mile international swimming contest came off at Coney Island yesterday between Johnson of England and Levey of Pittsburg for a purse of $500 and the championship of the world.

With two hands out and three men on bases a home run, hit by Brown, the curlyhaired right fielder of the Boston Club, in the seventh inning yesterday scored 4 runs for the Bostonians, snatched a victory from the Giants, and caused disappointment to the 4,000 spectators who assembled to see the game.

Roundsman Bingham of the Twentythird Precinct, while passing the Hotel Wellington, at Forty-second-street and Madisonavenue, at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, caught Officer William M. Felleman coming out of Paul S. Bolger's plumbing shop, in the basement of the hotel, carrying a three-pound lump of lead in his hand.

The steamship Persian Monarch, which arrived yesterday from London, brought 12 of the crew of the British bark Gylfe. They had abandoned their vessel in what they claimed to have been an unseaworthy condition in latitude 47 14' north, longitude 44 33' west, or about 350 miles from St. John's, Newfoundland.

WOONSOCKET, R.I., Aug. 27.--One hundred and twelve weavers in the Harris Woolen Company's Privilege Mill struck this morning against the heavy fines imposed by the new overseer. No steps have yet been taken toward settlement.

Judge Thomas M. Cooley of the Inter-State Commerce Commission spent yesterday in Castle Garden investigating the cause and probable blame of the present trunk line war in immigrant rates. He is also anxious to find if the inter-State commerce law is being violated.

SARATOGA, Aug. 27.--A committee of Saratogians intend to start for Columbus, Ohio, within a few days to attend the National Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, and urge upon the delegates the advisability of selecting Saratoga as the place for the National Encampment next year.

Gen. Francois Manigat, Deputy to the Legislative Corps of Hayti, arrived here from France on La Bretagne Sunday afternoon and was greatly surprised on hearing that Gen. Salomon had left the island and was now on his way to Paris.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 27.--With all points south of Waycross quarantined, Fernandina is the only northern outlet for persons from such places as are not infected. The Mallory and Clyde ships are running their usual weekly trips.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27.--Archbishop Ryan stigmatizes as absolutely false a paragraph from Dorchester's "Christianity in the United States," which is going the rounds of the press, in which the Archbishop is quoted as advocating the persecution of heretics as soon as Catholics in this country shall have become numerous enough to do so. He states that he never wrote or thought it, and absolutely repudiates the sentiment.

NIAGARA, Ontario, Aug. 27.--E. Strachan Cox, the ex-Toronto broker, who was instrumental in bringing about the failure of the Central Bank of Canada through his dealings with it, and who was arrested here last evening, ...

DETROIT, Aug. 27.--There was quite a sensation at Hillsdale to-day, over the discovery that Mr. Charles W. Waldron, part owner and manager of the Waldron Bank of that town, has been absent from home since last Wednesday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27.--The steamer Annie P. silver left St. Louis at 8 o'clock last night with 625 excursionists, women and children predominating. When opposite Madison, 12 miles north of St. Louis, the steamer ran on a bar.

HAMBURG, Aug. 27.--Seven old wooden warehouses at Steinwerde, containing cotton, rice, sugar, and saltpetre, valued at 7,000,000 marks, were destroyed by fire to-day. Twelve persons perished in the flames.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 27.--Michael McSlaret, 57 years old, for 17 years an employe of W.P Levis's paper mill, met with a horrible death this evening. In attempting to throw off an eighth inch pulley he was caught and his head crushed between the belt and pulley.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27.--There was a big freight train wreck on the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad between Devon and Strafford station this morning, in which 13 cars were totally destroyed by fire, half a dozen more badly damaged, and two men badly burned, one of whom will probably die.

The published rumors of yesterday that the Security Safe Deposit Company of Boston would not pay the damage sustained to property in its keeping through the storm of last Tuesday appears to have been without foundation of fact.

The Kings County Democratic General Committee decided last night to hold primaries on Friday night and Assembly Conventions on Tuesday next for the election of delegates to the State Convention, to be held in Buffalo on Sept. 12.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 27.--W.C. Van Horne, President of the Canadian Pacific and one of the best posted railway men on the American continent, is at the Hotel Ryan. It is commonly supposed that the legislation on the subject of non-intercourse with Canada is a matter of great interest to Canadian Pacific people.

WATERVILLE, Me., Aug. 27.--Mr. Blaine addressed an audience of about 2,000 people here this afternoon in the open air, but made only a short speech owing to hoarseness. He addressed himself principally to workingmen, dwelling upon the injury which he claimed would be done them should the President's tariff policy be carried into effect.

BRANCHVILLE, Conn., Aug. 27.--Up to last Friday evening William Burr Hill lived with his wife and five grown children in a fine large house in Little Boston, an outlying district of this town. His farm comprised many hundred acres, and is probably the finest and richest estate along the line of the Danbury and Norwalk Railroad.

A platform built for the band and the speakers at the banner raising and ratifiction meeting of the Hungarian-American Democratic Association in the square in Houston-street, east of Avenue A, broke down last night, and Henry Greenbaum, a boy, was killed and several boys and men were more or less seriously injured.

Chief Detective Byrnes has for the past two weeks been busy in endeavoring to right an official wrong, and yesterday had matters in such shape that the result he aimed at attaining will be brought about in a few days.

Cooper Union was packed last evening with a well-dressed audience, whose enthusiasm grew unbounded whenever the speakers gave utterance to the names of Cleveland and Thurman or expressed the Democratic sentiments of tariff reform. BOSTON, Aug. 27.--In sending a begging circular to the Post Office employes on Saturday last, Treasurer Lewis of the Democratic State Committee not only kicked up a fuss but had his labor for his pains.
Postmaster-General Don M. Dickinson yesterday, before his return to Washington, spoke of the campaign in Michigan, and expressed great confidence in a Democratic victory there.

GALESBURG, Ill., Aug. 27.--Dr. Talbot, Assistant State Veterinarian, has been ordered to investigate cases of Texas fever in this city. Thus far two cows have died from this cause and others are affected. The cases arise from pasturing cattle near the railroad track over which Texas cattle are shipped. There were several deaths in the same locality last year, and the people were then warned not to drive their cattle near the track.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 27--Ex-Senator Joseph E. McDonald delivered an address here to-night in the Criminal Court room, under the auspices of the Hendrick's Club. The meeting was very generally attended by citizens of both parties.

Sullivan, a married man, aged 75, and Mrs. Martha Morgan, a widow, aged 66, figure in the leading roles. KIRKWOOD, N.J., Aug. 28.--During the thunderstorm yesterday afternoon the large barn of Aaron Watson, at Watsontown, was struck by lightning and burned to the ground. Mr. Watson and his son were in the stable at the time and were badly shooked by the lightning, but were gotten out before the fire reached them.

NEW-BETHLEHEM, N.H., Aug. 29.--Yesterday was one of the severest days ever experienced on Mount Washington in Summer.
