BOSTON, Aug. 30.--Again the Giants failed to bat, and again the Bostons scored a victory. Clarkson was very effective, only five scattering hits being gained off him. Richardson, Ward, Tiernan, and O'Rourke, all big hitters, failed to make a single base hit.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 30.--Very few changes in political faith have taken place in this county during the Summer. The Rev. Herman G. Timlow, Rector of the Episcopal church in Burnt Hills, a neighboring hamlot, has always voted the Republican ticket, but came out yesterday for Cleveland and tariff reform.

ATLANTA, Aug. 30.--To-day the name of Mrs. Jane Hewitt Leamington, Warwickshire, England, was inscribed upon the hotel register of the Garnet House. LOCKPORT, Aug. 30.--Mrs. Jennie Robinson, wife of William Robinson, a wagonmaker of Gosport, lost the sight of an eye recently and the sight of the other was affected. She had the best medical aid, but without success.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 30.--Owing to the withdrawal of one mill and the refusal of another to join it, the cotton combine has resolved for the present to leave prices open for all the mills to deal with as they think best.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 30.--The Globe Soap Works, 31 and 33 Water-street, have been burning since 12:30 to-night. Loss likely to be heavy.

LIVINGSTON, Montana, Aug. 30.--A batch of 16 recruits were recently sent from Fort Keogh to Capt. Harris, at the Mammoth Hot Springs. They have turned out to be about as tough a gang as were ever together. Six of them are now in the guardhouse for quite serious offenses, three have deserted within the past...

DENVER, Col., Aug. 30.--A. J. Throckmorton, a nephew of Gov. Throckmorton of Texas, committed suicide at a ten-cent lodging house by taking morphine. Despondency, caused by poverty and whisky, is supposed to be the cause. He recently came from Pueblo. Col. where he and his wife had spent all they had.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 30.--A scheme is on foot among a number of the most prominent Knights of Labor in this city to have a resolution introduced at the next General Assembly, to be held at Indianapolis, making American citizenship essential to membership.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30.--Major Edwin V. Sumner, Fifth Cavalry; Major Guy F. Henry, Ninth Cavalry, and First Lieut. Philip Bende, Third Cavalry, Inspector of Rifle Practice, have been ordered to meet at Fort Niagara, New-York, for the purpose of witnessing the annual competition of the army rifle team.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--It now looks as if the time and labor spent in formulating an agreement by which the Western, Northwestern, and Southwestern roads were to be embraced in the reorganization of the Western States Passenger Association had been lost. The meeting of General Managers called to-day to ratify the agreement...

Emil Schaitberger, 16 years old, of 160 Attorney-street confessed in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday that he had for some time been stealing watches, silverware, lace shawls, , from his employer, Aaron Schlang, a pawnbroker at 558 Eighth-avenue.

RINGWOOD, Aug. 30.--The condition of Robert Garrett is unchanged. He walked about the grounds of the Miller villa this afternoon, and Dr. Jacobs said that the change of air had a beneficial effect on his patient, whose sleep is more regular than it was in the city.

Charles Jeremiah Selton, an actor, whose stage name is William Allen, aged 29, was arrested in Union-square last night on a warrant issued by Justice Power, in the Tombs Police Court, charging him with the abduction last...

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--The people who saw "The Crystal Slipper" at the Chicago Opera House last night were given a surprise, for Miss Ida Mulle, who has been playing acceptably all Summer in the piece, was no longer Cinderella and her old part was taken by Miss Marguerite Fish of New-York.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 30.--The trial of A.G. Sellon, the postal clerk, for killing Jerry G. Sinclair was begun to-day in the Supreme Court. Much of the afternoon was spent in getting a jury. At the request of Jasper Hutchings, counsel for the ac cused, the jury inspected the car in which the homicide occurred. L.C. Southard of Boston will be associated with Mr. Hutchings in the defense.

CALDWELL, Ohio, Aug. 30.--A month ago a mysterious disease appeared here. It had characteristics of typhoid fever and some of malaria, and whole families were attacked. The malady was lingering and victims rarely died under six or seven days.

Thomas F. Gilroy, Deputy County Clerk and Secretary of Tammany Hall, is on the Alaska, which is expected to arrive here from Liverpool on Sunday. His fellow-members of the Tammany Hall General Committee of the Twenty-third Assembly District and other prominent Tammanyites will go down the Harbor in a tug to meet him and escort him and Mrs. Gilroy to their home in Harlem.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--Articles of incorporation for another elevated road project were filed with the Secretary of State yesterday. The new organization is the Chicago West Division Elevated Railway...

President French of the Police Department spent an hour yesterday afternoon listening to the testimony of witnesses in the complaint of Thomas McLaughlin, a young cart driver, against Patrolmen James Mulvey and John T. Regan of the Twenty-third Precinct.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Aug. 30.--Mrs. Elizabeth Cady Stanton was tendered a reception tonight by Mrs. Helen M. Gougar, President of the Indiana Women's Christian Temperance Union. Mrs. Stanton and Mrs. Gougar will stump the State in the interest of prohibition and female suffrage during the month of September.

The Socialists of this city held a meeting last evening at 25 East Fourth-street to celebrate the election of the Socialistic candidate. Liebknecht, to the German Reichstag. The "Marseillaise" was sung and numerous speeches were made. The speakers said that the progress of Socialism in Liebknecht's district was unprecedented. At the last election he was elected by a majority of 1,871 votes, and now he has been returned by a majority of 10,594.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30.--The annual report of the Superintendent of Foreign Mails shows that the total cost of the service for the last fiscal year was $490,067, of which amount $26,649 was for the transportation of mails of foreign origin.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 30.--Eccles Robinson, Master Workman of the National District of the Brass Workers' Assembly, Knights of Labor, received word from the General Executive Board that a charter would be granted them as soon as all the money due the different district ...
TROY, N.Y., Aug. 30.--Two hundred veterans, survivors of the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Regiment, attended the reunion at Hoosick Falls to-day. There was a parade, with a dinner and speeches.

The very successful three days' extra meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club will close to-day, and the programme is of the same nature as on the two preceding days--moderatelysized fields, but of very even quality. It is a card which not alone promises good sport, but which will puzzle the speculators considerably in their efforts to locate the probable winners.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 30.--At the Greensbury quarries early this morning Hugh Morrison, a quarryman, was shot by John Cullen, another quarryman, who had been whipped by Morrison during the night. The wound is serious. The ball has not yet been extracted. A warrant was issued for the arrest of Cullen, but he cannot be found.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 30.--The annual retreat of the Buffalo Catholic Diocese has just been finished at the Seminary of Our Lady of Angels, at Suspension Bridge. There were over 100 priests present for the week. The time was passed in spiritual advisement.
HAVANA, Aug. 30.--A cable has been laid between Cuba and Hayti, connecting Cuba with Porto Plata, San Domingo, Curacoa, and Venezuela.

Richard Shields, an employe of the National Ice Company, made application to Justice Patterson in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday for the custody of his child, Lizzie, aged 3 years, on a writ of habeas corpus. He alleged that his daughter was wrongfully detained...

VIENNA, Aug. 30.--At Tarnobrzeg, Galicia, to-day 150 houses were destroyed by fire. Two hundred families are homeless. The loss is $2,500,000. One man was injured.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 30.--David B. Hill is foxy, and he and his myrmidons among the boss brewers have been playing a sharp game for capturing the support of the hop growers of the central and southern counties in behalf of his renomination and re-election as Governor.

A bronze statue of Rafael M. Baralt, the distinguished historian of Venezuela, who died about 40 years age, was exhibited for the first time yesterday at the Artistie Bronze Works, 209 Forsyth-street, the foundry where it was cast.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 30.--Dolos Lowe of Chaumont, this county, has just received papers granting him a pension amounting to $1,900 up to the present time and allowing him $30 per month in the future. The bill signed by the President last week increases the pension for deafness from $13 to $30 per month, thus insuring Lowe a small fortune.
FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 30.--Texas fever is decimating the herds belonging to the settlers on Northfork, in the easterly part of Greer County. The disease was given off by the Laurel Leaf cattle...

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 30.--A good day and track with an increased attendance marked the third day's meeting at the Driving Park. The track, never fast, was much better than previous days, and good time was made in the pacing race.

A meeting of chess players was held last evening at the rooms of the Columbia Club, 1 Second-avenue, to effect a permanent organization among the players in this city and elect delegates to the National Convention of Cincinnati on Sept. 4, when a national chess association will be formed.

Senator Quay being at Washington, trying to bring the recalcitrant Republican Senators to terms, and Mr. Clarkson being confined to his room by his sprained ankle, John C. New had command at the National Republican Headquarters yesterday, and very mad he was.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--The convention of the Young People's Methodist Alliance for the United States and Canada will be held at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Chicago, Sept. 26, 27, and 28. Every organization district and church is requested to send delegates.

A peculiar feature about Charles Crocker's will, which has excited a good deal of comment, was the fact that Mrs. Mary A. Crocker, the widow, is made the Executrix. Four ballet girls attached to Imre Kiralfy's "Nero," on Staten Island, were married on the stage last night just before the performance commenced to four of the supernumeraries, and after the show left on their wedding tour. They were Charles Brooks and Annie E. Carroll, Michael Hallorhan and Maggie Mitchell, James McClellan and Mary Hooley, Philip Glenny and Mary Aun Monohan. None of the parties were acquainted before their engagement with Kiralfy.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 30.--A Times special from Buffalo, Wyoming, says that all the Sioux Indians who had left the reservation have been returned. The troops have been withdrawn. No further trouble is apprehended.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 30.--The National Archery Tournament has attracted a large crowd of merry archers to this city. MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 30.--Five thousand strangers came from surrounding villages, towns, and cities to-day to help Milford celebrate the dedication of her soldiers and sailors' monument. MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 30.--The air in Minneapolis was charged with startling rumors today. The most surprising of the many is one to the effect that McGill's name will not be presented to the Republican State Convention next Wednesday for renomination. This rumor was not freely circulated. It is asserted that the Governor's friends have become disheartened...

The Knickerbocker Cutlery Company, at 527 West Twenty-fourth-street, has become financially embarrassed, and Deputy Sheriff Young has taken possession on a judgment for $5,272 in favor of H. A. Rogers.
MANNING, S.C., Aug. 30.--The dead body of Ben Brand, a negro, was found hanging by a rope from the limb of a tree near Salem, this county, early yesterday morning.

Judge Thurman will probably arrive here on next Wednesday evening, in order that he may have a food night's rest prior to the festivities of the rest of the week during which his visit will last. Whether he arrives then or Thursday morning, he will be received at the station by a large delegation of prominent Democrats, who will escort him to the Hoffman House in a befitting manner.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 30.--The depredations of the gang of sneak thieves who have been working in this locality for the past month assumed alarming proportions to-day, when the boarding house of Morris J. Silvers on Summerfield-avenue, West Asbury Park, was entered between 1 and 2...

HOWELL, Mich., Aug. 30.--Mrs. H.M. Dubois of Oak Grove is in jail here charged with arson. Her husband carried home a can of oil, and after filling a lamp set the can in its accustomed place and went to bed.

CROW CREEK AGENCY, Dakota, Aug. 30.-- At the grand powwow yesterday Judge Wright spoke at great length and thoroughly explained the bill to the Indians, who listened intently throughout the entire speech and very frequently grunted their approval.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30.--A conference of glass manufacturers and glass workers was held at the Continental Hotel this afternoon to agree upon a scales of wages for the next blast--that of 1889-90. At previous conferences no decision was reached, but to-day it was determined that the scale of the...

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 30.--The most important proceedings begun under the general provisions of the new railroad law were commenced to-day by 44 of the jobbers, manufacturers, and business men of Davenport...

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 30.--As the northbound passenger train on the Columbia and Port Deposit Railroad was passing Cold Spring this morning the body of a man was discovered lying on the roadbed. The train stopped and the train hands found the body badly mutilated.

Chief Engineer Church was seen yesterday in regard to the report of the Finance and Audit Committee of the Aqueduct Commission, published in yesterday's TIMES. "Of course I will not resign," said Mr. Church. "The report does not reflect on me in any way. Why should I resign?

ISHPEMING, Mich., Aug. 30.--A hundred pounds more of gold rock was taken from the Michigan to-day. This is the fifth lot, and the rock already taken out is estimated to be worth $8,000.

John Y. McKane has called primaries for to-day at Gravesend in spite of the refusal of the Democratic General Committee to recognize him or the Gravesend association. What the result will be is puzzling the local politicians.

ST. LOUIS, Aug 30.--The 10 pool rooms in this city that do business on the Eastern races were suddenly deprived of their telegraph service to-day and there is great excitement among the gamblers tonight.

BOSTON, Aug. 30.--On the subject of a sugar trust for retail dealers and the system of selling sugar by the card-price plan, the large Boston dealers do not agree with the New-York dealer quoted by THE TIMES. In the first place they all ridicule the statement that the plan of a third trust is a Boston idea.

The Staten Island Athletic Club held a lawn tennis tournament yesterday to pick out players to defend the lawn tennis trophy in the lawn tennis contest on Labor Day. The players making the greatest number of points on the final rounds will be chosen.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 30.--The case of William G. Stahl against J.J. Mitchell and others in which Judge Simons has just granted a new trial to the defendants involves an interesting point. In 1857 William Blakeley of Allegheny County, Penn., made an assignment to J.J. Mitchell.

RONDOUT, Aug. 30.--H.G. Dimmick of this town has been with Jay Gould in the Catskills for three days. In reply to questions this afternoon about Mr. Gould's health and outing, Mr. Dimmick said: "If any person has any doubt that Mr. Gould is in the best physical health that doubt would have quickly been removed...

Charles A. Billings, who is now in Raymond-street Jail, Brooklyn, For failing to contribute to the support of his wife, Ida, who recently obtained a separation from him, was served with a warrant yesterday charging him with bigamy.

The Picnic Committee of the Central Labor Union held a meeting last evening and determined upon the route of march for the labor parade. The procession will start from Thirteenth-street and move up Second-avenue...
A daring robbery was committed yesterday afternoon in broad daylight on Broadway. Miss Lena K. Brown was walking along Broadway.

LONDON, Aug. 30.--At the York meeting today the race for the great Yorkshire Stakes was won by Ossory, Arrandale second and Caerlaverock third. The last betting was 5 to 4 against Ossory. The race for the Gimcrack Stakes was won by Cheroot, Pinzon second and Prospective third. The last betting was 3 to 1 against Cheroot and 6 to 5 on Pinzon.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 30.--The Democratic Congressional Convention of the First Ohio District has nominated Otway J. Cosgrave for Congress. The Second Ohio District Democratic Convention nominated C.W. Gerard.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 30.--The death of William M. Lloyd of Altoona was announced to-day as having occurred last night. The announcement recalls the bankrupt proceedings into which Mr. Lloyd was forced by the panic of 1873. At the time his assets were among the millions and his liabilities about four times as much as his assets.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 30.--The life-size bronze statue of Robert Burns was unveiled in Washington Park this afternoon. The statue cost $27,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30.--Suit has been brought by Mrs. Dunbar Price, in the name of her father, George W. Burton, in the courts of this city against her husband, Dunbar Price, for the payment of a monthly allowance of $900, which the latter agreed to pay his wife...

Mrs. Andrew Mahling, the wife of a tailor living at 152 Graham-avenue, Brooklyn, Eastern District, was driven from her home on Wednesday night by her drunken husband, and when she returned yesterday morning she found him dead. Mahling had hanged himself to the door by means of a piece of stout twine, and had been strangled to death. He was 55 years old.
LONDON, Aug. 30.--The final meeting of the sugar bounties conference was held to-day. All the delegates representing powers which approved the convention affixed their signatures to the document.

At a meeting of the Emigration Commissioners at Castle Garden yesterday it was decided to adopt the resolution passed upon by the Castle Garden Committee, to the effect that the Commissioners asssume charge of immigrants' baggage on and after Sept. 1, each trunk line to pay its proportion of the expense.

The Commissioners of Accounts have made a report to the Mayor in which they say that, after a thorough examination of the management by Commissioner of Jurors Charles Reilly, they find that it has been all that could be expected under the law.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 30.--The Knights Templar of New-Jersey visited Asbury Park to-day over 500 strong and enjoyed their annual field day. The high-degree Masons, attired in their gorgeous uniforms and accompanied by tuneful brass bands, commenced to pour into the town at 10 o'clock.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., Aug. 30.--The jury in the case of Thomas Griflin decided that he was murdered, the evidence showing it plainly. Scully, the accused, will be held until detectives can further investigate the case.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 30.--Matias Romero, the Mexican Minister at Washington, has obtained leave to visit Europe. Rumors are current that the company which bought the Interoceanic Railroad is the Mexican company now operating the road between this city, Puebla, and Vera Cruz.
WARSAW, N.Y., Aug. 30.--At the Wyoming County Republican Convention held here to-day, the Hon. G.S. Van Gorder was renominatted for member of Assembly.

HARTFORD, Aug. 30.--There are no new developments concerning the amount of shortage in the trust accounts of Cashier Breed, who committed suicide yesterday.

PORT STANLEY, Ontario, Aug. 30.--Erastus Wiman has accepted an invitation from the Elgin Farmers' Institute to address a Harvest Home at this place on Tuesday next on the question of enlarged trade relations with the United States. ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30.--The representatives of the voters of the Seventh Missouri Congressional District decided the claims of two candidates for Congress in a unique but not popular way last night. The district is known throughout the State as the Dead-lock District.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 30.--The last span in the great bridge across the Hudson River at this point was finished at about 6 o'clock to-night, the event being celebrated by the firing of a cannon from the top of the bridge.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 30.--The wind was again very unfavorable for the riflemen at the Ontario Rifle Association a meeting yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Aug. 30.--The sight of a spacious house floating in from Long Island Sound this morning caused amazement among the longshoremen. It was a curious sight, with three puffing tugboats steaming in front and towing it.

Congressmen Mills and Breckinridge visited the National Democratic Headquarters yesterday with Congressman Stahlnecker, with whom they spoke at a Democratic meeting at Warburton Hall, Yonkers, last evening. Mr. Mills has just returned from a tour in Illinois, and he was enthusiastic over the Democratic prospects in that State.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 30.--The camp meeting at Ocean Grove was brought to a close today amid impressive services in the Auditorium. At 9 o'clock Drs. Stokes and Ballard baptized 24 infants, and this was followed by the sacrament of the Lord's Supper.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 30.--The weather here continues cloudy and showery, and exceedingly unfavorable to the cotton crop.

A new American play, entitled "Her Husband," will be presented for the first time at the Windsor Theatre in this city, on Sept. 25. The play is by Miss Johnson, the author of a piece called "On the Frontier," and is described as a domestic drama.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30.--Drafts--Sight, at par; telegraphic 7 cents.

Information has been received by Collector Magone that Miss Lizzie Prentice, who is supposed to be an employe of the Auburn Silk Mill, is bringing over several silk weavers from England on the steamer City of Chicago. They are all young women, and the claim is made that they are intended for the Auburn mill. The Collector has rivals on the City of Chicago will be carefully watched for foreign silk weavers.
BERLIN, Aug. 30.--In the election in the Sixth District of this city to-day Herr Liebknecht, Socialist, was successful, receiving 26,067 votes out of a total of 41,791.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--The opposition to the now transcontinental tariff has reached a maximum. To-day a circular was issued by the joint committee of the trunk lines and the Central Traffic Association which amounts to a repudiation of the published schedule. "The Transcontinental Association," the circular says, "having issued through tarrifs on Pacific...

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--Frederick Schuneman, an agent for the Best Brewing Company, was murdered early this morning in an alley near his residence, 432 West Randolph-street, He had left his home about 11 o'clock to take a walk and was probably returning when he was...

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 30.--Every day brings forth fresh evidence of additional forgeries on the part of Lawyer Herbert Gedney of Goshen, who absconded on the day when a warrant was issued for his apprehension.

Never was a party in sorer need of a guide, philosopher, and friend than the Republicans at the present moment. Unless some modern Moses comes along to assume leadership, there is danger that they will be lost in the wilderness...

WILLIAM'S GROVE, Penn., Aug. 30.--Forty thousand people congregated on the grounds at Williams Grove Grangers' Exhibition to-day. The first speaker of the morning was the Hon. Norman J. Colman, Commissioner of Agriculture, who delivered an address on agricultural pursuits.

NYACK, Aug. 30.--This has been the greatest day in all the year for the farmers of Rockland County and their friends. The thirteenth annual picnic of the Farmers' Club of the county was held in Sylvan Grove, Rockland Lake, and a happy event it proud to be. The weather was all that could be desired, and in the middle...
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 30.--While Cleveland will surely carry Tennessee, and probably by an increased majority over 1884, the election of the Democratic candidate for Governor is by no means assured.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30.--Senator Quay, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, furnishes the following letter for publication:

The stock market drifted along in its little way yesterday without much to distinguish it from other ordinarily stupid days. One or two stocks rose somewhat and fell back; one or two declined a little and then recovered. The day's net changes were few and inconsequential.

ANDOVER, New-Brunswick, Aug. 31.--The preliminary inquiry into the charges of shooting preferred against Day, Trafton, and Phillipine, the alleged murderers of Mrs. Howe, was further adjourned to-day until Sept. 11.
BOSTON, Aug. 31.--At last the Giants won to-day. They hit the curves of Sowders hard and often and took advantage of the errors of the home club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31.--Although the Republican Senators decided at last night's caucus to report their substitute for the Mills bill within 10 days, they attached a string to the decision in the qualifying words "if possible," which were a part of the resolution, and it is the general belief that the bill will not get into the Senate before Sept. 15 or 18. The announcement that the Finance Committee will continue ...
MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 31.--Mobile's Volunteer Fire Department, one of the last volunteer organizations in service in the South, will close doors to-morrow.

The new theatre just about being completed in Rochester is to be called the Lyceum, after the house of that name in this city, and negotiations have been pending for some time between Mr. A.E. Wollr, the manager of the new theatre, and Daniel Frehman with a view to having the house opened to the public by the regular company of its namesake in New-York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31.--Surgeon-Gen. Hamilton has received the following telegram from J.J. Daniel, President of the Jackson ville Citizens' Auxiliary Committee:

The time to put a high-license plank into the Republican State platform was last Tuesday. It cannot be done now by assertion or by argument. MANISTEE, Mich., Aug. 31.--C.E. Joys, dealer in general merchandise, made an assignment to-day. Liabilities, $45,000; assets, $25,000. A large loss through the collapse of the Manistee Salt and Lumber Company caused the failure.

SARATOGA, Aug. 31.--A great deal of grief and sorrow was visible to-night among the visitors to Saratoga and among the colored employes of the big hotels over the sudden death of John Lucas, head waiter of the United States Hotel.

The meeting of the Reform Club in its handsomely appointed quarters at 13 East Thirty-third-street last evening was one of the most interesting which, that organization has yet held. The large parlors could not contain the number in attendance, and many persons were compelled to stand in the halls and take seats on the staircase.

The project of the Long Island Railroad Company to build a tunnel under Thirty-eighthstreet from the East River to Tenth-avenue, with a branch under Fourth-avenue to the Grand Central Station, was before the Aldermanic Committee on Bridges and Tunnels yesterday, Aldermen Hubbell, McMurray, and Holland being present.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--A special from Atlanta, Ga., says: "The tropical fruit men have combined and consumers will be unable to get a single bananna or plantain save through the courtesy of the trust, which was organized in New-Orleans this week.
The work of widening the Toledo, St. Louis and Kansas City Road to standard gauge is being vigorously prosecuted, and about Oct. 10 will witness the completion of the work.

HARTFORD, Aug. 31.--William O. Buckley of this city, who was elected to the highest office in the Supreme Temple of Honor in the United States at the session of that body in New-Haven two weeks ago, will soon announce his appointments for the current year.

Col. George Bliss, counsel for absent Boodler Keenan, appeared in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday and asked Justice Patterson to issue an order requiring Mr. A.J. Whitton, confidential clerk and bookkeeper for the firm of O'Brien Clark to answer several questions he had refused to answer before the Referee.

Crowley, the famous chimpanzee of Central Park, died a little before noon yesterday of pneumonia. As the end drew near weakness compelled him to lie down. He rolled over on his back, drew up his legs, clutched his lewer jaw by the teeth with both hands, uttered a farewell cry of anguish, and his day was over. Next to Crowloy's cage is one occupied by his chimpanzee sweetheart, Miss Kitty O'Brien.
GENEVA, Aug. 31.--M. de Claparedes, the new Swiss Minister to the United Sates, has started for Washington.

A new tariff sheet of special immigrant fares from New-York was issued yesterday, to become effective this morning. The rates to Pacific coast points have been raised somewhat in consequence of the notice issued by the lines of the Transcontinental Association.
The Newark Gaslight Company has a gang of men laying pipes through Harrison for the ostensible purpose of supplying that suburb with gas.
The New-Yorks will play in Boston again today. On the Polo Grounds this afternoon the NewYork Reserves will play the Hackett, Carhart Co. nine.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31.--The three steamship lines which have been competing for the China trade have formed a pool on flour rates.
BOSTON, Aug. 31.--The Boston Commercial Bulletin, in its weekly review of the manufacturing news of the country, will say to-morrow:
The Staten Island Athletic Club lawn tennis players who are competing for the honor of defending the lawn tennis trophy which will be played for on Labor Day continued their trial contests yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--It was announced on the Board of Trade to-day that the well-known firm of Foss, Strong Co., which has long been one of the largest grain-receiving firms upon the board, would go out of business to-morrow.
J.H. Bass of Fort Wayne, the largest manufacturer of car wheels in the world, having factories at Fert Wayne, St. Louis, and Chicago, who is also a large iron miner and producer ...
Primaries for the election of delegates to the Assembly District Conventions on Tuesday were held by the Democrats in all the wards and towns in Kings County last night.

An inspection of the documents issued by the Republican campaign committees must excite the wonder of the inspector as to what the authors and promulgators of these documents think of the American people.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--The Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road has finally decided to reduce freight rates between Chicago and St. Paul to the basis of 40 cents first-class.
A meeting of the Depew Reception Committee was held at noon yesterday at the headquarters of the Republican County Committee on West Twenty-fifth-street.

A correspondent who is "heartily in favor of tariff reform" is troubled by the protectionist argument that under sections 3,019, 3,020, 3,021, and 3,022 "our manufacturer can have returned to him 90 per cent., ...
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31.--It is claimed the Rock Island has cut the rate from Pond Creek to $36 a car, a reduction of $54, and the cut has been met by the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe ...

A special meeting of, the Board of Aldermen was held yesterday in the vain hope of passing the Tax Levy bill before Sept. 1, in compliance with the statutes. Twenty members of the board must vote for the levy, and, as only 16 were present, nothing could be done.
SHAMOKIN, Penn., Aug. 31.--Last evening while a locomotive was standing near Marketstreet crossing on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad it was run into by another locomotive ...
There were two trots decided over the Queens County Driving Park's track at Brooklyn yesterday. The weather was fine and the attendance fair. The following are the summaries:...

Strange noises in an unoccupied house on the Passaic River, near Avondale, N.J., aroused curiosity, and started stories of ghosts. Wednesday evening Charles Caldwell, who has little faith in spooks, determined to ascertain the cause and slept in the building. He had scarcely put out his light before there was a tapping noise on the floor.

Elias Kahn of 714 Sixth-street murdered his wife some time early yesterday morning, by stabbing her with a jackknife, and then attempted self-destruction by cutting open his stomach. Kahn is 62 years of age, and is said to be worth about $40,000.
A service memorial of the Right Rev. Dr. Samuel Smith Harris, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Michigan, who died Aug. 21 at London, was held yesterday afternoon at Grace Church.
BERLIN, Aug. 31.--Emperor William has been appointed an Admiral in the Swedish navy.
On Monday the Knickerbocker Yacht Club's Fall regatta will be held off the clubhouse.

The special race got up by the Larchmont Yacht Club for sloop yachts from 35 to 41 feet in length resulted yesterday in one of the prettiest contests ever seen upon the Sound. So close was it that official measurements had to be made, and the final result was not known at a late hour last night.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 31.--A tremendous explosion of fire-damp, which shook the buildings on the surface, occurred this afternoon in the Mount Pleasant Colliery and blew the tower of the shaft into fragments.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31.--Information more or less official was received at the Gould headquarters in this city to-day to the effect that the magnate had at last decided to construct a grand union station here.

Judge Lawrence yesterday handed down a decision vacating the injunction which was obtained by James M. Hill against Margaret Haberkorn, known upon the stage as Margaret Mather, which restrained her from performing under the management of Gilmore Tompkins or any other person than Mr. Hill.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 31.--The attention of Senator Butler and the Department of Justice at Washington have been called to a disgraceful state of affairs which exists in Edgefield County, in South Carolina, where petty officers of the Federal Government are said to be prostituting their office to replenish their private purse.

When President Duncan of the National Electric Light Association entered the banquet hall of the Hotel Brunswick yesterday morning scarcely a baker's dozen of delegates had assembled. When, however, he called the convention to order the attendance was somewhat ...

The stairbuilders, carpenters, and sash and blind workers employed by the Ackerly Gerard Company, manufacturers of interior Woodwork, in Long Island City, went out on strike yesterday because of the refusal of the firm to permit John Garry, a walking delegate of the Stairbuilders' Union, to go through the shops at dinner time and talk with the men.
To-day's amateur sports are arranged to come off as follows: The Brooklyn cricketers play against the Staten Islanders at Livingston.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 31.--The sensation of the day has been the arrest of Mrs. Thomas Kean of La Sella, this county, widow of the late well known dramatic critic of the Buffalo Courier.

The National Democratic Headquarters will be closed on Monday in honor of Labor Day. At a meeting of the Twenty-third Assembly District Committee of the County Democracy last evening, Edward P. Steers, President of the Twelfth Ward Bank, was selected as district leader in place of Andrew J. White, resigned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31.--Mr. Anderson Gratz of St. Louis was called as the first witness before the House Committee on Manufactures to-day in its inquiry as to the alleged Cotton Bagging Trust. He said he was engaged in the baling stuff business in St. Louis, a member of the firm of Warren, Jones Gratz.
ST. PAUL, Aug. 31.--Work on the Eastern Railway of Minnesota is progressing rapidly, and President Minot expects that line will be completed and ready for traffic before the end of September.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 31.--Mrs. Lizzie Prince of this city, the woman for whose arrest Collector Magone of New-York has issued an order on the charge of bringing contract laborers from England to work in the Logan Silk Mills of this city, has worked for the silk mills for six years.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 31.--From present indications there will be another strike among the flint glass workers to-morrow.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Aug. 31.--A terrific rain, which apparently included a waterspout, fell upon this city last night. Six persons are known to have lost their lives, and $100,000 damage was done.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 31.--John Fillhart, 93 years of age, hanged himself in his barn at Depanville, Jefferson County, last night. His wife had been dead for some time, but he had a happy home with his son. No cause is assigned for the act.
A meeting of citizens will be held in the Board of Works rooms in Jersey City next Thursday evening to consider the question of a new water supply.

BOSTON, Aug. 31.--Tremont Temple was packed to-night to hear Gen. Butler discuss the tariff and the fisheries question at the invitation of the Republicans. Of course, all the old-time Butlerites were there, but there were few leading Republicans on the platform, the ...

Medical Director James Suddards of the United States Navy died yesterday at Atlantic City. Dr. Suddards entered the navy as Assistant Surgeon in 1849. In 1861 he was made Surgeon, from which rank he was promoted to that of Medical Inspector in 1871, and finally became Medical Director on April 5, 1875. At the time of his death Dr. Suddards was President of the Medical Examining Board.
LONDON, Sept. 1.--China refuses to ratify the American treaty restricting immigration.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 31.--The Republicans of the Fifth (Ford's) District have nominated Capt. Charles E. Belknap of Grand Rapids for Congress. This will make the campaign in that district exceedingly lively, as both candidates are very popular, for there can be no question of Ford's renomination.

There was a decided "twist" on No. 2 August oats in the Produce Exchange yesterday, which terminated in a sharp squeeze on shorts. The opening sales were made at 38 cents, followed by sales down to 35 cents.

The Hon. M.F. Tarpey, the National Democratic Committeeman for California, has especial charge of the campaign in that State, and he is conducting an aggressive and lively campaign--distributing documents and sending ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 31.--Although the Cabinet has not officially considered the matter, the impression prevails in official circles that the Government will not retaliate even though the United States should pursue a policy of non-intercourse toward Canada.
PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 31.--Judge Walton in the Supreme Court to-day issued a final decree discharging Receiver S.J. Andrews of the Portland and Ogdensburg Railroad.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 31.--After Gov. Hill had got through talking at the Greene County fair yesterday he came here with Judge Alton B. Parker of the Supreme Court, arriving this morning.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 31.--The bill respecting the agreement between the Northern Pacific Road and the Manitoba Government was read the second time in the Legislature at 4 o'clock this morning and carried by a vote of 27 to 10.
While Republican bosses charge Democrats in the South with preventing negroes from voting, they bring all the pressure they can to bear upon their workingmen to vote for Harrison and Morton.
A circular has been issued by the Passenger Department of the Transcontinental Association, at St. Louis, agreeing on a schedule of commissions to be paid to agents for the sale of tickets.

The cases of the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation, the New-York Merchants' Freight Bureau, (on behalf of some hundreds of retail merchants,) and Francis H. Leggatt Co. against the trunk line railroads have finally been submitted to the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.Y., Aug. 31.--Two men who had come from New-York and were walking into the country for work were struck by a fast express on the Pennsylvania Railroad last night. One, Israel Cohen, was terribly mangled and killed outright, and the other, Louis Greenburg, was internally injured. Both were well-dressed young Jews. Greenburg's people live at 6 Bayard-street, New-York.

BRANFORD, Conn., Aug. 31.--Robert J. Latta, the Branford drug clerk whose carelessness by giving aconite for brandy caused the death of Homer Bishop and Charles Appleby, was taken before a Justice of the Peace for examination to-day.
Personally, I cannot see how any man, unless he acts on what he imagines to be his selfish interest, can fall to be in favor of a revision of the tariff.
BOSTON, Aug. 31.--The suburban hamlet of Cliftondale was unusually excited this morning over the killing of a burglar while he was attempting to enter the large grocery store of Fiske, Price Amerigo.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31.--Gen. Harrison emerged from his seclusion on Middle Bass Island to-day and went to Put-in-Bay to give the public reception which it was presumed the American citizens were pining for.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 31.--The Memphis commercial year closed to-day under most encouraging conditions. The aggregate value of business done was $175,000,000, or nearly $2,200 for every inhabitant. The bank clearings, on a total banking capital of $3,360,000, amounted so nearly $107,700,000 over the preceding year.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 31.--It is stated that a demurrer will be filed to-morrow to the indictment charging Henry S. Ives, George H. Staynor, and E. Wilson Woodruff with embezzlement and grand larceny in connection with the disposition by them of certain securities of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad.

Mr. F.W. Richardson, General Eastern Agent of the Commercial Express, gave up the reins of office yesterday, after nine years of service with the company. He resigned to engage in mercantile business at Troy, and will be succeeded here by J. D. Abrams, who has also been connected with this company for the past 18 months.

John C. Kennedy, the Brooklyn policeman who was sentenced to four years' imprisonment by Judge Moore in 1885 for betraying a young girl, and who escaped from RaymondStreet Jail and was recaptured in Canada, was released from the penitentiary yesterday, his term having expired.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Aug. 31.--Since Aug. 19 the entire delta country has been visited by daily rains, and reports of incalculable damage to the cotton crop have some from various sections with such frequency as to justify the fear that the crop was in imminent danger.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 31.--One of the most frightful runaway accidents which has occurred in this vicinity for years took place on Ferbesstreet this morning and resulted in the probably fatal injuring of Mrs. Capt. J.J. Vandegrift, wife of the oil king, and the serious injury to her daughter, Mrs. Harry Vandergrift, and a niece, Miss Victoria Vandegrift of Jamestown, N.Y.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--A meeting of the traffic managers of the western and southwestern roads, called for the purpose of considering the objections that have been raised to the new transcontinental tariffs, was held at the office of Chairman J.W. Midgley to-day. Commissioner J.S. Leeds of the Transcontinental Association, was present by invitation.

Charles I. De Baum, the Assistant Cashier of the Park Bank, who absconded in April when he was a defaulter to the amount of $95,000, was arrested Thursday night at Stanstead Junction, Province of Quebec, barely 200 feet from the line, by Canadian officers, having been run down by Detective Sergeant Sheridan of Inspector Byrnes's staff.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 31.--Incessant rain here this morning and heavy showers this afternoon made the sport at the fair grounds tame, the track being deep with mud and slashy Gov. ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--Samuel R. Bullock of the firm of S.R. Bullock Co., New-York, railroad and public building contractors, was at the Grand Pacific this morning. In referring to politics, he said he was a Republican, but he deprecated the position of his party on the tariff question.
RINGWOOD, Aug. 31.--Much to the delight of his physician, Dr. Jacobs, and all his relatives, the condition of Robert Garrott shows a decided improvement during the last 24 hours.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 31.--Reports received from along the Northern Pacific for the week ending Aug. 30 indicate the best weather for harvesting purposes, and, as a consequence, the cutting of wheat is well advanced, in some localities being practically finished.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 31.--The Democratic caucuses were held throughout Oneida County to-day, and in several of the wards of Utica resolutions approving the Administrations of President Cleveland and Gov. Hill were adopted. In all delegates to the district conventions were elected favorable to ending Hill delegates to Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31.--The following changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Subsistence Department of the army have been ordered: Capt. William L. Elderkin, Commissary, ordered before Sept. 20 to close up his business at Newport Barracks, Kentucky, and to relieve Capt. John F. ...
MONTREAL, Aug. 31.--The Chief of Police received instructions to-day to raid every bucket shop in the city and arrest every one found therein.

Grand Marshal J.F. Sullivan of the Central Labor Union parade has issued a proclamation to all the trades and labor organizations who intend to participate, reminding the members that, while they may differ in other matters, they are a unit on the industrial question.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31.--United States District Attorney Thomas P. Bashaw entered 12 suits in the United States Court this morning against H.A. Smidt, an Olive-street tailor, for the offense of importing foreign labor, in violation of the statutes.

BOSTON, Aug. 31.--Within the last few days the Treasurers of the various Lake Superior Copper Companies having offices in this city have received overtures from agents of the French syndicate controlling the copper product, looking to an extension of the existing contracts by which the output of these companies is sold to them for a period of 12 years.
The Executive Committee of the German Democratic Organization of New-York met last evening at Germania Hall, 194 Third-avenue.

DETROIT, Aug. 31.--The Detroit Seating Company have filed two chattel mortgages, covering all their stock, machinery, and other personal property. One is for $16,154 18, to A. Ives Son, bankers, and covers six promissery notes; the other runs to a Cleveland firm.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 31.--It was supposed that the question of an unobstructed passage through Way Cross to all points north and west, which had been temporarily stopped Sunday, had been settled once for all and travel had started up again in the most lively fashion after its prohibition for two or three days. But the following telegram upset that idea last night:

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 31.--The first train over the new Derby extension from Derby to Hawleyville was run yesterday. New-Haven will reap great benefits, while Bridgeport will suffer correspondingly by the extended road.
The Coney Island Jockey Club will open its great Fall meeting, which promises to be the most successful in the history of the club, today. The new Futurity track is ready; ...

Samuel Spencer, President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, in company with President J.L. Emmons and General Superintendent Frank S. Gannon of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad, made a tour of inspection ...

ST. PAUL, Aug. 31.--Rumors have been going the rounds of railway circles for some time that a general change in the management of the St. Paul and Duluth Railroad was possible, and since the annual meeting of the stockholders of the road it has been the general supposition that W.H. Fisher would resign his position with the company.

Walter J. Damrosch arrived in this city yesterday on the steamer Lahn from Bremen. He sailed from this side on May 27, and has spent the last three months chiefly in Scotland as a member of Mr. Carnegie's coaching party.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 31.--The Selectmen of Pittsfield appointed E. McA. Learned Tax Collector of this town of Pittsfield for the coming year, because Mr. Prout, the present Collector, who was ...

The difficulty between the tin and sheet iron workers and their employers will probably be set tled to-day. They had given their employers three months' notice that on Sept. 1 they would demand $3 50 per day. Many of the employers have informed Walking Delegate Barr that they are willing to pay the advance asked for. Those employer whom Mr. Barr has not yet seen he believes will fall in line.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31.--The sessions of the Convention of the North American St. George's Union were brought to a close to-day.

Brooklyn's extra race meeting of three day's was brought to a successful close yesterday afternoon. There has been a large attendance, remarkably good racing, and pleasant weather on each one of the three days, so that the club has been able to make a good bit of money out of its venture.
It is now probable that ex-Senator Barnum, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, will preside over the great meeting at Madison-Square Garden in honor of Judge Thurman.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 31.--The Prohibition Congressional Conventions were held in Music Hall to-day, and Elwood G. Macomber of Portsmouth and Anson Greene of Exeter were the respective nominees from the First and Second Districts. Gen. Clinton B. Fisk, the party candidate for President, was present and made an address.

WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 31.--This is the centre of one of the most important industries of the country--the manufacture of the almost endless variety of articles in the useful and ornamental arts composed of brass, or chiefly of brass, and of the other wares employed in connection with brass. The city is beautifully situated among the hills on both banks of the Naugatuck River and wears an air of general prosperity.
DOVER, Me., Aug. 31.--James G. Blaine addressed a large open-air meeting at Foxcroft this afternoon, people coming from all parts of Piseataquis County.

After permitting the Brooklyn politicians to speculate for a month over the successors of Assessors William De Lacy and Augustus Kurth, Mayor Chapin yesterday surprised every one and disgusted not a few by appointing Gen. James McLoer to succeed De Lacy and reappointed Mr. Kurthy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--Warrants were sworn out here to-day charging C.A. Haslet, Louis M. Kane, and Algernon T. Osgood with conspiracy in obtaining $32,500. The complainant is a Mr. Bert, representing the Equitable Debenture and Assets Corporation of London, England.
MONTREAL, Aug. 31.--Charles De Baun, the absconding Cashier of the Park National Bank of New-York, was arrested to-day at Stanstead.
The account of affairs as they exist in the Trunk Line Association and which was published exclusively in THE TIMES yesterday morning, created a decided sensation in railroad circles yesterday.

Charles H. Litchman, who is now known among Knights of Labor as "the creature who has sold himself to the Republican Party," is the same man who was denounced before the General Assembly of the Knights of Labor at Philadelphia in 1884 as "a defaulter and a thief" by James E. Quinn of this city. Few men have had more right than Litchman to describe their careers as checkered.

Schedules in the assignment of Sigmund Eckstein, cigar manufacturer at 161 East One Hundred and Fifth-street, to Louis Cohen, were filed yesterday, showing liabilities, $6,118 04; nominal assets, $5,003 17, and actual assets, $2,748 64.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 31.--Dr. William H. Hornblower, veterinary surgeon, formerly in the employ of the Brooklyn Board of Health, was nominated by Mayor Both to-day for inspecter of milk. Some of the Aldermen objected to his personal habits, and confirmation was lost by a tie vote.

ALBANY, Aug. 31.--The closing day of the Island Park meeting opened with a most lively sensation. Yesterday three heats of the 2:24 class had been trotted, Greylight winning two and Lucille's Baby one. The Boston geld ing was a strong favorite, with the Utica mare second choice.
NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 31.--By the will of Dr. Ebenezer Banks Belden of New-York City, Yale University is designated the residuary legatee to a large estate.

While very much intoxicated yesterday afternoon Samuel Alexander, a seedy-looking young man, who said he lived in New-York, entered a saloon at Smith and Schermerhorn streets, Brooklyn, and asked for a drink.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 31.--Jay Gould continues to enjoy his outing in the Catskills. He takes long rambles each day, and the exercise agrees with him. He says he has an excellent appetite.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 31.--The Lancaster Daily Examiner will publish to-morrow evening reports from threescore correspondents, all practical farmers, in all sections of the country, showing the condition of the tobacco crop up to date.

MONTREAL, Aug. 31.--The steam yacht DashWood, with the owner, the Hon. Smith M. Weed, and family, from Plattsburg, arrived in port last evening in a partially disabled condition, having had a sections of her keel torn away while passing through the Champlain Canal, the waters of which are now exceptionally shallow. The yacht was sent into dry dock for repairs.

LONDON, Aug. 31.--A strangely horrible murder took place at Whitechapel this morning. The victim was a woman who, at 3 o'clock, was knocked down by some man unknown and attacked with a knife. She attempted to escape and ran a hundred yards, her cries for help being heard by several persons in adjacent houses.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 31.--The cricket match between the Gentlemen of Ireland and the Gentlemen of Canada was finished at about 5 o'clock this afternoon, resulting in an easy victory for the Irishmen by one inning and 86 runs.
In spite of Prince FERDINAND'S fresh declarations that he will "stick," it looks now as if a solution of the Balkan problem were at hand which will force him to quit his Bulgarian throne.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 31.--An evening paper says that Steve Brodie, the bridge jumper, and his wife were here yesterday, and that Brodie said they came up to look at the Poughkeepsie Bridge with the idea of Brodie jumping from it. He has concluded to perform the feat from the top of the second span from the west shore on Sept. 29. The top of the span is 212 feet above high-water mark.
Rollin M. Morgan, the Receiver of the Policemen's Relief Fund, was busy yesterday reviewing claims for moneys paid into the fund by retired members of the force.
"Skates" is the unique nickname of a peculiar character employed at Winter's stand in Fulton Market, whose real name is Henry S. Conklin, and whose age is 53 years.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 31.--The Quaker meeting house at Bird-in-Hand, one of the most ancient of the houses of worship belonging to the Society of Friends in the State, was destroyed by fire at an early hour this morning.

A meeting of the delegates appointed by the central organization of the Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association of the State of New-York to attend the convention of the various sections forming the association to be commenced in Buffalo Tuesday held a conference in this city yesterday to complete their preliminary arrangements.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 1.--The Pioneer Press, in an exhaustive crop report, says: "The weather conditions have continued favorable for the wheat crop throughout Minnesota during the past week, and great progress has been made in ...
CRESTON, Iowa, Sept. 1.--A wreck occurred on the Burlington Road east of this place yesterday, in which a number of passengers narrowly escaped.
Four children of Mrs. Annie Mackenzie of Chicago, who was a steerage passenger by the City of Rome, were placed in the ship's hospital a few days before they arrived at New-York.
Still another death was caused by reckless driving yesterday. At about 6:45 o'clock in the morning an old Italian woman, whose ...
Information was received in Newark from Morris Plains yesterday that Silver Downing, one of the most desperate criminals in the State, had effected his escape from the State Asylum at that place.
The thirteenth annual regatta of the Varuna Boat Club of Brooklyn came off yesterday afternoon, and was in every sense a highly successful affair.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Sept. 1.--Nathan Werley, a wealthy farmer living near Sieberlingville, Penn., was found hanging dead in his barn yesterday. He was found by his widow, who bravely cut the rope. Mr. Werley was a man of good standing in the community until recently. It is believed that he committed suicide through fear of disgraceful exposures.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 1.--Preparations for the Allegheny County Centennial Exhibition are going rapidly forward. Liberal subscriptions from citizens are pouring in, and there will be no lack of money to carry out the programme.

BUFFALO, Sept. 1.--An occurrence which caused a great sensation for a few minutes was the sudden death of William H. Rose at the entrance to St. Joseph's Cathedral this morning. Rose had come from Bradford to act as pallbearer for an uncle, also named William Rose, of this city.

AMHERSTBURG, Ontario, Sept. 1.--The steamship Tioga, bound down, ran on the beach here this afternoon just below the docks. She is three feet out of water forward. The accident was caused by the giving way of the steering gear.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Sept. 1.--Premonitory symptoms of a gold fever have been observed here a number of times, and the city has had slight attacks of the genuine disease. Gold was found six miles from the city 10 years ago, and from that find has grown the Ropes gold mine.

DUBLIN, Sept. 1.--Lord Clanricarde's evictors to-day attacked the house of a tenant named Tully at Cloncoe, facing the Shannon. A deep trench had been dug around the building by the occupants and the house had been banked to the roof with clay, stones, and slates.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept 1.--The receipts of wheat in Minneapolis for the crop year ending Aug. 31 were 47,109,490 bushels.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept 1.--Thomas Petitt and Harry Boakes, United States and Canadian court tennis champions, played in a four-handed match today a novel event for this country. Petitt's partner was Foxhall Keene, and Boakes's partner Charles Hickey. The latter were given odds of 15. Petitt and Keene won.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 1.--Secretary Woodward of the State Agricultural Society announces that the Hon. Warner Miller, Gov. Hill, and Mr. Martin Jones, (the Prohibition candidate for Governor,) will attend the annual fair of the society at Elmira from Sept. 17 to Sept. 22. Mr. Miller will be present on the 19th, Gov. ALBANY, Sept. 3.--W.D. Frear went driving with his wife and three children yesterday. The horse suddenly left the road and jumped over a stone wall near Hinsdale. The occupants were thrown out. One child, Maud, aged 4 years, was killed instantly, and the others were injured.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 4.--The city of Leon, which was lately inundated, is again experiencing heavy rains. The railway stations are flooded, and a general inundation is feared. Local train service was suspended this morning. Vera Cruz advices say that the political situation there is intolerable, and that intense excitement prevails. The Governor has been called upon for redress.

CHAMBERLAIN, Dakota, Sept. 4.--Favorable reports continue to arrive from Crow Creek Agency, Something over 100 signatures had been secured, and the signatures of almost every man is expected to be obtained by to-morrow. White Ghost, the head chief is still opposed to the treaty, but is not very radical, and the Commissioners have strong hopes of his signing before they leave the agency.

Mr. Jay Gould came to town yesterday, but he did not get to his down-town office, the doctors insisting that people having business with the sick millionaire should go up town to Mr. Gould's Fifth-avenue residence. And they who were permitted even this much of an opportunity to see "the little man" were exceedingly few. Mr. Gould did not stay in town over night.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Sept. 4.--New-York dedicated three monuments to-day. That of the One Hundred and Eighth Regiment, at Zeigler's Grove, represents a clover loaf, with a recumbent figure of a soldier out on it.
Columbus (Ohio) yesterday reported that the large increase of earnings of the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railway continues, showed a most healthy condition of business.

SIOUX CITY, Sept. 4.--As a result of the recent refusal of the Illinois Central and other roads to approximately give Sioux City a rate permitting competition with St. Paul in Sioux City territory, Sioux City business men will carry their case to the Inter-State Commission. A meeting of jobbers was held yestereday with this end in view. The jobbers will prosecute the case.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., Sept. 4.--All the railroad brakemen on the Manitoba Road in the St. Cloud yards refused to go on the trains this morning, and almost a general standstill of freight traffic is the result.

FARMINGTON, Me., Sept. 4.--The Hon. James G. Blaine addressed an audience of 4,000 people here to-day, speaking principally upon the tariff. WASHINGTON, Sept. 4.--A bill to suppress trusts, introduced by Senator Cullom to-day, proposes the seizure and forfeiture of all shares of stock and all property used in furtherance of the purposes of a trust.
PARIS, Sept. 4.--Sardou is enthusiastic over the Daly troupe, whose performance of a cumbrous and defective piece, he says, was most creditable.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 4.--Rollins Chapel, one of the finest of the Dartmouth College buildings, was badly damaged by fire to night. The building was the gift of the Hon. Edward A. Rollins of Philadelphia, and cost $30,000.

The opposition to the renomination of Gov. Hill, which is felt among thousands of respectable Democrats all over the State, has crystallized, as far as this city is concerned, into a call for a meeting of indignation and protest to be held in the large hall of the Cooper Union next Friday evening.

Mrs. Harry Fisher died quite suddenly Monday afternoon, only a few hours before her husband was to appear as Carlo Donnetto, the Italian in "Waddy Googan" at the Park Threatre. Mr. Fisher was devotedly attached to his wife, and nobody can measure the pain that he suffered behind the scenes, though he went bravely through his part and won the applause of the spectators.
DENVER, COL., Sept. 4.--The State Republican Convention, which met here to-day, chose ex-Gov. John L. Routt for temporary and also permanent Chairman.

LONDON, Sept 4.--This was the first day of the Derby September meeting. The race for Champion Breeders' Foal Stakes was won by the brown filly by Bruce, out of Mrs. Jones. Windfall was second, Bret Harte third. Fourteen horses started. The race for the Peveril of the Peak Stakes was won by Astrologer, with Sweetheart second, and St. Helen third. There were 17 starters.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 4.--The comet discovered by Prof. Barnard of the Lick Observatory, California, yesterday, was verified this morning at Warner Observatory by Prof. Lewis Swift.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 4.--A week ago the President of the Duckworth Building Association detected the Secretary in drawing an order in favor of a member for $180 when the books showed that the member had never paid in anything but the initiation fee.
The Omnium Handicap at a mile and an eighth will be the feature of the card at the Coney Island Jockey Club track to-day, though all the races promise to furnish some excellent sport.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 4.--The first race of the bicycle tournament at the international fair this afternoon was a one-file professional tandem freefor-all, and was won by the Englishmen, F.W. Allard of Coventry and Jack Lee of Nottingham.
SALEM, N.J., Sept. 4.--The election under the new election law took place in Salem County today. Complete returns give 997 majority against license.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 4.--Judge M. B. Koon has just returned from Hillsdale, Mich., where he has been visiting his brother, E.L. Koon, who was associated with Charles Waldron in the Hillsdale Bank.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 4.--The Rev. Thomas Harrison, the "boy preacher," has been assisting in the conduct of the camp meeting in Wesley Grove, near Montgomery, during the past 10 days. CHICAGO, Sept. 4.--The General Managers of the Southwestern Missouri River roads met to-day to reorganize the Southwestern Railway Association on a more substantial basis.
Col. R.E. Peyton, who takes great interest in the celebration of anniversaries of great events in American history, returned to the city yesterday from a trip through the Eastern States.

BUFFALO, Sept. 4.--One hundred and fifty men marched up Main-street this morning behind a German band, which, true to its mission, awakened everybody along the line of march and within two long blocks of either side thereof. At their head was a silk banner bearing in gold letters the words: "United Liquor Dealers' Association of Brooklyn."

The political complexion of the proposed reception to Chauncey M. Depew when he arrives from Europe is rapidly fading out. The politicians will only be there by the invitation of the employes of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 4.--A small sized riot broke out this afternoon in this city between a number of Italians and a contractor name Seymour.

Two years ago an association of firemen, including membership from all over the United states and Canada, was organized in this city. It now numbers some 13,000 members and is conceded to be the largest firemen's organization in the world.
ST. PAUL, Sept. 4.--An unauthenticated rumor was set afloat last evening that President Stickney of the Kansas City line had gathered the St. Paul and Duluth Road under his protecting wing.

Three men were seriously wounded, one probably fatally, during a fight in Felix Carrao's saloon at Third-avenue and Sixty-fifthstreet, New-Utrecht, late on Monday night. Annie Norwalk, who is a waitress in the saloon, was the cause of the row.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Sept. 4.--Mrs. Pierpont Morgan of New-York and some friends, while out among the Thousand Islands to-day, were all thrown into the water by the capsizing of the boat. Mrs. Morgan lost personal jewelry to the value of $15,000. Expert divers are searching for the valuables in 12 feet of water.

Each succeeding year adds a new value to Poor's Manual of the Railroads of the United States. Its independence and reliability being established and having no competitor, it has become the railway text-book of the country. Advance sheets of the volume for 1888 were issued yesterday, showing that at the beginning of this year there were 149,912 miles of track laid in the United States, an increase of 13,080 miles during 1887.

HARTFORD, Coun., Sept. 4.--To-day inaugurated the Grand Circuit Meeting at Charter Oak Park, and a large crowd gathered at the track. The sport was first-class. Four horses beat 2:20 for the first time in their lives, and every heat trotted was for blood. Silver Thread had the call in the betting before the start in the 2:17 pace.

The police of the Union Market station arrested a quartet of shoplifters--two men and two women--on Monday night, after a watch of several weeks. All lived at 234 Rivingtonstreet, and belonged to a gang of shoplifters which was broken up about six months ago.

BANGOR, Me., Sept. 4.--The jury in the case of A.G. Sellon, charged with stabbing and killing a fellow-postal clerk, Jeremiah Sinclair, in a postal car last June, after being out 17 hours reported that they could not agree and were discharged. Sellon was allowed to go under $5,000 bail.

Thomas L. James, Esq., ex-PostmasterGeneral, and Mrs. James sailed on the steamship Lahn this morning for Europe. With the exception of two weeks Mr. James has not been absent from his post of President of the Lincoln National Bank for four years.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., Sept. 4.--Thomas Hawkins and Edward Upton of Suspension Bridge, have been arrested, charged with the heavy jewelry robbery of E. Crayston's jewelry store, at the Bridge, three weeks ago. The evidence is given by a woman, a crony of Hawkins.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 5.--Gen. Harrison resumed his labors to-day after a vacation of two weeks, expressing himself to his friends as feeling refreshed and invigorated by his trip to Middle Bass. The day was quietly spent.
Mrs. Sarah Moore, a prepossessing widow, now nearing 50 years of age, and living at 1,723 Atlantic-avenue, Brooklyn, saw a few days ago the termination of a romance began a quarter of a century ago.

The stock market boomed again yesterday, handsome advances being scored in many quarters. Few stocks of consequence declined. Reading and Lackawanna rose to the highest points they have reached in a long while, all the other coal stocks sympathizing in their movement.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 5.--For the second time within a year the highly contagious and dangerous disease, splenic fever, sometimes termed splenic apoplexy of Texas fever, has been introduced among the herds of Orange County by cattle said to have been brought here from the Buffalo stock yards.

PARIS, Sept. 5.--An express train from Dijon left the rails last night while on its way to Paris, blocking the road. The Italian night mail train ran into the disabled train and was wrecked. Thirty persons were killed and eight injured.

The racing at Yonkers yesterday resulted very unsatisfactorily both to the management and the public. The bookmakers refused to do business on account of the small attendance, and a great many owners refused to start their horses on that account.

LONDON, Sept. 5.--At the opening of the new water works in Limerick to-day Bishop O'Dwyer, who has hitherto been hostile to home rule, spoke strongly in savor of the measure and expressed it as his opinion that Ireland would speedily obtain self-government.

WATERLOO, Iowa, Sept. 5.--Fong Wing, the Chinese laundryman of this city who made application to become a citizen a few days ago in order that he might go back to China to get married and return to America, will probably fail to secure his papers.

NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 5.--Col. George L. Perkins, for 50 years Treasurer of the Norwich and Worcester Railroad, died this evening of old age at the Fort Griswold House, in Groton, where, with his family, he was spending his annual, vacation.

LEXINTGTON, Ky., Sept. 5.--About 2,500 people witnessed the trots at the Paris fair today, although the weather was cloudy and of a most threatening character.
UTICA, N.Y. Sept. 5.--The Republicans of the Third Oneida District have nominated A.B. Baker of Forestport for member of Assembly.
An action for a limited divorce has been begun by Mrs. Catherine V. Murray against her husband, Judge Thomas E. Murray of the Eleventh District Civil Court.
The Hoboken Turtle Club varied its pleasing monotony of turtle soup and steak yesterday with an old-fashioned Rhode Island clambake on its grounds at Gabe Case's.
FOREST CITY, Ark., Sept. 5.--At Millbrook, a railroad station four miles, south of here, unknown parties in ambush fired upon some 30 white men this morning about 4 o'clock, wounding seven of them.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--Louis Larson, a workman for Crane Brothers, met with death in a very unusual way this morning. He crawled into an iron cylinder used for the piston of a hydraulic elevator for the purpose of cleaning it.

Most of the people who placed "In His Power" at the Windsor Theatre last week are very unhappy. The play had not been a great success, even undar George L. Harrison's management, and money was scarce.

Dr. Jacobs of Boston was in attendance constantly and at intervals noted the patient's pulse and respiration.

ROME, Aug. 12.--Deserter, insurgent, threefold murderer and life convict--such is the record of Hamilcar Cipriani, the popular hero of the moment, who has been elected no less than six consecutive times by overwhelming majorities to represent his native city of Ravenna in the Chamber of Deputies, and whose name is a watchword for all the lower classes from one end of the kingdom to the other.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 6.--The Society of the Army of the Tennessee closed its business session to-day.

LONDON, Sept. 6.--Sir Charles Tupper, in a speech at the cutlers' feast at Sheffield tonight referred in terms of high praise to the conduct of Mr. Joseph Chamberlain in connection with the fisheries treaty. He said that no one more acceptable to Americans than Mr. Chamberlain could have been found.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 6.--The Republican State Convention completed its labors today after a three days' session. The following nominations were made: For Treasurer--W. H. Brisbane; Auditor--Louis B. Breckinridge of Kentucky, Holden A. Evans of Florida, Gray F. Scott of West Virginia. George Wedekind and Edward L. Kellogg of New-York, Raymond D. Swigert of Iowa, and Randolph Ridgeley of Georgia.

Dockstader's was opened for the season last evening. After seven months of abeance Mr. Dockstader and his minstrels are at home, and once more jesting and singing to listeners who recognize them as old friends and welcome them with the abundant applause and laughter that seem to belong naturally to them.

The season at the Rockaways virtually ends this week. The Summer of 1887 was the best Far Rockaway has ever known, but that just closing has proved the dullest in 22 years. June and August were fair enough, but July was cruel.

LONDON, Aug. 25.--London is very empty. There are really not more than from four to five millions of people left in it. And the public offices are emptier. Enter what one you will and half the staff will be found holiday making. It is so even in the War Office, and yet next door at the Horse Guards they are as busy as bees.

A baggage blizzard has struck this city, and during the past few days thousands of pieces of luggage have been snowed under. The express companies and transfer companies have had about as much difficulty in doing their work as they had during the great storm of last March.
A little frost struck the stock market yesterday and quotations were generally inclined to shrivel up. St. Paul was the particularly weak sister and slumped easy and materially.
BERLIN, Sept. 6.--The North German Gazette, referring to approaching changes in the imperial departments, denies that certain offices will be withdrawn from the control of Prince Bismarck.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 6.--The Democratic State Convention assembled at 11:35 o'clock. There was a large attendance. The following permanent officers were elected: President--I. W. Drew of Lancaster; Secretaries--A.H. Chase and J.C. Browne of Manchester and W.P. Huntington of Keene. Mr. Drew, on being introduced, was warmly received.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 6.--Some excitement was caused in the grain trade this afternoon by the announcement of a new ruling by the State Grain Inspectors. It has been decided that Minnesota State grades shall be altered so as to admit frosted wheat, of which there is an unusually large proportion this season.

The promoters of the Nicaragua Canal Company had a meeting at their office, 36 Wallstreet, yesterday. There was some discussion on the probability of the bill of incorporation being passed before Congress adjourns.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Chairman Midgeley yesterday submitted to the members of the Pacific Coast Association a communication marked "Directly Private," which throws light upon the methods pursued by the Southern Pacific managers in making their discriminative tariff.

ELLENDALE, Dakota, Sept. 6.--The boiler of Goulette Letson's thrashing outfit exploded last evening. Ten or twelve men were engaged near by, and of this number eight were either killed outright or badly injured.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 6.--Francis Murphy, the temperance apostle, has determined upon a new departure.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 6.--Dr. John M. Crawford, whose translation of "The Kalevala" was reviewed at length in THE TIMES on Monday, has been a resident of this city for 12 years. He came here from Lafayette College, at Easton, Penn., whence he was graduated with much credit as a linguist.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 6.--Gorham Thurber of the Gorham Manufacturing Company, died at his residence at 10 o'clock tonight.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Sept. 6.--Two freight trains loaded with merchandise and running at a rapid rate of speed came into collision on the Kansas City, St. Joseph and Council Bluff Road near this city yesterday. Both were entirely wrecked. The crews escaped by jumping. The loss will reach $100,000.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 6.--The spinners in the Narragansett Mill struck to-day because they were compelled to work overtime in order to make up a few moments lost.

SEWELL, N.J., Sept. 6.--A farmhouse near here was burned to the ground about 1 o'clock this morning, and Miss Mary Morgan, a sister of Mrs. Clark, whose husband owned the house, perished in the flames. The origin of the fire is unknown.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Sept. 6.--A flood in the New River to-day carried away the big iron bridge of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad at Grand View, involving a loss of $50,000. A good deal of other damage is reported.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6.--Texas fever has made its appearance among cattle in the western suburbs of this city, and is killing off fine milch cows at a terrible rate. It is claimed the disease was brought here by several herds of Texas cattle which were driven from the North St. Louis stock yards to slaughter houses.
The congregation of the Bedford-Street Synagogue in Newark are excited over a dispute for the possession of a pew. Henry C. Dinglewitz, a year ago, paid $3 for a pew and was allowed to occupy it.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 6.--To-day the Chautauqua County Fair closed a successful four day's session. This afternoon Bishop J.H. Vincent of Buffalo delivered an address to a large audience. The feature of this year's fair was six exhibits on immense floats of the products of every department of the farm by as many grangers in this county.

Never was gag law more strictly applied than by the Pideock henchman who occupied the chair and obeyed every direction of his chief.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6.--Drafts--Sight, at par; telegraphic, 5 cents.
