NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 6.--The body of Louis Chappelle, the little son of Capt. Chappelle of the Whitehall canalboat. Burleigh, which was loading at the Pennsylvania coal dock in this city, was found to-day floating in the river. It is supposed that in crossing from one boat to another he fell from the deck and was drowned.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 6.--The third day's trotting at Charter Oak was attended by nearly if not quite 10,000 people. The track was fast, but the weather rather chilly. A great deal of indignation was expressed on almost all sides at the judges' decision in awarding the final heat of the 2:18 class to J.B. Richardson instead of to Governor Hill, and the officials undoubtedly erred in their decision.

The reports concerning the extermination of game in the Adirondacks are declared groundless by the Albany Journal, which asserts that the game laws are being strictly enforced and that a good effect has been produced by the imprisonment of a few offenders.

Elmsmere, the country home of Lester Wallack, was turned yesterday into a house of mourning. Its master lay dead in his chamber. The shock of the sudden bereavement unnerved his family and they were inconsolable. From the hour of the apoplectic attack on Wednesday morning there was but a chance of life.

SUNBURY, Penn., Sept. 6.--Philip A. Huber, the express agent, was convicted to-day and sentenced to three years at hard labor in the county jail. He was charged with stealing $29,000 from the Adams Express Company in August, 1886.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Sept. 6.--A terrific explosion of gas occurred at the Philadelphia and Reading Company's Monitor Colliery at noon to-day. A boy named Bryan was struck by flying timber and fatally injured. Assistant Superintendent Charles Brecker and a miner named O'Neill were seriously injured. The damage to the colliery is extensive. The gas was ignited by workmen engaged in turning a current of air into the adjoining Merriam Colliery.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 6.--No new developments were made in the passenger rate situation to-day and it was claimed by all lines except the Burlington that nothing had been offered in the way of round-trip tickets to Columbus, Ohio, at less than $14.25.
TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 6.--Oarsman Hamm arrived in this city very quietly this evening. He is supposed to meet Rogers, O'Connor's backer, in Buffalo to arrange a match with Teemer to-morrow.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 6, via. Galveston.-- Trains on the Mexican Central Railroad are running regularly and the road is in perfect order. Advices state that the Nazas River fell nearly a foot last night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Judge McAllister of the Appellate Court to-day decided an interesting case, involving the legality of a contract for the option of purchase of a controlling interest in the North Chicago City Railway Company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--George R. Blanchard to-day tendered his resignation as Chairman of the Central Traffic Association at a special meeting of the General Managers, which had been called for the purpose of considering the general situation and of "hearing a communication from the Chairman."

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 6.--Gen. William Terry, one of the most prominent citizens of Southwest Virginia, was drowned while attempting to cross a swollen creek near Wytheville yesterday. He was nearly 75 years of age and succeeded Stonewall Jackson in the command of the famous Stonewall Brigade of the Confederate Army.
PITTSBURG, Sept. 6.--The international cricket match between the Gentlemen of Ireland and the Pittsburg eleven began at Brushton to-day.

LONDON, Sept. 6.--There is nothing in London to-night to talk about but the production of "She" at the Galety.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Detroit had very little trouble in hitting Krock to-day, and they were assisted in scoring by Chicago's fielding errors, which in almost every case were very costly.

John McManus, white, 15 years old, and Lloyd Chase, colored, 13 years old, both of Jersey City, got into an argument about politics last night on Essex-street. McManus kicked Chase in the shins three times and Chase drew a clasp knife from his pocket and stabbed McManus in the breast, inflicting a serious wound. McManus was sent to the city hospital and Chase was arrested.
HAVANA, Sept. 6.--The cyclone of Tuesday last will be long remembered on this island. It was terribly destructive to both life and property. The gunboat Lealtad, lying at Batabano, ...
MATANE LIGHT, Quebec, Sept. 6.--The steamer Bratsberg is still ashore above this point. The sea is breaking clear over her. The tug Lake and a wrecking schooner are with the Bratsberg.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6.--The Chinese Exclusion bill has again failed to pass in the Senate for lack of a quorum, although a majority of the Senators were present when the vote was taken. Mr. Sherman and Mr. Hoar do not believe in rushing ...
The annual statement of the Trustees of the British Museum calls attention once more to the growing difficulty of accommodating "readers."

PALMER, Mass., Sept. 6.--The strike at the works of the Palmer Carpet Company terminated to-day and the mills have started up. President Dewey conceded the old price of 5 cents per yard, but declined to reinstate Broderick, the discharged weaver.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 6.--The American firemen from Poughkeepsie, N.Y., were treated yesterday to an exhibition by the Montreal Fire Brigade on the Champ de Mars, with which they expressed themselves highly delighted.

DALHOUSIE, New-Brunswick, Sept. 6.--The bark Kesmark, 627 tons, of St. John, was burned at Cambellton to-day, with her cargo. She was owned by Henry O'Leary and was loading lumber at his mill. In a few days she would have sailed for the River Plate.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 6.--The great sharpshooting contest of the Division of the Atlantic at Fort Niagara has ended. The final scores were made yesterday afternoon, and the men who did not earn a place on the army team were packing their gripsacks to-day and taking their departure to their different posts ...
At the monthly meeting of the Trustees of the Actors' Fund of America yesterday the death of Lester Wallack was the one subject to which all conversation eventually turned.

"D.F.O."--As far as is known he was killed at Khartoum.
Policeman Andrew McCormick of the Flushing-avenue station, Brooklyn, received his month's pay on Friday morning and immediately disappeared. He has not been seen since.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 6.--Heavy frosts occurred in the Catskill Mountains and in portions of Ulster, Delaware, Greene, and Sullivan Counties this morning. At the Hotel Kaaterskill the thermometers registered 2 below the freezing point and ice formed in shallow pools.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 6.--There was no material change reported in the coke situation to-day, The operators say that orders have been placed for this month at $1 per ton, but that there may be a slight advance in the selling price by next month.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 6.--Contrary to all expectations Mr. William R. Merriam was to-day, on the sixth ballot, nominated for Governor at the Republican State Convention. The result is all the more surprising from the fact that the McGill ad Scheffer men were supposed to be willing to unite on anybody to defeat him.

WATERTOWN, Sept. 6.--This little city is the home of the busiest bees in New-York north of the line of the Central Railroad. It would be difficult to find a drone on any of its street corners. The water power furnished by the Black River is unsurpassed. It drives nearly a score of wood pulp and paper mills, whose products are marketed at this point.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Sept. 6.--Mrs. Rebecca Snyder, who is thought to be one of the oldest persons in the State, celebrated her one hundred and third birthday a few days ago. She recently attended the farmers' picnic in Wantage Township, driving a distance of five miles.
ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, Sept. 6.--An outbreak is feared from the Navajo Indians. A squad of soldiers started out from Fort Wingate to arrest whisky peddlers, when a large force of Navajos ...
CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Mrs. John Noveck of 16 McMullen Court, found herself without food or money to buy it for her two children, and drowned herself in the Chicago River this morning.

RICHMOND, Texas, Sept. 6.--As the outcome of the attempted assassination of H.H. Frost several negroes, including C.M. Ferguson, the District Clerk of Fort Bend County, were ordered to leave the county forever by a mass meeting of white citizens.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6.--The Bagging Trust has advanced the price another cent per pound, making the range from 11 to 13 . It is claimed a still further advance is to be made soon.

WATERLOO, Iowa, Sept. 6.--Judge Ney, under the Iowa prohibitory law, decides that a man cannot lawfully manufacture cider for use in his own family, and instructs the Grand Jury to indict, if they find that such a thing has been done.

LONDON, Sept. 7.--The Standard comments mildly on Sir Charles Tupper's speech at Sheffield. It says the fact that England and Canada are bound to act together in the matter of the fisheries question cannot be too explicitly announced or too clearly understood.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 6.--Complaints are being filed before the Iowa Railway Commissioners under Sections 18 and 19 of the new law, alleging oppressive rates by the roads. The Davenport case was opened to-day, but only arguments were heard.

MONTREAL, Sept. 6.--A son of Mr. Dupuy, a seed merchant of this city, was on a shooting trip at North Wakefield with a friend named Brissette, yesterday. As Brissette was aiming at a plover young Dupuy rose to fire at the same moment and received the charge in the back of his head. He is not expected to recover.

The Paris correspondent of the Daily Telegraph has had an interview with the apostle of filth, with the object of obtaining from him a contribution to the columns of correspondence in that journal as to whether marriage is a failure or not.

MEXICO, Sept. 6.--At 8:45 o'clock to-night occurred here one of the heaviest recorded shocks of earthquake. Houses swayed and walls cracked. People rushed into the streets to pray, and there was for a few moments much apprehension. The phenomena was preceded by high winds and dust storms.

FOREST CITY, Ark., Sept. 6.--The most bitter campaign ever recorded in the history of St. Francis County was rounded up yesterday morning by the shooting of seven white men at the Bonair schoolhouse, near Millbrook. The Fusionists are strong in the county of Millbrook, which is heavily Democratic.

Railroad earnings complete for August were reported in Wall-street yesterday as follows: Manitoba, $790,000, an increase of $105,000; Ohio Southern, $51,398, an increase of $4,197; Mobile and Ohio, $188,774, a decrease of $10,575; Alton and Terre Haute branch lines, $77,990, a decrease of $6,710.

Gov. Hill left for Albany at 6 o'clock last evening, accompanied by Col. Rice, his private secretary. He was very busy during the day. Almost as soon as he had eaten breakfast he sent for Mr. Croker, and they had a long conference.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 7.--Traffic Manager Hannaford of the Northern Pacific is on his way to New-York, and it is said that he was hurriedly summoned there by General Manager Oakes.

ST. PUAL, Minn., Sept. 7.--The crop report of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company for the week ending yesterday says that the thrashing has not yet become general enough along the Northern Pacific lines to form an accurate opinion of the actual yield or grade.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 7.--Although the cool weather was accompanied with a continual drizzling rain, an attendance of at least 3,500 witnessed the trot for the 2:50 class at the Paris Fair Grounds to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7.--J.L. Palmer, Chairman of the Arkansas Prohibition State Executive Committee, claims that 40 counties of Arkansas have gone against license, and says that whisky had a great deal to do with the raid on the ballot boxes at the State Capitol. The returns carried away were from precincts which have large Probibition majorities.

ABERDEEN, Dakota, Sept. 7.--Reports of the losses and experiences during the great prairie fire in Northern Edmunds County which started Wednesday night continue to come in. Most of the region burned over is sparsely settled, and the damage is, therefore, comparatively light.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 7.--Henry S. Ives and George H. Stayner arrived in this city last night and took rooms at the Grand Hotel without registering.
The depth is announced of Gen. Riguelme, formerly Captain-General of Cuba, Granada, and Catalonia.

The horses comprising Messrs. Appleby Johnson's string of racers will be sold at the Sheepshead Bay track to-day, and the sale will mark the final dissolution of the well-known firm, its members having separated as bookmakers at the close of the Monmouth meeting.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Sept. 7.--Miss Ada Flynn, a handsome and accomplished young woman, was murdered yesterday at the house of her grandfather, Alexander Traxell, near Glasgow, Penn. Recently as attempt was made to rob Mr. Traxell, and the general supposition is she was killed by persons bent on robbery. The murder was committed in daylight during the absence of the family.

The members of the Association of American Cemetory Superintendents, in convention at the Clarendon Hotel, in Brooklyn, have been discussing various topics of interest to their business. Among the papers read was one on lot inclosures.

The funeral of Mrs. David Crawford took place yesterday at Southfield House, Southfield, N.Y., the old homestead of Peter Townsend, her father.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 7.--The National Association of Stationary Engineers this afternoon elected R.C. Smith of New-York President and John Fehrenbatch of Cincinnati Vice-President.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 7.--Another day of sorrow and depression. That this would prove a "Black Friday" is now a foregone conclusion. Up to 1 o'clock 40 new cases had been reported, with five deaths and several patients in a precarious state. This large report and the countless rumors in circulation add much to the distress ans alarm of the people.
The counterfeits of one and five dollar silver certificates which have been in circulation for several weeks past are being passed upon unsuspecting persons in large quantities.

The National Board of Marine Underwriters has addressed a letter to the New-York Cotton Exchange stating very clearly its position in regard to the use of a different kind of bagging for covering cotton bales from that in use heretofore.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 7.--The longshoremen's strike in Fernandina resulted in violent demonstrations yesterday. The Governor has ordered State troops there from Gainesville and Ocala and called out also the Nassau Rifles of Fornandina. The town has been placed under martial law, and 50 rioters were arrested.

Mr. Ross Fraser, who, accompanied by a collie dog, started from Edinburgh on Aug. 15 to walk to London in eight days, an average of about 50 miles per day, arrived in London last evening about 8 o'clock.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 7.--E. Strachan Cox, the alleged Central Bank wrecker, who is now standing his trial here for various charges of fraud and swindling, and whose bail was fixed at the enormous sum of $56,000, at which figure sureties were unobtainable, is now enjoying temporary liberty.

The pall bearers selected for Lester Wallack's funeral are: Joseph Jefferson, Henry E. Abbey, W.J. Florence, William Henderson, R. M. Field, Col. John A. McCaull, Theodore Moss, A.M. Palmer, Leonard W. Jerome, Alexander Taylor, Gen. W.T. Sherman, the Hon. Abram S. Hewitt, Edmund C. Stanton, Judge John R. Brady, Dr. Robert Taylor, and John Stow.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 7.--The Chicago Lumber Company of this city was attached today by Howell, Jewett Co. of Chicago for $113,686. It is understood that a number of other attachments will be served on them to-morrow. The company has $100,000 worth of lumber here and several yards in Kansas.
Detective Sergeant Philip Reilly of the District Attorney's office arrested Deputy Sheriff J.P. Reilly and took him to the District Attorney's office yesterday.
NEWTON, N.J., Sept. 7.--A most audacious robbery was committed in the Post Office of this place last night during a jollification in the vicinity.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 7.--A special from Havana says: The hurricane which has just swept over this city surpasses anything experienced for many years.

In order to have their accounts passed upon by the court as Trustees under the will of William B. Astor, Charles F. Southmayd, Philip Kissam, and Henry Day have brought a suit in the Supreme Court against all interested in their Trusteeship.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 7.--William Turn bull of New-York, who for many years was at associate of William H. Vanderbilt, and who died at the United States Hotel to-day, was well known in Saratoga, and many expressions on sorrow are heard on every side over his sudden death.

European buying orders were executed on an unusually liberal scale in the New-York stock market yesterday with the effect of causing a general advance in nearly the entire list.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 7.--A servant girl employed in a family at Upper Nyack distinguished herself as a heroine this morning in a desperate struggle with a burglar. Charles T. Harvey, a New-York business man, has his home in a large and attractive place at Upper Nyack, near the northern limit of that village, where he lives all the year round with his family, going to his business daily.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 7.--It is again reported that the Manitoba Road is negotiating for a purchase or Jease of the Emerson branch of the Canadian Pacific, with a view of making a Manitoba connection. This report is strengthened by a telegraph message received to-day by Biggs, legal adviser of the Manitoba Government, summoning the officials of the Manitoba Road to a meeting.

DETROIT, Sept. 7.--Gen. Russell A. Alger of this city has consented to deliver the enlogy on Gen. Sheridan at the annual meeting of the Society of the Army of the Cumberland, of which Gen. Sheridan was President. The meeting will be held at Chicago Sept. 19.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 7.--J.J. Belden was unanimously renominated for Representative in Congress for the Twenty-fifth District by the Republicans today. Belden made a long speech to show that the putting of salt on the free list would greatly injure the interests of this section.

The Board of Street Opening and Improvement convened in full session yesterday for the first time since Aug. 3, disposed of a mass of small business, and devoted some time in the consideration of the Elm-street improvement and the High Bridge Park. The Elmstreet improvement came up on a collateral ...
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 7.--Frank McCain and Pearson Eubanks, 14 and 18 years old, respectively, fought a duel with knives on the high way near Chickahah, Ark., on Wednesday last.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Sept. 7.--Something of a sensation was created in this quiet little town to-day by the arrest of a combination of counterfeiters who have been successfully posing as a respectable family.

United States District Attorney of Brooklyn, Mark D. Wilbur, read an exhaustive paper on the tariff before the Reform Club at 12 East Thirty-third-street last night. M.M. Friend presided at the meeting and there were present about 50 members of the club.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 7.--The Conservative demonstration at Beaverton yesterday was attended by 2,500 persons. Sir John Macdonald was not present, but sent a telegram saying that important State business would prevent him from leaving Ottawa at present. Ministers Tupper and Foster were present and made addresses, which were firm, dignified, and moderate in tone.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 7.--At the meeting of the Cincinnati Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamestown, Dr. Iliff, Superintendent of the Utah Mission, made a stirring address which aroused the good oldfashioned Methodist feruor of his audience.

A British Cabinet Minister, the Duke of RUTLAND, is quoted as saying that "England and Canada, united in a just cause, can stand a good deal more bluster than that which has just been addressed to them."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7.--Second Lieut. B.W. Dunn, Third Artillery, has been detailed to duty at the Pennsylvania Military Academy. Chester, Penn., relieving Second Lieut. George T. Bartlett, Third Artillery: Capt. H.P. Purrine, Sixth Cavalry, has been granted one month's additional leave of absence; Major John Jo. Upham, Fifth Cavalry, has been granted leave of absence for six months.

In St. Petersburg if a policeman is proved to have dealt a prisoner a blow Gen. Gresser punishes him severely. The constables in St. Petersburg are armed with revolvers which are unloaded and swords wich are seldom drawn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7.--The President to-day vetoed eight private pension bills, all of which originated in the House. The first granted a pension to Mrs. Jane Potts, as the widow of a soldier who enlisted in 1861 and was mustered out in 1865. It appears that he was taken prisoner and endured for a long time the hardships of prison life.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 7.--The State Capitol Board, consisting of the Governor, Secretary of State, Treasurer, Land Commissioner, and Controller, yesterday unanimously adopted a resolution refusing to receive the building, claiming that it is not built in accordance with the terms of the contract.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 7.--3-yearold stallion Whitewood, who trotted a mile in 2:24 on a half-mile track at Adams on July 4, and who was regarded as a very promising colt, died at Carthage this morning from inflammation of the bewels. His owner, Rufus White of Adams, recently refused $7,500 for the colt.

BOSTON, Sept. 7.--From all parts of Northern and Central New-England come reports of killing frosts in the last two nights that have done incalculable damage to growing crops. Thousands of farmers are mourning the loss of valuable crops, like corn, cranberries, grapes, ...

LONDON, Sept. 7.--In a letter Mr. Gladstone says: "Were the sentiments of the present generation of Irish Protestants unitedly such as those their forefathers held a century ago, all opposition to home rule in England would melt away like morning vapor in the sun."

BANGOR, Me., Sept. 7.--Whitney and Foster, the New-York crooks who with a third man robbed Peter Bennett of $31,000 last December, were today sentenced respectively to ten years, and eight years' hard labor in State prison.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 7.--People living near the Shawangunk Mountains are particularly proud of the many charms of that region. One of the cozy little villages situated at old Shawangunk's base, along which flows the Delaware and Hudson Canal, is Alligerville.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 7.--For eight innings to-day the outlook was a trifle gloomy for New York's Giants, but in the ninth they went to the front and won another game on the home stretch. Shreve pitched a good game, and until the last inning the New-Yorks were unable to gauge his curves with any degree of success.

At about 8 o'clock last evening a fire, the origin of which is unknown, was discovered in the hallway of the first floor of Joseph Paton's three-story brick and wood tenement house at 104 East Broadway, which was damaged to the extent of about $1,000.
SAG HARBOR, Long Island, Sept. 7.--Mrs. Harriet Beecher Stowe was prostrated a few days ago with an attack of apoplexy, and since then she has been confined to her bed.

"We are taking oysters right out of Delaware Bay and shipping them to Liverpool regularly," said James F. Powell, the well-known oyster dealer, at Sprace-street wharf yesterday afternoon. This remark developed the fast that American oysters have been shipped to England for many years past.

BERLIN, Sept. 7.--Emperor William arrived at Dombrowka this morning. He was received by the military and municipal authorities. His Majesty proceeded at once to the ground at Konarezevo, where the army manoeuvres will be held.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The Glen Falls Republican will announce a change of owners in its next issue. H.M. Harris, who has been editor and proprietor for 28 years, has sold out to Charles H. Buck, formerly of the New-York Gazette and Whitehall Times.

LONDON, Sept. 7.--The steamship Ambrose, (Br.,) Capt. Bisson, sld. from Para for New-York yesterday.

LOCKPORT, Sept. 7.--The Lockport wheelmen held their annual tournament to-day and the city was gayly decorated in honor of the event. The weather was perfect and quite warm. The parade was held in the morning.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 7.--A terrible boiler explosion occurred about noon to-day at Ingham Mills, a small place about four miles from here. Adam Keiser, Jr., and Arthur Leavitt, each 17 years old, were killed.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 7.--Work was begun last Monday on the construction of the Wharton Valley Railroad, from New-Berlin, the present terminus of the New-Berlin Branch of the Ontario and Western Railroad, to the village of Edmeston, Otsego County, a distance of seven miles.

Prince Bismarck has been seriously out of health for the last two months. He was much tried by the Emperor William's death and by the conflicts which incessantly prevailed during the reign of his successor.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 7.--The last day's racing at Charter Oak Park was well attended. The weather and track were fine. The postponed 2:20 paace was first called, with El Monarch selling as slight favorite in the pools. Roy Wilkes won the first heat.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 7.--The day with Gen. Harrison was quiet and uneventful. The General gave the most of his time to his correspondence, and it is presumed that he is at work on his letter of acceptance.

PLAINFELD, N.J., Sept. 7.--When Horace and Louis Van Nest were arrested and imprisoned some months ago for arson, citizens thought they would have no more trouble with fire bugs. There was a fire in a row of buildings on East Front-street on Wednesday night, ...

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 7.--The will of the late Christopher Meyer, which has been probated, was to-day given to the press. The codicil to the will is now under contest in the courts. It does not in any way affect the bequests.

News was brought by the steamer Aller of the North German Lloyds, which arrived from Bremen yesterday, that she had passed the steamship Nevada of the Guion Line about 257 miles from Sandy Hook disabled and in tow of the Hamburg-American steamship Polaria, bound for New-York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7.--Morgan Harvey and B.W. Greenacre, merchants of Natal, South Africa, are in the city. Mr. Harvey went to Africa in 1850, when the flourishing city of Natal existed only on paper. "Our progress has been very great," said he, "but not so great as your people would have made.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 7.--A farmhouse on the estate of Thomas Carroll, about two miles south of Milford, Del., took fire about midnight, and William Hopkins, 50 years old, and his little 5-year-old daughter perished in the flames. Hopkins's three other children and his housekeeper escaped from the burning building.

A remarkable siege has just been sustained by a villa at Passy, the owner of which is away in the country. Three burglarious youths entered the place and pillaged the house from ground floor to garret.
Steamship P. Caland, (Dutch,) Potjer, Amsterdam 13 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Funch, Edye Co.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7.--The question of whether the new rates governing transcontinental traffic have come to stay or not continues to agitate Chicago railroad men. At the present time they are only partially in force, the roads leading westward from this city having adopted ...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 7.--Maxwell, the murderer, who was prolific of sensations while alive, seems to retain the power to produce them after death. At 3 o'clock this morning two men attempted to resurrect the murderer's body in Belle Fountain Cemetery. After-the-execution Maxwell's body was placed in a vault.

About 100 citizens of Jacksonville met in one of the parlors of the Grand Central Hotel yesterday afternoon and formed themselves into an association for the purpose of aiding the people at home. Major Joseph H. Durkee, a retired real estate broker of Jacksonville, ...
MADISON, Ind., Sept. 7.--A vicious horse bit off the top of the head of the 3-year-old son of Albert Bantas, at Bragtown, near here, yesterday, causing instant death.
RINGWOOD, N.J., Sept. 7.--Robert Garrett's condition showed very little improvement to-day. It may be said that he is no worse and no better than he was yesterday.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 7.--Meat Inspector McCutcheon of this city is in Chicago investigating the meat sent to Pittsburg. In three scab pens he found 60 head of cattle collected.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7.--The shaft and bronze figure of the Grant Monument for this city were placed in position today and cemented, after which the figure was veiled for the present. A movement is now on foot to erect a similar monument to the late Gen. Sheridan in the block south of where the Grant Monument stands, in Twelfth-street.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 7.--A chilling rain set in early this evening and interfered somewhat with the plans made to receive th Hon. Warner Miller. He was met at the station by a procession ...

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 7.--A lively row broke out this morning among the Italians employed here on the sewers, and for an hour or more knives, clubs, bricks, stones, , played very conspicuous parts. The row started in the street near the steamboat dock, ...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 7.--The steamer Alpha is now being prepared at the Cunard's wharf for her first trip to Bermuda, Jamica, and Turk's Island under the new company. She will leave on Saturday of next week. Arrangements for the purchase of the Beta from the Cunards by the same company are about completed.

SHERBROOKE, Ontario, Sept. 7.--The case of Charles I. De Baun of the National Park Bank of New-York City was again before the court to-day. Assistant District Attorney Lindsay of New-York and Mr. Marshall, clerk of the National Bank of Baltimore, were examined. The case was then adjourned until Tuesday. De Baun will not yet permit any one to interview him.
After two or three days of weary search a Canadian named Williams, living near St. Thomas, located his eloping wife here in Detroit.

Cool weather has arrived, and the man who dresses tastefully has begun to look about him for different articles of apparel which distinguish the well-dressed man. The man about town who wears any hat of Knox's style can be readily recognized.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Sept. 7.--News reached here to-day from Tishomingo, the capital of the Chickasaw Nation, that serious trouble is expected to break out any moment among the Guy and Byrd factions over the election.
Rudolph Muek had the misfortune to see an affray in Bayonne a few days ago, and he was taken into custody as a witness. Bail was demanded, but he could not furnish it.

Posthoff, $38,321; Ernest Greef, $7,634; ...

A fortunate isle is Labuan, according to Gov. Hamilton; for the health of the island is good, the poorer classes know nothing of actual poverty, and the total number of persons in the jail is only nine.

EL PASO, Texas, Sept. 7.--The work of building the El Paso, Kansas City and Mexican Railroad has been begun in earnest, and several large construction gangs are at two points, ten and five miles north of the city, respectively.

The members of Conterno's Band have lost patiance waiting for pay that is due them by the State, and are clamoring loudly for it. On June 30 Mr. Conterno and his band were engaged to accompany the Ninth Regiment to Gettysburg.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 7.--Grand Master F.P. Sargeant of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, reached this city to-night to attend the Convention of the brotherhood, which meets here on Monday.
PITTSBURG, Sept. 7.--A third division of the Pittsburg, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad has been constitued and goes into effect to-day.
Princess Beatrice contributed two exceedingly meritorious paintings by herself to the Amateur Art Exhibition at Ryde.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7.--A bomb was found this afternoon by workmen at George F. Kimball's glasshouse, at Wabash-avenue and Congress-street.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 7.--At Greenville, Tenn., to-day, George Van Huss, a prominent farmer, was killed by one of his laborers named Ledford. They were quarreling about a tobacco bled to death before assistance arrived.
LOWER BRULE AGENCY, Dakota, Sept. 7.-- Opinion among the Inidans is about evenly divided on the Sioux bill. A prominent chief in opposition is Left Hand Thunder.

Judge Thurman has fully recovered from the attack of cholera morbus which prevented him from speaking at the great meeting on Thursday night, and more than that he has made arrangements with the National Democratic Campaign Committee to revisit New-York on or about Oct. 15 and speak to the assembled multitudes which his presence will again call together.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 7.--Advices from Richmond, Texas, are to the effect that the negroes ordered to leave Fort Bend County for the attempted assassination of H.H. Frost will resist.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 7.--The Long Branch Law and Order League has secured evidence against several druggists who have been selling liquors by the glass during the Summer. This is contrary to one of the sections of the high license and local option law of last Winter. The evidence secured by the League will be submitted to the Monmouth County Grand Jury next month.
In some of the districts the County Democracy held conventions last evening and elected delegates to the State Convention at Buffalo.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 7.--In the shooting at the Rideau Ranges in the Dominion Rifle Association matches the standing of the teams in the Dominion match was: First, Tenth Royal Granadiers: second, Sixty-third Battalion; ...

ALBANY, Sept. 7.--Outside the officeholders in the State departments, the Democrats of Albany County are against the renomination of Gov. Hill. The phalanx which went to Chicago when Clevelend was first nominated at its meeting last evening adopted resolutions approving the course of the National Administration, but said not a word about Mr. Hill's course.

BOSTON, Sept. 7.--The steamer Hibernian, from Glasgow, reports the death at sea from apoplexy of Ship Surgeon Nivens. He belonged in Scotland. On the same day Mrs. Margaret Lynstry, passenger, of this city, died of heart disease.

The denunciation of Mayor Chapin of Brooklyn by the Kings County Democratic General Committee on Monday night has frirhtened the men who proposed it more than it has affected the Mayor. No sooner did the affair get into the papers and its full significance became apparent than the "leaders" began ...

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 7.--The time for John Teemer of McKeesport to answer the challenge of William O'Connor to row for the single scull championship of America expired at noon to-day. By thus failing to come to time the champion renounced all claim to the title. This makes O'Connor champion oarsman of America. It is now likely that a match will be arranged between Gaudaur and O'Connor for the championship.

The head of the Franciscan Order in France has memorailized the Pope in favor of the beatification of Joan of Arc. This will probably lead to a renewal of an old and embittered dispute between the French Catholics and the French Radicals.
A curious old marriage custom, which is still widely prevalent in Brittany, was recently interpreted in a novel and amusing manner.

ANDOVER, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The Allegany County Democratic Convention, which met to-day at Wellsville, elected the following delegates to the State Convention: A.E. Cowles, Henry McIntosh, and Chester R. Hopper, Charles Dauteimont of Angelica was nominated for member of Assembly. The convention warmly indorsed the President.

HAVANA, Sept. 7.--Matanzas reports that, in addition to the destruction of property there by the cyclone on Tuesday last, three persons were killed. Much damage was also done in Cardenas and Caibarien.

CULTER, Ind., Sept. 7.--For the fourth time this place was the scene of a terrific explosion last night. Dynamite was placed under the Post Office and that structure literally blown to atoms. A large quantity of dynamite was found yesterday morning under the hotel, with matches half burned. A strong gale undoubtedly extinguished the matches.

The Brooklyn Republicans will open the campaign on the night of Sept. 20 with a mass meeting at the Clermont-avenue rink. Warner Miller has promised to be present.
Cappa's Seventh Regiment Band will play on the Mall in Central Park at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 7.--The match between Mr. Wood of London and Mr. Hyman for the lawn tennis championship was played this afternoon in the presence of a large and fashionable company. Hyman won in straights, 7--5, 8--6, 6--2, and thus still retains the championship.
VIENNA, Sept. 7.--It is reported here that Prince Bismarck will accompany Emperor William to this city.
HALIFAX, Sept. 7.--The courts have unseated Gen. Laurie, member for Shelburne in the House of Commons, for irregularities by his agents.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Sept. 7.--The Matamoras Cronista of to-day publishes an article in which it suggests that all foreign residents of that place who dared critcize the late farcical Mexican quarantine by expelled from the county as pernicious foreigners.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 7.--Fire broke out in the great Yuengling brewery at Fifth and Mahantongo streets this morning. The fire was occasioned by the overflow of a caldron of boiling pitch in the cooper's shop. John Aller, a workmen, was terribly burned about the head and body. The firemen succeeded in confining the flames to the cooper's department. The loss is not yet estimated, but covered by insurance.

Tammany Hall's Committee on Organization met last evening in full numbers. Sheriff Grant presided. It made final arrangements for the attendance of the members of the organization at the Democratic State Convention at Buffalo next Wednesday, and adopted the calls for the City, County, Congressional, Assembly, and Aldermanic Conventions.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 7.--John Crabtree of Boston is negotiating with the owners of the Grand Opera House here with a view to purchasing the property. He represents Lotta, the actrees.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7.--Manager J.H. McVicker was in rather a bad humor to-day over a report printed in a city paper that Mr. A.M. Palmer of New-York had secured a lease of his theatre for $30,000 a year.

After a day's intermission the meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club will be resumed with an excellent programme, containing no less than four stake events, arranged under conditions and at distances that will, provided the weather is favorable, make them enjoyable to witness and decidedly interesting for the speculative portion of the attendance.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7.--There was a full attendance to-day at a meeting of the Western, Northwestern, and Southwestern lines to revise the charges on live stock shipments.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 7.--The side-wheel excursion and towboat Melzingah was totally destroyed by fire at Milton, near Pensacola, Fla., last night. She was an old New-York towboat, and once belonged to Harry Hill. She has been in Southern waters about eight months, the property of George W. Wright and Christian Corner of Pensacola, and was insured for $10,000.
The leaders of the Democratic Party in this State will find food for wholesome and profitable reflection in the reports of the meeting held last night to oppose the renomination of Gov. HILL.

The Public Administrator yesterday took charge of the effects of a dead miser, Mother Jarvis, an old Scotch hand manipulator, who was worth about $20,000, but lived in a filthy room at 272 West Thirty eighth-street until three months ago, when she was taken from it almost by force and placed in St. Vincent's Hospital, where she died.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 8.--A novel scene was witnessed here this afternoon. This was the day for the big annual clambake of the guests of the Prospect House, and the pouring rain did not prevent it. Perfect shelter on the premises of the Prespect House was secured for the 300 guests, well-known New-York and Brooklyn people.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Sept. 8.--An epidemic of malignant scarlet fever is raging at Rittersville, several deaths having already occurred. The entire family of Harry Johnson, consisting of himself, wife, and five children, are prostrated and not expected to recover. Improper drainage is given as the cause of the epidemic.

A report just published from the British Consul-General at Warsaw contains the translation of a new law extending, with certain alterations, the scheme of peasants' land banks, established in Russia since 1882, to the Kingdom of Poland.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 8.--At the convention of physicians held in this city the committee appointed from members of the different societies to investigate and report upon the most practical and reliable artificial means for relieving deafness have reported unanimously upon the invisible device of H.A. Wales of Bridgeport, Conn., known as the Sound Disk, which concentrates the waves of sound.--Herald.

PARIS, Sept. 8.--It is stated that the bear sales made in copper on a very large scale in London during June and July are now about to reach their climax. The Copey Island Jockey Club had a bad half holiday yesterday, and the people who went to the track had a worse one. As it threatened rain about the time for people to start for the track several thousand neglected to take their customary Saturday afternoon's outing.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8.--John Tener, Chicago's new pitcher, played his third game to-day and won it. He showed himself a very cool hand, and the Bostons were unable to bunch their hits when bunching was necessary. His support was good.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Sept. 8.--The official vote of Warren County upon the liquor question is as follows: Against the sale of liquors 4,075; for the sale of liquors, 2,984. The liquor men will contese the constitutionality of this local option law.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 8.--The courts have commenced action against the use of poles for telephone and telegraph purposes. The Grand Jury indicted the New-York and Pennsylvania Telephone and Telegraph Company for obstructing the streets of North East.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8.--Col. Lamont, in reply to an inquiry to-night, said that the President's letter of acceptance was finished this afternoon and will be given to the Associated Press to-morrow evening for publication Monday morning. This decision was not arrived at until to-night.

CRYSTAL FALLS, Mich., Sept. 8.--Early yesterday morning the farmhouse of Louis Brown, on Point River, about 20 miles from this place, was destroyed by fire. Mrs. Crown was terribly burned and will die. Brown got out unharmed, but returned to get some money and was burned to death. The fire was caused by a lamp exploding in the bedroom.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 8.--Two games were played by the Pittsburgs and Philadelphias, resulting in a game for each. The threatening weather kept the attendance down to about 1,500.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 8.--The forty-third annual report fo the Bank Commission of NewHampshire shows the condition of the one State bank, the three trust companies, and the 69 savings bank of the State. The depositors number 139,967, an increase of over 7,300. The amount due depositors is $53,939,070, and the increase in deposits $3,646,412.

A multitude of Hill delegates to the Democratic Convention will assemble in the city of Buffalo on Wednesday. They come from every part of the State. Most of the districts in the interior appear to have chosen delegations pledged to HILL.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Sept. 9.-- Much opposition is shown here among European interests to the transfer of the concession for a mortgage bank to a New-York syndicate, and Spanish bankers are especially active in their endeavors to prevent the consummation of the plan.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9.--At 2:30 o'clock this morning a train containing John Robinson's circus, while stopping to take water at Corwin station on the Little Miami Railroad, 51 miles from this city, was crashed into by a heavy freight train, and a scene of terror seldom equaled ensued.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9.--The Western amateur championships were decided to-day at Sportsmen's before an audience of 6,000 people.

LONDON, Sept. 9.--Discount was firm during the week at 3 to 2 per cent. On the Stock Exchange business was very active, English railways taking the lead in a general advance. Favorable views are current as to the future course of prices.

Shotwell, a wealthy resident of New-Orleans, who was visiting his brother here, committed suicide early this morning by strangling himself with a towel, wnich he fastened to a door knob. AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 9.--A shooting affray occurred at the corner of Dill and State streets in this city at 6:30 o'clock this morning.

WILKESBARRE, Sept. 9.--A freight train on the Lehigh Valley Railroad was badly wrecked near Glen Summit at a late hour last night. The accident was caused by one of the wheels breaking. The wreck took fire and burned for several hours, causing considerable loss. All passenger trains were run over the Jersey Central Road between White Haven and this city. The track was cleared to-day and trains are running regularly to-night.

BERLIN, Sept. 9.--The Austrian press condemns the resolutions adopted at Fuida and Freiburg in favor of the restoration of the temporal power of the Pope. The papers declare that the restoration of temporal power would be an anachronism, besides giving Emperor William's visit to Rome an undesirable political character.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--The rate disturbance between Chicago any Kansas City is gradually involving all the Missouri River territory. Live stock rates from the West via Omaha have been reduced to correspond with those from the Southwest.
QUINCY, Ill., Sept. 9.--A cloudburst struck this city last evening, doing much damage. Searcely a tree in the city escaped. Numbers of houses and outbuildings were unroofed and demolished.

She gives every reason to expect that she will come on and shake hands with the New-Jersey voters.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 9, via Galveston--A heavy wash-out is reported on the Mexican Railroad between here and Vera Cruz, and a train from there for this city is now over 18 hours overdue. Advices from Vera Cruz state that the force of the cyclone is broken and that the shipping is safe.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 10.--Mrs. Harriet Beecher Stowe arrived here on the Sunshine from Sag Harbor at 6 o'clock this afternoon, and was able to walk from the boat to the carriage, being assisted by her son, the Rev. Charles E. Stowe, and her nephew, Dr. E.B. Hooker.

HELENA, Montana, Sept. 10.--Parties who have just arrived here from Upper Teton County report disastrous prairie fires in that section. Ranges have been burned off for an area of 60 miles, and the fire has assumed such dimensions as to baffie all attempts to keep it under control.

President Harris of the Northern Pacific Railroad is finally to have his own way and give up the onerous duties of that corporation's Presidency. Vice-President Oakes will succeed to the Presidential post, Mr. Harris taking the place of Chairman of the Board of Directors, where his experience and ability will still serve the company. John C. Bullitt of Philadelphia will enter the Northern Pacific directory as the successor of August Belmont, who resigns.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 10.--Nurses are arriving in comparatively large numbers, but are still far too few to be able to attend to the sick. AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 10.--Heavy rains on Sunday along the Savannah Valley caused the river to rise rapidly last night and this morning. Three inches of rain fell from 1 o'clock Sunday morning until last night.

The Judge and party arrived here this morning safe and well, and will remain here guietly for some days to come.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10.--The cricket match between the Gentlemen of Ireland and the Baltimore Club was played to-day at Mount Washington. The grounds were soggy, and fine playing was impossible. The visitors won the game easily the score standing 119 for Baltimore and 173 for the Gentlemen of Ireland, who had three wickets to spare. The Baltimore Club was allowed 15 men against the Irish 11.

The stock market was not broad yesterday, though there was an activity (confined largely to "fancy" shares) that kept speculative interest from lagging. In the latter part of the day the Granger stocks got a lively shaking up, one or two of the more conspicuous ones dropping off sensationally.

Peter W. Land, dealer in awnings and tarpaulins at 200 West Thirty-fourth-street, made an assignment yesterday to James O'Neil. He has been in the business in this city for 7 years and previously in San Francisco for 25 years, and used the style of the Manhattan Awning Manufacturing Company.

Lester Wallack, the famous actor and manager, was yesterday buried in Woodlawn Cemetery Scores of well-known actors and managers followed the body to the cemetery, while hundreds of faces familiar in the theatrical world were conspicuous at the "Little Church Around the Corner," where a public funeral service was held.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10.--Ex-Senator Grady of New-York, who spoke at Masonic Hall this evening, arrived in the city last night. He says that a Democratic victory in New-York is certain. He denies that there are any dissensions in the party, and as the State is numerically Democratic he thinks that the majority will be 40,000.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 10.--Charles Davidson of this city had a narrow escape from instant death yesterday. He fell from a third-story window, landing upon his feet on the pavement. His right leg was smashed, and he received severe internal injuries.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10.--There is a general strike in the Bevier (Mo.) mines, and 600 men are idle. The miners demanded for Winter wages 78 cents per ton for unriddled coal and 93 cents for riddied. This scale was to have taken effect Sept. 1. The mine owners have steadily refused the advance, and the strike is the result.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--Capt. Lewis V. Crampton, Assistant Surgeon, has been ordered to inspect certain Signal Service property at Fort Bridger, Wyoming, for which Capt. F.B. Jones, Assistant Quartermaster, is responsible.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 10.--Low Young, an employe at the Louisville and Nashville shops, accidentally stabbed and killed Robert Cowell, a bricklayer, to-day. They were both young man and close friends. While skylarking Young made a feint with a small knife, and through a move of Cowell's the blade entered the left breast and penetrated the heart at the apex.

MONTREAL, Sept. 10.--The trial of Pitcher, the absconding Teller of the Union Bank of Providence, R.I., was begun to-day in the Court of Queen's Bench before Chief-Justice Sir Alex Dorien. Mr. Johnson, the Cashier of the bank, was the first witness examined.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--Once more the NewYork Giants were beaten by the local club. Lack of heart was not the cause of defeat to-day. The New-Yorkers, although luck, one of the strongest elements in baseball, was against them, played with rare vim and determination and stubbornly contested every inch of ground.

Des MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 11.--The first plant of Iowa corn is safe from frost, unless in mucky ground, where late rains forced the stalk growth unduly, unless the warm sun and wind of late have absorbed from the ear while curing the stalk. The crop will be over an average. The Northern Iowa corn will be mainly all right. Late planting will only be good for fedder.

The pictures exhibited on the stage of the Broadway Theatre last evening were beautiful and unusual. The landscapes revealed dense masses of tropical vegetation and the tints in the skies were unlike anything we ever see in this part of the world. The interiors were tasteful, roomy, and inviting, and quite as strange to Western eyes as the swamp and forest.

CRAWFORDSVILLW, Ind., Sept. 11.--Senator Dan Voorhees spoke to an immense audience this evening, delegates being present from surrounding towns and cities. His speech was a masterly argument upon the tariff, and was in most respects similar to that delivered at Lafayotte last night. Senatar Voorhees will make four more speeches in Indiana during September.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--Calvin S. Brice, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, will arrive in Chicago Friday morning to commence a new plan of campaign in the Northwestern States. RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 11.--Henry Bennett, a well-known farmer of Oceanport, narrowly escaped being killed by a locomotive near his place this afternoon. He was driving across the railroad track, and, being deaf, did not hear an approaching train. The two horses were struck and one of them was instantly killed. The other will probably die. Mr. Bennett was also badly injured.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 11.--The extensive pork-packing establishment of George H. Hammond Co. is in a state of eruption over the dividend question. PORTLAND, Sept. 11.--Returns continue to come in slowly, as many of the back towns and plantations in Maine are far removed from telegraph stations. The most important cities and towns have already reported, and it is improbable that the general result-- 19,000 to 20,000 plurality--will be much changed.

HELENA, Montana, Sept. 11.--A premature explosion of a blast in the south face of the Wicks tunnel of the Montana Central Railway, south of Helena, this morning killed 10 men and seriously wounded 5. The accident was caused by the concussion of a giant cap fired as a warning in the north face, the headings being now close together. This is the first casualty recorded in the tunnel, which is over a mile in length.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11.--Capt. William A. Thompson, Fourth Cavalry, has been granted four months' leave of absence on account of sickness. The resignation of First Lieut. David D. Johnson, Fifth Artillery, has been accepted, to take effect on July 12, 1889, and he has been granted leave of absence until that date.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 11.--The work of taking the water out of the Calumet and Hecla copper mine has now progressed so far that it has reached a point 50 feet below the twenty-ninth level. In about a month the work of clearing the mine will be finished.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12.--The Board of Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania to-day elected to the Chair of Analytical Chemistry Dr. Edgar F. Smith, Ph. D., (Gottingen,) formerly instructor in analytical chemistry in the university, and recently Professor of Chemistry in Wittenberg College, Springfield, Ohio. Prof. Smith has a high reputation on both sides of the Atlantic as a teacher, writer, and original investigator.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Sept. 12.--For the last week prairie fires have been raging fiercely in this locality. The grass is considerably higher and drier than ever before and burns quite readily. A vast area of prairie is covered by the fire. Though many miles away, it is observed quite clearly. There is a rumor that a whole family had fallen victims to the flames, but it has not yet been confirmed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--The Hale select committee to investigate the operations of the civil service gave a hearing to-day to Mr. Lucius E. Swift of Indianapolis, member of the Executive Committee of the Indiana Civil Service Reform Association.

HAVANA, Cuba, Sept. 8.--Owing to the interruption of the wires details are still missing of the effects of the cyclone in many parts of the island. Leon Urbina was the name of the commander of the gunboat Lealtad, which foundered at Batabano, and who was lost, together with ...

LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 13.--The Lewiston Journal has returns from all the towns in Maine. Burleigh has 79,603 votes, Putnam 61,108, Cushing 2,971, Simmons 979; Republican plurality, 18,495. Legislature--Senate all Republicans; House--Republicans, 123; Democrats, 28.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 13.--The nineteenth annual renuion of the Seventh Regiment, Connecticut Volunteers, was held at Seaside Park, Bridgeport, to-day. The business meeting was called to order at 1 o'clock, and l30 veterans answered to their names.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--The latest official communications received by Mr. Stephen Preston, the Haytian Minister, state that after the fall of Gen. Salomon's administration, on the 10th of August last, Gen. Boisrond Canal, ex-President of the republic, was called by the people to maintain public order.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13.--The Cotton Rates Committee of the Central Traffic Association met to-day at the Southern Hotel for the purpose of fixing cotton rates for the season of 1888 and 1889.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13.--Andrew Patterson, 35 years of age, who said he formerly lived at 2,230 Richmond-street, but who until Saturday had been a yellow fever nurse at Jacksonville, was sent to the Municipal Hospital to-day suffering from what is supposed to be yellow fever.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 13.--Alfred Russell, a leading lawyer of this city, in a communication to this morning's Tribune, sets at rest all doubts as to the question of national rights in the ship channels at the mouth of the Detroit River, which has been mooted at Washington and elsewhere for the past few days.

BUFFALO, Sept. 13.--The convention has come and gone and the city begins to present a natural appearance once more. The County Democrats were marshaled by Col. Michael C. Murphy early this morning, and at 9 o'clock they boarded their train for New-York.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Sept. 13.--The Rev. Father Richardson of Cedar Rapids fell from the window of his room, on the fourth floor of the Lorimer House, yesterday, receiving such injuries that he died in a few hours.

No person need fear yellow fever, either as an epidemic or because of sporadic cases, in this city. Men may come and men may go, but unless they bring the germs of the terrible scourge of the South with them, they will be Yellow-Jack proof here.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Sept. 13.--The persistent hostility of the organs of the Clerical Party toward everything American shows itself in press comments on the transfer of the Mortgage Bank charter to a New-York syndicate.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 13.--At this morning's session of the National Wholesale Druggists' Association the following officers were elected for the ensuing year: President--George A. Kelly of Pittsburg; Vice-Presidents--P. Von Schaack, George M. Olcott, J.C. Richardson, C.H. Pettitt, and H.B. Gilman; Secretary--A.B. Merriam; Treasurer--S. M. Strong; Board of Control--W.A. Rust, A.U. Andrus, J.E. Davis, F.W. Schulte, and R.W. Powers.

The Catholic News has received a dispatch from Rome announcing a decree concerning the Knights of Labor. The dispatch says that the Holy Office has forwarded to Cardinal Gibbons the decree, which decides that there is no cause for action.

The play yesterday in the first round of the games in the eighth annual tournament of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association at the grounds of the Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club, Livingston, Staten Island, was at least equal to any of this season in quality.

The Richmond and West Point Terminal Railway and Warehouse Company yesterday filed a demurrer in the United States Circuit Court to the suit in equity brought against it by Levi P. Morton, George Bliss, and Richard J. Cross.
ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 13.--The manoeuvres at Novaja Praga have terminated. The Czar was much pleased with the manner in which the reserve corps of 10,000 behaved.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13.--To-day's races at Gentlemen's Driving Park were largely attended. The first race for pacers of the 2:30 class, which was unfinished yesterday, was won to-day by Seventysix, who won a heat yesterday and two to-day. Time--2:32 ; 2:29 .

Deputy Sheriff Young has taken possession of the store of Charles F. Koester, dealer in jewelers supplies at 41 Maiden-lane, who has confessed judgment for $4,466 in favor of Leo Hammel. Mr. Koester began business in 1876 as a partner in the firm of Reichhelm Koester.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 13.--This was Governor's Day at the State Fair, and it was one of the most successful days ever known at Howard Park, fully 10,000 people being pres ent in spite of the fact that the cold air made overcoats a stern necessity.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 13.--Mrs. Jesse Hunter of Woodbridge has been divorce proceedings against her husband.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--Lieut.-Col. Session Snyder, Tenth Infantry, has been relieved from duty in the Department of Arizona and ordered to Fort Lyon, Colorado, for duty in the Department of the Missouri.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 13.--Burglars made a raid Tuesday night, for the second time within a week, on Cornwall boarding houses. The Bayside House was entered through a basement window.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 13.--Henry S. Ives remains here in waiting for his trial, which is now set for next Monday. Mr. Stayner is spending the intervening week in the East.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 13.--The Railroad Commissioners have adopted the same grades of wheat that obtained last year, and a few easily frightened operators are breathing more easily. The commission says that no change was ever in contemplation.

MARYVILLE, Mo., Sept. 13.--The Hon. John Edwards, who was recently defeated in the Democratic Convention for the Judgeship of the Kansas City Court of Appeals, committed suicide here today by shooting himself in the head. He was one of the most prominent lawyers in the State, and his family is among the most influential. His wife is a well-known literary woman.

LONDON, Sept. 14.--Mr. William Redmond, member of Parliament for Fermanagh, has been convicted at Wexford of offenses under the Crimes act and sentenced to three months' imprisonment without hard labor.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 14.--This morning a grist mill owned by Anthony H. Lawatsch, on Union-avenue, this city, was destroyed by fire. The flames communicated to the Exceisior Iron Works, owned by John H. Cordts of Rondout, Robert H. Shultis and Joseph Gilmore of Kingston ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 14.--Railroad men are not slow to see that the Manitoba Central is the Manitoba Road and that Col. Clough, finding that he could displace the Northern Pacific in no other way, has executed a coup d'etat which bids fair to give the Manitoba the inside track and take it under the wire several lengths ahead of its rival.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--The Chicago Club has signed Hutchinson of the Des Moines nine, who has made a great record in the Northwestern League. Hutchinson was a famous Yale pitcher seven years ago, and Chicago has been after him for two years. The Chicagos are making a desperate effort to win the League championship, and expect to make the Eastern trip with one of the biggest string of pitchers ever got together.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 14.--The Hampden Park meeting closed this afternoon under favorable circumstances. The weather was the finest of the week, and a very good crowd assembled to see the sport. Gen. Alexander Harbison of Hartford relieved E.C. Robinson in the judges' stand, and James Goodrich of Springfield took Mr. Fuller's place.

LOWER BRULE AGENCY, Dakota, Sept. 14. --The Commissioners have secured about 250 of the 300 Indians at Lower Brule in favor of the Sioux bill, and it is expected that a number more will sign. Not many have signed the red paper, and several who have done so are anxious to have their names transferred to the black paper.

Before Chauncey M. Depew started for his office yesterday morning he was called upon by J.R. Tysen of the Jacksonville Auxiliary Association of this city for a contribution, and Mr. Tysen received a check for $250. Cornelius Vanderbilt contributed a check for $1,000 through Mr. Tysen.
PESTH, Sept. 14.--Count Csaky is Premier Tisza's candidate for the Ministry of Education.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14.--The way passenger train which left New-York this morning at 9:01, and was due at the New-Haven station at 11:53 o'clock, landed its passengers 200 ...

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 14.--At Varnes today one pier of the Eutawville Railroad bridge over the Santee River gave way, precipitating several loaded cars and a number of employes into the river. Five men are still missing but as some of the others escaped after floating five miles down stream on timbers it is hoped all will be rescued.

BOSTON, Sept. 14.--A destructive fire visited the lumber district on Albany-street this evening causing a loss of about $80,000. The fire originated in an unknown manner upon the lumber wharf of Blacker Shepard, where it burned $2,500 or $3,000 worth of lumber.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 14.--The two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the first settlement of Swedes in America was celebrated here to-day with imposing ceremonies. Many distinguished guests from all over the country were present at the exercises in the Exposition.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 14.--Under order of the court the entire stock of Shotwell, Clerihew Lothman, the suspended wholesale dry goods firm, was sold at their store to-day under the direction of Assignee A.H. Lindeke.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 14.--The cotton factors have organized a pool to fight the bagging trust by importing the covering of last year's cotton and using it in place of syndicate bagging. Samples of old covering have been secured and the plan is pronounced practicable. Since the organization of the pool syndicate bagging has been offered here at to cent less than quotations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--A Chicago attorney will sail for England next week to effect a settlement with Charles W. Waldron, the Hillside (Mich.) bank President who absconded a short time ago with a large amount of money and the wife of a friend.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--Inspector Bonfield has succeeded in capturing an Anarchist who, in a rear room in a small west side boarding house, manufactured dynamite bombs. Several detectives are trying to ascertain whether the man had accomplices.
The uneasy feeling that made Thursday's dealings on the Stock Exchange sensational to the verge of a panic continued yesterday, but in a much modified form. Prices kept on downward.

COLUMBUS, Ohio., Sept. 14.--This was the closing day of the Grand Army encampment. At to-day's session Vice-Commander Cole of St. Louis presided, and the report of the Committee on Administration was first made. It reported the treasury in a good condition.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 14.--The ball given by the Sloanes at their elegant cottage here to-night was the most brilliant social event of the season. It was attended by all the society people staying in town, including the foreign diplomats.

One of Brooklyn's millionaires, Samuel McLean of 47 Pierrepont-street, is credited with the latest story in regard to the movements of James McDermott, the Brooklyn politician who, as "Red Jim," disappeared after being accused of selling information in regard to the inside workings of the Irish party in America.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14.--It is said that John H. Starin has assured Horace C. Wilcox, President of the Meriden and Waterbury Railroad, that he will build a branch of that road to Wallingford. He (Starin) will agree to see that the road is extended to connect in NewHaven with his steamboat line to New-York.

EL PASO, Texas, Sept. 14.--A novel race took place yesterday between a horse and a bicycle, from Silver City, New-Mexico, to Denver, 50 miles. The course was over a rough mountain road and long stretches of sand.

Mr. HARRISON makes a statement in his letter of acceptance which must be due to that profound ignorance of the tariff tax and its effect upon our industries which is revealed in everything that he says upon the subject.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 14.--The ship Syren of this port. 822 tons, Capt. A.H. Merriman, coal laden bound from Baltimore to San Francisco, encountered a heavy gale June 28, became badly strained, sprang a leak, and put into Rio de Janeiro, where she has been condemned. She was insured for $7,000.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 14.--Typhoid fever has broken out over the river, in West Springfield. Several deaths have already resulted, and others are probable. Fifty cases thus far have been reported, but the physicians believe they have the disease in check.

WASHBURN, Wis., Sept. 14.--A fire which broke out in this city about 2:30 o'clock this morning wiped out the business part of the place, destroying in all about 30 buildings, and causing a loss of nearly $150,000, with no insurance.
FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Sept. 14.--Typhoid fever rages alarmingly here. Over 100 cases are reported about town.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 14.--The Vermont State Fair closed to-day, which was children's day. All children under 15 were admitted free, and as the public schools were closed the school children were present in large numbers.
READING, Penn., Sept. 14.--A canvass was made this morning in the Reading Railroad machine shops here, which employ about 400 hands, as to how many would go into President Corbin's relief plan.

John Johnson, colored, formerly a preacher in a Baptist church in East New-York, obtained a writ of habeas corpus from Justice Pratt in the Supreme Court. Brooklyn, yesterday, directing the production of his daughter in court.

A Russian stag hound, the gift of a United States Consul to the wife of President Cleveland, arrived yesterday on the Wilson Line, steamer Colorado. It resembles a greyhound and has a white coat, with black spots on the head and shoulders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--The Pennsylvania and Vanderbilt lines to-day gave notice of a further advance in dressed beef and live stock rates from Chicago to the seaboard and intermediate points, to take effect Sept. 24.

John Frey, a Union Hill carpenter, is lying at the point of death in St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken, as the result of a dispute between himself and his wife, Mary, for the possesion of a gun. Frey is considerably older than his wife.

The free and open discussion of tariff questions which the Reform Club courted when it began its Friday night talks has been attained by the members of that organization.

LONDON, Sept. 14.--At the Doncaster September meeting to-day the Park Hill Stakes was won by Belle Mahone, Spice second, and Fair Haven third. The Doncaster Cup was won by Grafton, with Surbiton second and Stronvar third. The Doncaster Stakes was a walk-over for Rada.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Sept. 14.--There is no perceptible change in the condition of Robert Garrett, who remains at the Miller mansion here. His physician, Dr. Jacobs, authorizes the statement that Mr. Garrett is about the same.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 14.--A package containing $2,049 was stolen yesterday from the Paying Teller's counter in the Third National Bank while he was at lunch. The thief must have mounted a chair, reached over the high plate-glass framework around the desk, and secured the package by means of a spiked cane.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--Calvin S. Brice, Chairman of the Democratic National Executive Committee, arrived in Chicago this morning and went to the Palmer House. Mr. Brice says that the outlook in the East is very bright.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 14.--The Baltimore and Ohio north-bound passenger train, due in this city at 5:55 o'clock this morning, was derailed by a switch at Ankneytown siding 25 miles south of this city, and ran into a freight train on the siding.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14.--John Cruetzi was found dead in Druid Hill Park last evening. The Coroner thought the man had been drinking, seated himself on a bench, and fell asleep. His head dropped over on his chest and then his stiff collar stopped the windpipe and checked the flow of blood through the already contracted veins, causing the death to ensue from asphyxia and apoplexy.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 14--In spite of the renomination and pressure brought to bear, the Hen. William L. Scott has finally convinced the Democratic conferrees in this district that he will not be a candidate for re-election to Congress. He had declined before the convention and by letter, but the conferrees refused to give him up to-day. Mr. Scott's successor on the ticket will be nominated on Monday.
PITTSBURG, Sept. 14.--The funeral of J.N. Gotthold, the well-known actor, took place to-day at 9 o'clock from his residence in Sewickley.

BOSTON, Sept. 14.--The condition of William Warren remains unchanged, with those about him feeling slightly more hopeful than for the past few days. This hope, however, has no basis beyond the great vitality shown by the patient.

It is many a long day since Fleetwood Park has sheltered as many fast and game trotters and pacers as are now quartered there. All the best Circuit performers are there, and if at the forth coming meeting the sport furnished is not equal to that of the other Circuit tracks, the fault will not lay with the horses that will compete in the different classes.

MACON, Ga., Sept. 16.--For three weeks the rains have fallen almost incessantly, one resuit being irreparable damage to the cotton crop.
NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 16.--The Right Rev. Francis Janssens, the newly-elected Archbishop of the Roman Catholic diocese of New-Orleans, was received in his capital city to-day with great pomp.
Brooklyn whitewashed the Athletics on the Ridgewood Park grounds yesterday, through the effective pitching of Hughes. Bierbauer was the only visitor who could solve his delivery.

Mary Miller was on Saturday sent to the Jefferson Market Police Court Prison in default of $300 bail for drunkenness and disorderly conduct, despite the zeal of her counsel, Abraham Webb.

With the close of the Coney Island Jockey Club's meeting the attention of the racegoing people will this and next week be attracted to the races at the Brooklyn track, after which will come the closing scenes of the season at Jerome, Park.

The monument erected to the memory of Capt. Samuel H. Sims, who was a member of the Fifty-first Regiment, New-York Volunteers, was unveiled in Greenwood yesterday afternoon in the presence of a number of friends and members of the old regiment. The monument is situated in Locust Valley, beyond Chapel Hill.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Sept. 17.--Mr. Garrett's condition is practically unchanged. He has been somewhat restless the past two days because of his being unable to go out of doors on account of the inclement weather.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 17.--Railroad freight business is booming. All the roads reaching this city are very busy. One prominent railroad man when asked this afternoon from whence came the increase replied: From all channels of trade."

The latest manifesto from the document room of the Republican National Committee has in it an element of humor which ought to insure E.H. Ammidown a situation on a comic paper when he shall take himself out of business in consequence of the Mills bill.
BERLIN, Sept. 17.--The Third Army Corps, led by the Emperor, was repulsed after a hot battle in an attack to-day upon Berlin, which was defended by the Guards.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 17.--Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Florence opened their season here to-night in "Our Governor" to a crowded and very enthusiastic house. Mr. Florence made a speech when called before the curtain.
BERLIN, Sept. 17.--Count Herbert Bismarck has gone to visit Count Scheuvaloff, the Russian Ambassador to Germany, at his estates in Courland.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 17.--Great surprise was manifested to-day by the announcement that F.W. Patterson of New-Brighton, Penn., was about to be appointed General Superintendent of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie, succeeding E. Holbrook, the present incumbent.

Dr. Benjamin Andrews, a wealthy retired physician, living at 227 Berkeley-place, Brooklyn, applied to the local charities authorities a few days ago to have his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Benjamin E. Andrews, of 316 Fourth-avenue examined in regard to her mental condition.

John Grabatschek, a married man of 40, who, however, lived alone at 193 Johnsonavenue, Brooklyn, committed suicide yesterday morning. He hanged himself to the transom of his room by a light rope. MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 17.--Charles A. Pillsbury Co., the largest milling firm in the World, have just finished a division of $40,000 among their employes. This has been made in pursuance of a profit-sharing plan adopted four years ago. For two years there have been no accounts to divide, but last year was profitable and the firm keeps its promise.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17.--So much irritation has been caused by newspaper discussions of the discrimination against Cincinnati by the railroads with reference to the Centennial Exposition that a meeting of railway representatives, guarantors, and Exposition Commissioners was held this afternoon to discuss the situation. There was a very large attendance.

The public schools in Jersey City were opened yesterday. The city has an insufficient number of schools, and consequently many applicants were rejected. Five hundred children were refused registration for lack of accommodations.

BELGRADE, Sept. 17.--The members of the Servian Ministry have tendered their resignations. They will, however, retain their offices until King Milan returns to Belgrade. It is understood that M. Jovan Ristics will become Prime Minister in place of M. Christics.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 17.--The Fall meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club opens to-morrow. The track is in fine condition and the weather promises to be fair and cool. No agreement in terms has been reached with the Western Bookmakers' Association.

While the French steamer La Bourgogue was being pounded by the cyclone in midocean last week the storm was making its presence known to those on the Anchoria, which was on the north or further side of the cyclone.

BERLIN, Sept. 17.--The Independance Belge recently published an article purporting to reflect the views of the German Conservatives, to the effect that Prince Bismarck will follow the example of Gen. von Meltke and resign.

Dr. J. The case of Fred May ,indicted for assault upon Policeman McGowan with a revolver on the night of June 19 last while grossly intoxicated, was on the calendar for pleading in General Sessions yesterday, but was not called.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 17.--Col. James H. Rico, who has been at the National Committee Headquarters in New-York for several weeks assisting in the management of the Democratic campaign, has returned to give some attention to his business interests in Indiana.

The meeting of the Republican County Committee at the Grand Opera House Assembly Booms last night was chiefly notable for the sealing and delivery of articles of peace between the Gibbs and Cowie factions in the Thirteenth Assembly District.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 17.--The Ives-Stayner embezzlement case was called in the Criminal Court again to-day, and Mr. Ives and Mr. Stayner were both present.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--The annual report of the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railway Company for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1888, has just been made public.
Anton Bacchus, the watchman employed at the Eagle Drying Plate Works in Greenville, died yesterday in consequence of having been burned while attempting to save the factory from destruction by fire.

HELENA, Montana, Sept. 17.--The mining camp of Castle, or rather Bonanza, Creek, which is five miles from Castle proper, is the scene of great excitement.
