HAVANA, Sept. 17.--In the district of Roque springs which have been dry for a long time are again flowing, and some estates are in danger of being submerged. This reappearance of the springs excites general alarm throughout the district.
HELENA, Montana, Sept. 17.--On the summit of Old Bald Mountain, some 13 or 14 years ago, a Frenchman named Gohnue and his son Jim, a lad of 15, sunk a shaft 75 feet deep.
"Der Verein fur Kunst and Wissenschaft," in other words the Society of Art and Science, opened its fair at the Lexington-Avenue Opera House last evening under auspicious circumstances.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 17.--The declination of William L. Scott of further Congressional honors was accepted to-day by the Congressional conferees, and the Hon. James R. Burns of Erie was named in his stead. Burns is an Irishman, a Roman Catholic, a finely-educated gentleman, and a lawyer. He has served two terms in the Pennsylvania Legislature. He holds a Professorship in the Erie High School. He is the choice of Mr. Scott.

William Seeligsberg, the bookkeeper who has been missing since Saturday afternoon, is thought to have committed suicide or to be wandering about insane.

With clear weather, in spite of the fact that the track will be heavy, the opening day of the Brooklyn Jockey Club's Fall meeting at Prospect Park cannot be otherwise than highly enjoyable from the number and quality of entries in the over-night events and the lists of probable starters in the two stakes.

The Jacksonville Auxiliary Association of this city has collected up to date a total of $6,989.60, and it is expected that this amount will be materially swelled by the report of contributions which will be made at the meeting of the association which will be held this afternoon at 5 o'clock.

A lawn party was to have been given at the Brooklyn Athletic Association grounds on De Kalb-avenue yesterday by the Young Men's Christian Literary Association of St. Patrick's Church, but at the last minute Bishop Loughlin interfered and put a stop to it. PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 17.--Music Hall, which seats 2,500 people, was packed with men to-night, despite a heavy rainstorm. Under the auspices of the Collins Club of this city the meeting was held for the ratification of the nomination of Cleveland and Thurman.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The convention of labor organizations of the State in session here to-day falls far short of the anticipation of its promoters, both in the attendance of delegates and in the amount of interest manifested by the fraternity.

Nearly 1,000 workmen and many ladies braved the storm last night to go to the Brooklyn Athenaeum and cheer for Cleveland, Thurman, and Warner Miller. The meeting was under the auspices of the followers of Henry George and believers in the single-tax idea.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17.--First Lieut. William Crozier, Ordnance Department, has been ordered to temporary duty at New-York and Boston.

A large and well-pleased assembly gathered in Koster Bial's Concert Hall, in West Twenty-third-street, last evening. The entertainment provided for them was full of variety and fun.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17.--The National Convention of the Switchmen's Mutual Aid Association was called to order this morning in the Olympic Theatre. There are about 500 delegates, and all the cities and States in the Union are represented. The convention is the most important that the organization has ever held.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 17.--The box shook manufacturers here are in considerable trouble over their inability to ship shooks manufactured by them to the United States. They manufacture for the Standard Oil Company and other companies. For months these oil companies have not been able to get ocean tonnage from Boston or New-York, and in consequence are unable to receive shooks. Unless relief comes shortly, several hundred men will be thrown out of employment.

All Long Island is talking about the first annual fair of the Live Stock Association, Limited, which will be formally opened to-day at Huntington, on the mile track grounds, not over a quarter of a mile from the railroad station at that place. Elaborate preparations have been made for the event, and the support received by the management is very encouraging.

The body of Prof. Richard A. Proctor was buried in Greenwood Cemetery at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The corpse was taken from North-Brother Island at noon by the health authorities, and at the wharf at the foot of East Sixteenth-street it was formally given in charge of the relatives of the deceased.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 17.--Several of the New-York papers published a story last Saturday about a Miss Pomeroy, an inmate of the poorhouse at Canandaigua, being cured by faith of paralysis.

The first meeting of the new school for officers, organized by Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, was held last night in the old armory of the Second Battery at Broadway and Forty-fifth-street.

One of the prettiest boat races witnessed on the Harlem in a long time was the championship double scull rowed yesterday between James Pilkington and Rock Kent of the Metropolitan Rowing Club, and Harry Force and George Delaney of the Nonpareils, for two cups offered by the Sporting Times.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 17.--A.P. Tucker, lately Assistant Superintendent of the Canadian Division of the Michigan Central, has been appointed General Superintendent of the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio section of the Erie system, with C.R. Fitch as Superintendent of the Mahoning Division.

Judge Barrett of the Supreme Court, who has just returned from a trip to Europe, opened the adjourned June term of the court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, but as there was no business adjourned it until Monday.

MEXICO, via Galveston, Sept. 17.--Silver miners are very much interested in the transfer of the Montagage Bank to a New-York syndicate, having an idea that this will eventually benefit mining interests by making it possible to sell their silver directly to the bank and thus save many small changes.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 17.--Col. Frank W. Cheney, who heads the Republican Electoral ticket in this State, presided at the annual reunion of the Sixteenth Connecticut Regiment, at Lake Compounce, to-day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17.--Inter-State Commerce Commissioner Schoomaker to-day delivered an opinion, dissenting from that of the majority in the case of the Kentucky and Indiana Bridge Company against the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company, recently published.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 17.--A meeting of the Central Traffic Association has been called for next Wednesday to be held in Chicago, although there is some talk of postponing it.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--The New-York Lyceum Theatre Company opened the regular season at Hooley's Theatre to-night with "The Wife" to an overflowing house. Mr. Frohman's players made a pronounced impression and the play an instant hit. There were repeated calls before the curtain, and the two weeks' engagement promises to be a memorable one.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 17.--Patrick Cassidy was twice arrested to-night for distributing Democratic campaign literature among a Republican audience as those comprising it entered Hawes's Opera House to hear John L. Wheeler deliver a Republican speech.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--The Chicago and Grand Trunk has given notice that on and after Sept. 28 the rate on dressed beef will be 35 cents to both New-York and Boston. The Brooklyn police were still unable yesterday to discover what really caused the death of young Edward Barry, who was found on the track of the Brooklyn, Bath and West End Railroad on Sunday morning.
In no season since books first were made on the race courses of this country has it been so easy to make money by betting as in the one now fast drawing to a close.

Justice O'Brien of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision in favor of Philip Braender, who brought an action against the Harlem Lighting Company to have the company restrained from continuing its electric lighting station in East One-Hundred and Twenty-second-street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--The Boyington Folding Bed Company, at 295 South Loomis-street, one of the oldest concerns of the kind in the city, made an assignment to-day to George P. Jones, without any preferences. The liabilities will reach $18,000.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 17.--Genesee County Republicans to-day renominated John M. McKenzie for the Assembly. Senator Walker secured this county's State delegation to the Thirty-first District Congressional Convention.

An inquest on the body of Carl Otto C. Mueller, the merchant who committed suicide at his Brooklyn residence on Sunday, was held yesterday, but no motive for the act other than insomnia and consequent nervous prostration could be discovered. The dead man's daughters were ignorant of any financial or domestic trouble that would have caused their father to take his life. A verdict of suicide while temporarily insane was rendered.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 17.--Thomas Patton of Perth Amboy was lodged in jail here today for shooting his wife. The two had a disagreement, and Patton, to frighten her, pointed a pistol at her, supposing, he says, that it was not leaded. When he pulled the trigger the charge was lodged in his wife's neck, and she received serious, if not fatal, injuries. Patton's case will go before the Grand Jury.

In the interests alike of manufacturers and consumers a petition has been started for the admission of raw copper into this country duty free. EASTON, Penn., Sept. 18.--Rough estimates indicate that $100,000 damage has been done in this--Northampton--county by rains and floods last night and to-day, and that half as much was done in Western New-Jersey.

ROCKVILLE, Conn., Sept. 18.--The firm of Samuel Fitch Son, one of the largest manufacturers of stockinets, plushes, and knit goods in the country, employing 150 hands, posted notices to-day that the mill would shut down Sept. 29. The company has more orders than it can fill and is strong financially. The shut-down is caused by some disagreement of the firm.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 18.--For almost a week the people of this afflicted city had been crying for sunshine and warmth. The rain and the cold disappeared, and this morning the sun appeared in orthodox Southern splendor.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 18.--As Antone Velazquez was lighting the gas in the double window of Joaquin Rodriquoz's cigar store, in Main-street, this morning, an explosion occurred, which blew out the front of the store, severely burning Velazquez and a boy named William Wilkins. CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--Mrs. C.J. Delon, a widow boarding at 415 Dearborn-avenue, committed suicide last night by running a rubber tube from an open gas jet to a sort of reservoir made by her bed clothing. POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 18.--The propellers, John L. Hasbrouck and Daniel S. Miller are carrying immense loads of grapes to NewYork nightly, each boat averaging 2,000 crates a night. The steamers City of Kingston and James W. Baldwin are also carrying big loads. Because of a lack of warm sunshine the grapes are not ripening as fast as it was expected they would, but there is no end to the crop.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--Henry Thieme set out to kill three persons yesterday afternoon. Going to the house of his divorced wife, in Section 36, a suburb recently incorporated from the town of Jafferson, he attempted to murder the woman and his step daughter. The latter escaped, but Thieme sent a bullet into his wife's head, causing a wound which is almost certainly fatal. He then shot himself, and died almost instantly.

Catherine Nagler, a German woman, 71 years old, died in an ambulance on the way to the Presbyterian Hospital yesterday of carbolic acid poisoning. She had been using the acid for sore legs. Since her husband died, some months ago, she has been melancholy. She went to live with her son Adolph, at 420 East Eighty-eighth-street, after breaking up her own home, and it is supposed she took her life while a victim of melancholic.

BERLIN, Sept.19.--A long train bearing recruits, who were returning from the army manoeuvres, collided with a freight train at Meppen, Hanover. Four of the recruits were killed and a large number were wounded. Twelve of the cars carrying troops were wrecked. The accident was caused by a misplaced switch.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 19.--Dr. Ingalls, the attending physician of William Warren, the actor, states that while Mr. Warren's illness is tending to death he could not tell when the final moment would come. "It may come," said he, "to-morrow, or next week, or a month hence but I think there is no chance for him to recover." He added that the patient's condition had not materially changed within the past four days.

WASHINGTON, Sept 19.--Capt. John P.Story, Fourth Artillery, has been ordered to visit Wash ington, Annapolis, Wilmington, New-York City, and West Point, under special instructions from the Major-General commanding the army.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--A romantic story, in which a young man saves a girl from drowning, is rewarded by her father, and afterward left heir to $15,000 by the father's will, has come to light in this city.

Capt. R.B. Forbes was born in Jamaica Plain Sept. 18, 1804, and this is the anniversary of his birth. At the age of 13 he went to sea before the mast; at 16 he was third mate, at 20 Captain, at 26 he owned a ship and commanded her, at 28 he left the sea, and at 36 was head of the largest American house in China.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 19.--There were 6,000 people at the Erlanger, Ky., barbecue eight miles south of here to hear Speaker Carlisle, and Senator Blackburn speak.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept.19.--The Michael Bay Lumber Company suspended to-day. It is one of the largest lumber firms in the Province and did an immense business. The suspension is owing to difficulties arising out of the recent failure of the Central Bank. The figures are not known yet.
Gen. Joseph B. Carr of Troy, ex-Speaker Titus Sheard of Little Falls, and ex-Congressman James S. Smart of Washington County, called at the State Republican Headquarters yesterday.

Messrs. Plumer, Porter Barker of the Laurel House, Lakewood, N.J., have issued a circular to their patrons announcing that the hotel will be opened for business Monday, Oct. 1. This popular hotel is being thoroughly renovated and renewed for the season of 1888-9, and the management will strive to maintain the excellent reputation of the house for solid comfort and entertainment.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept.19.--President Corbin is back at his desk at the Reading general office after a vacation enjoyed in New-Hampshire.

George P. Baldwin, bookbinder, at 31 East Houston-street, has become financially embarrassed, and Deputy Sheriff Burke has taken possession of his establishment on an execution of five judgments aggregating $5,600.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19.--The Hon. W. Bourke Cockran, who represents the Twelfth District of New-York in the House of Representatives, has announced that he is not a candidate for a renomination, and will not run if such an honor is conferred upon him at the coming convention.

BOSTON, Sept. 19.--The report circulated about town this afternoon to the effect that John L. Sullivan had suddenly died away at Crescent Beach is without the least foundation. Sullivan, like any other man whose stomach is wholly out of condition, is in a very uncertain state. But with the nursing he is receiving there is no reason why he should not pull through all right.
BIDDEFORD, Me., Sept 19.--Warren Rice,exUnited States Consul at Panama, suffered a severe shock of paralysis at his home in Saco this morning, and is not expected to recover.

HARRISONBURG, Va., Sept. 20.--Stewart F. Lindsey, selected in May last Elector for this (the Seventh) district by the anti-Mahone faction, in a long letter to-day withdraws in favor of Carter M. Loutham, Mahone's Elector. Lindsey claims his action is in the interest of harmony.

BOSTON, Sept. 20.--Through the action of a New-York agent the AEtna Insurance Company of Hartford has got into trouble with the Insurance Commissioners of Massachusetts. The insurance laws of this State are unusually strict.

LONDON, Sept. 20.--Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, in his address at the conference of Radical Unionists at Bradford yesterday, positively approved of the policy of the Government as far as it had gone, and said that he was partly responsible for it.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 20.--Mrs. M. W. Mersner, aged 61, of New-York City commit ted suicide at the residence of Mrs. Dr. A.G. Shears, 1 Sylvan-avenue, in this city, yesterday by taking Paris green. She was said to be unfortunate and slightly insane.

LACROSSE, Wis., Sept. 20.--As the passenger train on the Chicago, Burlington and Northern Railroad was making the crossing at the junction at East Winona, Wis., yesterday it was run into by a gravel train of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad.

CITY OF MEXICO, VIA GALVESTON, Sept. 20.-- Louis Huller gave a banquet to-day at his palatial country seat at Tacubaya to Mr. Wells of NewYork, President of the International Company. which is colonizing Lower California.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20.--A dispatch from San Francisco says an elevator cage in the Bancroft Building dropped five stories and several people were badly injured. The elevator was run by a cable and had a small cage that was supposed to hold only eight. It was always overcrowded when work stopped.

PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 20.--John M. Langston, the colored candidate for Congress in this district, arrived in the city to-night from Farmville. He was met at the station by a great crowd of negroes and given a royal welcome.

In the matter of the Third Order of St. Francis litigation which has been pending for some time and has been involved still further by the death of Mary McNulty, Mother Superior, the present legal situation was yesterday explained by the counsel representing both the petitioner and the opponents.

The Jacksonville Auxiliary Relief Committee received yesterday an order from Jacksonville calling for 20 acclimated nurses. ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 20.--Yesterday afternoon a novel spectacle was presented on the streets of Fort Gaines. O.S. Brown, one of the most successful farmers, drove into town on a wagon drawn by four fine horses, which were hooded and decorated with cotton sheeting.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Sept. 20.--Rena Burr, daughter of Edward Burr, and Alice Lane, daughter of Nathan Lane, aged 16, residing at Burlington, were drowned in the Assiscunk Creek at that place last night. Both bodies were recovered.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 20.--The five Anarchists who were the ringleaders in the redflag demonstration Labor Day, which provoked a riot, were convicted is the police court to-day of disturbance and were fined the costs and sentenced to the workhouse,
At the annual meeting of the Northern pacific Railroad Company's stockholders yesterday the programme announced in THE TIMES a fortnight ago was carried out fully.
The annual Fall regatta of the New-York Yacht Club, which has been omitted for three years owing to the prior claims of the America's Cup races, was sailed yesterday in a fine southerly breeze.

Fair skies and a deliciously cool atmosphere brought a crowd to the Huntington Fair yesterday, half again as large as the day before, and everything went off with a dash and spirit that must have been as gratifying to the directors as it was enjoyable to the spectators.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 20.--Mrs. Stowe had a long walk to-day and is apparently gaining strength.

The County Democracy assembled in force and with much enthusiasm at the meeting at Cooper Union last night, and not only crowded the big hall to the doors, but swelled over until it required two extra hands of music to keep the crowd without doors in good humor.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 20.--News reached here to-day of the unparalleled work of the rainstorm in the upper part of Rockland County this week.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 20.--A severe electric storm prevailed along portions of the Hudson River to-night. In several localities the clouds seemed to travel in circles.

The official statement of the cotton crop of the United States for the season of 1887-8 was given out at the Cotton Exchange yesterday. The crop is the largest oue ever grown in America, being 547,248 bales larger than the previous one, and exceeding that of 1882-3,

BOSTON, Sept. 20.--One of the most hopeful signs of Democratic growth was developed to-day is the result of a canvass of the delegates to the Democratic Convention in the Fifth Congressional District. The second day's play in the second annual inter-State cricket match between NewYork and New-Jersey was finished yesterday on the Newark Cricket Club ground, and, although it ended in a draw, it was almost a certain win for New-York, as their opponents had 125 runs to get with only 6 wickets to fall.

Clark Bruce and William H. Owen, composing the firm of Bruce Owen, wholesale dealers in fruits at Washington and Barclay streets, made an assignment yesterday to James C. McEachen giving two preferences for $974. They succeeded C. Bruce Co. March 1, 1888, claiming a capital of $2,500.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 21.--The case of Mary J. Roll against Adam Rae of South Amboy, which is being tried here, involves the title to onethird of the property in the business part of South Amboy Mrs. Roll is suing for the possession of Rae's land. FORT WORTH, Texas, Sept. 21.--Better order prevailed at to-day's session of the Republican State Convention. Chairman Brady apologized for the stormy scenes of yesterday and the committee reports were called for J.C. Degrees charged Dr. A. Cochran of Dallas with forging the credentials from Johnson County.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 21.--The Conkling letter and Crandall interview published yesterday in THE TIMES created a great sensation throughout Central New-York. Telegrams concerning it are coming from all over the country.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21.--The number of Freshmen in the academic department at Yale this year is 212, and it is expected that the aggregate will be increased to 220. In the scientific department there are about 125. The figures are not much different from those of last year.
CALCUTTA, Sept. 21.--Letters have been received from the Ameer of Afghanistan dated Sept. 13, stating that he was then in good health, having recovered from a recent attack of gout.

NASSAU, New-Providence, Sept. 17.--A severe hurricane passed over Fortune Island, Castle Island, Ragged Island, and Acklin Island on sept. 2 and 3. An account of the damage done on Fortune Island and Castle Island has already bean given. Ragged and Acklin Islands are isolated, and the news from them has just been received.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 21.--A matter which may strongly tend to strengthen the already strained relations between the Dominion and the United States has presented itself in connection with the limits of jurisdiction at points adjacent to the imaginary boundary line between Alaska and British Columbia.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 21.--The electric sterm at points along the Hudson River and inland last night and early this morning was very severe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21.--First Lieut. Frank E. Hobbs, Ordnance Department, has been ordered from Philadelphia to Washington on special duty.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 21.--The Thirtythird Republican Congressional Convention was held in this city to-day, and resulted in the nomination of ex-Congressman Richard Crowley of this city.

UTICA, N. Y., Sept. 21.--At the Oneida County Fair in Rome to-day. victor Prince won the three-minute class in straights, Clarence G. second, Joyce third. Best time--2:38 . The 2:36 race was won by Linwood in straights, Nixdorf second, Dick Toomer third. Best time --2:31 .

BERLIN, Sept. 21.--The publication of the Emperor Frederick's diary has caused a sensation in Berlin. The North German Gazette today makes no reference to the matter. The National Gazette says it regrets the indiseretion shown in publishing the diary.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Sept. 21.--The Marquis de Mores is contemplating an extensive plan of railroad building in China, and his friends here who were with him in his Medora cattle enterprises are watching developments with keen interest. Over 20 citizens of this vicinity are thinking seriously of going to China and joining the Marquis in his railroad scheme.

The long-wished-for and much-talked-of meeting of the Presidents of the trunk lines has been held, and nothing whatever has been accomplished. It was the largest railroad Presidents' meeting ever held in New-York, and turned out to be the biggest kind of a fizzle. For many months past both freight and passenger business has been in a deplorable state of demoralization.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Sept. 21.--The reports circulated to-day in New-York about the dangerous condition of Mr. Garrett are entirely erroneous. The fact is this has been one of his best days since coming to Ringwood. He slept eight hours last night and has been out of doors all day. His appetite is excellent.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark, Sept. 21.--A small cyclone passed over Mammoth Springs, Fulton County, to-day at noon. Seven houses were wrecked, trees blown down, and corn and cotton crops are said to be ruined. Several people were injured, but no one is reported killed.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 21.--D. L. Weeks, a prominent coal dealer of this city, was killed by the early train on the Valley Division of the Consolidated Road this morning. He was crossing the track at the foot of Court-street and being very deaf, failed to hear the electric bells sounded by the approaching train. He was about 75 years of age and very highly respected.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Sept. 21.--Peter Belack, the New-York bunko steerer and confidence man, who was arrested in this city last Monday, was sentenced this morning to one year's imprisonment in the Albany County Penitentiary and to pay a fine of $500 or, in default of the payment of the fine to serve an additional 500 days. William Wheeler, his confederate, was discharged, as nothing could be proved against him.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 21.--In consequence of Dufresne's assignment yesterday John Jamieson Co., oil merchants, and Brodie Jamieson, oil merchant, suspended payment to-day. TROY, N. Y., Sept. 21.--The Democrats of Troy flung to the breeze this evening one of the handsomest campaign banners yet displayed by any political party in this vicinity. The Second Ward Cleveland and Thurman Club had charge of the arrangements Assemblyman Nicholas R. O'Connor of New-York spoke.

BERLIN, Sept. 21.--The Cologne Gazette pleads for united action by England, Germany, Belgium, and the Congo State in an endeavor to relieve Emin Bey. There is no time or reason, it says, for jealousies. Europe's honor and prestige with the Africans are at stake.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 24.--Alfred Birdsall of Central Valley committed suicide this morning by hanging himself in the barn, where he had gone at an early hour to milk. Arrangements have been completed for the erection of a John Jacob Astor memorial cathedral in Sioux Falls, Dakota. The main building will be 108 by 58 feet on the ground, 48 feet high, with a tower 110 feet high, a chapter house 42 by 50 feet and 44 feet high, three stories, and with tower the same as the other. Sioux Falls granite will be used throughout.

Ex-Assistant District Attorney Purdy created a sensation yesterday in the Schilling case, and surprised the representatives of the District Attorney's office who are prosecuting Schilling for the murder of his wife on March 14 last.
LONDON, Sept. 26.--The new Gilbert and Sullivan opera will be produced on Oct. 3.
HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 25.--George W. Thomas, formerly of the place and now of Brick Church, N.J., one of the leading Prohibitionists in the State, has come out for Cleveland.
Yesterday was the first day of registration in Brooklyn, and, notwithstanding the disagreeable weather, a very large number of people enrolled themselves.

Detective O'Brien of Inspector Byrnes's staff took to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday Arthur C. Parker, a handsome, welldressed young man, and asked that he be held for 30 days, if necessary, to procure requisition papers from the State of New-Jersey.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 25.--Hard batting in the first and seventh innings won the game for Brooklyn to-day. Foutz and Corkhill led the hitting for the visitors. Burns, Kansas City's new fielder from the Omaha team, played his first game with the club to-day.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 25.--The Pennsylvania Company will have a heavy suit for damages on its hands as the outcome of the war in excursion rates between this city and Columbus and Cincinnati.
The Florida Auxiliary Belief Committee held a business meeting yesterday afternoon at its rooms in the Grand Central Hotel.
BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The Republican Congressional Convention for the Thirtyfirst District, comprising the counties of Genesee, Livingston, Orleans, and Wyoming, met here to-day.

LONDON, Sept. 25.--At the Newmarket meeting to-day the race for the Tenth Great Foal Stakes, for 3-year olds, was won by a length by the Duke of Portland's Ayrshire, with Lord Rosslyn's Grafton second, and the same owner's Surbiton third. There were eight starters. The last betting was 9 to 4 on Ayrshire, the favorite.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--William Schneider, a South Chicago clothing dealer, was forced to suspend to-day, judgments for over $9,000 being entered against him. The total liabilities are about $14,000, with assets amounting to about half that sum.

LONDON, Sept. 25.--Most of the Lancashire cotton mills are running on short time. The mill owners calculate that they will have to run an short time two months before the ring is broken. Liverpool brokers attribute the increase in prices not to ring operations, but to natural causes. Mills spinning Egyptian cotton are not affected.

Ever since Le Grange Brown was arrested in Brooklyn a week ago for having in his possession objectionable photographs of young girls the fathers and brothers of some of the most fashionable young ladies in the city have been beseaching the authorities to let them see the 500 and odd photographs found in the prisoner's room.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 25.--Five white convicts made a break for liberty here to-day. Two were killed, two got away, and one was recaptured.
CARLISLE, Penn., Sept. 25.--The County Fair opened here to-day with unfavorable weather. The chief amusement booked for today was the bicycle races.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 25.--There are at present evidences of renewed activity on the part of the Highland Bridge Company, an organization chartered some time ago for the purpose of building a railroad bridge across the Hudson River, between Anthony's Nose and ...
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 25.--State Auditor Braden has written a letter in which he states that if the State were to go out of business July 31, 1889, the assets would just about meet the liabilities.
One hundred and fifty Mormons, or wouldbe Mormons, arrived at Castle Garden yesterday among the steerage passengers of the steamship Wisconsin.

Brooklyn's retail grocers had a gala day of it yesterday. They were to open their big fair in Grand Army Hall in Bedford-avenue in the evening, and they resolved that they would show their customers what they could do in the way of a daylight parade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25.--The condition of Associate Justice Stanley Matthews is somewhat improved to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 25.--Residents of Canonicut Island, a Summer resort near this city, are rejoicing over the biggest real estate transaction ever made there. The purchaser is Isaac H. Clothier of Philadelphia, who has paid $35,000 for Bull's Point, which comprises about nine acres.
The Tribune is deeply moved by the alleged failure of the Ways and Means Committee to prepare and report any bill for the suppression and prevention of Trusts and other combinations.

LONDON, Sept. 25.--The associated American shareholders in St. Paul held a meeting to-day and resolved to act in union with J. S. Morgan Co. in the reform movement, though as an independent organization. About 10,000, shares were represented.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--A local paper says: "There is trouble in the parish of St. Adelbert's Polish Catholic Church.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 25.--The latest estimate obtainable from authentic sources as to the yield of corn in Ohio is that it will amount to 115,000,000 bushels, or 4 per cent. more than a full crop.
The cheering reports about New-York which the Democratic State Committee have received are accompanied by equally cheering reports from Michigan.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 25.--The Grand Army papers are giving attention to claims to the honor of being the youngest enlisted soldier, but none of them seems to excel the record of Edward Black, now dead, the son of George H. Black of this city.

LOWER BRULE AGENCY, Dakota, Sept. 24, via Chamberlain.--According to the latest order of the department each of the six agencies included in the Sioux bill is represented here today by its agent, interpreter, and a delegation ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 25.--When Ignatius Donnelly was nominated for Governor by the Farm and Labor Party, at the State Convention in St. Paul a few weeks ago, he stated in his speech of acceptance that he would make a lively campaign if the party gave him the proper assistance.

BOSTON, Sept. 25.--The steamer Worcester, which arrived this morning from Halifax, brought the Captain, Amos W. Hanson, and the crew of 10 men of the schooner Isaac Keen, which was wrecked off the coast of Newfoundland on Friday, the 14th of this month.

CHIPPEWA FALLS, Wis., Sept. 25.--A settlement was made this morning between the parties connected with the big pine land deal, which was made some days age and in which it was found that fraudulent deeds had been made in the interest of one of the purchasers.

BONHAM, Texas, Sept. 25.--The evidence in the Bean trial has been closed and the argument begun. It was developed that should Saunders win the suit another set of claimants stand ready to contest his rights to the estate.
EASTMAN, Ga., Sept. 25.--Giles Melton, a farmer, was out hunting in the woods near his house recently.
ROME, Ga., Sept. 25.--The rumored postponement of the North Georgia and Alabama Industrial Exposition at Rome is without foundation. The exposition will open on Monday, Oct. 1.

There can be no doubt that the expectation of union is growing in the minds of both Tammany and County Democracy men. Each side is confident that in a straight-out fight it could beat the other, but the fear that in a straight-out fight between them the national ticket would suffer is beginning to make itself felt.

Rain or shine, hot or cold, there should be some first-class racing at the Brooklyn track to-day, for the probable starters in all the races are numerous enough to make it look as if there would be lively contests and close finishes, with good betting in all the races, even if the scratches are many.
Referee Charles W. West yesterday had another hearing in the case of the American Dramatic Fund Association's petition for a voluntary dissolution, in the Bennett Building.
LENOX, Mass., Sept. 25.--This has been, the day of the Lenox Club races at the Lee Pleasure Park.

BOSTON, Sept. 25.--Twenty-three hundred women were assessed yesterday and an equal number to-day, sending the total to date up to over 7,000, or more than twelve times as many as were assessed in all last year.

HAVANA, Sept. 25.--Senor Rafael Mauri, who was recently kidnapped by bandits in the District of Bajucal, has been released on payment of a ransom of $4,200.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25.--Drafts--Sight, 5 cents; telegraphic, 10 cents.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 25.--About 9:30 o'clock last evening a north-bound engine on the Southwest branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad, running at the rate of about 30 miles an hour, struck a cow between Fairchance and ...

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 25.--To-day's registration at Cornell University shows that this vigorous young college is booming. At least 1,200 students are enrolled, and the final totals promise more, an increase of over 200 over last year.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 25.--This afternoon five penitentiary convicts working on the Missouri Pacific Railway within the city limits made an attempt to escape. The guards fired upon them. John Davis was killed, Chris Wells was mortally wounded, two escaped, and one was captured.

LONDON, Sept. 25.--Advices from Zanzibar state that the coast tribes who attacked the German residents of Bagomoyo last Saturday have retreated inland. The Germans are preparing to pursue them. Natives have murdered two Germans and as Indian clerk at Kilivd.

Fifty stalwart young lads with remarkably well developed limbs sprang down the gangplank of the steamer Wisconsin of the Guion Line in a lively fashion when the vessel was made fast to her dock yesterday morning.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The two-story dwelling on Fulton-street, occupied by the family of Thomas Loucks and another family, was totally demolished by an explosion of natural gas in the cellar last night. Loucks was badly burned. The other occupants escaped with slight injuries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25.--Col. Alfred L. Hough, Ninth Infantry, (promoted,) has been relieved from duty in the Department of the Platte and ordered to join his regiment at Whipple Barracks, Arizona Territory.
Rarely does a magazine print a number with the contents as uniformly good as the contents of this. From beginning to end everything in it is interesting.

"For the sake of the poor, do not give money to street beggars," is a maxim of life to all organizations such as are known as "associated charities." Its justice and wisdom is proved anew by the annual report of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--A dispatch from Grand Forks, Dakota, says: "The death of George Fulljames, the pugilist, from injuries received in a match with Barrett has caused much uneasiness to those who participated.
The second day's play in the international cricket match between New-York and the Gentlemen of Ireland was a great cricket event. Such large scoring has not been seen for a long time.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--Frank Lawler was renominated for Congress to-day by the Democrats of the Second District. There was no very strong opposition, in spite of a great deal of gossip which has been circulated to the effect that he would be beaten.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 25.--The answers received at the Department of Agriculture, to inquiries sent out by Commissioner Henderson some days ago, as to the damage to the principal crops by the recent unprecedented rains, cover the State generally and were compiled yesterday.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 25.--John Thornton Wood, the Washington scientist, is at the residence of his sister, Mrs. James B. Greeley, at Thornton's Ferry, N.H. He is all right, although suffering from the effects of his long journey from Washington.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The Democratic Congressional Convention of the Twentieth District was held in the parlors of Given's Hotel, in this city, this noon.
Two fires which have occurred within 10 days past in the Ava apartment house, a structure not yet completed at 11 East Tenth-street, have puzzled and alarmed William H. Russell, the owner.

The Circuit Court, with the Hon. Willard Bartlett presiding, which opened at Richmond, Staten Island, on Monday, closed yesterday. The jurors were dismissed for the term, and the Grand Jury will bring in their indictments today.
A curious and so far unexplained accident occurred at 15 East Thirty-sixth-street, the residence of Henry, M. Braham, a wealthy retired merchant.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--A Cairo (Ill.) special says: "It was ascertained to-day that Elmer E. and Walter Comings had been indicted by the Grand Jury for the alleged embezzlement of over $20,000 from the New-York Store Company, an old wholesale grocery firm of this city.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25.--The music festival opened very appropriately this afternoon with the Beethoven cantata. "The Praise of Muisc," the full chorus starting off with a grand rush on the invocation.
The Coroner's inquest in the case of Michael Martel, the 4-year-old boy who was killed by a Seventh-avenue car at 172 Thompson-street on July 13, was continued yesterday.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 25.--Congressman Robert J. Vance of New-Britain was renominated by acclamation by the First District Democratic Convention held here this afternoon.
Wheat shot along rapidly yesterday on its upward flight. The highest point yet reached was scored.
The temperature yesterday took another drop, bringing up in the evening with a mean for the day of 9 below the normal.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Sept. 25.--Mr. Garrett's condition was unchanged to-day. Dr. Jacobs says Mr. Garrett is resting better at night now than at any time since his arrival at Ringwood. Owing to the inclement weather Mr. Garrett was not permitted to take his usual daily airing to-day about the grounds of the Miller mansion.
The annual Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New-York will be opened in St. Augustine Chapel, on East Houston-street, this morning.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 25.--The promised visit of the Acting Mayor and a deputation of colored men to Camp Mitchell took place to-day and was most satisfactory to all.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--P.D. Armour is irritated over the criticism that has been heaped upon him as a Director of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad in passing dividends. He said to-day, in explanation of his vote, that he was a legitimate business man in his financial affairs and not a stock jobber.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25.--The new Board of Directors of the Keely Motor Company met to-day in the office of the company, 911 Walnutstreet.
TROY, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The little cloud on the horizon disappeared before noon, and the proceedings of the Convention of Democratic Clubs were, on their surface, peaceful from beginning to end.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--A dispatch from Wichita, Kan., says: "Attorney-General Hallowell has brought action in the District Court to have the fine and costs in the noted Stewart whisky case made a lien upon the Timmermeyer Block, in which the liquor was sold.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 25.--Congressman J.L. Macdonald of the Third District returned from Washington this morning. When seen by a reporter he stated his object at present to be more to regain his health and get free from the malaria than to look after fences.
Capt. Ponsen and several of the steamship Zaandam's crew handed affidavits to the Commissioners of Emigration yesterday concerning the alleged ill treatment of steerage passengers.

LONDON, Sept. 26.--The steamship Island, (Dan.,) Capt. Skjodt, from New-York Sept. 9, arr. at Copenhagen yesterday. The steamship Earl Wemyss, (Br.,) Capt. Colquhoun, from San Francisco May 29 for Queenstown, was sunk in a collision with the ship Ardencaple. A portion of her crew were saved.

Last month we pointed out the causes which were forcing up the price of wheat, and from these predicted that it would sell at a dollar a bushel in Chicago this month. At the time that was written the price of cash wheat there was between 89 and 90 cents per bushel.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Sept. 25.--The Hon, R.Q. Mills addressed 20,000 people here tonight, and was tendered an ovation. He arrived in St. Louis this morning and dined with the Hon. W.R. Morrison and the Hon. W.S. Forman at the Planter's House.
On Thursday at noon the entries for the first day's races at the Country Club's meeting at Pelham will Close with E. Bickle, the Assistant Secretary, at 13 Park-row.

BOSTON, Sept. 25.--Delia Bresnahan, 38 years old, said to be the wife of Cornelius Bresnahan, was carried to the City Hospital this forenoon in a herdic by two persons (whose names are unknown) who said that she seemed to be badly injured.

Frank Mass, a lawyer connected with the Society for the Prevention of Crime, wrote to the Police Commissioners Sept. 19, offering to give them a list of saloons and pool rooms where direct violations of the laws are constantly going on, gathered by the officers of the society.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 25.--The Board of Pardons has granted a pardon to Milton Weston, the Chicago millionaire, who is serving a five years' sentence in the Western Penitentiary for contributory murder in causing the death of a man named Haymaker during a fight between the employes of the two men over the possession of a piece of land in Western Pennsylvania about four years ago.

Rock Island hedged the stock market yesterday morning in the handsomest sort of a way. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25.--The foundations of the new Yale recitation building, money for which has been given by an unknown friend of the university, have been partly laid.

His father thinks there has been a decided change for the worse in his son's condi tion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--The President gave a special reception at noon to-day to the Hon. William F. Cody (Buffalo Bill) and the members of his Wild West troupe, including the Indians, who appeared in their most brilliant native costumes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--To-day's bond offerings aggregated $345,250, as follows: Coupon fours--$6,000 at 130. Registered fours--$238,000 at 130, $4,000 at 130, $800 at 129, ex interest. Coupon four and a halfs--$3,000 at 107 . Registered four and a halfs--$5,000 at 107 , $8,450 at 107 , $80,000 at 107 .

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26.--The Yale class crews are in training for the Fall regatta on Lake Saltonstall. Fifteen men are trying for places in the Academic boat, among them six of the last St. Paul's crews.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26.--The tug Graham, while trying to get alongside of the steamer Arecuna this morning, was caught in the suction, capsized, and sunk in four fathoms of water on the range lights, above Wilmington Creek, Delaware River.

Ephraim S. Wells, manufacturer of proprietary medicines in Jersey City, and the owner of "rough on rats," has not yet succeeded in effecting a compromise with his creditors, as it is said he has not raised the money on his trade marks which he contemplated.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 26.--Chairman Blanchard of the Central Traffic Association this afternoon sent a telegraphic communication to all the managers in the association recommending that rates in the fourth, fifth, and sixth classes be restored Oct. 8.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 26.--The Gazette publishes what purports to be the outcome of the Bay State House meeting held last Saturday by the Republicans opposed to the nomination of Mr. Walker in the Tenth Congressional District. Although 45 gentlemen were present the important action has been kept secret.
A strong anti-Hill movement has manifested itself on Staten Island among the Independent Democrats.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 26.--The State Woman's Christian Temperance Union, now in session in this city, had an attendance of some three thousand ladies to-night.

A movement has been on foot of late among the music unions of New-York and Brooklyn that now belong to the Knights of Labor to form a new music association entirely independent and outside of that body.

Capt. Ramsay, commanding the United States steel cruiser Boston, thinks she will be ready to sail Saturday. To-day was the one originally set for clearing, but delay was caused by the decision to exchange the old Brush electric plant for a new Brush system designed especially for boats.

The Trustees of the College of the City of New-York met in the hall of the Board of Education yesterday and adopted the report of the Executive Committee which fixed the amount needed for the support of the college during the year 1889 at $146,500.

The last touches are being placed upon a very great painting by John La Farge in the Church of the Ascension, Fifth-avenue and Tenth-street, on which the artist has worked for several years.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 26.--The Hon. Warner Miller delivered an address at the Camden Fair this afternoon to over 3,000 people. It was political, but a part was intended to show the superior condition of the American as compared with the Old World farmer, especially the English farmer.

Mr. Jay Gould was in town yesterday. He was at the Windsor Hotel while the Stock Exchange was open. He hung over the ticker and nursed the tape with an air that had no listlessness in it. He was interested.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26.--Cash wheat to-day scored the biggest advance on the Board of Trade and reached the highest point it has so for made on the up-turn is prices.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 26.--L.B. Ives, halling from Detroit, who has been for some time wanted in that city on a charge of forgery, was arrested here last evening, and in the Police Court this morning remanded by the magistrate until the Detroit authorities decide what to do. He will no doubt be taken home.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 26.--Frank Norcross was sentenced in the Eighth District Court of Olneyville last night to three years in the State workhouse for lewd and wanton behavior.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--The recent deficiency in the redemption division of the Treasury Office turns out to have been a more serious matter than was at first supposed.

The news which has just reached the Zanzibar coast from Uganda gives little ground for satisfaction. It is brought to a date of about three months ago, up to which time nothing whatever had been heard there either of STANLEY or EMIN Pasha.

The Grand Jury of the Circuit Court of Richmond County, Staten Island, closed its labors yesterday. Indictments were found against Celeste Kaul and Josephine Bernard for attempting to "extort money by verbal threats " from Joachim Sanchez of New-Brighton.

GODERICH, Ontario, Sept. 26.--The sculling race here to-day between William O'Connor of Toronto and George W. Lee of New-York--two miles, with three turns--was won by O'Connor by one length, in 12:50.
GALENA, Ill., Sept. 26.--A freight train from the South on the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City Road came into collision at Menominee Station with an Illinois Central working train yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--New-York's Giants secured a mortgage on the pennant this afternoon by defeating the Senators in two games. Two games were played to-day--one on account of yesterday's postponement and the last one the regular schedule game.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26.--Forty-five bales of wool shipped from Toronto, Canada, to Thomas Lee Co., wool merchants of this city, are under seizure at the United States Appraiser's storehouse.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.-- Justice Matthews of the Supreme Court continues in a very feeble condition, and he will in all probability be unable to take his seat on the bench when the October term of the court begins.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26.--Jacob Schaefer to-night reiterated his determination not to go into any of the cushion carrom tournaments which the Eastern exports are discussing.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., Sept. 26.--An epidemic has broken out among the cattle in some parts of Berks County. It is known as splenic apoplexy, or Texas fever, and proves very fatal. During the past week a large number of horses and cows have died.
TROY, N.Y, Sept. 26.-- Farmers all through this section are much disheartened by the partial failure of the potato crop, a large portion of it having retted by reason of the recent rains.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 26.--Judge Dennis to-day annulled the marriage contract existing between Florence R. Winchester and Charles E. Brook on the ground that at the time the ceremony was performed the bride was not morally responsible. Brook is a music teacher.
CORONA, Long Island, Sept. 26--The body of a man in an advanced state of decomposition was found in some woods about 100 yards from the Cornish mansion on Flushing Bay last night.

BATAVIA, N. Y., Sept. 26.--One hundred more ballots were taken in the Thirty-first District Republican Convention to-day, making just 200 in all, and the two hundredth was precisely like the first--14 for Congressman Sawyer and 7 each for Senator Walker and ex-Lieut.-Gov. Hoskins. The convention will meet again to-morrow morning.

Shippers of pig iron from this city to points up the Hudson and elsewhere frequently receive complaints of shortage by the consignees. Very often it has been a great mystery as as to how these shortages occurred.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Sept. 26.--The Rondout Creek here is full of baby shad, and a toothsome morsel they prove to big, fat, black bass that feast on them. Bass is plentiful hereabout, and they are up to many sharp tricks.

BOSTON, Sept. 26.--With the exception of the very short gale in this section a few weeks ago, the storm which began shortly after midnight this morning and continued until noon was the most severe that has visited the New-England coast for several years.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 26.--President Samuel Spencer of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad said to-day that the company had completed arrangements for extensive additions and improvements to its property in this city.

LONDON, Sept. 26.--At the Newmarket first October meeting to-day the Great Eastern Railway Handicap was won by Wise Man. Sandal was second, and Maiden Belle third. There were 14 starters. The last betting was 11 to 2 against Wise Man.
Responses are coming in to the call for contributions made by the National Democratic Committee from all sections of the country.

The trust craze has reached the makers of white lead, and they have made an iron-clad combination. The first edict of the new combine was given to the paint trade two or three days ago, when the price per ton was advanced $15 on large orders and $25 on small ones.
DENVER, Col., Sept. 26.--Interesting revelations of a conspiracy between certain employes of the Union Pacific Railway to swindle that company are coming to light.

An agents' line meeting was held yesterday at Commissioner Fink's office in this city, and all lines were represented save the Inter-State Despatch, Lackawanna line, and Traders' Dispatch.
A house is to be built for the hippopotami in Central Park. It is to cost $1,000. These matters were determined by the Commissioners of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday.
St. Augustine's Chapel, on East Houstonstreet, was crowded yesterday morning at the opening session of the Diocesan Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the NewYork Diocese.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26.--Martin Loftus, a brakeman on the second extra eastbound freight train due in this city from NewYork at 8:55 A.M., had a narrow escape from death or serious injury this morning.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 26.--The detectives here believe that in arresting W. August Fonde at Biloxi, Miss., yesterday, they have captured the leader of a gang of counterfeiters numbering at least 15 men, most of whom were recent ly driven out of Illinois.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Sept. 26.--Mr. Garrett's condition is more favorable, his appetite being good. He sleeps well and is gaining in weight. To-day he walked about the lawne for three or four hours and read all the daily papers.

PIERRE, Dakota, Sept. 26.--In a sham battle at Fort Sully this morning between Companies A, B, C, and D hot blood arose and the men got into such close quarters that several were severely injured, three being in the hospital now with wounds received. The officers drew their swords and Lieut. Aughem received a severe wound in the arm.

IHACA, N. Y., Sept. 26.--All day long registration continued at Cornell University. Late students are coming in on every train. Over 50 young women were admitted to the Freshman Class this morning. This is nearly double any...
BISMARCK, Dakota, Sept. 26.--The wheat crop in the Missouri slope and within a radius of 100 miles of Bismarck is 50 per cent. better than last year and is mostly No. 1 hard.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 26.--The Directors of the Norfolk and Western Railroad Company to-day declared a dividend of $1.50 per share upon the preferred stock out of the earnings of the past year, payable Oct. 25.

A meeting of the cheese trade was held yesterday in the Mercantile Exchange to consider the advisability of forming an association for the protection of the cheese receivers and exporters. M. Folsom was elected Chairman and A. D. Marks Secretary.

Mamie Nolan of 46 Market-street, Newark, was taking a drink of water direct from the faucet when something lodged in her throat and she fell to the floor. A physician was called and he extracted an eel 11 inches long. She then soon recevered, but her throat is much inflamed.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 26.--The Inter-Association lacrosse match to-day between the Brants of Paris, Ontario, the champions of the Canadian Association, and the Ottawas of the National Association resulted in a draw. Each took three goals.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26.--Drafts--Sight, 5 cents; telegraphic, 10 cents.

His body was removed to the station house. His address is not known.

The clear skies yesterday brought a big crowd to the Westchester County Fair, at White Plains, and the managers were, consequently, in the best of humor as they contemplated the corresponding increase in the matter of receipts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26.--Capt. Anson of the Chicago ball team said in an interview to-day that he was ready to admit that Chicago has no chance for anything nearer than second place at the end of the season and that New-York will almost certainly win the pennant. He attributes this result to having inexperienced pitchers in the Chicago team.

EASTON, Penn., Sept. 26.--A few days ago Harry Groover, a prominent merchant of Berwick, disposed of his store there and neglected to settle with his creditors.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 26.--Ohio and Indiana united to-day again, through their delegations, in paying their respects to Gen. Harrison. BELVIDERE, N.J., Sept. 27.--Michael Bollimshire, a Hungarian, was murdered at Oxford Furnace last night. He was shot twice, his head was crushed in, and he was robbed of $80. The murderer was arrested at Phillipsburg and placed in jail.

DOUGHERTY, Texas, Sept. 27.--Gov. Guy marched to the Chickshaw Capitol this morning with an armed force and took his seat about 7 o'clock. Gov. Guy was legally elected Governor, but was counted out by the Byrd party and Byrd took the seat as Governor.
WINNIPEG, Sept. 27.--Bishop Young of the Church of England has forwarded to the Dominion Government at Ottawa an appeal in behalf of the starving Indians in the Canadian Northwest.

LONDON, Sept. 27.--Henry M. Stanley's interpreter, Farran, has signed a statement withdrawing the charges of undue severity made by him against the late Major Barttelot. Farran admits that he was actuated by spite in bringing the accusations.

LISBON, Sept. 27.--The Crown Prince, who is acting as Regent in the absence of the King, to-day received Herr Gottler, the new German Minister to Portugal. Herr Gottler, in presenting his credentials, alluded to German colonial extensions as bringing Germany in close and friendly contact with Portugal.

The second union of the veterans of the Sixth New-York Cavalry was held in the Metropolitan Hotel yesterday. One hundred members of the association were present. President Hermance, who presided, made a few appropriate remarks, and after the reports of...

Henry S. Baker, 79 years old, a resident of Harrison, Westchestsr County, while at Ann-street and Park-row yesterday morning was knocked down by a horse belonging to the Bleecker-Street and Fulton Ferry Railroad, and had his left arm broken, and his left leg and left eye contused. He was taken to the Chambers-Street Hospital.

The Democratic State Central Committee has reliable information from six Republican counties that they will go Democratic this year on the tariff issue. A large Norwegian vote in these counties is almost solidly Democratic.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 27.--Ed A. Lipton, Secretary of the Trotting Horse Breeders' Association, to-day perfected arrangements by which Prince Wilkes, Rosalind, and Susie S. will participate in a race for a two-thousanddollar purse on Friday, Oct. 12. Axtell, the famous 2-year-old, will also be here.
Steamship City of Rome, (Br.,) Young, Liverpool and Queenstown 8 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Henderson Brothers.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 27.--The steamer Eolus of the Newport and Wickford Line, caught fire this morning while off Gould Island, in the bay. The fire was caused by an explosion of hitroglycerine, a quantity of which was in one of the express packages. The side of the schooner was quite badly burned, but she is making her trips as usual.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 27.--President Neal Mitchell issues the following official bulletin for the 24 hours ending at 6 o'clock to-day; New cases, 131; deaths, 8; total number of cases to date, 2,368; total number of deaths to date, 238. The deaths are:

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 27.--Bach Brothers, clothing dealers at Wabash, have failed. Liabilities, $36,000; assets, $21,000. About half the liabilities are due to New-York, Philadelphia, and Cincinnati firms, the remainder to residents of Wabash.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27.--Major Charles A. Wikoff, Fourteenth Infantry, has been detailed as a member of the Army Retiring Board at Vancouver Barracks, Washington Territory, relieving Col. Thomas M. Anderson, Fourteenth Infantry.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 27.--Articles of association were filed in the Secretary of State's office this morning by the Kansas City, Fort Smith and Southern Railway Company of a new road, which will run from a point on the northern line of Arkansas, in Benton County, south...
General Passenger Agent Farmer of the Erie Road advised Commissioner Pierson yesterday that he had notified General Passenger Agent Shattue of the Ohio and Mississippi Road...
AUCKLAND, Sept. 27.--The latest advices from Samoa state that Malietoa's followers had occupiad Apia and proclaimed Mataafa King. A battle was fought on the 12th inst. lasting several hours.
MADRID, Sept. 27.--Eighty cases of dynamite have exploded on a wharf at Carthagena, causing much damage. Nobody was killed.

With the promise of a good track this afternoon the trainers at Prospect Park were more liberal in their entries last night, and unless rain should again interfere the sport will be a decided improvement over that which the public has had to content itself with of late.

BOSTON, Sept. 27.--Beautiful weather largely increased the attendance at Mystic Park to-day, and between 3,000 and 4,000 people were present. The track was heavy and the trotting slow. In the first event Gillig was an easy winner, leading his competitors at the finish in each heat.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 27.--The meeting of the National Farmers' Alliance, which is to take place in Meridian, Miss., in a few days, will have before it as the leading question the Cotton Bagging Trust resolutions, first adopted by the State Farmer's Alliances in Alabama, Georgia, and South Carolina. After denouncing the trust the resolutions continue:

It seems to us that the Southern Senators--Messrs. GIBSON of Louisiana and COKE of Texas particularly--make a mistake in opposing the investigation by a Senate committee of allegations of systematic suppression of votes in their States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27.--The "bloody shirt" waved in the Senate Chamber for several hours to-day, and it was accompanied by some of the discreditable personal controversies and bandying of epithets which have so frequently disgraced the Senate.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 27.--William K. Vanderbilt, Leonard Jerome, F. Bronson, Prescott Lawrence, and one or two others of NewYork, arrived in Batavia this morning in a private car on the New-York Central Railroad.

The Ontario and Western Road will have an excursion leaving Toronto to-morrow for this city with 300 persons aboard. They will come on a special train from Suspension Bridge to New-York, arriving here Sunday morning.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 27.--Postmaster Larkin said to a reporter to-day: "The rumor is true that a prominent manufacturer in this city has gone over to Cleveland, and is in favor of the passage of the Mills bill. He had also subscribed $5,000 to the Democratic campaign fund."

The new White Lead Trust and its probable effect on the paint and oil business throughout the country was the chief subject of conversation among merchants dealing in that king of goods yesterday. The jobbers who handle great quantities of white lead were not consulted by the organizers of the scheme.

BERLIN, Sept. 27.--The Reichsanzeiger publishes a report to Emperor William prepared by Prince Bismarck, in which the Chancellor says that there are some errors of fact and chronology in the published extracts from Emperor Frederick's diary which lead him to believe that they are not authentic. The text of Prince Bismarck's report is as follows:
TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 27.--Charles Horming, a young man suffering from typhold fever, shot himself in the stomach while delirious this afternoon while his nurse was out of his room.
The Diocesan Convention of the Episcopal Church finished its work yesterday afternoon and adjourned. The sessions were well attended and interest in the deliberations of the body kept up to the end.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 27.--John M. Pollock of the banking firm of John R. Wiltsie Son, who was convicted yesterday of grand larceny in the first degree for having appropriated to the use of his firm the proceeds of a...
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 27.--The greatest novelty at the Rhode Island State Fair at Narragansett Park was the marriage this afternoon of a young Providence couple in the balloon Commonwealth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27.--The Senate Committee on Finance began to-day the inquiry, provider for by the resolution of Senator Platt, into the operations in this country of the French copper syndicate.

John Townsend, a colored man, 54 years old, whose home is in Bayside, Long Island, was found murdered in bed this morning. Townsend had not been seen for two days, during which time his cottage had been closed. Mrs. Stranahan, who was the first to discover the murder, found everything in the house in confusion as though thieves had ransacked it. The Coroner will make a thorough investigation.

LONDON, Sept. 27.--At the Newmarket meeting to-day the race for the Newmarket October Handicap was won by Sir R. Jardini's Wise Man, with Kingfisher second, and St. Helen third. The betting was 4 to 1 against Wise Man.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 27.--The gasket blew out of the boiler at the electric light works tonight and Engineer John Hodapp was badly scalded by the escaping steam. He will recover. The city was plunged in darkness for an hour and a half by the accident.

In the early part of September, at the request of Lieut. G.L. Dyer, the United States Hydrographer stationed at this port. Everett Harden was detailed to go to the West Indies to make a study of West Indian hurricanes.
The Clifton Tennis Club began its tournament at Fort Wadsworth, Staten Island, yesterday, with this result:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27.--The old side-wheel steamboat Juniata, which has been plying between Wilmington, Del., and Penns Grove, N.J., was burned to the water's edge this morning. The loss is unknown, but is small. The boat was built in 1848.

Maxwell P. Jackson, 36 years old, of 512 Jersey-avenue, Jersey City, a guard on the Ninth-Avenue Elevated Railroad, while coming down town on a Sixth-avenue train last evening fell off the platform of the car between Fifty-sixth and Fiftyseventh streets. The train ran over his legs, cutting both off. He was taken to the Roosevelt Hospital. His condition is serious.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 27.--The return cricket match between the gentlemen of Ireland and All Philadelphia was begun this morning. Owing to their great victory over All New-York at Staten Island, together with...

CHICAGO, Sept. 27.--Cards were issued yesterday for the wedding of Miss Kate Gresham, daughter of Judge Walter Q. Gresham, and W.H. Andrews of this city. The wedding will take place next Tuesday evening at 7:30 o'clock, the ceremony being performed in the Fourth Presbyterian Church.

Ten lawsuits have been begun in the Supreme Court to recover $89,400 from as many companies operating ferry lines from this city. Stephan Wray and Francis A. Wilson are the persons who hope to have the corporations forced to pay this amount, and John A. Amund son is the attorney.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 27.--Three hundred enthusiastic Democrats of the Third Congressional District, which comprises the counties of Monmouth, Ocean, and Middlesex, met in the Opera House here at noon to-day to nominate a candidate for Congress.

Corporation Counsel Beekman yesterday sent to the Police Commissioners a letter advising them to refuse the application of the United Labor Party for the recognition of the election inspectors appointed in its behalf last year.
In one respect the County Democracy have the advantage of Tammany Hall. They have a man whom they can and do point to as a candidate for Mayor.
CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 27.--Water has covered the track of the Vera Cruz Railway at Apam and the company is endeavoring to prevent the encroachment of the floods.

An informal reception was tendered to the team of 50 Irish athletes last night by the Gaelic Society at its rooms, 17 West Twenty eighth-street. All of the members of the team were present under the leadership of the Rev. Father Concannon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27.--The investigation into the charges of fraud in the construction of the Washington aqueduct was continued to-day and fully confirmed the conclusions reached from the examinations made the previous day. Each day brings to light new evidence of fraud and bad workmanship.

AMERICUS, Ga., Sept. 27.--Charles Blackman, was to-day sentenced to be hanged on Oct. 19. This is the fourth time sentence has been passed upon him, but he has now reached his last chance. He crept up behind Stonewall Fondoe in the dark and shot and killed him.

The attendance at the third annual fair of the Westchester County Agricultural and Horticultural Society at White Plains yesterday was the largest of the season by several thousands. Various estimates placed the number present at between 6,000 and 8,000.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 27.--James Stone and wife, an aged couple of Poland, while driving home to-day from Randolph, were strvck by an Erie express train, and both were killed.
In a very kind letter to the President of the New-York Press Club, Miss Cora Tanner volunteers to devote the gross receipts of a matinee to be given at the Fourteenth-Street...
COLORADO CITY, Texas, Sept. 27.--O.J. Wiren's big ranch and herd of cattle, the wellknown Circle Bar outfit, was sold to-day at Trustee sale to satisfy a mortgage for over $300,000.

Coroner Nugent yesterday held an inquest in the case of James Fogarty, the 19-year-old printer, who was found dying at Cherry and Catharine streets on the night of Sept. 9, with three inches of an umbrella ferule in his right eye.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 27.--A meeting of the Democratic State Central Committee was held at the headquarters in the Merchants' Hotel here to-day. The committee's session was strictly executive, and was very long.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 27.--William Elliott (Democrat) was to-day renominated for Congress from the Seventeenth District.
The latest accident on the elevated road is a surprising illustration of the good luck that has attended the operation of the system.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27.--A small sample of political clap-trap was started some days ago to the effect that during the Grand Army encampment the residence of Judge Thurman was not decorated and no flags were visible.
New-York's coming champions arrived home yesterday and in the afternoon began their final series in a game against the Washington Club.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 27.--The opinion of Judge Brewer on the appointment of a Receiver for the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway was submitted to the distinguished attorneys this morning.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 27.--Gen. Harrison's visitors to-day came from Ohio--from Hancock and Allen Counties--and numbered several hundred. Gen. Harrison was looking refreshed, and spoke with his accustomed vigor, touching upon wages, the tariff, and pauper labor. He said:

LONDON, Sept. 27.--"Carina," the new comic opera produced at the Opera Comique to-night, gives every indication of achieving a pronounced success: The story is light and good, the comedy opportunities are numerous, and the music is artistically firm and popularly pleasing.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27.--One man did great things on the Board of Trade to-day. He turned the wheat market just as he pleased, and the only turn he allowed was upward. He handled September wheat so successfully that in spite of a slight reaction at the last it closed at an advance of 21 cents a bushel.

SIOUX FALLS, Dakota, Sept. 27.--Several days ago a lady living on the outskirts of this place was surprised to see coming to her house a middle-aged woman, with golden hair and blue eyes, who looked tired and worn out. She said: "I am lost and hungry.
The police interfered on Wednesday last with the preparations of the Cleveland and Thurman Club of the Consolidated Exchanges to swing a banner across Broadway near Morrisstreet.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 27.--The Victoria British Columbia Board of Trade is protesting to the Dominion Government regarding the encroachment of American fishermen in fishing inside the three-mile limit in British Columbia.

The jury in the Schilling case after being locked up all night appeared in court yesterday with a verdict of manslaughter in the first degree, with a recommendation to mercy. The verdict was much criticised by many who had watched the progress of the case.

The performance of Guy at Fleetwood track on Friday last has been both equaled and surpassed by Maud S. this year without any preparation either of herself or of the track. On July 23 last John Murphy drove her a mile,...

Police Captain McLaughlin marched James E. Bedell, the dishonest managing clerk for Shipman, Barlow, Larocque Choate, into the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning. Mr. Solomon Hanford of the legal firm defrauded by Bedell was present to represent their interests.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 27.--At last the Northwestern roads are in harmony. They have patched up their differences and agreed unanimously to advance freight rates to the basis of 60 cents (first-class) between Chicago and St. Paul.

Late on Tuesday afternoon a slightlybuilt, well-dressed young man entered the wholesale jewelry establishment of S.F. Myers Co., 48 and 50 Maiden-lane, and, stating that he was a customer of the firm, desired to be shown some watches. He selected a dozen gold cases and movements and ordered them mounted.

The Stock Exchange had a boom in earnest yesterday. It was such a day as Wall-street lately has known only by recourse to memory. There wasn't a bull but that was radiant and rosy. There was hardly a stock that didn't rise.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27.--To-day's bond offerings aggregated $537,500, as follows: Registered fours--$60,000 at 130, $1,500 at 128 ex interest.

ALBANY, Sept. 27.--At a recent meeting of the State Railroad Commission with several representatives of railroads, regarding the putting into effect the heating of cars by steam, as directed by chapter 616, Laws of 1887, and chapter 189, Laws of 1887, it was suggested that the commission recommend a steam coupler for universal use in this State.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 27.--The Republican politicians were here in force to-day, and the convention for the selection of Presidential Electors was therefore well attended. Senator Henry M. Nevins of Monmouth presided.

At a late hour last night the mangled body of a man believed to be Joseph Young, Jr., of 259 West One Hundred and Thirteenth-street, was found on the tracks of the suburban elevated railroad on Third-avenue, between One Hundred and Thirtythird and One Hundred and Thirty-fourth streets. He had evidently been struck and crushed to death by a passing train.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Sept. 27.--Gov. Hill delivered an address on the grounds of the Ontario Agricultural Society this afternoon to a large throng of people. This evening, after reviewing a big parade of Democratic clubs, he addressed an enthusiastic audience, almost as large as that on the agricultural grounds.

ALBANY, Sept. 27.--Lieut. Gov. Jones presided at the session of the State Board of Equalization to-day. All the State officers, excepting Speaker of Assembly Cole, were present, as were also the three State Assessors. The latter presented a table of equalized values which they had prepared since the last meeting early in the month.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27.--The races here to-day so far as concluded were with the results given below. There was no poolselling, word having been received from Police Headquarters that it must be stopped.

The performance for the benefit of the yellow fever sufferers given at Wallack's Theatre yesterday afternoon under the management of Col. John A. McCaull was, artistically and financially, one of the greatest successes ever realized for a charitable object.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 27.--To-day was the third day of the Republican Convention of the Thirty-first Congressional District, and this afternoon, on the two hundred and thirty seventh ballot, the dead-lock was broken. The twoterm idea, which has prevailed in this district,...
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 27.--The Thirtythird District Democratic Congressional nomination was made at the International Hotel, Niagara Falls, this afternoon. E.B. Swift of Niagara was Chairman.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Sept. 27.--At the opening of the session of the Indian Conference this morning, the announcement of the appointment of Mr. Oberly as Commissioner of Indian Affairs was received with applause.

LOWER BRULE AGENCY, Dakota, Sept. 26. --Contrary to expectations no general council was held here to-day. The delegations from different agencies have been holding private councils in various places, but although the Commissioners express themselves as hopeful no great change is manifest in the sentiment of the Indians.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27.--The investigation into the charges against Representative Stahlnecker of New-York was resumed to-day. Senator Voorhees said he had talked with Mr. Stahlnecker repeatedly during the Forty-ninth Congress about material for use in the new Library building.

The fight against Gov. Hill's re-election is rapidly spreading, and well-informed men are calculating that at least 35,000 Democrats in this part of the State will unite against the rumsellers' nominee for the Governorship. One of the latest, and at the same time most vigorous,...

T.P. Rogers Son, dealers in cider and vinegar at 370 to 376 Washington-street, have become financially embarrassed. A few weeks ago the firm gave a chattel mortgage for $10,000 to ketcham Co. as security for money loaned.

The first noonday meeting of the Cleveland and Thurman Wholesale Dry Goods Club yesterday at its headquarters, 343 Broadway, was a crowning success. When Chairman Walter Stanton called it to order there were present fully 900 citizens, nearly all engaged in the dry goods trade and many of them leading merchants of the city.
This afternoon the New-York and Detroit Clubs will play on the Polo Grounds. Whittaker, a pitcher of the Dallas, (Texas,) Club has been engaged by Baltimore.
