The Brooklyn Jockey Club will to-day bring to a close a meeting that has, considering the disadvantages it has suffered by reason of inclement weather, been a very successful one.
The cable ordered by the Fire Department to be used in underground telegraphic service has been delivered, and on Monday the work of drawing it into the subways will be begun.

Two to two was the result of the NewYork-Detroit game yesterday. Ten innings were played, and as neither side could tally a deciding run the contest was called on account of darkness. At times the Giants played good ball, especially when the bases were unoccupied, and evoked applause from the spectators.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28.--The Prohibition Party has nominated Robert R. Corson for City Treasurer and John B. Scott for Register of Wills.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 28.--A white man named Benjamin De Berry met a horrible death to-day in Anson County. He was driving in a buggy and was much intoxicated.
The Dry Goods Chronicle to-day contains an article, concerning the proper site for the proposed new stores in this city for the Appraiser's Department.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 28.--A month ago a widow named Tobin, who had been employed in a millinery shop at Potsdam, died. Before her death she declared her belief that a Miss Clay, employed in the same shop, and of whom she was jealous, had poisoned her.

Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court has granted an injunction in favor of John Sevier, restraining the Missouri, Kansas, and Texas Railway Company from applying the earnings of the road to any purpose but the operating expenses, repairs, and interest.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 28.--The Chicago Freight Committee of the Central Traffic Association to-day passed a resolution providing that on east-bound freights the rates on articles in the first, second, and third classes be restored to the tariff on March 5.

Just two months ago that extremely erratic and at times very speedy filly Connemara, with "Spider" Anderson riding at 100 pounds, went out at Monmouth Park and won the Navesink Handicap at a mile and a half, beating Mr. Haggin's filly Firenzi easily by four or five lengths in 2:35 . Firenzi was a hot favorite then, Garrison riding at 121 pounds, and the odds were 20 to 1 against Connemara.

The fifth season of grand opera in German at the Metropolitan Opera House will open on Wednesday evening, Nov. 28, with either "Don Giovanni" or "Siegfried." There will be 47 subscription nights and 16 matinees, making a total of 63 performances. The season will close March 23, 1889.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Sept. 28.--The September product of the Ropes Mine in gold and silver bullion and concentrates exceeds $6,000, the largest product in the history of the mine.
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 28.--A peculiar will case has just been decided in the Probate Court for Washtenaw County.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--The majority report of the Utah Commission, signed by G.L. Godfrey, A.B. Williams, and Arthur L. Thomas, was received this morning by the Secretary of the Interior.

BUFFALO, Sept. 28.--It would seem as if there was no limit to the extent to which the Polish people will go in their efforts to conceal cases of smallpox, and that, too, when cold weather is approaching.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--Waclav Zanelzky, a Bohemian laborer, shot his daughter, Mrs. Mary Jelick, last evening; inflicting a fatal wound. Zanelzky had been drunk and quarrelsome all day, and finally began to abuse his wife.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 28.--Judge Given of the District Court has struck another blow at the liquor sellers of Iowa.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Sept. 28.--There is no change in Robert Garrett's condition to-day. Dr. Jacobs, the attending physician, permitted him to take some exercise on the grounds. He has not had one of his violent attacks for two days, and his physician feels more hopeful.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 28.--With scant newspaper notice and without brass band or parade of any kind the City Opera House was filled to-night by an intelligent and responsive audience assembled on the call of the New-York Reform Club to listen to the Hon. John E. Russell of Massachusetts discuss "The Woolen Industry as Affected by the Tariff."

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 28.--There was great rejoicing among the railroad men in St. Paul when the news was received from Chicago that an agreement had been reached by which rates would be raised, and it was considered the most important action taken by Northwestern lines in many months.

Mr. Blaine arrived in the city last evening on the Shore Line train from Boston, accompanied by his son, Walker Blaine. He left Boston at 1 o'clock in the afternoon. Mrs. Blaine, who had intended to accompany him, was obliged to return home, which she did, accompanied by "Joe" Manley.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 28.--The Democratic State Committee has been in session this afternoon, and, with the approach of the election, it may be expected to assemble at headquarters every day. It is called "A ways and means meeting" by Chairman Jewett, and that is about as much as it is possible for the public to learn regarding the business proceedings.

JAMESTOWN, Dakota, Sept. 28.--Reports from the prairie fires continue to come in, and the worst fears are realized. In the southern part of the county whole townships have been swept and many small farmers have lost everything.

A shot was fired on the skirmish line yesterday. It sped from the County Democracy's side and went through two parroy men who happened to be outposts. It is a question yet whether it was fired with malice or was accidental.
NOGALES, Arizona, Sept. 28.--Details have arrived of the recent suicide of Senor Florence Luiz, one of the best known and wealthiest ranchmen in Sonora.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 28.--There is trouble in the Union National Bank in this city, but exactly what the nature of the trouble is it is hard to determine, for the officials are reticent. Cashier D.A. Chapin has resigned, and his resignation was due to a demand made by Bank Examiner Getchell.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28.--Lewis Cobb, 65 years old, committed suicide near the Lincolnsquare crossing on the Boston and Maine Railroad at 8 o'clock this morning by throwing himself in front of a moving car. He was instantly killed. He had been suffering with rheumatism.
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 28.--Charles W. Waldron, the Hillsdale banker who converted all his assets into cash and ran away with Mrs. Nellie Bidwell, is in London, England.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--Capt. Benjamin Munday and Capt. William O. Owen, Jr., Assistant Surgeons, have been ordered before the Army Medical Examining Board at New-York for examination for promotion.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28--The attendance at the international match between the Irish cricketers and All Philadelphia to-day was very much larger than that of the previous day, the grand stand being nearly filled, while the ropes were well lined with interested spectators.

Peter Bergstrom, proprietor of an iron foundry at 179 Plymouth-street, Brooklyn, was testing a new boiler yesterday when it exploded. His face and head were badly torn by the flying metal and he died before he could be removed to the hospital. Bergstrom was 35 years old and lived with his family at 164 High-street.

A dispatch from Lieut.-Col. CLENDENIN, Third Cavalry, commanding at Ringgold Barracks, gives assurance that the peril from the mob in Rio Grande City is practically over. As is usually the case on the Mexican border, the danger was exagger ated, as the facts will show.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 28.--Mrs. McGarrigle, wife of the Chicago boodler, arrived here to-night and will join her husband at Banff Hot Springs to-morrow. McGarrigle has decided to locate permanently at Banff.

Capt. Reilly and Detective Brett last night arrested Dr. Jeremiah Coughlin of 225 Henry-street for violating the law relating to lotteries at the Anti-Poverty Fair in Madison-Square Garden. He was admitted to bail in the amount of $500. Detective Brett secured the evidence against him by buying a ticket in the drawing for the bust of Dr. McGlynn.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--Cash and September wheat made another long jump to-day, going from $1 25 to $1 50 a bushel. In many respects the day gave a close reproduction of yesterday's doings on the Board of Trade. Hutchinson, the sole monarch of the situation, was just as calm, just as philosophical, and just as steady in advancing prices as he was yesterday.

Jacob Stark, a tailor living over his shop at 839, Park-avenue, Brooklyn, shot himself in the right breast last night while suffering from de spondency caused by poor business. The ball passed through one of his lungs. He was removed to the Homeopathic Hosptial where it is thought he will die.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 28.--Richard Coleman, a prominent farmer of Edgefield County, has recently been very despondent over the damage to the crops by the freshets. Yesterday he arose from the family dinner table, went into an adjoining room, took his gun, seated himself in a window, placed the muzzle of the gun against his heart, and pushed off the trigger with a yard stick, killing himself instantly. He was 53 years old.

The dinner which was given to Oscar S. Straus, Minister to Turkey, at Sieghortner's restaurant, in Lafayette-place, last night, was one which will be remembered by its participants with pleasure. The pretty dining room was artistically decorated, and the company, being limited to personal friends of Mr. Straus, was peculiarly congenial.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28.--The music festival closed to-night with a grand performance of Handel's oratorio, "The Messiah," the noble choruses of which were given with thrilling effect by the magnificent choir under Carl Zerrahn's direction.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 28.--Princeton College has chosen the following football team, subject, however, to change: Rush line--S. Hodge, Cook, Irvine, George, Cowan, Tredinnick, and Bovaird. SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30.--Betting on the result of the Presidential election has not as yet assumed very extensive proportions in this city. The opinion prevails that the contest will be a close one.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--Nothing is more certain to provoke laughter and derision in Republican circles in New-York, Indiana, or Illinois than the suggestion that Illinois is a doubtful State.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--Betting on the results of the coming election has not been spirited in Chicago. In fact, wagers of any considerable amount have been few and far between, and even when they have been made there have been no standard odds.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30.--What were the handsome headquarters of the Young Repubicans, at Twelfth and Chestnut streets, are now three stories of burned timbers, broken walls, and water-soaked ceilings.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 30.--Albert Hyde, a prominent citizen of this town, who had been ticket agent at the Boston and Albany Railroad station in Pittsfield for the past 25 years, dropped dead at a ...

CINCINNATI, Sept. 30.--The Lincoln Club filed a petition in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday for an injunction against the removal from the cars of a street railway company of display cards upon which are printed maxims favoring high protective duties.

T.B. Barry of the General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor came to twon yesterday and called on the Pythagoras faction of District Assembly No. 49, and toll the delegates that the split in the District Assembly was due to wrangling.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--Peter Straubb, a Chicago machinist, went to Matton, Ill., not long ago to secure employment. While in that town he got the idea that he was being pursued by demons.
WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 30.--Mrs. L. Hildebrandt died this morning from the effects of pistol shot wounds inflicted by her husband about 8 o'clock last evening at the residence of ...
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30.--It is impossible to find any betting of consequence on the Presidential election. One bet is in the hands of a leading broker--$500 to $400--on Cleveland.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 30.--Yesterday was a "banner day" in freights, at least as far as rates go. In consequence of a lack of available room and the continued demand in the North the figures for steam were put up to 7.16d. ...

LONDON, Sept. 30.--There was an active demand for discount during the past week at 4 to 3 . The shipments of gold to Russsia and La Plata, combined with the immediate redemption of three millions of Indian stock, leads to the expectation that the Bank of England rate will become 1 on Thursday. On the Stock Exchange business was good and prices were firm.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 30.--Some betting on election has been done here, but it is mostly in a small way and dollar for dollar. The heaviest wager laid is $4,000 on the general result.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 30.--The first through train from San Luis Potosi to this city, over the newly-constructed Mexican National Railway, due this morning, did not arrive here until afternoon, having been thrown from the track at Zirizicuaro in the State of Michoacan, owing to the bad state of the track. It is not yet learned that there were any casualties.

We presume that Brig.-Gen. S.V. BENET is an efficient and accomplished Chief of Ordnance, and that he acted with entire sincerity when he issued his order of Jan. 4, 1886, directing that preference should be given to Democrats in appointments to vacancies in the armories and arsenals.

At a meeting held in St. Michael's Institute in Jersey City last night in favor of home rule for Ireland speeches were made by Gov. Green of NewJersey, Congressman McAdoo, and others. It was one of the largest meetings ever held in Jersey City, Mayor Cleveland presided.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 30.--Very few bets on the result of the State and National tickets have been made in this city. During the week three bets, even money, of $100 each, have been made that Hill's majority in the State would be over 20,000.

There was just enough rawness in the air yesterday to make topcoats comfortable and a clipping gait along the road enjoyable. Thousands took advantage of the day to drive out on Seventh-avenue, over Macomb's Dam Bridge, and up Jerome-avenue to the Park.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 30.--The interest in the Presidential election here is totally void of financial features. Just before the Chicago Convention there was some disposition to make wagers upon the result between the two political parties.
The General County Committee of the Personal Liberty League not at Beethoven Hall in Fifth-street, yesterday afternoon.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--Good business has been the rule at the playhouses of Chicago during the last week. While Booth and Barrett have, of course, held the first place in public interest.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30.--Very little money has been placed on the election in this city. Sporting men, when asked why this is so, reply that those having money which they are willing to risk on the result do not care to have it tied up until November, but prefer to wait ...

Chairman Midgley of the Southwestern Division of the Western Freight Association is in receipt of a letter from Chairman Blanchard of the Central Traffic Association signifying a willingness on the part of the Eastern lines to have the joint rate committee resume its former duties.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 30.--Few election wagers have been made here, and these for small sums ranging from $100 down. Ed Sanderson bet a Chicago Democrat $1,000 to $800 that Harrison would be the next President.

The sections of the Socialistic Labor Party held a conference yesterday at 89 First-avenue. First a resolution was passed not to participate in the parade in commemoration of the execution of the Chicago Anarchists.

ST. Louis, Sept. 30.--The crowd that gathered to see to-day's St. Louis-Brooklyn game was probably the largest that over witnessed a ball game in St. Louis, and eclipsed in size the great crowd that witnessed the last Sunday St. Louis-Athletic game in 1883.
HAMBURG, Sept. 30.--Prof. Geffcken returned here from Heligoland last evening and was immediately arrested. He will be ex amined before a magistrate to-morrow.

Siegfried Sittner, who is a trade watch reparier at 61 Nassau-street, was arrested on Saturday for disposing of 10 chronometers worth more than $1,500 which belonged to H. H. Heinrich of 14 John-street and for cheating a number of jewelers, watch dealers, and diamond brokers out of $4,500 worth of property obtained on memorandum.

DENVER Col., Sept. 30.--The betting on Presidential and State elections in this city this year is not so heavy as in former years, but a great deal more exciting.

The last two weeks' racing in this State this year begins at Jerome Park this afternoon, racing continuing daily, excepting on Saunday, until Saturday of next week, when the horses will most of them see the close of a hard season's work.

Democratic primaries for the election of delegates to the City, County, Assembly, and Congressional Conventions will be held in Kings County on Oct. 18. The County Convention will be held at 3 o'clock on Oct. 22. the City at 8 o'clock on the same day, the Assembly Conventions on Oct 23, and the Congressional on Oct. 24.
Oscar Simeons, 60 years of age, a salesman for Rosenthal Co., cloak manufactures, in Broadway, was found dead in his bed yesterday morning at his home at 115 West Twelfth-street.

The telegraphers of this city, and in fact of every other city in the country, will be glad to learn than Willis J. Cook, who has been seriously ill at the Roosevelt Hospital for five weeks, is now in a fair way to recover.
The two events in the tourney of the Clifton Tennis Club, which came off at Fort Wadsworth, Staten Island, yesterday, were the final rounds in the ladies' and gentlemen's singles.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 1.--The Pennsylvania Company, after a bitter fight, has been defeated in its effort to stop the payment of commissions on the sale of tickets.

Over half a million shares of stock, were dealt in on the Stock Exchange yestersday, and up to the very close of the day's business everything boomed beautifully. In the last half hour of the day, though, a little chill crept into the market, contracting some of the buoyancy and chilling the ardor of the boom.

There are some theatrical enterprises every Winter involving the expenditure of large sums of money that puzzle even the old habitues of the playhouses who understand perfectly well the uncertainty of experiments in the drama and the prevailing fallibility of judgment regarding the value of plays.

Judge Barrett, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday denied the motion of Henry Parsons for a writ of mandamus to compel the Board of Police Commissioners to fill the vacancies in the lists of United Labor Party election inspectors.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 1.--A terrific storm of rain and wind, accompanied by vivid lightning, passed over the city between 5 and 6 o'olook this evening. In the city many shade trees were broken down, telegraph and telephone wires mixed up, and roofs blown off. At the Centennial grounds considerable damage was done to buildings and exhibits amounting to fully $10,000.

Senator Barnum returned to the city last evening in good health and ready for business. Gov. Hill spent the day at the Hoffman House, where he conferred with Col. Brice, Edward Murphy, Jr., William H. Murtha, Richard Croker, and other politicians.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 1.--The canal lockages for the month of September from this port, the leading one on the line of the canal, amount to 3,904. There were 1,422 eastbound loaded boats and 1,411 west-bound, with 261 cribs of timber, going east.
C.C. Marsh Co., bankers and brokers in the Mills Building, suspended yesterday and made an assignment without preference to George H. Adams.

ALBANY, Oct. 1.--In the Court of Appeals today the following business was transacted: Appeals Argued.--No. 9--Cyrus W. Lades, re- spondent vs. William M. whelpley, et al., appellants. --Case was on appeal from decree, or judgment of the General Term.

Five to nothing and in New-York's favor was the result of the game yesterday on the Polo Grounds with Detroit. It was a bitter dose for the champions, but when the Giants start out to do a thing they seldom do it by halves.

LONDON, Oct. 1.--Advices from Africa say that an expedition consisting of 300 Houssas, led by English officers, left Winnebah, on the gold coast, to punish the Togo negroes for murdering Capt. Dalrymple.

Mabel Vaughn, daughter of a retired NewYork merchant of this city, caused a sensation in Montclair, N.J., yesterday, by eloping with her father's coachman, Henry Lupton. He is a goodlooking young Englishman and well educated. It was known that Miss Vaughn accepted the addresses of Lupton, but Mr. Vaughn objected to him for a son-in-law. Saturday the pair, the girl taking $5,000 of her own money, left the town.

"Katti" had its first performance in NewYork at the Bijou Theatre last evening. Miss Marietta Nash, a vivacious seabrette, sustained the principal part. Extended notice of the play and the performance is deferred.

As early as 7:30 o'clock last night the great hall of the Cooper Union was filled with the members of the Wholesale Dry Goods Men's Republican Club and their friends, among whom were a great many ladies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1.--The news of President Cleveland's approval of the Chinese Exclusion bill was received here to-day with a marked degree of interest. Large crowds congregated around the newspaper bulletin boards and discussed the situation.

The General Term of the Supreme Court in Kings County has decided the cases of Edward Annan and F.E. Pinto growing out of their arrest for overcharging for handling grain at this port.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--The United Labor Party issued a circular to-day indorsing Gen. Palmer, the Democratic candidate for Governor, and urging workingmen to vote for him.
The conference committee of the Downtown Business Men's Cleveland and Thurman Club met yesterday at the Stevens House and completed arrangements for the big demonstration on Saturday next.

LONDON, Oct. 1.--Sir Arthur Sullivans new opera is entitied "The Yeoman of the Guard; or, The Merry Man and His Maid."

E.D. Dewert of the Oregonian composing rooms, who accompanied the recent expedition to Crater Lake, taking views of charming bits of scenery, accomplished one thing which he did not look for--the photographing of his own shadow.

Several weeks ago the drug clerks in east side pharmacies inaugurated a movement to shorten their hours to labor, and their efforts have at last been crowned with a measure of success.

N.T. Hardman of 401 Gates-avenue, Brook lyn, reported at Police Headquarters yesterday that as he was riding on the Third-avenue elevated road, from Forty-second-street to City Hall, on last Saturday afternoon, his inside coat pocket was picked of a wallet containing $40 and four gold medals valued at $1,000. He can furnish no clue to the robbers.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 1.--Frank L. Janeway, the President of the company which owns the Fredonian, the leading Republican paper in Central New-Jersey, confirmed to-day the statement that he would vote for Cleveland.
DENVER, Col., Oct. 1.--A.M. Palmer's MadisonSquare company opened here to-night for a week's engagement previous to returning home. The receipts were over $1,000 for the first night.
Investigation in the affairs of Forger Bedell still proceeded yesterday at the law office of Shipman, Barlow, Laroeque Choate without disclosing anything more of importance.
Col. John R. Fellows last night repudiated the statement attributed to him that no more boodle cases were to be tried.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 1.--John Ashworth was committed to-day to the State Insane Asylum. Ashworth and his brother Henry came to this country from England 12 years ago and engaged in the manufacture of Turkey red tablecloths, napkins, , in Cranston.

In giving his approval to the Chinese Exclusion bill President CLEVELAND has taken the somewhat unusual course of sending a message to Congress explaining the reasons which in his opinion justify that measure.
ZANZIBAR, Oct. 1.--The Germans at Bagomoyo are preparing for an expected attack by natives to-morrow. The Italian Envoy, Signor Cecchi, has left, having failed to arrange the dispute with the Sultan.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 1.--The Morning Commercial of this city was sold to-day by the estate of Gen. J.M. Comly to Richard Smith of the Cincinnati Commercial Gazette. The formal transfer will not be made until Nov. 12. Mr. Smith will not himself leave his Cincinnati paper.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1.--Eugene C. Mosely, bigamist, was tried in the Criminal Court today. He pleaded guilty, and threw himself on the mercy of the court. His first wife, whose maiden name was Catherine Frial, sat in company...

The case of William R. Foster, Jr., and Produce Exchange mortgage forger, has become one of exciting interest to the detectives. The statement that a compromise would be accepted by the Trustees of the Gratuity Fund is indignantly repudiated by the President.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 1.--The police authorities at Suspension Bridge have received a request from the police at Newark, N.J, to arrest and hold a handsome and dashing Jewess sailing under the name of Sonna Cohen or Sarah Goldstein, who was expected to arrive at the bridge to-day.

Custom House Inspectors Brown and Donohue on Sunday morning arrested Henry A. Norman, a passenger on the French steamer La Gascogne, for smuggling $1,000 worth of garnet watch jewels. Norman is the agent of the Duber Watch Case Company, and lives in Cincinnati.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 1.--Drafts--Sight, par, telegraphic, 5 cents.

It looks as if the Republican national managers had pretty well decided to leave the fortune of their party in NewYork to the care of Mr. WARNER MILLER. So far as an active canvass of the State on national issues is concerned there has been none and hardly any pretense of any.

BOSTON, Oct. 1.--The Bay State Sugar Refinery shut down Saturday night for an indefinite period, and the fact was unknown to any but those immediately interested until this morning, although such action has been expected by the sugar men generally for the past month.

Postmaster Pearson has been informed by telegraph from San Francisco that the steamship City of New-York arrived at that port Sunday with mails from China and Japan,including mails of HongKong, Aug. 9; Shanghai, Aug. 31:

At Koster Bial's Concert Hall the playbill this week has some new features. Many of the old ones, however, still serve to attract and amuse.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 1.--One of the first acts of President M.E. Ingalls, in assuming charge of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad to-day under the reorganization of that company, was to promulgate a circular announcing the names of his subordinates.

BOSTON, Oct. 1.--The arrest to-day at Lynn of Delia A. Ruggles for arson reveals a pathetic side to a very serious crime. Miss Ruggles is a prepossessing young shoe stitcher in the factory of C.B. Tibbetts, and was about to be married to an estimable young man.

The Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur of Calvary Baptist Church, in Adelphi Hall, at Fifty-second-street and Seventh-avenue, last night, addressed the Young Men's Republican Club of the Seventeenth and Nineteenth Assembly Districts.

MEXICO, Mo., Oct. 1.--Wabash passenger train No. 5, going west and due here at 12:39 A.M., was wrecked one mile west of the Union Station.

The Fall session of Columbia College opened yesterday with its usual excitement and renewal of college duties. The number of students, except in the Law School, was about as usual.

BOSTON, Oct. 2.--The legal time for the assessment of women who desire to vote for members of the School Board at the coming municipal election expired at 10 o'clock this evening.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--James D. Carson, proprietor, and W.H. Morton opened their new Columbia Theatre to-night. It was the most brilliant event of the kind Chicago has ever known.

Two incendiary fires occurred late Sunday night at Port Richmond, Staten Island. One was at Berlan's Hotel, formerly known as the Haggerty Mansion, the other at the residence of Mr. Klingelhoffer, both on the shore road. The fires were fortunately discovered by the police, who extinguished them without the aid of the Fire Department.

The hogs of New-Jersey are growing fit for bacon on the finest apples in the State. The farmers shake the trees every morning for the swine's benefit after the latter have eaten all the russets that have fallen from the overburdened boughs.
A fire broke out yesterday afternoon in the cellar of the double tenement house at 208 and 210 East Fifty-fifth-street caused by the ignition of escaping gas.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 1.--A splendid gift to the people of Detroit has just been completed and will be fully opened for their use within the next fortnight in the shape of a new hospital, which will be placed under the care and management of the homeopathic medical profession.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 1.--The leading Canadian newspapers are talking of what they call the audacions act of Erastus Wiman of New-York in supplying them with information regarding the consideration by the Senate Committee of Foreign Affairs of the question of inviting Canada to become a part of the United States.

The opening article in the Century for October is "An English Deer Park," by the lamented Richard Jefferies. Few men since White of Selborne have written so charmingly of nature as he.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 1.--The first of the races to-day between the schooner yachts Grayling and Sachem was one of the prettiest and closest races ever sailed here, the yachts starting less than a minute apart and there being no time over three minutes between them.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 1.--John S. Wilson, the General Freight Traffic Manager of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company declined to-day to confirm or deny the report that he would soon resign and enter the service of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad.

BOSTON, Oct. 1.--Justice Holmes of the Supreme Court to-day, upon application of the Savings Banks Commissioners, granted a temporary injunction forbidding, the officers of the Union Savings Bank of Fall River to receive deposits or to pay out money.

As the Canadian Pacific takes an excursion from here to NewYork to-morrow at $9 for the round trip, the Canada-Atlantic's action is taken to be the beginning of a rate war.

There was plenty of room on the grounds of the Country Club at Pelham for people who went up there to see the closing races under the auspices of the Country Club Steeplechase Association.
CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 1.--After all there is likely to be a hitch in the much-discussed restoration of rates from here to the seaboard.

LONDON, Oct. 1.--Excitement over the Whitechapel murders has steadily increased during the day, the evening papers devoting all available space to the gory details. As in the preceding cases, however, the murderer continues unknown and unsuspected.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--There is not much hurrahing for Harrison in illinois, but there is a great deal for Fifer. Fifer is the Republican candidate for Governor.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 1.--A man who says his name is Edward Houilihy was arrested here this afternoon by Officers Costello, Hahill, and Sullivan of this city, charged with being the murderer of Millionaire Snell of Chicago.

Miss Cora Tanner, who has been charming New-York's theatregoing people in "Fascination" at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre, has tendered a special matinee perfermance of the play next Thursday afternoon in aid of the newspaper men and their families in Jacksonville who are suffering from yellow fever.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 1.--The Democratic Congressional Convention for this district was held at the Clinton House in this city to-day.

Freight rates on all Western lines were restored yesterday to their old basis. The new agreement is a very strong one, and heavy penalties are to be imposed for violations. The disposition among the general Eastern agents of these roads is to strictly maintain rates, but all are jealously watched that there are no breaches of the agreement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1.--The debt statement issued this afternoon shows that the decrease of the public debt during the month of September amounted to $12,247,026 30. The total cash in the Treasury is $636,376,287 98.

President Knox of the National Bank of the Republic said yesterday that the package containing $5,931 in bills, which mysteriously disappeared Friday from the First Teller's desk, had not been found. At the Pinkerton detective office it was said there were no new developments in the case.

At the meeting of the Municipal Council of the Irish National League last evening Treasurer Roderick J. Kennedy reported that $136 had been received from individual subscribers for the Parnell Defense fund.

The large lecture room of the Loomis Laboratory, 410 East Twenty-sixth-street, was well filled with the pupils of the Medical Department of the University of New-York. and their friends last evening.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2.--Joseph O. Rutter, President of the Traders' Bank, is dying, and his bank, one of the oldest institutions in Chicago, was to-day placed in the hands of a Receiver. The nominal assets are placed at $1,000,000 in round figures and the liabilities at about the same amount.
The return of cold weather brings to this city the usual number of students of art in search of further instruction.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 2.--Six special trains passed south on the Hudson River Railroad to-night, from points along the Rome and Watertown Railroad, and from places in the Mohawk Valley.

The thirty-sixth annual fair of the Suffolk County Agriculture Society was opened yesterday on the society's grounds at Mineola. There was a large attendance for the first day, the visitors present coming from all parts of the county, and many from Queens County.

John Scanlon, a Hoboken laborer, had his wife arrested yesterday for attempting to murder him. He says that when he reached home Monday night he found her intoxicated and abusing the children and he upbraided her.

HARTFOPD, Conn., Oct. 2.--The town election returns in this State, so far as received, show that the Democrats have held their own, and that the State election in November cannot be won by the Republicans without the hardest sort of work.

HAVANA, Oct. 2.--Careful calculations show that the decrease of the sugar crop, owing to the recent cyclone, will not be more than 10 per cent. Estimates made immediately after the cyclone placed the loss at not less than 25 per cent.

The New-York Historical Society held its first stated meeting of the Fall season last night at its library, at the corner of Eleventh-street and Second-avenue. The large hall was comfortably filled.

There is a strong feeling between the Freshmen and the Sophomores at the Stevens Institute of Technology this year.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Oct. 2.--The United States steamer Constellation, from Norfolk. Va., for this navy yard, came into the lower harbor last night and ran into the schooner Nathaniel Lank, carrying away the Lank's jibboom and headgear.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 2.--The start in the second race between the Sachem and Grayling was made at 11:57 o'clock, the Grayling taking the lead. The leg of the course was to the southwest.

A party of Republicans, headed by Col. H.L. Swords, Sergeant-at-Arms of the National Republican Committee, invaded the cafe of the Hoffman House last evening and stirred up considerable excitement there.

An advertisement appeared yesterday saying that "any parties having seen a young man on a bicycle run down by a dog cart in Central Park Sunday noon will confer a favor by sending their addresses to W. Comyns, 345 Sixthavenue."

The Young Republican Club of Brooklyn held a mass meeting last night in the Rink in Clarmont-avenue. Two-thirds of the seats were filled with an audience made up largely of ladies. It was not a very enthusiastic assembly.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 2.--An extraordinary scene was witnessed in the police court this morning, when a negro who had shot two white men was discharged by the Police Judge.

A telegram was received by Mayor Hewitt yesterday from James M. Schumacher of the Executive Committee at Jacksonville. Fla., charged with the distribution of the funds sent there for the relief of the sick and destitute, announcing that three members of the committee are sick and one very near to death.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2.--Ex-Gov. Thomas M. Waller, Consul-General at London, is expected to return home in about two weeks and take an active part in the Presidential campaign, putting in all the time at his disposal after his arrival in Connecticut.

ST. THOMAS, Ontario, Oct. 2.--James G. Blaine passed through this city to-day in Gov. Alger's private car "America." A large number of American and Canadian citizens assembled at the station to welcome him. On his arrival the band played "Blaine of Maine."
MUNICH, Oct. 2.--A banquet was given at the Palace this evening in honor of Emperor William. The Prince Regent proposed the health of the Emperor.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 2.--The Supreme Court of the State has decided that the anti-Mormon test oath, passed by the last Legislature, is unconstitutional.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 2.--An unusually sad and remarkable fatality occurred this morning at Port Sanilac, a small port on Lake Huron 15 miles above Port Huron. The gale on the lakes last night was quite severe and caught many vessels out.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 2.--Chief of Police Child has received a letter from S.Y. Baldwin, the parachute jumper, clearing up the mystery concerning the balloon found on Cumberland Hill Thursday night. Mr. Baldwin parted company with it in midair after an ascent from Freehold, N.J.

An investigation of the attractive display of goods at the furniture warerooms of the George C. Flint Company, 104-108 West Fourteenth-street, will convince the investigator that there are many things new in furniture.

WASHINGTON,Oct. 2.--The "Samoan Question" has reached a point which wakes its satisfactory settlement a matter of very great concern to the United States, and the most careful attention is now being paid to it by our Government.

The seventh debate under the auspices of the Prohibition County Committee will be held in the large meeting room, Cooper Union, at 7:30 this evening. The subject will be "Low License vs. High License vs. Prohibition." The debate is open to all.

The new Lyceum Theatre in Rochester, which has been in process of erection all Summer, will be opened on Monday next. The stockholders decided to secure as strong an attraction as possible to inaugurate the new theatre, and finally concluded to engage the Lyceum company of this city for the opening week of the season.
The finals in the gentlemen's and ladies' singles in the Prospect Park Lawn Tennis Association tournament were played yesterday before a large concourse of people.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 2.--A serious accident by which seven persons were more or less injured occurred on the Maple-street line of the street railway this morning.
RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 2.--George Comstock, Francis Weaver, and William J. Smith, three fisherman of the Navesink Highlands, started on a fishing trip to the Banks early this morning.

BOSTON, Oct. 2.--The State-street sensation to-day was the practical passing of the Atchison dividend. The Atchison Directors this morning decided unanimously to declare a dividend of one-half of 1 per cent. far the quarter instead of 1 per cent., as had been anticipated.

The nineteenth annual fair of the Somerset Agricultural Society began at Somerville, N.J., yesterday under the most favorable auspices. The entries exceed last year's both in numbers and variety in almost every department.

OTTAWA, Oct. 2.--The Dominion Government has learned that the Eighteenth Company of the Royal Engineers, now serving at Halifax, have been increased by a strong draft from the submarine section of the Royal Engineers and the depot companies from Chatham, England. The incident is not regarded here as significant.

Mr. Garrett was more calm yesterday. He is gradually recovering from the violent attack he had on Sunday afternoon. His attendants had less trouble with him yesterday and Monday night, when Mr. Garrett slept comparatively well. If the weather is pleasant to-morrow he will go for a short walk.
Three criminals escaped from the prison pen of Part III., General Sessions, yesterday, owing to its flimsy construction. One of them was quickly recaptured; the others made good their escape.

"The display of dress fabrics, cloakings, and millinery is richer in every respect this Fall than I have ever seen it in either this or any other country," said the buyer of a prominent importing house yesterday to a TIMES reporter.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 2.--The Erie Railroad Company has given notice to the city authorities that, it will hold the city responsible for damages sustained here by the recent washout in the line of the road within the corporate limits.

The Eastern Archery Association will hold its annual meet to-morrow and on Friday at Prospect Park, Brooklyn. The contests will begin at 10 A.M.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Oct. 2.--Henry Tyree was found dead yesterday in the cabin of John Hambrick, a lumberman, on Smither's Creek. There were about a dozen stabs in his breast, one of them being through his heart. Hambrick has disappeared. There is no cause known at present for the murder, and the Coroner's Jury returned a verdict simply charging Hambrick with the crime.

Chicago's bank failure, the reduction of the Atchison Railroad's dividend, and a continuation of the general scare among the room traders knocked yesterday's stock market topsyturvy. Prices went down all along the list. Even the cliqued and pooled specialties suffered.

LONDON, Oct. 2.--The carnival of blood continues. It is an extremely strange state of affairs altogether, because before the Whitechapel murders began several papers called attention to the fact that there have been more sanguinary crimes committed in London and its vicinity this Summer than ever before known in this city in the same space of time.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2.--Minnie Kratzenburg, a 13-year-old girl living at 3,218 Wentworth-avenue, coolly confessed to-day to having tried to poison her family by putting rat poison in their soup.

PARIS, Oct. 2.--Owing to the increase of immigration into France President Carnot has signed a decree regulating the residence of forgation to furnish a declaration with documents to prove their identity.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2.--The Nickel Plate Road, which created such a stir in the Central Traffic Association yesterday by threatening to agree to nothing short of a total restoration of eastbound rates to the tariff of March 5, backed down from its position to-day.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 2.--Attorney-General Longley of Nova Scotia is here attending the Supreme Court. He has created a sensation in the stronghold of Toryism by his outspoken utterances on international questions.

Mr. William C. Bucklin, who was arrested late on Monday night on complaint of Dr. Nelson C. Chapman of the Hotel Brunswick for creating a disturbance in front of the New-York Club, was taken before Justice Duffy at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 3.--The Grand Jury to-day brought in a bill of indictment against Street Superintendent Wallace of this city for violation of the law in not giving preference to old soldiers in work on the streets. RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 3.--The Richmond Exposition was formally opened to-day in the presence of 20,000 people. Mrs. Lee, wife of the Governor, set the machinery in motion by touching an electric button. There was a magnificent street parade previous to the ceremonies at the Fair Grounds.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 3.--Owing to the recent interruption of travel by quarantines in several Southern States the management of the Alabama State Fair Association this morning decided to postpone the date of opening of the fair from the 22d of October to the 12th of November. Purses and premiums will stand as heretofore announced.

BERLIN, Oct. 3.--Prof. Delbruck, in an article in the Preussische Jahrbucher, says that Emperor Frederick's diary of 1870 was never metallographed, but that extracts from the 1866 diary were. Copies were made of the diary of 1870, and a few were confided to Frederick's inner most circle.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5.--The statement of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company for the month of August shows gross earnings of $2,273,702, a decrease of $108,400 as compared with the corresponding month last year; net earnings, $68,889, a decrease of $275,516. For the eight months ending Aug. 31 the gross earnings were $14,114,168, a decrease of $3,712,841; net earnings, $2,328,626, a decrease $5,594,231.

Lynn, Mass., Oct. 5.--The final deposit of $200 a side for the series of bicycle races for the championship of the world between Ralph Temple and W.A. Rowe was made with the Daily Item at noon to-day. The first race of the series takes place in Lynn to-morrow afternoon.

TORONTO, Oct. 5.--E.S. Cox, the exstock broker of this city who obtained about $100,000 of the funds of the Central Bank of Toronto shortly before it collapsed last Fall, was discharged to-day on the last of the charges preferred against him.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 5.--Ignatius Donnelly, the wire-pulling and political sage, says that he thinks he will net be a candidate for Governor on the Labor ticket. His great ambition for years has been to occupy a seat in the United States Senate.

The stock market did not cheer bull hearts overmuch yesterday. Quotations were inclined to weakness throughout the list, and one or two bob-tailed bull pools had an active time trying to keep up the courage of their "friends."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 5.--President Neal Mitchell has issued the following official bulletin for the 24 hours ending at 6 o'clock this evening: New cases, 57 deaths, 6; total number of cases to date, 3,022; total number of deaths, 277. The deaths are:

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 5.--The Republicans held a mass meeting here to-night which was addressed by State Senators E.L. Pitts of Medina and John Laughlin of Buffalo. The affair was a fizzle as far as attendance was concerned, the hall not being half full. The Republicans seem to be losing their grip in this county.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5.--The Acting Secretary of War has appointed a board, consisting of Col. H.L. Abbott, Col. W.P. Craighill, Col. C.B. Comstock, Lieut.-Col. D.C. Houston, and Lieut-Col. W.R. King of the Engineer Corps., to establish harbor lines at the port of New-York, in accordance with section 12 of the River and Harbor bill.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 5.--Wisconsin and Indiana were the States represented to-day at Gen. Harrison's reception. The Indiana delegation numbered between 1,300 and 1,500 from Covington, Logan, Fountain City, and other towns in Fountain County.
Capt. Benjamin Gleadell, commander of the White Star Line steamship Germanic, and one of the most experienced Captains in the Atlantic service, died suddenly on Thursday night, Sept. 27.

Last night the Brooklyn Democrats held a ratification meeting at the Academy of Music. It was a great meeting in every sense. Had the Academy been twice as large it would not have accommodated one-half the people who desired to be present and testify to their approval of the nominations of Cleveland and Thurman.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 5.--A meeting of the State Democratic Executive Committee will be held here to-morrow. The call was made necessary by the startling discovery that four members of the Alabama State Electoral ticket are disqualified by virtue of their holding other offices. The names of the gentlemen are A.A. Wiley, John W. Bishop, Augustus W. Barnes, and Peter M. Horn.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 5.--Col. James H. Davidson said to-day that the deal for the purchase of the Grand Opera House property by Lotta is not off. He states there are 60 days from Sept. 28 in which the deal may be consummated, according to the terms of the contract entered into at that time.

After the Board of Street Opening adjourned yesterday afternoon Mayor Hewitt, Gen. John Newton, Controller Myers, and Park Commissioner J. Hampden Robb stood at a window of the Mayor's office and discussed the local political outlook.

HUGH J. GRANT was born in this city about 34 years ago. He is the leader of the Tammanyites of the Nineteenth Assembly District and Chairman of the Committee on Organization. In 1882 he was elected to the Board of Aldermen and re-elected in 1883. In 1884 he attained the distinction of being one of two Aldermen who voted against the Broadway Surface Railroad franchise.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 5.--A committee appointed by the Baltimore and Ohio Directors several months ago to investigate the condition of the road and its finances is still at work, and its report is expected to have an important influence on the market value of the stock.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5.--As a last resort to prevent a strike on the North Side street railway, a conference was held to-night between the men and the officers of the road.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 5.--The Pioneer Press to-morrow will print the following: The thrasher has been busy in the wheat fields of the Northwest for the past four or five weeks.

The postponed beauty show was opened to-day at the Casino, but only 20 ladies were present. France, Belgium, Germany, Portugal, Sweden, Austria, Bohemia, Russia, Hungary, Italy, and the West Indies were represented.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Oct. 5.--The Concord grape season along the Hudson Valley is now at its height. The gross tonnage exceeds that of 1887 by fully 15,000 tons. There are individual growers here who will ship 100 tons each.

McKane and the Kings County Democratic General Committee has been taken by the Executive Committee of the latter organization in recommending the reinstatement of Jne. McMahon and John L. Voorhies as members from Gravesend.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 5.--The defeat of theconstitutional amendment increasing the number of Supreme Court Judges from three to five has paralized the city politicians of Georgia.
TORONTO, Oct. 5.--Small pox is spreading here. Last night another case was discovered, this time on Sherbourne-street, one of the finest streets of the city.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5.--The merchants constituting the Chicago Freight Bureau have not abandoned their proposed war on the transcontinental roads for discriminating in freight rates on Pacific coast business.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 5.--Prices for flour have again been advanced 40 to 50 cents a barrel, which had a tendency to check business, still some orders were filled at that price.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 5.--The steamboat Mary Powell has had her damages repaired at a shipyard at Newburg, and is again running on her route between Rondout and New-York City. The "Queen of the Hudson" will make her last trip of the season on the 15th inst.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 5.--Special reports from all the towns in Genesee County show, what is not frequently the case, that the farmers as a rule express themselves as being well satisfied with their crops for this season and pleased with their prospects. Wheat was hardly a full crop, but the improved prices make up the discrepancy. The yield of barley, oats, and corn was excellent and the quality admirable.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5.--The conference committees of the Eastern and Western railroads appointed last month for the purpose of establishing harmonious relations in the interchange of traffic will meet at Chairman Abbott's office Oct. 17.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 5.--Tom Eck, the bicyclist, is as renowned in love as he is on his machine. It was only a few moons ago when the public was treated to the full details of his romantic courtship and final clandestine marriage with a young lady of Minneapolis, Miss Jennie Carlisle, living with her parents at Second-street and Twenty-eighth avenue, North.

BOSTON, Oct. 5.--Giovanni B. Dendero surrendered himself to a patrolman this morning, stating that he had killed a relative named Giovanni Dendero.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5.--Arrangements have been completed by which on Monday, Oct. 8, a new fast mail, east and west, between NewYork and St. Louis, will go into operation over the Pennsylvania Railroad.

A member of the class of 11 non-commissioned officers recently examined at Fortress Monroe for appointment as Second Lieutenants in the regular army, was interviewed yesterday by a TIMES reporter regarding the examination and general mode of procedure.
The fifteenth annual meeting of the NewYork Riding Club was held last evening at the clubhouse, and the following officers were unanimously elected:
GETTYSBURG, Penn., Oct. 5.--The Democrats of the Nineteenth District to-day renominated Levi Maish for Congress.

Frederick Conklin, the policeman who was dismissed from the force after the discovery by Capt. Gunner that he was an ex-convict, was taken into the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus.

LYONS, N.Y., Oct. 5.--Ex-senator Warner Miller and Lieut.-Gov. Jones made addresses at the Wayne County Fair to-day. Five thousand persons heard them. The Hon. John H. Camp gave a dinner in honor of the distinguished gentlemen.

There was a full attendance last night at the meeting of the veterans of the Eighth Regiment, held at the armory, to complete arrangements for the parade and ceremony attendant upon the laying of the cornerstone of the new armory on Oct. 19.
MARINETTE, Wis., Oct. 5.--There is a marked undercurrent of excitement here and at Oconto over the discovery of a pocket of gold quartz that promises to yield from $50,000 to $75,000 per ton.
It would be difficult to find a more suitable site for athletic purposes than that chosen for the grounds of the Berkeley Atletic Club, and now approaching completion at Morris Dock.

The American Jockey Club was favored With another lovely day for racing yesterday and a good crowd was at Jerome Park to enjoy what proved to be a good day's sport, for, with the exception of the Hunter Stakes, there were good fields of horses and sharp contests for the purses.

LONDON, Oct. 6.--A dispatch from Paris says: "Mrs. Paran Stevens, a wealthy American lady, has charged her maid, an Italian named Anita Celanza, with robbing her of diamonds valued at 6,000. The girl has been arrested. She asserts that her mistress sent the diamonds to London."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 5.--A large card party was given last evening at the residence of Dr. I. Dever Warner, President of the Young Mens Christian Association. During the evening a sneak thief stole all the overcoats of the guests. The garments belonged to prominent Republicans and great alarm is expressed in Republican circles to-day over the fact that several of the overcoats contained data and campaign literature.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 5.--Judge Allen G. Thurman arrived in Pittsburg soon after 10 to-night, en route via the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad from Columbus to Washtington to attend to the Pan-Electric suits at the capital and incidentally to confer with President Cleveland there to-morrow, among other things upon the advisability or otherwise of writing a national executive indorsement of Gov. Hill's candidacy and record, as demanded by Hill's partisan followers in New-York.
A Wall-street operator yesterday made the sage remark that the firmest believers in trusts were those who gathered in the dividends that the trusts declared.

ALBANY, Oct. 5.--When the $700,000 appropriated by the Federal Government for the construction of suitable buildings and necessary machinery for turning out big guns at the Watervliet Arsenal is available about 500 men will be employed.

DENNISVILLE, N.J., Oct. 5.--An industry the like of which does not exist anywhere else in the world furnishes scores of people in this part of New-Jersey with remunerative employment, and has made comfortable fortunes for many citizens.

RAPID CITY, Dakota, Oct. 5.--The Right Rev. Bishop Hare of the South Dakota Episcopal Mission, one of the best posted men in the country on Indian affairs, was seen here this morning, having just returned from a three-weeks' ...
PARIS, Oct. 5.--The registration of foreigners, in accordance with the decree recently issued by President Carnot, began to-day at the Prefecture of Police. So far 1,000 have been registered.
RINGWOOD, N.J., Oct. 5.--Robert Garrett rested well last night. His condition to-day is slightly better than it was yesterday. He was out to-day in charge of his attendants.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 5.--A collision occurred on the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad, on a sharp curve two miles east of Hannibal, about 8 o'clock this morning, between the Lehigh Valley passenger train going east and a special train going west.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5.--A small sloop-rigged boat was capsized and sunk off Thirty-fifth-street this afternoon. There were two men in the boat, and although the life-saving crew at once put out neither of them was rescued. The boat was owned at South Chicago.

READING, Penn., Oct. 8.--A daring robbery was perpetrated on a passenger train of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad last night.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 5.--Brickmakers at a number of points along the Hudson River are preparing to shut down their yards for the season. They have made no heavy profits this year.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 5.--The people of this city are very much disappointed at the crushing of their union station scheme. A high official of the Western New-York and Pennsylvania Road denies the statement that that road backed out.

MONTREAL, Oct. 5.--Friends of the men who fled from New-York to avoid the Broadway Railroad bribery prosecution say that there is great rejoicing over the decision of the Court of Appeals in the McQuade case, and that they expect to be able to return to New York by the end of the year.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 5.--The appearance of Chaska, the Indian, and his bride, Cora Belle Fellows, the Washington girl who threw herself away upon the redskin, at the dime museum, is still fresh in the memory of Eastern people.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 5.--Col. W.D. Dickey and Leander Brown, acting as attorneys for a syndicate, the former of Republicans and the latter of Democrats, made a wager of $1,000 a side on the result of the national election.

ROME, Oct. 5.--It is semi-officially stated that the decree of the Franco-Tunisian Government subjecting public and private schools to inspection by the French authorities will not be accepted by Italy.
LONDON, Oct. 5.--Sir Charles Warren, Chief of the Metropolitan Police Force, has decided to employ bloodhounds in his efforts to discover the perpetrator of the Whitechapel murders.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5.--The case of Kate Claxton, who wants to recover $1,500 and five years' interest from J.E. Kingsley Co. for the loss of her diamonds in the Continental Hotel in September, 1883, went to the jury to-day.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 5.--Justice C. F. Brown of Newburg, sitting in Supreme Court, Chambers, rendered a decision yesterday in the suit of the Port Jervis, Monticello and New-York Railroad Company against the Erie Railroad Company.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 5.--Robert Hartman, selling gloves and mittens for a New-York house, was arrested in Lansing to-day for swindling M.H. Clark, a Williamston hotel keeper out of $25 by means of a forged order. This occurred two years ago, and about the same time he is charged with treating four Lansing men in a like manner, with one of whom he afterward settled.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5.--During the past 24 hours the crowd entering the Exposition Building were requested to vote on the Presidential question. To-night the votes were counted and found to foot over 8,000. Cleveland's majority Was 800. On the strength of this showing the odds on Cleveland went up in the pool rooms.

LONDON, Oct. 5.--This was the first day of the Kempton Park October meeting. The race for the Kempton Park Champion Nursery Handicap was won by Fleur de Lys. Theophilus was second and Italica third. The last betting was 12 to 1 against Fleur de Lys. There were 14 starters.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 5.--Senator Sherman was in the city to-day en route from New-York to his home at Mansfield. In an interview he said that Congress would probably adjourn in a week.

LONDON, Oct. 5.--A dispatch from Milan states that guides are searching for George Rudd, a New-York artist, who recently disappeared while making a tour of Italy. Rudd's movements have been traced to Tione. It is believed that he was lost in the Alps.

Walston H. Brown, senior member of the firm of Brown, Howard Co., aqueduct contractors, whose offices are at 20 Nassaustreet, began proceedings in the Supreme Court yesterday for a dissolution of partnership, and this was followed by an application by Mr. Brown, through his attorney, Wheeler H. Peckham, for his appointment as Receiver.

T.P. Conneff will attempt to beat the amateur five-mile running record at the National Association's championship meeting this afternoon. The meeting will be held at the Manhattan Athletic Club's grounds at Eighty-sixth-street and Eighthavenue.

Tammany Hall has nominated its ticket and the agony of expectation that has possessed politicians since Wednesday is over. But Tammany has not redeemed its promise of a political sensation. Its ticket is of the old order.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 5.--Mrs. Potter appeared at the Academy of Music in this city to-night before one of the largest and most fashionable audiences ever assembled here.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 5.--Philip Palledoni, the Italian who in cold blood murdered his brother on the evening of June 22, 1887, suffered the death penalty to-day.

DES MOINES, Oct. 1.--Iowa is a most interesting State in this Presidential contest; a State in which neither or the National Committees appears to be taking any particular interest or expending any money, yet still a State in which the Republicans are confident of winning, while the Democrats are also hopeful of success.

HARRISBURG, N.Y., Oct. 5.--Intense excitement prevailed in the southern part of this town when it became known yesterday that a big bear had broken into a sheep pen on the farm of Joe Loucks and killed four of the best sheep to be found in it.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 5.--At the village of Oakfield, six miles from here, Mrs. Louisa A. Moore, wife of Joseph T. Moore, a produce dealer, committed suicide this morning at her home by shooting herself through the heart with a small rifle.
LONDON, Oct. 6.--The Cunard Line steamship Etruria, from New-York, passed Brow Head on her way to Liverpool at midnight last night.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 5.--The American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions adjourned to-day until next year. The closing session was devoted to farewell speeches from missionaries and to appeals from the Secretaries for increased subscriptions in order to raise an additional $150,000. The customary resolutions of formal gratitude were adopted.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5.--The east-bound rates out of St. Louis are still in a chaotic condition. The threat of the Pennsylvania to cut eastbound rates out of Louisville and Cincinnati to-day has not been carried into execution and may be abandoned.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 5.--For some time there have been vague rumors of corruption in some of the departments of the Milwaukee Road. At the same time a secret investigation has been going on at the headquarters in Milwaukee.

The telephone was put to a novel use in Toronto yesterday. A citizen who had been summoned to appear at the police court for breach of a by-law, finding that he would be unable to appear in person telephoned the fact to headquarters, admitting his guilt, and was fined $1 and costs through the same medium.

GREENVILLE, Texas, Oct. 5.--J.M. Ragsdale, dealer in hardware, implements, buggies, and wagons, was attached to-day by local creditors, the attachments aggregating $24,000. The liabilities amount to $55,000; assets, $35,000.
ALBANY, Oct. 5.--D.L. Sheppard, barrister, of Carleton-place, Ontario, came here yesterday on a mission of inquiry.

KUTZTOWN, Penn., Oct. 5.--A terrible accident occurred shortly before 2 o'clock this afternoon on the Kutztown Fair Grounds. The Roman chariot races had just commenced, and two chariots, each drawn by four horses hitched abreast, had made one circuit of the race course when one of the teams bacame unmanageable and dashed into the crowd of spectators.
VIENNA, Oct. 5.--Emperor William and the Crown Prince of Austria went deer stalking to-day in the Lainzer Thiergarten. After returning Emperor William partook of luncheon at Schoenbrunn Castle.

RACINE, WIS, Oct. 5.--Three persons drank embalming fluid at a "wake" in this city last night in mistake for beer. One of the victims, James Payton, will probably die. The others are very sick, but will recover.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5.--The President and Internal Revenue Commissioner Miller returned this evening from their fishing excursion to the Upper Potomac. They caught a good string of bass.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 6.--A young men's colored Democratic club has been organized here with 28 members. Caesar Reilly is the President and Isaiah Shemo Secretary. President Really says the club will soon have 100 members.

G.C. Clark of New-haven has in his front yard a couple of rose geraniums 10 feet high. These plants were raised from slips in two years. He recently set them outdoors, as they had grown too tall for the rooms in the house. Passengers on the ferry from Vancouver were treated to a novel and rather exciting spectacle yesterday morning. Just as the boat was approaching the Oregon shore a salmon was seen pursued by a soal. The fish swam near the surface, and although evidently putting forth its best endeavors the seal kept close behind it.

ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 6.--Just before 8 o'clock this evening Brown's powder magazine blew up, giving the entire city a terrible shock, breaking a great number of plate glass store fronts and hundreds of panes of glass in private residences.

A cable dispatch was received in the city yeaterday by a friend of Miss Virginia MacTavish, from her, which positively denied that she was engaged to the Duke of Norfolk. When the engagement was first announced this young lady wrote to Miss MacTavish, asking her about it and congratulating her. The answer to the letter was the cablegram denying the engagement.

The Charity Organization Society of the City of New-York has recently issued its sixth annual report. To the sociologist it furnishes much food for thought. It is replete with figures bearing upon many details of charity work, and from these data some exceedingly interesting conclusions are presented, and, as to several matters also, some very startling ones.
PARIS, Oct. 6.--M. Floquet's decree respecting foreigners--for though the signature was Carnot's, of course, the act was the Premier's--has thrown non-native circles into a distinct commotion.

That James S. Bedell had reduced the forgery of real estate securities to a scientific system is daily becoming more and more apparent. Weeks W. Culver, a Brooklyn lawyer, residing at 496 Third-street, Brooklyn, gave a mortgage to Katherine A. Anderson upon a piece of Brooklyn property for $6,000.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 6.--The latest charges made against Premier Greenway by the Free Press, and which he is challenged to question in a court of law, are of a most serious nature.

Father Kelly of St. Patrick's Cathedral was robbed of $227 last Wednesday. While the priest was at mass his room was entered and the money was abstracted from a bureau drawer. Detective Shelly of the Fifty-first-street police station was notified of the theft, and, learning that a boy named Harry Flannery had been in the priest's house, accused the lad of taking the money.

Good progress has been made with the annex to the Imperial Museum which is to contain the sarcophagi discovered by Hamdi Bey at Sidon last year, and if the builders continue at the present pace it may be hoped that the work will be completed in about three weeks' time.

SITKA, Alaska, Sept. 20.--As much has been said controversially since the acquisition of Alaska in regard to its industrial possibilities, I may be pardoned for diving a faw fasts, the results of personal observation.
On Saturday a week ago the market closed with a full head of steam on, and every one predicting higher prices for the week following. Monday's market verified these predictions.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 6.--Over 50 of the best students that ever came to Cornell competed for the nine university scholarships awarded by the Faculty to-day.

The improvements and repairs which are now is course of completion at the New-York quarantine station on Hoffman Island bid fair to more than double the efficiency of the means for accommodating detained crews and passengers.

BERLIN, Oct. 6.--Emperor William's reception at Vienna has sent a thrill of gratification throughout the empire. Apart from the popular demonstrations, the enthusiasm shown, and the scenes at the banquet given to his Majesty, the visit has been of immense value in displaying the Emperor's latent qualities.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Oct. 6.--The Kishpaugh mines, the largest ore-producing mines in Warren County, have suspended operations. They are owned and were operated by Pardee Co., and have been in active operation for 19 years. A shaft has been sunk to the depth of 500 feet, and the vein is found to be exhausted. The hundred men are thrown out of employment by the suspension.

The Queen of Italy spent the last fortnight of August at Courmayour, which is a favorite resort of her Majesty. During her stay she distinguished herself as an Alpine tourist, making five considerable mountain ascents within 10 days.

Casey, of Minneapolis, who is one of the Directors and Trusteee of the road, were seen in St. Paul in regard to the statement that the contract for the building of the road has been let. William McNiel, 20 years old, a son of Robert McNiel, attempted to commit suicide at Port Chester on Friday night because he had been jilted by his sweetheart, Miss Mamie Kraft, daughter of Joseph Kraft.
PORTLAND, Oregon, Oct. 6.--W.B. Hamblin, General Freight Agent of the Burlington and Northern Pacific, passed through the city to-day, en route to San Francisco.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Oct. 6.--An attempt was made on Friday night to assassinate John Zulauff a well-known resident of Oxford Furnace. Mr. Zulauff had been to see a neighbor and was on his way home when he was confronted on the highway by a desperado, who drew a revolver and began firing. One ball struck the rim of Mr. Zulauff's hat and another grazed his left ear.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 6.--One of the oldest hunters in Jefferson County to-day is Joe Christy, who lives in a log cabin near the Lewis County line on the borders of the big Osceola woods, Joe, or "Old Christy," as he is now familiarly known, is about 74 years of age, and he has lived in or near his present habitation upward of 40 years.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 6.--James Jowett was sentenced this morning by Judge Tillinghast, in the Court of Common Pleas for manslaughter in shooting Arthur Craven to five years in State prison. The limit is 20 years. Clemency was extended on the ground of provocations.

ALBANY, Oct. 6.--The opinions of the Court of Appeals in granting a new trial to exAlderman McQuade have just been made public. The prevailing opinion by Judge Andrews is exceedingly long and goes much into the details of the questions of law raised on the appeal.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 6.--Dr. C.S. Maynard of Pawpaw has been appointed the nominee of the Democratic Party for the Fourth District by the Congressional Committee, in the place of the Hon. George L. Yaple of Mendon who declined to accept the nomination of the convention on account of his health.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 6.--There are numerous cases of typhoid fever in the villages of Woodberry and Hampden, part of the district recently annexed to this city. There are 20 cases of fever in the former and in the latter there are 10 cases in one row of houses, caused by using well water contaminated try the wasts from a slaughter house.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 6.--An apparent attempt to desecrate the grave of Philipo Palladoni, the Italian murderer of his brother, hanged here Friday, was frustrated by the vigilance of the men appointed to guard the grave.
A Texas merchant a short time ago ordered a carload of coal oil from a firm not in the Oil Trust, and got it at 20 per cent. less than the trust was selling it.

Spite of rain-dropping clouds fully 300 Free Masons, together with a goodly sprinkling of ladies, left the Grand Central Station yesterday afternoon by special train for Woodlawn Cemetery to attend the exercises at the unveiling of the monument erected in memory of the Hon. James E. Morrison of this city.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 6.--The Calumet and Hecla Copper product for September was the largest monthy yield ever made in its history, 3,084 tons; the Quincy output was 355 tons, and the Atlantic, 201 tons.

The Columbia Yacht Club sailed its Fall regatta on the Hudson yesterday. Twenty-five yachts, ranging from goodly-sized cabin sloops to small catboats, took part. It was one of the prettiest races of the year.

READING, Penn., Oct. 7.--A beautiful Sunday was this day turned into one of mourning, as the result of a terrible accident, in which over 100 persons were more or less injured, some of whom will undoubtedly die.

Henry Junge, the American agent of the Hamburg Rubber Comb Company of Germany, has been missing from his home at Avondale, near Newark, N.J., since last Sunday. On that day he left ostensibly for Philadelphia. During the week two gentlemen from New-York visited the house and informed Mrs. Junge that her husband's accounts were about $7,000 short. It is supposed that he lost the money on the race track.

The statue of the late Mr. Samuel Morley, executed for the town of Nottingham by Mr. Harvard Thomas of King's Road, London, is now completed. It represents Mr. Morley as addressing an audience, and is considered to be an excellent likeness.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7.--Judge Thurman spent Sunday quietly at Oakview and will not come into the city until to-morrow morning in time to attend the opening of the Supreme Court. He and the President both rose late and they spent several hours on the porch of the latter's country home. Judge Thurman said this evening that there had not been a single visitor during the day.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 7.--The Grand Opera House was reopened to-night with "Richard III.," Thomas W. Keene playing the title role. The house was crowded.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 7.--The good news is that the pestilence abates. The official bulletins the past week have shown it, and in two days there has not been a single death.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Oct. 7.--If any one wants to enjoy the full glories of muskrat shooting he must come to Dorchester County. CARLISLE, Penn., Oct. 7.--B.F. Seitz, a prominent Republican of this county, addressed a Democratic meeting in this place last night in favor of the re-election of President Cleveland.

ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 7.--John Brown, a farm hand, was killed by a powder magazine explosion near here last night. This morning fragments of Brown's body were found over 300 yards from where the magazine stood. A revolver, with two cham bers exploded, was also found, and it is supposed that Brown shot at the magazine and caused the explosion.

Commissioner Croker said last night that Tammany Hall would nominate a straight ticket throughout, naming candidates for Congress, Assembly, and the Board of Aldermen in every district.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 7.--Workmen began last week demolishing the old United States Court Building in Royal, between Dumaine and St. Philip's streets.

LONDON, Oct. 9.--The death is announced of Sir Anthony Musgrave, the Governor of Queensland. The Carleton English Opera Company began a week's engagement at the Grand Opera House last evening in Genee's familiar operetta, "Nanon." It is unnecessary to say anything about the work itself, as it is thoroughly well known to this public.

The suit Mrs. Sarah N. Smith against ex-Judge Henry Hilton was brought up again yesterday in the Supreme Court, Special Term, before Judge Patterson, where a demurrer to Mrs. Smith's reply to the fourth defense was argued.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 8.--The Morris County Democratic County Convention was held here this afternoon. Dr. J.W. Jackson presided.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 8.--A Prohibition club of about 50 members has been organized at Princeton College. The officers are: President, --D. Todd,'89; Vice President--Lee, '89; Secretary, Meyers, '91.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct.8.--The Second Assembly Democratic Convention of Monmouth County met here to-day and renominated Dr. Archibald A. Higgins of Manasquan for the Assembly.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 8.--The Eastern press seems determined that the Mormons shall move to Mexico, and enterprising reporters out of a few facts have woven fabrications that are really very ludicrous to the inhabitants of Utah.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 8.--While Patrick Conlon of Stony Hollow, proprietor of a grocery and liquor store, was returning home from here early this morning his horse jumped off a bridge into the creek near what is known as the Ferris place, on the Stone road. The wagon controlling Mr. Conlon went over the bridge also. His body was found in the water.

The eyes of Uncle Sam are just now pretty sharply fixed on the Warehouse Trust. This combine is made up of all but a very few of the storage institutions that fringe the water front of Brooklyn and thrive elsewhere ae well.

READING, Penn., Oct. 8.--To-day only fully developed the extent of the terrible accident at the cornerstone laying of St. Mary's Catholic Church yesterday afternoon, when a girder broke and nearly 300 persons were precipitated into the basement.

On the subject of the weather some very interesting facts are given, both in the report of the Meteorological Service of the Dominion and in that of the Ontario Bureau of Industries.

"Welcome" was the word that shone in bright letters over the entrance to the NewYork Maennerchor's new hall, at East Fiftyseventh-street, near Third-avenue, last night, and was reflected in the open hospitality found within doors.
The suit of Miss Mary E. Jones against her uncle, ex-Congressman Morgan Jones, came on for a third trial yesterday before Judge Lawrence in the Supreme Court.
