ITHACA, N.Y, Oct. 9.--B. Clark of Groton started out Sunday to shoot a wild sheep. He was accompanied by his son, 9 years old. By some accident the father shot his boy. Clark picked up his son and carried him to the house, almost distracted with grief. The wound is thought to be fatal.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9.--Some one giving the name of W.W. Findlay, Third Vice-President of the Union Pacific Railroad, applied at Miss Campbell's school of stenography, in this city, for a young lady typewriter.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9.--First Lieut. T.J. Grumley, Seventeenth Infantry, has been granted leave of absence for three months.
LONDON, Oct. 9.--Reports and rumors of new trust combinations in England are creating, a good deal of comment among business men.

John Fitzgerald, the boatman in the employ of the Quarantine Commissioners who was reported yesterday as having been blown out to sea while rowing from Staten Island to Hoffman Island, was picked up off the Sandy Hook Lightship Monday ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--T.J. Callinan Co., jobbers and importers of tailors' trimmings at 284 and 286 Madison-street, have assigned, with liabilities of from $85,000 to $90,000. The stock on hand is estimated at $50,000, and there are outstanding accounts receivable amounting to between $30,000 and $40,000.
BOSTON, Oct. 9.--Boston, 5; Indianapolis, 11. Base hits--Boston, 9; Indianapolis, 12. ErrorsBoston, 14; Indianapolis, 9. Pitchers--Sowders and Burdick.
District Attorney Fellows said yesterday that he had read the decision of the Court of Appeals in the McQuade case. "The main point," he said, is on the peremptory challenges of jurors by the people.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 9.--Another Chinaman dressed in American clothing, with his cue cut off, and claiming to hold citizenship papers of the United States, was refused admission into the port of Suspension Bridge, having arrived there on the Grand Trunck Express from Toronto last night.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 9.--A peculiar phenomenon has been discovered in Laurens County, this State. On the side of a steep hill a section of land about two acres in extent has apparently dropped about four feet below the surface of the surrounding country.

WARSAW, N.Y., Oct. 9.--Warner Miller and Judge Tourgee arrived here from Geneseo to 9 o'clock this morning. The Entertainment Committee expected him to some on the Erie, but, he came on the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg.

LONDON, Oct. 9.--The British man-of-war Osprey has captured off Mocha three dhows, having on board 204 slaves. The Captains of the dhows and four of the slaves were killed before the slavers surrendered.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 9.--This great manufacturing city in to-day's election gives a Democratic majority of over 500. This is a gain of 2,000 over the vote polled at the charter election preceding the Presidential electron of 1884.
It required either an intense love for horse racing or a wild desire to get even on previous losses to induce people to go to Jerome Park yesterday to see the races.

Mme. Patti is a woman of peculiarities, and she showed one of them on sailing from South America at the close of her engagement under Mr. Abbey by leaving behind her a farewell to her audiences in manuscript, which she intrusted to the manager of the Opera House with instructions to publish it after her departure.

Ladies who go to Altman's, at Sixth-avenue and Nineteenth-street, for an inspection of the novelties here may as well know in advance that they will need to make more than a single visit in order to do half justice to themselves.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct., 9.--In the second District Assembly Convention Col. Johnston L. Depeyster of Tivola was nominated for Assembly to-day by acclamation.

Quarantine Commissioner John A. Nichols has retired from politics so far as the Twentieth Ward of Brooklyn, where he resides, is concerned. There will be no Nichols faction in the field at the coming primary and consequently no fighting.
The subject of the crowded calendar of the Court of Appeals received a somewhat through discussion last evening at the meeting of the Bar Association.

Physicians have been called upon during he last week to attend to more cases of influenza than have been brought to their attention in any season since 1876. So great has been the number of the patients that the doctors have agreed that at present the city is called upon to endure an epidemic of cold-in-the-head in its worst form.

The convention of the Christian Alliance opened at 9 o'clock yesterday morning in the Central Baptist Church with a preliminary prayer meeting led by Major Blandley. At 10 o'clock the mornning session proper began with an address by the Rev. Dr. Peck of Boston, followed by addressee by the Rev Dr. Greenwood of Brooklyn and the Rev Mr. Hawkins of Philadelphia.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 9.--The second day of the inter-collegiate tennis tournament to-day was characterized by some excellent playing on the part of Sears of Harvard.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 9.--The skyrocket career of young Latimer E. Jones, schemer, speculator, and swindler, who is alleged to have cheated B.L. Ludington and other New-York capitalists out of over $200,000, and who is now a fugitive from justice, is recalled here by the sale, which has just taken ...

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9.--Theodore Mcgargee, 55 years of age, a member of one of the oldest paper establishments in the city, was thrown from his horse while out riding this afternoon and instantly killed.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9.--A special from Xenia Ohio, says: "Lydia Washington, aged 84 years, was at the colored Wesleyan Church last night and participated in the services, speaking and shouting in an unusually happy way. While engaged in shouting she sank back into her seat and died. 'Aunt' Lydia was famous about Xenia for being the mother of 21 children."

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 9.--A unique feature of the technical instruction at Cornell University is the system of non-resident lecturers. The list of Sibley College lecturers announced for this year includes Edward Atkinson, the political economist; the Hon. E.B. Coxe, ex-President of the Mining Engineers; J.C. Bayles, President of the New-York Board or Health; Emery, the marine expert Babcock, the inventor of ...
ALBANY, Oct. 9.--In the court of appeals today the following business was transacted:

A scene was witnessed at Sing Sing Prison yesterday afternoon the like of which was never witnessed there before. It was the discharge of Michael Gorman, who had served 32 years 8 months and 21 days within its walls for the killing of Charles Johnson on July 4, 1855, in Brooklyn.
The Columbia Billiard Room, Broadway and Twenty-second-street, was reopened to the public last night. Its new proprietors, George F. Slosson and William Riley, who have succeeded John D. ...
PITTSBURG, Oct. 9.--At McKeesport, Penn., yesterday, M.P. Wampler was nominated for Congress by the Democratic Conferrees of the Twentyfourth District.

Patrick Coffey was placed on trial in Judge Knapp's Court, Jersey City, yesterday for the murder of Agnes Smith at his home, on Hendersonstreet, last August. Coffey in his own defense swore that the shooting was accidental. The case was given to the jury, which was locked up for the night.

Any time before Oct. 18 interested real estate owners may file remonstrances against the awards reported by the New Parks Commissioners preliminary to the hearing to be given in the Supreme Court Oct. 23. Though Gen. Lane has not yet been burdened by the number of remonstrants, it is likely that there will be no lack of them when the last day of filing arrives.

WASHINGTON, Oct.9.--The marble-faced clock that stands just above the American eagle which is perched over the chair of the ChiefJustice of the Supreme Court marked 12:03 o'clock to-day when the court crier arose and announced "the Chief-Justice and Associate Justices of the Supreme Court."

The wheat-market is broken at last and the bears were on top when they left the Produce Exchange speculative pit. Prices have fallen off 11 cents in two days and are still on the decline. Bakers all over the country have been too hasty in raising the price of bread on what has proved to be nothing but a speculative market.
The Hudson, at all times charming, is now at the height of its glory. Not a bare tree and hardly a naked branch can be seen anywhere from Albany to New-York.

Impressive services in memory of Capt. Benjamin Gleadell of the White Star Line steamship Germanic, who died at sea on Sept. 28 durink the voyage of his ship from Liverpool to this port, were held in the main saloon of the vessel yesterday afternoon as she lay at her dock at the foot of West Tenth-street.

DETRIOT, Mich., Oct. 9.--Mrs. Martha Strickland, Detroit's woman lawyer, argued a motion in a divorce suit to-day before the Supreme Court of this State. This is the first time that a woman ever appeared before that tribunal in the capacity of an attorney.
There was no question of Mme. Jane Hading's success at Palmer's Theatre last evening after she had reached the first expression of emotion.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 9.--Saturday's dispatch from this place regarding the Duluth and Winnipeg Road has been fully verified, and THE TIMES was the only paper in America that published it. Further details show that several prominent Minneapolis men are interested in the work.

FORT FAIRFIELD, Me., Oct. 9.--A great freshet prevails in this vicinity, and nearly all the mills on the Aroostook River have lost more or less lumber. There are washouts on the railroad, and there have been no through trains since Sunday morning.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 9.--Gen. B.F. Butler arrived in the city to-day on professional business. He is counsel, with Mr. Dupignac of New-York and others, for Miss Irene Hoyt in the famous contest over her father's will.
GETTYSBURG, Penn., Oct. 9.--The Porter Guards, Tenth New-York Cavalry, to-day dedicated their monument at the scene of the cavalry fight east of the town.
Estimates of the cost of the Police Department for the year 1889 were presented by the Police Commissioners to the Board of Aldermen yesterday.
Yesterday was another day of bull serenity. Everything on the Stock Exchange had buoyancy in it, and gentlemen who had stocks for sale stood in rows and were made happy.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 9.--President Neal Mitchell's official bulletin for the 24 hours ending at 6 o'clock this evening is as follows: New cases, 93; deaths, 4 total number of cases to date, 3,319; total number of deaths to date, 299. The deaths are:

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 9.--Mr. Blaine's programme to-day included no speaking of any kind. In the morning a visit was made to various manufacturing establishments, and in the afternoon Mr. Blaine called on Mrs. John Covode, widow of the well-known Pennsylvania Congressman.

CHIGAGO, Oct. 9.--There were 500 street railroad strikers in Chicago yesterday. There are 2,000 of them today and the general situation is just about four times as bad as it was yesterday. The west side men carried out their intention of striking and at 6 o'clock this morning not one of them was at work. On the north side the strikers are still out.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9.--The entire family, seven in number, of Dr. A. Trego Shertzer of this city were attacked with lead poisoning last night, the result of drinking milk which had stood for 36 hours in a new milkcan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--The Chicago Freight Committee of the Central Traffic Association met to-day to consider the advisability of further advancing east-bound rates. The Pennsylvania refused to advanced the grain rate to the twenty-five-cent basis.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--One hundred sheep were burned to death at a fire at Schoenaman Co.'s slaughter house and butterine factory in Archer-avenue to-day.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 9.--Joseph T. Moore of Oakfield, in this county, whose wife, Louise, committed suicide last Friday by shooting herself through the heart with a rifle, was arrested to-day in Buffalo whither he went to attend his wife's funeral yesterday. The charge against him is assault in the third degree. He was taken to Oakfield this afternoon.

A one-story frame shed at First-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street and used as stables was destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. The building, which had a frontage of 100 feet on Thirty-fourth-street and 125 feet on Thirtythird-street, was owned by Mr. D.D. Withers of the American and Coney Island Jookey Clubs, ...

ALBANY, Oct. 9.--The State Railroad Commission to-day handad down a decision in the matter of the collision on the Ninth-avenue railroad structure of the Manhattan Railroad Company, New-York City, at Sixty-fourth-street and Ninth-avenue, Sept. 26. After setting forth the facts, as already told, it says:
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 9.--The question of high license provoked an animated debate in the Genesee Methodist Episcopal Conference in session in this city to-day.

TORONTO, Oct. 9.--At the meeting of the City Council here last night serious charges were preferred by Alderman Gillespie against Alderman John Baxter, one of the oldest members of, the Council; Arthur W. Godson, a prominent city contractor, and various officials in the employment of the City Council.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 6.--Ex-Gov. Hubbard of Minnesota is more sanguine of Republican success in this State than are the members of the Republican State Committee. He predicts in New-York that Minnesota will give Harrison 25,000 majority, and it is promptly telegraphed to St. Paul.

A pretty October wedding was that of Miss Gertrude Gottheil and Mr. Joseph S. Rich, which took place last evening. The bride is the daughter of the Rev. Dr. Gustave Gottheil, minister of Temple Emanu-El, on Fifth-avenue.

Mayor Hewitt will to-day publish his letter accepting the nominations of the citizen and of the County Democracy. He announced this fact to a committee appointed at the recent mass meeting of citizens and which called on him yesterday.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 9.--The Catholics of this town are greatly excited over the denouncing from the altar of three young women, prominent members of the parish, by the Rev. Father Mallon last Sunday.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 9.--Alexander G. Sellman, the most successful chess player Baltimore ever produced, is dead in the thirty-third year of his age. He had been quite an invalid for a year past, and had spent that period in traveling.

The fifth annual session of the New-York State Medical Assoiciation was begun at the Hotel Brunswick yesterday morning and will continue through to-morrow. The attendance was unusually large, and never in its history has there been so much interest shown in the work of the organization as at present.
BERLIN, Oct. 9--The German frigates Moltke, Stosch, Gneisenau, and Charlotta, which were lying in the bay of Naples for the purpose of firing a salute in honor of Emperor ...

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9.--A special dispatch from Wilkesbarre says: "A decided sensation has been created in mining circles here by the effort of the Kingston Coal Company to obtain from its employes their signatures to the following paper, which is styled 'The Dockage Confession:'

Another move in the seemingly endless litigation over the Paran Stevens estate was made yesterday in Supreme Court Chambers, before Judge O'Brien. A motion was made in the suit of Alfred and Mary Fiske Paget against Charles G. Stevens and others, to set aside the order that service of summons in the action be by publication.

An ailantus tree in front of Mrs. William Wood's residence, on Jersey-avenue, Jersey City, fell aginst the house yesterday afternoon. Every pane in the front of the house was broken and the front door was braced so that it could not be opened. Mrs. Wood, who was not at home at the time, was unable to get into the house. Her servant had to climb over the back fence to reach the street.
BERLIN, Oct. 9.--The police have seized the remaining copies of the October number of the Deutsche Rundschau, which contained the extracts from the diary of the late Emperor Frederick.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9.--The case of Burlington Griffee against the Missouri River Railroad Company in Nebraska, has been decided by the Inter-State Commerce Commission, opinion by Schoonmaker, Commissioner.
Morgan Hopson Johnson, who was for years city Hall and political reporter for the Herald, was buried in the Press Club's plot in Cypress Hills Cemetery yesterday.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 9.--The Hon. Daniel Dougherty was obliged to disappoint a large Democratic assemblage in this city tonight. Arrangements were made for a meeting in the Columbia Rink, but Mr. Dougherty, suffering from the effects of speaking in the rink at Hartford, Conn., Saturday night was ...

The fact that the striking feather workers had returned to their places in Cohnfeld's factory at their former rate of wages and with the promise of several betterments of their condition rather took the edge off the special meeting of the Working Women's Society of New-York yesterday morning, and not more than 50 ladies went to the rooms in 28 Lafayette-place.

The Forty-fifth Regiment of New-York Veteran Volunteers left last night for Gettysburg to dedicate its monument, which has been erected there by subscriptions of its members and by the State of New-York.

A horse belonging to C. McArthur become frightened while being driven up Newark-avenue, Jersey City, yesterday. At Erie-street he freed himself from the traces and leaped through the big plate glass in the front of James Henderson's fancy goods store. The animal was badly cut.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9.--Mr.Charles Cramp, of the firm of Cramp Co. of Philadelphia, called on Secretary Whitney to-day and informed him that a canalboat, which was carrying 200 tons of coal to the ship yard yesterday morning for the gunboat ...

James N. Langley of the alleged-to-be mythical Texas Land and Mortgage Company, whose trial for swindling John A. Murray and Arthur C. Brady out of $750 by inducing them to put up the money to establtsh a branch office in this city, was yesterday, in General Sessions, discharged because the prosecution was unable to make out its case.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9.--The passenger-rate war out of St.Louis is over. Rates will be restored to-morrow on this basis for a St. LouisNew York rate: Vandalia, $23; Bee Line, $23; Wabash, $21, and Ohio and Mississippi, $20. The rates are the same as before the cut, except the vandalia's which is 50 cents less.

A new proposition has been submitted to Jacob schaefer. Instead of Slosson and schaefer playing the 14-inch line against the 8-inch of Daly, Sexton, and Carter in the second or Chicago tournament, the latest ingenuity oomprehends that the two leaders shall play the 14inch game even up, 600 points, and that the other three shall make 500 against Slosson, but only 400 against Schaefer.

The single issue presented to the people of New-York in the local contest this year is that of good municipal government. It is not Mr. HEWITT'S crankiness or his "bad manners" of the question of naturalization, and it is not a matter of politics, State or national, or even foreign.
TONAWANDA, N. Y., Oct. 9.--The enthusiasm of the farewell given the Thomas Jefferson at Buffalo last evening was repeated in the enthusiasm of the reception at Tenawanda tonight.
DENVER, Col., Oct. 9.--A railroad war which in all probability will make matters interesting in Denver for some time is on the eve of taking place.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9.--The passenger packet W. H. Cherry was sunk this morning near Paducah, Ky., on the Tennessee River. The Cherry belonged to the same company as the John M. Gilbert, sunk yesterday near Chester, Ill.

BOSTON, Oct. 9.--The Boston School Board this evening practically ended the Swinton textbook controversey, so far as the board was concerned, by refusing to reconsider its action at the request of a committee of the Evangelical Alliance, as well as of the Committee of One Hundred, and by the adoption of Anderson's textbook in place of the objectionable work.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 9.--The east-bound shipments of flour, grain, and provisions by the lines in the central Traffic Association last week aggregated 30,331 tons against 27,518 for the preceding week, an increase of 2,813 tons, and against 25,373 for the corresponding period of 1887, and increase of 4,978 tons.
Wallace Ross made the largest score yesterday in the six days' roadsculling match at Madison-Square Garden. His record from 2 P.M. until 12 midnight was 107 miles and 2 laps.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 9.--No little excitement was caused in Lancaster to-day by the news that the Supreme Court has declared the act of May 24, 1887, known as the Municipal bill, to be unconstitional. In an opinion affirming the proceedings of the court below ordering the opening of Grant-street Judge Paxson says:

ALBANY, Oct. 9.--"If they base their hope of electing their National or their state ticket on a reduced Prohibition vote in this State they make a serious mistake," said Chairman Fred Wheeler of the Prohibition State Committee.

Chief-Judge McAdam Of the city court yesterday granted a motion to make charles L. Davis, known on the stage as Alvin Joslin, a co-defendant with the Lincoln Safe Deposit company in the action brought by Jennie Noble, an actress, to recover from the company three trunks, containing a stage wardrobe, valued at $250, which are on deposit with the company.
What was expected to be the red-letter day of the Fall meeting at Jerome Park bids fair to be one of a rather commonplace character.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 9.--A Chicago dispatch announced yesterday that an agent of the Albert Lea route had purchased a ticket at the Wisconsin Central office for $8, which is $1 less than the agreed rate, and in consequence of this the Minneapolis and St. Louis declined longer to be bound by the agreement.
RINGWOOD, N.J. Oct. 9.--Mr. Garrett appears to be steadily improving, mentally and phsically.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 9.--In a probate proceeding to-day it was discovered that in the office of Public Administrator, which has the management of all vacant successions, there existed a shortage of $40,000.
CARBONDALE, Penn., Oct. 9.--Chauncey Huckboon of this city was injured here several days age by a barrel falling on him. He died yesterday at the Lackawanna Hospital, Scranton.
CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 9.--Cashier Tallman, of the broken traders' Bank, was examined before a master this afternoon and his testimony showed that a queer system of banking had been carried on.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9.--A special from Waco, Texas, gives details of the escape and recapture of a number of prisoners in the McLennan County Jail. Deputy Sheriff Sam Wheatley having, as he thought, securely locked the cells of the prisoners, entered the corridor of the cage with a large basket of food in each hand.

There are two reasons why the ladies who never go shopping without taking a look in at McCreery's, at Broadway and Eleventh-street, have flocked with their friends to that establishment daily since the Fail trade opened.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 9.--Wilmington's first agricultural fair was opened this morning on the newly fitted up grounds at Hazel Dell Park. Secretary Bayard was the orator of the occasion. He spoke for 20 minutes, urging upon farmers the conservation of forests and favoring legislative enactment of an Arbor Day. The fair will close saturday evening. The attendance is good and the ex hibits the best ever made in Delaware.
There was a full attendance of the members of the commission for the revision of the excise laws yesterday when it resumed its sessions at the Bible House, Ex-Surrogate D. ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--At the meeting of the Western Freight Association to-day the question of uniform classification was taken up. It was decided to recommend the appointment of a committee of three by each of the six traffic associations in the United States to meet at the earliest convenient date for the consideration of this question.

Senator Quay's private and confidential conference of eminent Republicans came off at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon in accordance with the terms of his private and confidential letter, which was published in THE TIMES yesterday morning.

Another authoress whom I have frequently met is Miss Laura Jean Libbey, whose sensational, rather indecorous, novel, "Miss Middleton's Lover," is the talk of the time. Perhaps Miss Libbey caught some of her inspiration for "Miss Middleton's Lover" from the French.

The people of Fernandina, Fla., have been persuaded for some time that the yellow fever existing there is of a milder type than afficting Jacksonville, and have in consequence seriously objected to their supplies being handled and forwarded by Jacksonville.
READING, Penn., Oct. 9.--Lawrence J. Ibach, known for 40 years throughout this county as the "blacksmith astronomer," died this forenoon at his modest home, in Newmanstown, Lebanon County.
Col. QUAY is to be congratulated upon avoiding the repetition of the banquet of 1884, which has come to be known as BELSHAZZAR'S feast.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 9.--The trial of Mary A. Stone, charged with atrocious assault and battery on Mrs. Estella Todd on April 2, was begun to-day. Mrs. Todd was the first witness in her own behalf.

Just as the big rate wars in the West approach settlement a fight breaks out among the railroads of the South. Threats of it have been heard for some time. Yesterday there came what amounted practically to an official announcement of it.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 9.--Last year's "world beaters," the famous Detroit team of the National League, which is at present tied with Philadelphia for third place, is doomed. Its star players are being sold, and the oft repeated and as oft denied rumors of Detroit getting out of the League is at last to be fulfilled.

MICHAEL C. MURRPHY is a native of Ireland and is about 54 years of age. He came to this country in his boyhood and learned the printing business. He interested himself in politics as soon as he became of age and had made himself recognized as a good political worker before the war.
Mr. CARNEGIE has returned from Cluny Castle and given to the public some remarks about those Trusts and other combinations which his companion on the top of the coach calls "private affairs."

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 9.--The appeal of W.W. Reed of New-York in the case of the Fidelity Insurance Trust and Safe Deposit Company, Trustee, against the West Penn and Shenango Connecting Railroad Company from the decree of the Common Pleas Court of Mercer County was argued to-day in the Supreme Court.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 9.--Mrs. Eliza Black, wife of ex-judge James Black of Lancaster, Penn., a member of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Asso ciation, died at Ocean Grove last evening at the age of 65 years. The association met to-day and held a memorial service in honor of the decreased, after which the remains were taken to Lancaster for interment.

ROME, Oct. 9.--It is now announced that Emperor William will upon his arrival in Rome proceed to the Quirinal, where he will receive the Ministers, Court officials, and the Presidents of the Senate and Chamber of Deputies. He will afterward visit the Pope.

Three to two was the score of the NewYork-Pittsburg game yesterday, and strange to say the Giants again scored the 2 runs. The game was a repetition of Monday's contest. Crane, like George, pitched strongly, but he was wretched supported, errors by Ward.

DUBLIN, Oct. 9.--Mr. T.D. Sullivan, speaking at a meeting of the Irish National League in this city this evening, said that Mr. Balfour's indecent dance upon Mandeville's grave would be an everlasting disgrace, and that his slanders upon the Irish patriot would strengthen the cause for which he died.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9.--A very secret caucus of the Republican Senators was held this morning, in the Commerce Committee room at the Capitol. Special care had been taken to keep the caucus quiet, and a cordon of doorkeepers was placed around all the approaches to the second floor to prevent any stray, visitor from getting within gunshot distance of the committee room.

On behalf of the daughters of the late John H. Stout, formerly a well-known banker of this city, a motion was made in the Surrogate's Court, Brook lyn, yesterday to enjoin their stepmother from spending $3,000 of the estate.
The handsome new chapel of the Rutgers Riverside Presbyterian Church, at Seventythird-street and the Boulevard, was filled to overflowing at its dedicatory exercises last evening.

MONTREAL, Oct. 9.--Considerable uneasiness and not a little excitement exists here over the presence of typhoid fever in this city. Physicians state that the disease is increasing and that the cause is due to the defective sanitary condition of the city.

At the services for the installation of the Rev. John E. Lloyd, formerly of Nyack, at the Twelfth Street Reformed Church, Brooklyn, last evening the Pastor was welcomed to his new charge by representative ministers of the Congregational, Baptist, Methodist, Presbyterian, and Episcopal denominations.
A fatal and very peculiar driving accident occurred in Central Park last night. About 10 o'clook Officer Thomas Nicholson was patrolling the East Drive.

Is it not strange that in a land of free institutions and free men the word "free" in any of its applications should be a term of dread, and that freedom to apply labor in a way to produce the largest results and to exchange its products in a way to get the most for them should be a bugaboo to frighten intelligent men withal?

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 9.--The Indiana Fair Election League is an organization that promises to make trouble for any one who proposes to corrupt the suffrage in this State. It has been very quietly organized, but it has come to the front to-day, and its leading officers avow themselves.

The first meeting of the Veteran Corps, Twenty-second Regiment, since June 12 was held last night at the Hungaria 4 Union-square. Col. Briggs presided. Only routine business was transacted, with the exception that a vote was taken upon a proposition to reduce the annual dues from $5 to $2. This resulted in its unanimous adoption. After the meeting the members enjoyed in a collation in the Hungaria Cafe.
Chief-Justice Larremore of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday denied a petition to have the Importers and Grocers' Exchange dissolved.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 9.--About two inches of snow has fallen here and it is still snowing. ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Oct. 9.--Snow commenced falling here last night,and to-day at noon the storm is still is progress.

Owing to the incompetency of the builder, the platform used for the political meeting in East Houston-street on Aug. 27 was not properly erected, according to the Coroner's inquest concluded yesterday, and by its fall 9year-old Henry Greenbaum, who lived at 301 East Houston-street, was killed.

A big sale of unimproved lots in the Eighth Ward of Brooklyn belonging to the Thomas Hunt estate took plane at the Real Estate Exchange yesterday. Three hundred and tour lots were offered without reservation, and were sold by Adrian H. Muller Son.

LONDON, Oct. 9.--The race for the Czarevitch Stakes was run at the Newmarket meeting this afternoon and won by P. Almont's b.f. Tenebreuse, 4 years, by three parts of a length from Millstream, with Capt. Machell's ...

There is nothing more irritating or that will tend to ruffle an even temper more than an uncomfortable shoe, and the man who produces footwear that does not, when new, put the wearer in actual misery may certainly lay claim to the title of a benefactor.

Yesterday was the second day of registration in Brooklyn. The places of registration were open from 7 to 10 A.M. and from 3 to 10 P.M., and during those hours an average of over 120 names were registered in each of the 375 polling districts.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 9.--The advance in freight rates agreed on in Chicago two weeks ago by all the Chicago-St. Paul lines went into effect to-day. The change is from 40 to 60 cents first class.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 9.--It is very generally conceded now that Bosworth the defaulting Treasurer of the Stafford Mills, led a sort of a double existence in Fall River, Boston, and Providence, and, in the light of his past history, the theory of suicide is discredited.

The season began at Daly's Theatre last evening with the customary enthusiasm and merriment. The new play was a great hit, the popular actors who appeared in it were seen at their best, the audience was large in numbers, and included, or seemed to include, nearly everybody of note in this city and many distinguished persons from elsewhere.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 9.--The Democrats held a big rally here to-night and heard addresses by Judge Westcott of Camden, who heads the Electoral ticket, and William A. Warner of the same city, who gave object lessons on tariff reform.

The National Cross-Country Association spent four hours Monday night at its meeting in the Knickerbocker Cottage in wrangling over proposed changes to its constitution, and even waxed so warm over the matter as to threaten to impeach the presiding officer.

Henry Adams, who admitted that he had also assumed the names of Smith, Wilson, Day, and a number of others which he could not recollect, was tried ands convicted yesterday in the General Sessions for the larceny of $706 worth of diamonds from the store of Ludwig Niessen, 18 John-street, on Sept. 5 last.
The trial of the suit of Mrs. Louisa C. Hoffkins, a widow residing at New-Rochelle, Westchester County, against the Manhattan Railway ...
Messrs. Shipman, Barlow, Larocque Choate yesterday presented to Mr. Joseph F. Solari, Executor of his brother, the late Emanuel Solari, a check for $33,067 50.
To the editor of a Boston campaign paper Senator Edmunds writes this luminous and emphatic indorsoment of the Republican candidates:
The registration in the city yesterday was an unusually large on for a first day. The gains are especially great in far up-town wards and show the growing parts of the city.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9.--The Hon. R.Q. Mills was given a banquet to-night by the University Club. When Mr. Mills spoke in East St. Louis several weeks ago a delegation from the University Club went across the river, and, after his address, brought him to the club rooms, where he was informally entertained.

MONTREAL, Oct. 9.--The bark Mary K. Campbell, Capt. Temple, from New York for this port, is ashore at Matane, at the mouth of the St. Lawrence. No particulars of the disaster have as yet been received, but it is rumered that three of the crew were drowned while trying to make the land in a boat.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 10.--It has been discovered that James B. Caunce, for 20 years the trusted bookkeeper of the Dolphin Silk Manufacturing Company of this city, and for a long time the Treasurer of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, is an embezzler to the amount of about $10,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10.--Philip Pietquin, a Belgian peasant, accompanied by his wife, Angelina, entered the Coroner's office to-day carrying the corpse of a babe wrapped up in a blanket. Through an interpretor they told a sad story.
Bull hopes went to pieces in Wall-street yesterday. The air was full of prophecies of disaster and the speculators suffered from the effect of a bad scare.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10.--The Yale National Bank yesterday accidentally discovered that it was being made the victim of extensive forgeries which were worked on a scheme similar to the Bedell forgeries. The exact figtures are not known, but will probably reach $20,000.
Chief-Judge McAdam of the City Court yesterday ordered the Family Fund Society to make a full and detailed statement of the diseases with which it claims William H. Cushman was afflicted...

ALBANY, N.J., Oct. 10.--Dr. Hugh S. Kinmouth of Asbury Park and Miss Maude Stanford of Albany were married this evening, the ceremony being performed in the Madison-Avenue Reformed Church, which was crowded.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 10.--The Presidents and General Managers of the following roads met here this evening to consider their re lations with the Central Traffic Association and what action they should take as regards continuing their membership in the association:

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 10.--Rumors are flying thick and fast in railroad circles of Buffalo and Rochester regarding the oppointment of a General Passsenger Agent on the New-York Central to fill the vacancy caused by Henry Monett's death.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 10.--Receiver H.C. Cross and General Manager Frey of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway arrived here to-day and are in consultation with General Manager S.H.H. Clark of the Missouri Pacific. Receiver Cross was asked by a reporter to outline his plans, but he refused.

Just as John McMackin called the County Convention of the United Labor Party to order last evening the delegation from the Twentyfirst Assembly District marched in with fife and drum and a silk banner bearing the inscription, "For Mayor, James J. Coogan."

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Oct. 10.--Roadmasters in towns along the Hudson River in Ulster County and adjoining counties, have been annoyed because a few men have refused to spend the time specified by law in work on highways. A test case has been made here. The time required was one day's work.

There was some excellent shooting at the second day of the tournament of the Jersey City Heights Gun Club in Marion, N.J., yesterdar. A strong wind blew across the range, but it was not as gusty as during the preceding day. Sigler of Montclair. N.J., made the best score.
A telegram contradicting the report from London that the steamship Baltic of the White Star Line had sunk at her dock was received by the agents of the company here yesterday.

MERIDEN, Conn., Oct. 10.--Mary Griffin, 55 years old, died at the aimshouse here to-day after 55 days of voluntary starvation. She took nothing but water during that time, and could not be forced to do otherwise. She was insane on this subject.

The open Fall games of the Orange Athletic Club were begun at Roseville, N.J., yesterday with a ball match between nines of the Staten Island Athletic Club and the Orange club. At 3:30 P.M. the athletic sports began and an audience of about 500 persons cheered itself hoarse over the efforts of the amateurs. M.J. Ford, who has been reinstated, took part in some of the events.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Western Union Telegraph Company was held yesterday at Broadway and Dey-street. President Norvin Green presented his report, from which it appears that the present outstanding capital stock of the company is $86,199,852 06, of which $25,976 70 belongs to the company.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10.--The final contests in the inter-collegiate lawn tennis tournament were played off to-day. Sears of Harvard won first place in the singles and Campbell and Hall of Columbia first place in the doubles.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 10.--Alexander M. Lowry, formerly a wealthy capitalist, was this afternoon held to appear at the United States court in Auburn on a charge of frauds in obtaining pensions. The examinations were before United States Commissioner Hazeltine, Col. S.M. Welch of Buffalo representing the Government.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 10.--A conference of railroad officials has been in progress in this city for several days, the object of it being the consolidation of lines in opposition to the Richmond and Danville Road.

Of the four racers that held the track from 4 to 6 o'clock yesterday in the roadsculling match at Madison-Square Garden, Gaudaur, Conley, Bubear, and East constituted the first batch, and East had his usual bad luck with his machines, meeting with as many accidents as the other three put together.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 10.--William Scott Knight of Brooklyn, an inmate of the Hudson River State Hospital for the Insane for four years past, dropped dead in the Post Office here to-night.

LONDON, Oct. 10.--A dispatch from Shanghai to the Standard says: "It is alleged here that a secret treaty has been signed by Russia and Corea which, secures extensive privileges to Russian traders and residents in Corea and the establishment, of an exclusively Russian port at Funei. The Grand Duke Alexander recently had a cordial interview with the King of Corea."

LONDON, Oct. 10.--The race for the Middle Park Plate was run at the Newmarket second October meeting to-day. Donovan won. Gulliver was second and Clover third. There were 14 starters. The last betting was 5 to 4 against Donovan.

A temperance demonstration in honor of the ninety-eighth anniversary of the birth of Father Mathew, the apostle of temperance, was hold last evening in the hall of the cathedral school, 111 East Fiftieth-street, by the Father Mathew Total Abstinence Memorial Society of New-York, assisted by the Provincial Council.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 10.--Homer W. Nash, United States Bank Examiner in this State, has been elected Cashier of the Fourth National bank of Grand Rapids, and will at once accept it resigning his Government position.

The programme to be run at Jerome Park to-day contains no big event like the Titan Stakes, but while not being a brilliant one it is infinitely better than that of yesterday, and bids fair to produce some spirited contests, instead of a succession of easy victories with little or no interest attached to them.

MACON, Ga., Oct. 10.--Ten days ago Barney Fair and Eli Barnes were playing a game of cards in Sparta, near this city. A dispute arose. Barnes fired three shots into Fair's abdomen, from which the wounded man died yesterday.

The National Line steamer The Queen at 3 o'clock on the morning of Oct. 5, in a comparatively, smooth sea, ran into the French fishing bark Madeline of Granville, and cut into her so that she Bank almost immediately. The collision occurred in latitude 46 1', longitude 48 28'.

The American Jockey Club never had a more unsatisfactory day's racing since their organization than was that of yesterday/ Great things were expected of the Titan Stakes and the Appeal Stakes, the first because, under its conditions and with $5,000 added by the club, it looked as if the best 2 year-olds of the East would meet in it for a battle royal, one that would be worth going miles to see.

The result of the Newark charter election on Tuesday was a stunning blow to Republicans because of its very probable effect on the general election next month. Democrats are elated in consequence and Republicans are correspondingly depressed.

EASTMAN, Ga., Oct. 10.--The murder of Mr. J.A. Sheffield, a wealthy merchant of Irwinton, has baen fastened upon William Collins, a colored man. It seems that Sheffield was in the habit of carrying home large sums of money after nightfall.

New-York may not be the pivotal State after all. At the meeting of the Democratic National Committee yesterday all the members were satisfied from the reports made to them that Michigan is already sure for Cleveland and Thurman, and that, if the current toward Democracy in Illinois keeps flowing on at its present...

VIENNA, Oct. 10.--Emperor William and Emperor Francis Joseph arrived at Murzzuschlag from Neuburg at 12:30 P.M. to-day. They were met by the King of Saxony, the Regent of Bavaria, and the Duke of Tuscany. After luncheon Emperor William bade all farewell.
The Special Grand Jury in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, which was organized in June last, was discharged yesterday by Judge Daniels after it had made the following presentment:

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 10.--There have been no new developments in the passenger-traffic difficulty engaged in by the Minneapolis and St. Louis and Wisconsin Central, although decisive action may be looked for at any time. General Passenger Agent Barker of the latter road declares that his line has withdrawn from the agreement, giving his reasons as follows:

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 10.--Since the town elections were held in this State, one week ago last Monday, there has been a tremendous amount of hurrahing and throwing in air of caps by Republicans who profess to see in the results certain promise of victory for Harrison and Morton in November.
Postmaster Pearson's attention has been called to an unsigned circular, which has been extensively distributed throughout this city, purporting to quote from Article IV., page 697, of Postal Laws...

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 10.--The Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company te-day accepted the resignation of John S. Williams an General Freight Traffic Agent, and in doing so passed a resolution in which they...

A telegram was received from St. Louis yesterday by W.G. McCormick Co. saying that any telegrams from there saying that the firm of D.R. Francis Brother of St. Louis were in financial trouble were absolutely false, having no foundation whatever.

Carlota Felipe wants possession of her 13year-old son Joseph, who is at present getting his hands blistered in learning to be a farmer with Elwood K. Cross of Oregon, Ill., where he was sent by the New-York Juvenile Asylum. Mrs. Felipe, through her counsel James T. Williamson, obtained a writ of habeas corpus to...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 10.--The mimic siege of Halifax to-day resulted in the enemy ontwitting the defense and capturing MacNab's Island. It was the most important and interesting naval and military demonstration that ever occurred here, but the population,
Judge O'Brien, in Supreme Court, Chambers, was asked yesterday to declare Emma Foley, W. Duryee Hughes, William H. Ottman, and Charles A. Bergermann guilty of contempt of court.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 10.--Work was begun to-day by the Wheeling and Harrisburg Railroad Company on the Union Railroad bridge over the Ohio River at the north end of this city and also in East Wheeling on the terminal system to reach all the roads centring here.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 10.--A smash-up occurred yesterday afternoon on the Newark and Paterson Railroad, at Franklin, causing a loss to the company of $100,000.

There was a decided feeling of depression at the Now-York Produce Exchange yesterday. The trading in wheat amounted only to 9,250,000 bushels, about 4,500,000 of which was December and about the same amount May. Prices opened much lower than the closing quotations of Tuesday, but they were pushed slowly back again.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 10.--The principal society event of the season in this place was the marriage of Miss Cora Marsh, daughter of W.W. Marsh of Schooley's Mountain, to E.J. Fox of Easton, Penn., yesterday.
GETTYSBURG, Penn., Oct. 10.--Three regiments dedicated monuments on the battlefield to-day. the veterans of the Fourth and Seventeenth Maine Regiments gathered around their memorials this morning.

MIDDLETOWN. N.Y., Oct. 10.--There is quite a boom prevailing just now in the Orange County horse market, and some note worthy sales of fine trotting stock are recorded. The most important transaction is the sale by Joseph Gavin of chester of the Stallion Chester Chief, son of old Hambletonian, dam by Young Andrew Jackson.

LONDON, Oct. 10.--The report of the Howard Association for promoting the best methods of treatment of criminals and the prevention of crime has just been published. It warmly eulogizes Mr. George Kennan for his thorough and conscientious work in investigating the Russian prison system.

Miss Helen Kessler, daughter of Samuel Kessler, was married last evening to Sol S. Fridenberg of Philadelphia at the Vienna, Fiftyeighth-street and Lexington-avenue. A brilliant party of about 200 gathered to witness the ceremony which was performed by Rev. Dr. Kohler. There were no bridesmaids.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--Capt. Louis M. Maus, Assistant Surgeon, has been relieved from duty at Fort Schuyler, New-York, and ordered to duty at Fort Porter, New-York.

Elijah A. Morse of Canton has attained the object of his ambition--the Republican nomination for Congress in the Second District The most devoted and sanguine of his followers can scarely hope that he will make good the loss of his predecessor, ex-Gov. Long.
HELENA, Montana, Oct. 10.--While workmen were excavating for a sewer in Main-street yesterday they discovered traces of gold.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10.--The game of football to-day between the two league teams of Princeton College and the University of Pennsylvania resulted in a victory for Princeton by a score of 63 to 0.

A thoroughly well-appointed and admirably-stocked dry goods store has boon opened by J.H. Truesdell Co. at 20 WestFourteenthstreet. Monday the doors were thrown open to the public, and, judging by the crowds which filled it then and yesterday, the firm may look forward to a success.
Seven day laborers and skilled workmen at the Brooklyn Navy Yard were discharged yesterday by Paymaster Loomis upon an order from Secretary Whitney.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 10.--The Republicans of Rochester had the largest parade of the year here to-night in celebration of a visit of Warner Miller, their candidate for Governor. Not only all the Republican clubs of Rochester paraded, but also clubs from Albion, Media, Brockport, Canandaigua, and other places near here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--The October returns of the Department of Agriculture make a decline in the condition of cotton. The heavy rains of the latter part of Angnat have been continued during the larger part of the last month, causing sprouting of seed is the bolls, rotting of the flower, and shedding of the top bolls and foliage.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 10.--The weather has been so exceedingly disagreeable this week thus far that many have gone away. The afternoon trains to New-York have been filled with society people, but others have come on to take the vacant places, so that the hotels are completely filled and every cottager has from four to nearly a dozen guests.

At the meeting of the Commission for the Revision of the Excise Laws yesterday ex-Surrogate Daniel G. Rollins presided, and there were also present Commissioners Dr. Howard Cresby, Max D. Stern, Gallus Thomann, Assemblyman Kruse, Senator Smart, and ex-AttorneyGeneral Denis O'Brien.

James H. O'Neill, who was arrested on Tuesday for taking a watch and chain from Andrew Ruthy of Elmira while the latter was on the Bowery under the influence of liquor, had another watch chain, which he told the police was connected with a Brooklyn burglary and murder.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--The October crop returns, as reported by the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture, show that the condition of the present corn crop has been equaled only three times in tea years, and is exceeded materially only by that of 1879, when the condition was 98, and the subsequent ascertained yield 28 bushels by the census of 1880.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 10.--After a number of fruitless attempts the 40 delegates to the convention of the American Party of the State found a hall to-day.

For three hours last night local Republicans sat as the Executive Committee of the County Committee without doing anything to determine who should be presented to their County Convention at the Grand Opera House to-night for nomination to the Mayoralty and other city and county offices.

PARIS, Oct. 10.--M. de Brazza declares that there is no doubt in his mind that Stanley is safe and pursuing his own scheme to subdue the country by diplomatic dealings with the tribes and then present it to England.

It was offically announced yesterday that the Adams Express Company has concluded a contract for a term of years for the express facilities over the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, now occupied by the United States Express Company.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10.--General Master Workman Powderly of the Knights of Labor, writing on the "Chicago Whest Corner" in this week's Journal of United Labor, says:
A proposal from John W. Sullivan to repair the fire boat William F. Havemeyer for $11,000 was referred yesterday by the Board of Fire Commissioners to the Controller for action on sureties.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 10.--The Laundrymen's National Association closed its annual session to-day. The officers elected are: President--John R. Purchase, Minneapolis; VicePresidents--W.H. Garlock, Cleveland; George Moher, Pittsburg; A.L. Richards, Philadelphia;

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 10.--A local milk trust was formed here to-night. Its principal object is to prevent grocers who sell milk from charging less than the regular price of all, the milkmen, which is now 8 cents per quart. The grocers at present charge 5 cents, and are even accused of giving away milk for the purpose of gaining custom.

Henry S. Ives has sold his house at 136 Joralemon street, Brooklyn, to John Natman, a wealthy young lawyer, for $54,000. Ives bought the place for $25,000, but according to report spent nearly $100,000 in fitting it up.

The weights for the Kensico and Grand National Handicaps to be run at Jerome Park on Saturday were announced yesterday. The Kensico is for 2-year-olds, to be run over the Titan course, and the weights are as follows:

The New-York agents of the Hamburg-American Packet Company have been informed by the company at Hamburg that the twin-screw steamship now building at Stettin will be named the Victoria Augusta instead of the Normannia, in honor of and with the consent and approval of the Empress of Germany.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 10.--The rumor of a terrible accident near Penn Haven is confirmed. The fifth division of the Father Matthew excursion returning from Hazleton on the Lehigh Valley Railroad was wrecked and the cars piled in a shapeless mass, one being stood upon its end.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 10.--The proceedings brought by Mrs. Josephine P. Heap as Administratrix of the estate of her husband, G. Harris Heap, who from June, 1884, to June, 1885, was Consul-General at Constantinople, to recover an...
The following dispatch was received yesterday by W.B.C. Dnres, Chairman of the Fernaudina Relief Committee, from R.S. Schuyler, Secretary of the Howard Association at Fernandina:
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 10--Two cases of mortgage foreclosure were brought against surah Frederica Porter Burrill of London, England, one by Mary B. Gray and the other by Emilio Delpiro.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 10.--Mr. and Mrs. W.J. Florence produced "Heart of Hearts" for the first time at Harris's Academy of Music this evening before one of the largest audiences ever in the theatre.

An interesting wedding took place at 8 o'clock last evening at the house of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Sprague at the Rensselaer, 1,271 Broadway. Miss Nena Britton Barbee aria Albert Waterbury Lane of Mount Vernon were married by the Rev. Dr. Bitting, formerly of Virginia, but now of Harlem.

Dr. Jeremiah Coughlan, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Anti-Poverty Society, again appeared yesterday before Justice Duffy in Jefferson Market Police Conrt on a summons obtained by the Society for the Suppression of Vice...

The convention of the Christian Alliance opened its morning session at 9 o'clock yesterday with the customary prayer meeting, led by the Rev. Mr. Orne of New-Hampshire, and then the members listened to addresses by the Rev. F.A. Jones of Newark and Mr. O.M. Brown of Oberlin, Ohio.

The second trial of the suit for divorce of Josephine M. McBride against Robert P. McBride, who carries on the tea business under the name of the Union Pacific tea Company, was begun yesterday in the supreme Court before Judge Beach. Joseph Choate and Preston Stevenson appeared for Mr. McBride, and W. Bourke Cookran and Samuel G. Adams for Mrs. McBride. The afternoon was consumed in securing a jury.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10.--E. Popper, S.J. Johnson, and J.H. Purdy, the committee appointed by the holders of the Wabash first mortgage bonds, finished their investigation of the road's books and accounts yesterday, and leave to-day for a tour of the entire system in company with Gen. McNulta. Mr. Popper said to a reporter last night:
One to nothing was the result of the last game with the Pittsburg, and the New-York scored the 1 run. Titcomb pitched in such a puzzling manner that only one hit was gained off his delivery.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 10.--A leading Prohibitionist of Connecticut, who wishes his name withheld for personal reasons, declares that Connecticut Prohibitionists generally believe that there is an understanding batween the rum element and the 'managers of the Republican campaign in Connecticut.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 10.--The death of Mrs. Sarah Ripley of this city, widow of Gen. James W. Ripley or the United states Army, renders available a scholarship amounting to $3,000 left to Trinity College by Miss Maria...
CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 10.--There is much dissatisfaction among the Eastern roads at what they term the dictatorial attitude of the Pennsylvania arrangement in regard to eastbound rates.
WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 10.--The factory of the Wheeling Match Company has been closed down by the Match Trust for an indefinite time, and all the employes discharged.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--It is doubtful whether, in all the history of the United States Senate, the majority of that body ever spent the funds of the people for the publication of a more malignant and bitterly partisan report than that made by Mr. Hale to-day from the select committee to investigate the operations of the civil service.

The representation of French comedy at Palmer's Theater last evening was a rare treat. It appealed successfully to the intellect of the spectator, and touched his sympathy as well. Emile Augier is not a great poet, nor is he a great dramatist in comparison with the best.
The Columbia College Athletic Association held an enthusiastic meeting yesterday afternoon at Prof. H.T. Peck's lecture room, and elected the following officers for the coming year:

DENVER, Col., Oct. 10.--Mining circles throughout Colorado have been greatly excited all day-over the reports which have been received from Aspen stating that the Silver Star Mine had struck a rich vein.
ABERDEEN, Dakota, Oct. 10.--Bangor, Walworth County, expects a lynching bee. A farmer living 14 mills southwest of that town, whose name could not be learned, married a Miss Battles some months ago.

Richmond, Staten Island, yesterday enjoyed the most exciting day it has seen for years, not excepting the Fourth of July. They had the First Congressional District Democratic Convention there, and the little country cross roads were nearly swamped by it. Sixteen delegates from Queens County, regular: 12...
ST. ALBANS, Vt., Oct. 10.--The stockholders of the Central Vermont Railroad Company and those of the Consolidated Railroad Company of Vermont held their annual meetings here today.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10.--The death s few days ago of Charles Sylvestor Stannard of Rockland, Conn., recalls one of the most celebrated murder trials which over took place in Connecticut.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 10.--A pretty wedding took place in the Second Dutch Church here to-night, when Miss Nellie Porter, daughter of the late Lucius P. Porter, was married to Neilson T. Parker. Most of New-Brunswick's society people and many guests from...

In his recent annual report as Treasurer of the Amoskeag Mills Mr. T. JEFFERSON COOLIDGE said that "picker hands, carders, mule spinners, and weavers receive in this country from 40 to 30 per cent. more than they do in England."

The Executive Committee of the German Master Bakers' Association met at 311 East Fifthstreet last night, and made arrangements for a mass meeting of bakers to be held next Sunday at Free masons' Hall, 215 East Fifteenth-street, at which...

CHICAGO, Oct. 10.--The troubles arising from the street railroad strikes took a more serious turn to-day. There was rioting on both the north and west sides, tracks wore torn up in places, barricades were built across streets, and the ugly crowds which collected frequently gave the police force all it could do to handle them.

The uprising of the tribes along the coast of Zanzibar to resist the inroads of foreigners is the natural outcome of the eagerness with which the Germans, British, and Italian's have been pushing their rival interests in that part of Africa.

The New York Commission for Gettysburg Monuments, composed of Gens. Sickles, Carr, and Graham, and Major Richardson, met at 23 Fifth-avenue yesterday, with the intention of doing a great deal of work.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10.--The oldest wholesale liquor firm in the city, Weadley Cleary, made a voluntary assignment to Jonathan Abel yesterday, for the benefit of creditors.

The Gaelic athletic team has determined to make its last appearance in this country at a great athletic meeting which will take place in Madison-Square Garden Saturday, Oct. 20. The rules of the Gaelic Association will govern all the contests.

The gay costumes of the Essex County huntsmen were yesterday surpassed in brilllancy only by the gorgeous raiment of the Orange Mountains. Where one coat of cloth flashed red in the October sunshine a million trees bore aloft a covering of the most wonderful colors.

LIBERTY, N.Y., Oct. 10.--George Moulthrop of Pike Pond missed a Spring calf three weeks ago, A couple of days ago a neighbor in passing the old tannery near the pond heard weak, plaintive pleadings. Investigation showed the cries were uttered by the calf.

The books at the Building Bureau show rather a calling off in building affairs during the present month. The specifications entered are for the most part on small buildings, though permission has been asked to erect three or four apartment houses to cost from $75,000 to $100,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 11.--The Republican demonstration to-day was one of the largest ever held in Indiana. The early trains poured thousands of people into the city.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 11.--The South Carolina Railroad Commission to-day issued its report of the earnings of the various roads in the State during August.
RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 11.--This town put on a holiday attire this evening. Flags, lanterns, and bunting adorned the principal dwellings, and the streets were filled with interested spectators.

TORONTO, Oct 11.--Three elections for the local Legislature of Ontario came off to-day. Hugh Smith (Conservative) was elected in Frontenac, J. C. Dance (Reformer) in East Elgin, and Dr. Willoughby (Conservative) in East Northumberland.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 11.--Lightning performed a singular freak among the cattle of Washington Schmeck, a farmer residing in Ruscumb Manor Township, Berks County, the other day.

LONDON, Oct. 11.--This was the fourth day of the Newmarket second October meeting. The race for the Champion Stakes was won by Friar's Balsam. Minting was second and Zangbar third. There were six starters. The last betting was 5 to 2 against Friar's Balsam.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 11.--"Wanted--Information as to the exact whereabouts of 'The Cyclone of Fear.' (Copyrighted by Chauncey M. Depew.) If found in Connecticut a liberal reward should be paid by the Republican National Committee. Reported discoveries by representatives of the New-York Sun and the NewYork Tribune will not be considered authentic until otherwise indorsed."
BOSTON, Oct. 11.--The Senior Class of Harvard held the most important of all its class meetings this evening, that for the election of Class Day officers.
Beginning Oct. 15, the Wabash Western Railway will run a through line between St. Louis, Denver, and Cheyenne, via Kansas City and the Union Pacific Railroad.

At yesterday's meeting of the Commissioners for the revision of the excise laws all were present except ex-Attorney-General Denis O'Brien. The Commississoners continued their former plan of going through the present laws, section by section, making changes where they were considered advisable.

The residents of New-York and Brooklyn were startled yesterday morning by a volume of thick black smoke that arose apparently somewhere in the neighborhood of Greenpoint and floated in a lowering sooty cloud for several miles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11.--Cablegrams from Heidelberg, Germany, were received yesterday by young James Flood, giving accounts of a dangerous relapse suffered by his father, the bonanza millionaire, at that place.
WEST CHESTER, Penn., Oct. 11.--William Scott, who resides near this city, owned a valuable shepherd dog, which was known by the name of Prince.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 11, via Galveston. --Recent heavy and prolonged rains caused an immense lake to form between Yrolo and Apam, which threatened for a time serious damage to both the Interoceanic and Mexican Railroads.

PEEKSKILL, Oct. 12.--The complications which made Westchester Democracy odious to the party managers last Fall do not exist. Differences there are, but not to an extent that will imperil the national ticket.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 12.--Despite inclement weather registretion here yesterday, the first of the four days set apart for that purpose, was about 25,000, or one-third of the total vote. The registration on the same day last year was 20,000.

LONDON, Oct. 12.--Daniel Goulding, formerly a warder in Tullamore Jail, was arrested to-day charged with having committed perjury at the inquest into the death of Mr. John Mandeville. Goulding deposed at the inquest that Mr. Mandeville had been ill-treated by himself and the other warders, under orders of the Governor of the jail. Goulding was admitted to bail.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct, 12.--The horror caused by the Lehigh Valley disaster at Mud Run Wednesday night is still widespread and profound, and the black emblems of death are displayed on many doors in and about Scranton to-day. The death list of authentic names today numbers 64, and it is expected that at least one-half the injured will die.

MONTREAL, Oct. 12.--The true inwardness of the disgraceful scene at the reception of Lieut.-Gov. Angers on Wednesday has been made public this evening. It appears that at the Council meeting on Monday Acting Mayor Clendenning was drunk in the chair.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 12.--Next Tuesday the First New-York Volunteer Engineers' Regiment Association will hold its reunion in this city.

MACON, Mo., Oct. 12.--The strike of the miners in the Bevier coal district culminated to-day in a riot, in which Thomas Wardell, the leading coal operator of this section of the State, was shot and killed.

Surrogate Ransom has had prepared a statement comparing the week done by him during the seven month of this year that he has served with that accomplished by his predecessor, Surrogate Rollins, in 1887.

Yesterday the Commissioners for the revision of the excise laws in this State adjourned until Oct. 30, in order to allow their Secretary, George B. Colby, to frame a new law upon the resolutions, suggestions, and revisions of the old law made by the Commissioners during their sessions of the last two weeks.

HARRISBURG, Oct. 12.--"Joe" Dull, a famous hunter, fisherman, trapper, and guide, who has lived among the mountains of Central Pennsylvania for many years, was fatally shot by a companion hunter, Thomas West, on Wednesday.

LONDON, Oct. 12.--Dr. Mackenzie, in his book on the case of the late Emperor Frederick, states that after the Emperor's death an attempt was made to entrap him into a false position, and it was therefore settled that no postmortem examination should be made.

MONRTREAL, Oct. 12.--The story telegraphed to some of the United States papers today stating that the Hon. Mr. Chapleau, Canadian Secretary of State, made a warlike speech at the dinner to Mr. Richard White, the new Member of Parliament for Cardwell, was untrue...

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12.--James L. Flood to-day received a cablegram from Heidelberg, Germany, stating that there was no change in the condition of his father, James C. Flood, and that there is slight hope of the patient's recovery.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 12.--A rumor that the hide dealers of the Northwest were about to form a trust for the control of the hide market was current yesterday. James McMillen Co., with their Chicago and Helena (Montana)...

The Scriptural injunction to heal the sick by anointing with oil was yesterday complied with by the leaders of the Christian Alliance or believers in Divine healing, now holding a convention in this city. The ceremony was performed at Standard Hall, 1,476 Broadway, which was well filled.

It appears that the Dominion has set on foot inquiries into the location of the ship canal or channel through the St. Clair Flats without waiting for the reply of our own War Department to the Senate resolution on that subject.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 12.--All the races ever which the Trotting Horse Breeders' Association have control have been declared off on account of the continued rain. The stake races for 2 and 3 year-olds and the 2:40 class will be trotted to-morrow, rain or shine.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 12.--The registration of students for the Michigan State, University closed at Ann Arbor yesterday. The figures show a gain over those at the same date last year, when there were 1,481 students enrolled. DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 12.--A horrible accident accurred at a sawmill near Greenville, in this State, Tuesday night. After the close of the day's work, and when all the employes had gone home. Cloris Peterson, the night watchman, started the machinery in motion to clear out the sawdust conveyers, as was his usual custom.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 12.--The Post Office at Matteawan was entered by burglars last night. The safe was blown open, money and postage stamps were taken, and registered letters rifled. About $30 in cash was taken, but the amount of stamps and other articles stolen cannot be stated. Entrance was gained through a window.

The subscriptions to the Florida relief fund received at the Mayor's office yesterday amounted to $183 57, and were as follows: St. Luke's Church, Montclair, N.J., $100; employes New-York Athletic Club, $54 40; cash, $10; per the Tribune, $18 77; Four Friends of Humanity, 40 cents. The aggregate receipts are $61,655 87.

A loan on real estate at 4 per cent., which is believed to be the first loan of American capital at so low a rate in this city, has this week been placed. The amount was $75,000, and the property was a block on Washingtonstreet.

MASON CITY, Iowa, Oct. 12.--Iowa had two bank failures yesterday. The Boyer Valley Bank at Woodbine and the Caldwell Bank at Logan closed their doors, and Judge King was appointed Receiver. Both banks were operated by the same firm. The total deposits will not exceed $50,000. The failures are attributed to too heavy speculation in land.

Lumber rafting by sea is to be tried on this coast. It should be safer business here than in the treacherous weather of the East, and the scheme of rafting from Puget Sound to Chilean ports looks feasible enough in view of the fact that some years ago a timber raft crossed the Atlantic.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12.--Arthur Rich, 17 years old, who recently attempted to poison Mrs. C. S. Russell at Rock Landing, was arrested Thursday...

BOSTON, Oct. 12.--There were a great meny crestfallen police officers in the Boston Municipal Court to-day, when Inspector Dennis A. Mountain, occupying a position of honor and trust at Headquarters, was arraigned on the charge of receiving stolen property.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct, 12.--F.N. Vilas offered to be $1,000 on Harrison yesterday. He was promptly taken by a syndicate of Democrats and the money was put up to-day.

MITCHELL, Ind., Oct. 12.--This little town, with a population of 1,300, was the point selected by the Democratic State Committee for Gov. David B. Hill of New-York to open his brief canvass of Indiana, Lawrence County to thickly populated, and Mitchell has long been famous for its large and enthusiastic Democratic gatherings.
BELLEVILLE, Ill., Oct. 12.--Clavis Soucy, Supervisor of the Township of Cattokia, in this county, was arrested to-day for an alleged shortage of $40,000 in his accounts.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12.--There was a meeting representing nearly all the cracker bakers between Pittsburg and the Rocky Mountains today at the Grand Pacific Hotel, at which it was unanimously agreed to advance the price of crackers from to 1 cents per pound on the various grades. The advance takes effect tomorrow, the factories being given notice by telegraph of the decision of the meeting.
ALBANY, Oct. 12.--State Superintendent of Insurance Maxwell is keeping close watch of bogus insurance companies and those that evade the provisions of their charters that they may gull the public.
Tammany Hall held its Congressional Conventions last night. In four districts--the Seventh, Tenth, Eleventh, and Twelfth--the conventions appointed conference committees and adjourned.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 12.--A distinguished party of Georgians will leave on a special car for Austin, Texas, where Mr. Henry W. Grady will deliver the oration at the Texas State Fair. The party will consist of Mr. Grady, Gov. Gordon, ex-Gov. McDaniel, Senator Colquitt, Capt. E.P. Howell, and others.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--The President today vetoed Senate bill No. 1,040, authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to state and settle the account of James M. Willbur with the United States for alleged extra work done by Wilibur in furnishing and laying illuminated tiling in the New-York Custom House and Post Office Buildings.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 12.--Pauline McCoy, colored, who was hanged at Union Springs at 10 o'clock this morning for the murder of Annie Jordan, white, last February, was the third woman hanged in Alabama since its incorporation as a State and the first since the war.

There was a fight at Pythagoras Hall last evening, and James E. Quinn and his faction secured possession of the Master Workman's and Secretary's offices, from which they had been ousted a couple of months ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12.--Betting on the coming election is becoming very active in this city. Most of the bets on the national contest are even, but offers of money on Harrisonare snapped up much more eagerly then offers on Cleveland, and where any odds are given they are in every case on Cleveland.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 12.--A Newport coaching party, consisting of Col. Goddard and wife, J.J. Van Alen, A. Herbert, R. Peters, and the Misses Slater and Gwynn, arrived here last night, and left here this morning for Tuxedo Park, on their way to New-York.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 12.--Joel P. Heatwole and the Republican State Central Committee are becoming desperate.
