WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--It is authoritatively stated at the Treasury Department that Secretary Fairchild's visit there yesterday had nothing to do with the matter of bond purchases, and furthermore that there has been no change in the policy of the department in that respect,

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 12.--Mr. Blaine and party arrived at 6 o'clock this evening and were received by a large concourse of citizens. At Terre Haute, on the way from Indianapolis, there was an enthusiastic crowd of several hundred, whom Mr. Blaine addressed as follows:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 12.--Forty-seven horses were sold at the combination sale to-day for $11,000. Only one brought over $500, it being Steel, bay stallion, by Lucas Brodhead, dam by Happy Medium, bought by Mr. Beamer, Philadelphia, for $775.

TORONTO, Oct. 12.--There has been considerable excitement in police circles and some indignation among citizens generally on account of what is held to be a miscarriage of justice, namely, the light sentence of five years' imprisonment which the notorious tough, Tom...

Rain or shine, whether the Belgian pavements of Broadway are covered with its own peculiar rainy-weather slime or are as clean as the proverbial new pin, the Democratic business men of this city will ratify the nomination of Cleveland and Thurman after such a fashion to-day as will cause all the skeletons in the Republicans' closets to rattle their decaying bones.

RACINE, Wis., Oct. 12.--Miss Amanda Case, youngest daughter of the Hon. J.I. Case, was married last evening, to Jonathan J. Crooks of San Francisco. The residence of the bride's parents was beautifully decorated. Mr. and Mrs. Crooks left here in the evening for San Francisco, where they will reside.

Miriam Keller, wife of Col. Joseph Keller, who was burned by the explosion of a can of alcohol on Thursday evening, died yesterday. Col. Keller told Deputy Coroner Jenkins that he had just returned from his business to his home, at 7 Lafayette-place,

Mrs. Frances Cleveland and Mrs. Folsom were interested spectators at Palmer's Theatre last evening, and were the objects of scarcely less attention than the play itself. The audience was one of the most brilliant that has been gathered at any theatre this season.

GLASCO, N.Y., Oct. 12.--The Democrats of the First Assembly District of Ulster Country met in convention here yesterday afternoon and nominated Michael E. Donlon of the town of Saugerties for member of Assembly on the first ballot. Mr. Donlon is a coal dealer.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12.--Judge Shepard entered an order in the Traders' Bank case today allowing the Receiver to set of notes made by the depositors against deposits now in the bank to their credit, and, after credit is allowed,

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 12.--Lawrence Harris is a young white man until now of good social standing in Piercetown, Anderson County, this State. Miss Minnie Hammond is the only daughter of D.H. Hammond, one of the wealthiest planters of the county, and is the acknowledged belle of the village.

An act passed at the last session of the Legislature makes it the duty of the County Clerk to prepare and distribute ballots for and against the proposed constitutional amendment intended to empower the Governor to appoint seven Judges of the Supreme Court to act as an auxiliary Court of Appeals whenever the calendar of the court of last resort is over burdened.

WASHINGTON, Oct 12.--A report has been received here, access to which is denied, giving an official account of a serious mishap to the Tallapoosa on the South Atlantic station. It is said that the vessel ran on a reef, and besides breaking machinery and seriously damaging her hull, filled her cylinders with sand. The mate rial necessary to repair her, it is reported, cannot...

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12.--The Philadelphia Amateur Dramatic Association, a downtown organization of young colored Thespians, to-day in Common Pleas Court, No. 3, asked $1,000 damages of Peter Reuter, the proprietor of Wheatley Dramatic Hall, at Fifth and Gaskill streets, for breach of contract.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12.--Residents of the treat side held a mass meeting last night and appointed a committee to do something to stop the strike, which has not only been causing a vast amount of inconvenience, but has also seriously out into trade.

About 80 weft weavers employed in the carpet mills of Joseph Wild Co., Long Island City, went on strike yesterday because one of the hands was put to work on a new loom without the permission of the other employes.

GRAND FORKS, Dakota, Oct. 12.--An article appears in this month's American Review entitled "Old Shady, With a Moral," written by Gen. W.T. Sherman. "Old Shady" is a resident of our city, his name being R.B. Durant, popularly known as Major Durant.

The interest in the roadsculler race centred yesterday in the contest between Gaudaur and Ross. By midnight Thursday Ross was within four miles of the leader. Gaudaur did not like this apparently and started in yesterday with a determination to annihilate his antagonist.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 12.--Last night the Robert R. Carson, a cattle steamer, sank four miles below here in 30 feet of water. Fifty head of cattle, four horses, and some freight were lost.

MONTREAL, Oct. 12.--Transportation companies, vessel owners, and merchants interested in the transportaion of grain received telegrams early this morning from Cornwall to the effect that there had been a bad break in the canal at that place, and that St. Lawrence navigation would be interrupted for some weeks.
MILLERS, Oct. 12.--About 20 millers, mainly from Southern Minnesota, held a meeting at the Nicollet House on Monday and formed an organization known as the Northwestern Millers' Association.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 12.--The examination into the affairs of the Public Administrator's office was resumed yesterday Col. Gus A. Breaux, the attorney for the Public Administrator during the past eight years, spent the day on the witness stand.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 12.--Some two weeks ago a letter was sent from the Union League of this city to Chairman Quay of the Republican National Committee, asking that O.V. Tousley be employed to stump the State of Minnesota in the interest of Harrison and Morton, and evincing inferential alarm concerning the result in the State unless the most strenuous efforts were made to save it from the Cleveland men.

HARTFORD, Oct. 12.--It has been said in letters to THE TIMES concerning the political situation in this State that the conduct of the Democratic campaign is not entirely satisfactory to all the members of the party. Mr. A. E. Burr, editor of the Times of this city, is one of the gentlemen who believes that different methods of work would be better.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 12.--The records of Dartmounth College Observatory show that the rainfall for September was 5.9 inches--more than double the average of the last 23 years and six times that of the corresponding month last year. The amount of rain in September has only been exceeded in the years 1868, 1869, and 1882. There were only seven clear days during the month.

Justice Duffy rendered a decision yesterday in the case of Dr. Jeremiah Coughlin of the AntiPoverty Society, who was charged with violating the lottery laws in permitting the selling of chances on the bust of Dr. McGlynn at the fair. The magistrate decided that the law had been violated, but dismissed the complaint on the ground of ignorance.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 12.--The races here to-day resulted as follows: First race--One mile. Mute won, Lovies second. Time, 1:58. Second race--One and one-sixteenth miles. Vigilant won, Triple Cross second. Time, 2:05. Third race--One and one-eighth miles. Yorick won, Boccaccio second. Time, 2:25.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 12.--The United Labor Party will not vote for a candidate for President of the United States in Pennsylvania this year.

The deaths of James Flynn and Thomas Durken were officially investigated yesterday by Coroner Eidman. The men were killed by the collapse of a five-story building at Ninth-avenue and Eightythird-street on Aug. 25.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12.--The rumors of a bequest to William Foley of this city prove to be true, but the correct amount cannot be learned.

The oil boat Ella Vose, which is still burning at the North Tenth-street dock, Brooklyn, still has 3,000 barrels of naphtha aboard, and is regarded with anxiety. None of the firms who are losers by the fire will give an idea of its loss, but Assistant Engineer Smith, who has charge of the firemen, places the damage at $200,000. The four firemen who were injured are doing well.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 12.--Alexander Taylor, a prominent resident of this city, and one of the oldest business men, was discovered in his apartments this morning with a bullet wound clear through his left side, quite near the heart.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12.--The tennis tournament was a success financially to the Intercollegiate Tennis Association, but not so to some of the players. There were two robberies committed.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 12.--The residents of Clark County, Wis., were thrown into a fever of excitement in the latter part of May, 1884, by the murder of Hugh Meadows, a well-known lumber merchant of Neillsville.

The programme announced by the American Jockey Club for yesterday did not promise very much in the way of sport, and, together with the threatening weather, it was hardly to be expected that the attendance would be large.

Robert P. McBride, the wealthy tea merchant, whose wife, Josephine M. McBride, wants a separation, told his side of the story of their marital disasters yesterday before Judge Beach and a jury in the Supreme Court, Circuit.

Mme. Jane Hading and her mother and M. and Mme. Stuart of the Coquelin-Hading company laughed heartily at the antics and grimaces of Dockstader's Minstrels last night.

KINGSTON, N.Y. Oct. 12.--John Parsloe, a shoemaker of this city, fell out of his bedroom in the third story of his house on Washington-avenue, this morning, to the sidewalk below. He was instantly killed. In his descent his feet struck a window in the second story. Underneath the window are stone steps. He fell head first on them. Parsloe leaves a family.

LONDON, Oct. 12.--This was the fifth day of the Newmarket second October meeting. The race for the eleventh Great Challenge Stakes was won by Sandal. Ormuz was second and Irgunder third. The last betting was 3 to 2 on Sandal.
Elbridge T. Gerry, President of the NewYork Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, has written the following letter to THE TIMES:

BUFFALO, Oct. 12.--A bushel of letters, directed to persons and business houses in this city, and coming from all parts of the country, ware stolen from the Post Office some time during last night. The night stamping clerk, John Shields, has been arrested as the thief.

The Jersey City Heights Gun Club's tournament at Marion, N.J., was concluded yesterday, and the sportsmen and dead shots who have gathered there from all parts of the United States will now journey to Dunellen, N.J., where the Middlesex Gun Club's annual shoot, one of the biggest in the country, will take place.

BOSTON, Oct. 12.--The warfare between Frank B. Sanborn and the Board of Lunacy and Charity assumed a farcical phase to-day, when the clerk of the board sent for Mrs. M.L. Morris, an amanuensis and typewriter for Mr. Sanborn, and summarily dismissed her from the force.

Eighteen weavers employed in Joseph Wilde Co.'s Dunswick Carpet Mills, at Astoria, Long Island, went out on strike yesterday. Nearly all of the 175 employes of the firm are Scotch or English, the 18 mentioned being mostly Scotchmen. Yesterday Superintendent Armitage put a German, who is a naturalized citizen, to work.

EASTMAN, Ga., Oct. 12.--News reaches here from the lower end of Montgomery County of the assassination of Troy McCoy at a colored ball. McCoy was inside the room, and was shot from the outside through a crack. His head was blown to atoms.

MONTREAL, Oct. 12.--The action taken by the Local Government against LeMonde for pub lished the advertisement of the Louisiana State Lottery was dismissed by Judge Dunderand today, on the ground that the accused was a corporate body, and the penalty provided for this offense could not be enforced against them, as a corporate body could not be sent to jail.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 12.--Freight traffic on the Central-Hudson Railroad is at a standstill. Trains are lying along the road in this vicinity through a strike of the switchmen employed in the West Albany yards. There are about 50 switchmen employed there. The strike was caused through the refusal of the company to increase the pay of the men 20 cents a day. Everything is quiet about the yards.

An interesting case was decided in the Court of Chancery at Newark, N.J., yesterday. The litigation was between Capt. Richards of Port Oram, N.J., and George Frederick Collins and Mary J. Collins of Newark over the latter's 10-year-old daughter.

Mrs. O'Sullivan Dimpfel, the Baltimore lady who recently decided to go upon the stage after horse-whipping a friend of her husband, has severed her connection with the Duncan Bradley Harrison company.

Gen. John Newton, Commissioner of Public Works, made a report to the Mayor yesterday, showing that in the quarter ending Sept. 30 he expended $824,658 30 on the appropriation account, and $636,441 39 received from the sale of bonds and on special account.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 12.--Arguments in cases prepared to test the Chinese exclusion act began in the United States Circuit Court this afternoon, and were not concluded at the hour of adjournment. From expressions made use of by Judge Hoffman, however, it is surmised the court is not inclined to grant the petition for writs of habeas corpus to enable Chinese now detained in port to land.

WORCESTER, Mass, Oct. 12.--James A. Cary, the confessed incendiary set fire to the house of Leander Sibley, at Spencer, Oct. 2. Cary occupied the house himself and carried considerable insurance on his furniture.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12.--Unusually close contests are looked for in the regatta of the Yale Navy on Lake Saltonstall to-morrow afternoon. There will be three races, one for the two-hundred-and-fifty-dollar cup offered by the Cleveland Alumni, one between the Juniors and Sophomores, and one between the Academic and Scientific Freshmen.

DANBURY, Oct. 13.--The little town of Monroe is noted throughout the State for the peacefulness of its inhabitants and as a place where political fights are unknown. Monroe's record is now broken, as it is stirred from one end to the other in the most bitter post-election fight ever heard of in the annals of the State of many murders and few executions.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 13.--The complete registration of Cornell University shows a total of 1,164 students. There are 414 Freshmen; last year's entering class numbered 350, showing an increase of 20 per cent.

BRAINERD, Minn., Oct. 13.--The dissatisfaction which has existed among the switchmen in the Brainerd yards of the Northern Pacific Railroad on account of alleged discrimination in the rate of wages culminated last night in a general strike of all the men in the yard, some 25 or 30 in number, with the exception of the yardmaster.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 13.--Leander Whitlock, the son of respectable and well-to-do parents, though he is a worthless fellow, to-night attempted to steal some fruit from A. Cerrigeno's stand. When the latter interfered Whitlock drew a knife and stabbed the Italian. Bystanders seized the man and disarmed him and he was locked up. Cerrigeno was not much injured, though his clothing was cut in several places.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13.--Cases to test the Chinese Exclusion act were submitted to Judges Sawyer and Hoffman in the United States Circuit Court to-day. Decision will be rendered on Monday. The opinion of the attorneys for the Chinese is that the decision will be in favor of a strict enforcement of the provisions of the new law. Should this be the case an appeal will be taken to the United States Supreme Court.

The Verestchagin battle paintings arrived in New-York last Tuesday in charge of two heavily-bearded and fierce-looking Russians, who have since been making frantic endeavors to master the English language. The steamship Excelsior, which arrived yesterday from New-Orleans, reported that she had passed an abandoned three-masted schooner at 10:45 A.M. on Saturday, in latitude 37 4' north, longitude 74 45'.

A jubilee service began at the East Baptist Church, Madison and Gouverneur streets, yesterday, and is to be continued every evening this week. This is the church's fiftieth anniversary, and the celebration is emphasized by the lifting of a mortgage debt which has been hanging over it for 18 years.

ZANZIBAR, Oct. 14.--Negotiations are under way to settle the outbreak of the natives. The Germans are returning to Bagomoyo. It is not true that the rising originated in religious fanaticism. The trouble was caused by the German officials treating the natives and the Sultan's officials with contempt.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 14.--Among the many noble organizations which have looked after the welfare of their members during the prevalence of this terrible disease may be mentioned the Knights of Pythias.

There was a lively fight at Pythagoras Hall at 4 o' clock yesterday morning. Members of the Quinn faction of District Assembly No. 49 came flying out of the doors and windows coatless, shoeless, collarless, and yelling "Murder! Police!" as loud as they could.
The last Sunday afternoon meeting of the Christian Alliance at the Central Baptist Church, in West Forty-second-street, yesterday, was attended by an unusually large congregation.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 14.--The fishery cruiser Charles H. Tupper arrived in port to-day. She will go out of commission.

LYONS, N.Y., Oct. 14.--The Thomas Jefferson's challenge to debate was accepted for the first time at Lyons last evening. The Court House was packed to suffocation, nearly 1,000 being present, with Republicans largely in the majority.

Catherine Quina, the young girl who jumped on the track of the Third-avenue elevated railroad from the platform of the Fourteenth-street station in front of an approaching train on Saturday was arraigned in the Yorkville Court yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14.--The Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad have under consideration a proposition from the Suburban Rapid Transit Company to form a connection with the Consolidated Road's tracks at the Harlem River freight yard.
We continue to-day our inquiry concerning the manner in which certain combinations of mannfacturers would be affected by the Senate Tariff bill.

DANVILLE, Va., Oct. 14.--Mr. John A. Tuckett of the large tobacco firm of George A. Tuckett Sons of Hamilton, Canada, has concluded to go into the manufacture of tobacco in this city on a large scale, having secured a factory for 10 years. He will work probably all the year.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 14--Before coming to this town from Hartford I went to New-Britian and also spent a day in Meriden. Congressman Robert J. Vance, the member from the First Connecticut District, lives at NewBritian.

Mr. Garrett spent another quiet day at the Miller mansion, at Ringwood, yesterday. He sat in an easy chair on the veranda a portion of the after noon and told Dr. Jacobs that he was feeling quite well. Mr. Garrett continues to rest well at night and his appetite is good. Dr. Jacobs says that Mr. Garrett will probably remain at Ringwood until the latter part of November.

It was decided at a mass meeting of the German Master Bakers' Association held yesterday morning in the German Masonic Hall, East Fifteenth-street, that the price of the cheapest loaf of bread shall not be loss than 6 cents.

TANGIER, Oct. 14.--The Government of Morocco persists in its refusal to salute the Portuguese flag. The dispute is becoming acute. The Sultan has arrived at Fez, where he will remain during the Winter.

BOSTON, Oct. 14.--Treasurer Billings of the Boston Club confirms the report that the Boston Club has offered a large sum for five Detroit players, but says the deal cannot be consummated until after the 20th.
Antonio Flacomio, a grocer of 607 Thirdavenue, who had been fatally stabbed, was found last night on the pavement near Cooper Union.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 14.--The steamship Nachoochee arrived here to-day having on board the Captain, his daughter, and a lady passenger and seven men composing the crew of the schooner Nava May, abandoned off Cape Henry. Friday morning, water-logged.
Now that the racing season in this State has ended, the season in New-Jersey will open with racing at the new Clifton track to-day and at the Guttenberg track to-morrow.

The boss bakers of Newark who have been endeavoring to raise the price of bread 1 cent per loaf on account of the rise in flour have failed to agree. Two firms refused to go into the combine, and bread will remain 5 cents a loaf.

The present week will witness the beginning of the local campaign in Brooklyn. All the Republican nominations will be made by Saturday night, while the Democrats will hold their primaries Thursday and their City and County Conventions on Monday of next week.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 14.--The Democratic national ticket will be honestly supported in this, the Fifteenth Congressional District. In the counties of Orange, Sullivan, and Rockland the party is well organized and is doing effective work.

When the American workingman comes seriously to consider the burdens which the tariff tax imposes upon him he must recognize the fact that he is not reaping the benefits of the free institutions under which he lives nor enjoying the fruits of a country that is still comparatively young.

HEMPSTEAD, Texas, Oct. 14.--Louis McDade, (colored,) the Republican candidate for cotton weighter, was shot and killed from ambush in the streets of this city at 10 o'clock last night. No particulars of the assassination have been obtained. Everybody condemns the deed.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--With what would seem to be a big factor of their prosperity removed, the Chicago play houses have prospered during the last week nearly as much as usual.

Among the three shiploads of immigrants which arrived from Europe at Castle Garden yesterday were seven Arab peddlers whom Superintendent Simpson thought it advisable to detain on account of their apparent poverty and the likelihood that they would sconer or later become a public charge. If Collector Magone decides that they are not desirable as citizens they will be returned to the other side of the ocean.
At the American Temperance Union's meeting in Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon Mrs. Mary A. Livermore of Boston told why she had forsaken the Republican Party and joined the Prohibitionists.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 14.--Congressman Robert T. Davis just now finds business of importance to keep hinn in Fall River, and will probably not find time to get book to Washington for several weeks.
The raw, rainy afternoon yesterday made Jerome-avenue look like a country turnpike, so few were the vehicles which passed over it.

The congregation of the Kingsley Methodist Church, of which the Rev Mr. Johnstone is Pastor, of Stapleton, Staten Island, yesterday celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the foundation of the Sunday school.
The value of the opportunity now afforded to American theatre-goers to compare the artistic methods of the most renowned French comedian with those of our own actors should not be underestimated.

Col.W.W. Dudley of Indianapolis, the Treasurer of the National Republican Committee, is lying at the Everett House quite ill with typhoid fever. Mrs. Dudley is with him. He was taken sick on Thursday, but no serious symptoms were displayed till yesterday.
TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 14.--Capt. J.M. Sutterthwait is in the city in the interest of the movement to Oklahoma, in the Indian Territory.
LONDON, Oct. 14.--The rate of discount receded daily during the past week and closed at 4 to 4, being fully 1 per cent. under the Bank of England minimum.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 14.--R.W. Johnson, President of the Johnson Johnson Company, one of the largest manufacturing establishments of the city, has announced his intention of removing the establishment from the city, on account of the high taxes he has been compelled to pay. By simply moving over the Raritan River into Piscataway Township, and out of the city limits, the company will save $2,500 a year.

LONDON, Oct. 15.--The Dublin Freeman's Journal publishes to-day the gist of the charges against the Parnellites, which the London Times will bring forward before the commission of inquiry. The only specific charges are the paying of money to criminals for their defense and to help them to escape.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted $380,100 bonds as follows: Registered 4 per cents at 108 , $300,000, $50,000, $25,000, $2,000, $3,000. Coupon 4 per cents, $100 at 108 .

ALBANY, Oct. 15.--Gov. Hill remarked of the Democratic organization of Albany County a year ago that it was the most complete and best drilled to be found in county of the State. The remark is equally true of the organization to-day.
HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 15.--Warner Miller, the Republican candidate for Governor, who intends to make speeches in the chief cities of the Hudson River Valley this week, arrived here this afternoon.
The installation of the Rev. Dr. Charles L. Thompson as Pastor of the Madison-Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison-avenue and Fifty-thirdstreet, took place last evening.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 15.--The Prohibitionists have commenced a tent campaign in this city. The canvas is stretched in a vacant lot in the business centre. Joseph English, familiarly known as "Joe," an ex-circus clown and a temperance speaker of some renown, is in charge of the work. The Prohibitionists say that the tent method is effective. They will remain here all this week.

The nickel-in-the-slot accident insurance machine that stood in the inclosure did a rushing business, some of the contestants insuring themselves as many as three times against prophesied casualties.

Col. W.W. Dudley, the Treasurer of the National Republican Committee, who has been threatened with typhoid fever, was better last evening. He still keeps his bed at the Everett House, but will soon be out again unless he has a relapse.

The report of a pistol yesterday afternoon near the sheep fold in Central Park, led Sergt. Ferris of the Police to a shed near by, where he found an elderly man sitting down, with a wound in his forehead.

The Anchor Line steamer California arrived at Quarantine yesterday from Mediterranean ports with 347 steerage pas sengers. The ship's surgeon reported that one mild case of varioloid developed during the passage, a child of 3 years. The patient was convalescent, but was removed to hospital. All the passengers were vaccinated and the vessel disinfected and allowed to proceed to the city.

During a political dispute last evening in the liquor saloon 418 East Twenty-third-street Charles Heller, 36 years old, of 264 Avenue A, was stabbed in the right side by Frank Phillips of 326 East was arrested.
Cleveland will have a League club in 1889. The Athletics defeated the Clevelands 7 to 5 yesterday in Philadelphia.
The second annual convention of the Vereingten Staaten Braumeister-Bundes (United States Master Brewers' Association) opened in this city yesterday to continue for three days.
The Democratic and independent move-- ment against Gov. Hill is doing much thorough work.

The supporters of ballet reform held a mass meeting at Cooper Union last night to protest against the re-elction of Gov. David B. Hill. A large, intelligent, and thoroughly orderly audience filled the hall long before the meeting commenced.

James Byrnes, 68 years old, of 456 East One Hundred and Thirty-fifth-street, while at work last evening on the Fourth-avenue railroad bridge across the Harlem River, was struck by a southbound train of the New-York and Harlem Railroad and was instantly killed.
Tho October meeting of the Congregational Club of New-York and vicinity was held at Clarke's restaurant on West Twenty-third-street last evening, with President Roswell Smith in the chair.

Mrs. Mary A. Bennett, aged 50, widow of Edward Bennett, at one time a well-known contractor at Port Richmond; Staten Island, who resides in a neat cottage in Van Pelt-avenue with her three sons, was yesterday taken to the West New-Brighton police station, whither she had been committed by Justice Hulsebus until to-day, when she will be sent to the county insane Asylum.

SHELBYVILLE, Ind., Oct. 15.--Ten cars, with Col. Brice's private car, carrying Judge Thurman and party, left Cincinnati on the Big Four at 8:30 this morning for the big Democratic barbecue at Shelbyville.

The working model of a machine for justifying type composition automatically was on exhibition yesterday at 22 Spruce-street.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 15.--The furnacemen of the Ohio Valley are raising a terrible howl on account of not being able to get sufficient coke to keep their furnaces in blast.

BERLIN, Oct. 15.--Forty thousand copies of Dr. Mackenzie's book have been seized by the police of Leipsic. The police are visiting the book shops in this city and are seizing all copies of the book wherever they are found.

Fifteen Senators and some twenty-five members of the House are now the sole remnants of the Fiftieth Congress in actual attendance at Washington. Of course no business of any consequence can be transacted by such numbers.

Robert Davidon, a saloon passenger on board the Anchor Line steamship Ethiopia when she left Glasgow, was not to be found on the ship on Sunday morning when the vessel was within 24 hours of New-York.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 15.--Judge Brown this morning denied the motion for a new trial in the case of John M. Pollock of the suspended banking firm of John R. Willsle son, who was recently sentenced to serve five years in Sing Sing for grand larceny. Pollock was taken to Sing Sing this morning.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, Oct. 15.--Fong Tang, a Chinaman, age 27, without a cue, and dressed in English clothing, accompanied by his English wife, age 22, from Toronto, arrived here from that city this afternoon en route for New-York.

At a meeting of the Bar Association held at 7 West Twenty-ninth-street Oct. 9 it was resolved "that this association approves as wise and necessary the proposed amendment to section 6 of Article VI. of the Constitution, providing for facilitating the determination of causes on the calendar of the Court of Appeals."

The price of bread per loaf was advanced 1 cent yesterday pursuant to the action of the German Boss Bakers' Union at their meeting Sunday. The advance was practically confined to the members of that organization.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 15.--Mrs. William Morse of Pawtucket, who has been several times confined in an insane asylum, was found by her husband this morning in a room adjoining their bedchamber in her night clothing enveloped in flames. Mr. Morse smothered the flames with a blanket, but the woman was tertibly burned and lived only a few hours.

EX-Alderman Robert B. Nooney called on Mayor Hewitt yesterday and asked him to request the Manhattan Railway Company to put more trains on the elevated railroads and thus add to the convenience of the public. Mr. Hewitt said he had already asked the company to do this, and it had agreed to put on 10 more trains during the busy hours of the morning and evening.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Oct, 15.--Mr. Garrett's condition continues favorable. He was in good spirits to-day, and spent part of the morning walking about the grounds of the Miller mansion. He is furnished with illustrated papers, but is not allowed to see the daily newspa pers containing stock quotations. Dr. Jacobs says that Mr. Garrett talks very little about his business affairs.

PARIS, Oct. 15.--The Chamber of Deputies reassembled to-day. Gen. Boulanger was present at the opening of the session. M. Floquet, the Prime Minister, introduced a bill providing for a revision of the Constitution.

Erhardt said there was perfect harmony in the Republican ranks; that he was a candidate for Mayor, and expected to be elected.

Nobody doubts now that a large amount of money remains to be accounted for. It may not be quite $216,000, but it is not far from it.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 16.--Pine straw bagging from North Carolina was given a thorough test during the past week by the Cotton Exchange here and pronounced good. A bale of cotton covered with this bagging was shipped to-day for Liverpool on the steamer Heraclides.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 16.--Hibbard Baker, a lawyer and real estate agent, was nominated by the Republicans to-day as their candidate for Congress in this district in opposition to Judge Chipman. The district is strongly Democratic.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Oct. 16.--The annual parade of the Point Pleasant Fire Department took place this afternoon. There were over 300 uniformed firemen in line. Visitors from nearly all the departments in Ocean and Monmouth Counties participated.

Alfred H. Gillam, an artist, 26 years old, and a brother of Bernard Gillam, who has been living at 966 Dean-street, Brooklyn, for nearly a year, cut his throat last night in an attempt at suicide. He was found in his room by his wife, and a physician was immediately summoned.

ALBANY, Oct. 16.--It is currently reported in municipal circles to-night that Corporation Counsel D. Cody Herrick has written his resignation to that office, which will be forwarded to Mayor Maher at an early date.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 16.--The American Society of Mechanical Engineers is now holding its ninth annual meeting in this city. More than 100 members are in attendance from all parts of the United States, and the programme is one of unusual interest.

The Rev. Ballard S. Dunn, a regularly ordained clergyman, who is now without a church, and who lives in a boarding house at 7 Fifth-avenue, was a prisoner before Justice Gorman at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to answer for an assault upon Daniel Jackson, a patent agent, of 33 West Sixty-first-street.

CARLISLE, Penn., Oct. 16.--The ninth annual report of the Indian Government training school in this city, Capt. R.H. Pratt manager, was filed today and forwarded to the Indian Commissioner at Washington. It shows that there are 637 Indian boys and girls at the school, and the Apache Indians constitute the largest element of any one tribe. The school is in a flourishing condition.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 16.--A hastily-arranged meeting of General Freight Agents was held at the Omaha general offices yesterday for the purpose of agreeing if possible upon an advance in flour rates to the seaboard.

Deputy Clerk George F. Lyon of the Supreme Court showed his loyalty to Tammany Hall yesterday by betting Hotel Keeper William D. Currier $100 that Hugh J. Grant will be elected Mayor, $100 that James A. Flack will be elected Sheriff, and $100 that Edward F. Reilly will be elected County Clerk. Finally he bet his petted but almost imperceptible mustache against Mr. Currier's side whiskers that he would win all the bets.

Boston is the leading American market for the shares of copper mining companies. The Transcript asserts that the total market value of the shares of the sixteen companies in which Boston capital is invested is more than $61,000,000, at current quotations.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16.--James Pryor, a man 75 years old, came to Chicago from Indiana a few weeks ago and hired a room at the Dearborn Hotel in State-street. There he committed suicide to-day by drinking two ounces of laudanum. He is said to have had wealthy relatives, but he ran out of money here, and, failing to secure any more, took his life.

There has been no doubt from the time when Col. QUAY appointed a number of the least reputable and scrupulous politicians in this country to "secure an honest election in New-York" what his purpose was.

The board of regular army officers which was recently appointed by the Assistant Secretary of War under an authorization of Congress to fix the harbor "lines" or limits of New York Harbor will meet for organization this morning.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 16.--Perhaps the largest and most enthusiastic political meeting ever known in this historical old town was that held by the Democracy this evening in the Opera House to listen to a speech by the Hon. De Lancey Nicoll on the subject of tariff reform and the Mills bill.

Dr. Miller B. Hutchins of the Skin and Cancer Hospital at Fordham Heights ws arrested last night shortly before 12 o'clock by the police of the Thirtieth-street police station on complaint on Matthew Flynn, a brakeman on the Sixth-avenue elevated railroad.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., Oct. 16.--Mrs. Susanna Benninger of Lehigh Township died a few days ago and left a bequest of $1,000 to the county poor house. This is the first time a bequest has ever been left to a county poorhouee in the State of Pennsylvania.

Frank Pratoman, 11 years old, of 164 Van Winkle-street, Jersey City Heights, and his younger brother left home Monday evening to pick coal on the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks.

Moliere's "Tartuffe" was carefully acted by the French comedians at Palmer's Theatre last evening. The house was crowded, the play was watched with interest, and the performance was eminently smooth and artistic.

The new concert hall of the Grand Conservatory of Music will be opened this evening. Frank Ven der Stucken's first classical matinee will take place at Chickering Hall this afternoon.

The Master Brewers' Association opened its business session yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. Louis Frisch of Chicago presided over the convention, the entire proceedings of which were carried on in the German language.

Dullness and weakness made Wall-street unhappy till a late hour yesterday. Then of a sudden an army of patriots seemed terrifically anxious to buy every stock that has ever been printed, and the stock market closed in a blaze of glory, the whole list apparently bound for par and a half.
Michael Lipman, who for more than 20 years was a well-known circus clown, died in the Longview Insane Asylum, near Cincinnati, on Monday.

DETROIT, Oct. 16.--A chattel mortgage for $95,000 was given to-day by Carleton A. Beardsley of this city to Judge Augustus C. Baldwin of Pontiac.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16.--A woman named Dalton was arrested by the police this morning on the inhuman charge of trying to make fuel out of her own son.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 16.--A peace warrant was served on Joseph King today on the complaint of Gertrude Holman. King had been paying attentions to Miss Holman and had asked her to marry him. When she refused, King, she says, whipped out a pistol and threatened to kill her unless she would marry him. He will be bound over to keep the peace. King is also accused of assaulting the girl.

BOSTON, Oct. 16.--Frankie Raymond of New-York, charged with the theft of diamonds, is under arrest here and is very sorry she ran away. The Sunday express from New-York brought to Boston an unknown young woman who sadly needed and received attention on her arrival here.

The County Democracy of the Fifteenth Assembly District will raise a Cleveland and Thurman banner in front of their headquarters, 267 West Thirty-fourth-street, to-morrow evening. Among the speakers will be Col. M.C. Murphy, Ex-Senator James Daly, Adolph L. Sanger, E.S. Abbott, and Assistant District Attorney Fitzgerald.

James Smith and Richard Dudley, two exconvicts, had an altercation in the saloon kept by George Schuster at 15 Chrystie-street last night. Dudley pulled a revolver and fired three shots at Smith.

The Spartan Harriers will have their first outing of the season on Sunday, Oct. 28. NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 16.--Thirteen Deputy United States Marshals went on duty at the registry polls in this city to-day. They were appointed by United States Marshal McMahon of New-York. These men will be at the polling places during registration and on election day.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 16.--Negotiations were completed to-day by which an Eastern syndicate will, on the 1st of December, assume control of the street railway lines of the Milwaukee City Railway Company, of which Peter McGeoch is the principal stockholder. The purchase price is said to be above $1,000,000.

A decision of vital interest to the commercial community was rendered by Judge Andrews at the Special Term of the Supreme Court on Monday under the amendment of 1887 to the General Assignment act of this State.

MAUCH CHUNK, Penn., Oct. 16.--A wreck occurred on the Pottsville Division of the Lehigh Valley Railroad near Tamanend, about 8 o'clock this morning between a Lehigh gravel train and a Pennsylvania Railroad fast freight.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 16.--The steamer Ulunda, on her last trip from Halifax to London, had a thrilling escape from destruction on the Newfoundland coast.
